ruby: a red variety of corundum, used as a gem.
red: any of various colors resembling the color of blood; the primary color at one extreme end of the visible spectrum, an effect of light with a wavelength between 610 and 780 nanometers.
variety: the state of being varied or diversified: to give variety to a diet.
of: (used to indicate distance or direction from, separation, deprivation, etc.): within a mile of the church; south of Omaha; to be robbed of one's money.
corundum: a common mineral, aluminum oxide, Al 2 O 3 , notable for its hardness: transparent varieties, as sapphire and ruby, are used as gems, other varieties as abrasives: often made synthetically.
used: previously used or owned; secondhand: a used car.
as: to the same degree, amount, or extent; similarly; equally: I don't think it's as hot and humid today as it was yesterday.
gem: a cut and polished precious stone or pearl fine enough for use in jewelry.
any: one, a, an, or some; one or more without specification or identification: If you have any witnesses, produce them. Pick out any six you like.
various: of different kinds, as two or more things; differing one from another: Various experiments have not proved his theory.
the: (used, especially before a noun, with a specifying or particularizing effect, as opposed to the indefinite or generalizing force of the indefinite article a or an): the book you gave me; Come into the house.
color: the quality of an object or substance with respect to light reflected by the object, usually determined visually by measurement of hue, saturation, and brightness of the reflected light; saturation or chroma; hue.
blood: the fluid that circulates in the principal vascular system of human beings and other vertebrates, in humans consisting of plasma in which the red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are suspended.
primary: first or highest in rank or importance; chief; principal: his primary goals in life.
at: (used to indicate a point or place occupied in space); in, on, or near: to stand at the door; at the bottom of the barrel.
one: being or amounting to a single unit or individual or entire thing, item, or object rather than two or more; a single: one woman; one nation; one piece of cake.
extreme: of a character or kind farthest removed from the ordinary or average: extreme measures.
end: the last part or extremity, lengthwise, of anything that is longer than it is wide or broad: the end of a street; the end of a rope.
visible: that can be seen; perceptible to the eye: mountains visible in the distance.
spectrum: this band or series of colors together with extensions at the ends that are not visible to the eye, but that can be studied by means of photography, heat effects, etc., and that are produced by the dispersion of radiant energy other than ordinary light rays. Compare band spectrum, electromagnetic spectrum, mass spectrum.
an: the form of a before an initial vowel sound (an arch; an honor) and sometimes, especially in British English, before an initial unstressed syllable beginning with a silent or weakly pronounced h : an historian.
effect: something that is produced by an agency or cause; result; consequence: Exposure to the sun had the effect of toughening his skin.
light: something that makes things visible or affords illumination: All colors depend on light.
with: accompanied by; accompanying: I will go with you. He fought with his brother against the enemy.
wavelength: Physics. the distance, measured in the direction of propagation of a wave, between two successive points in the wave that are characterized by the same phase of oscillation.
between: in the space separating (two points, objects, etc.): between New York and Chicago.
and: (used to connect grammatically coordinate words, phrases, or clauses) along or together with; as well as; in addition to; besides; also; moreover: pens and pencils.
state: the condition of a person or thing, as with respect to circumstances or attributes: a state of health.
being: the fact of existing; existence (as opposed to nonexistence).
varied: characterized by or exhibiting variety; various; diverse; diversified: varied backgrounds.
or: (used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives): books or magazines; to be or not to be.
diversified: distinguished by various forms or by a variety of objects: diversified activity.
to: (used for expressing motion or direction toward a point, person, place, or thing approached and reached, as opposed to from): They came to the house.
give: to present voluntarily and without expecting compensation; bestow: to give a birthday present to someone.
diet: food and drink considered in terms of its qualities, composition, and its effects on health: Milk is a wholesome article of diet.
indicate: to be a sign of; betoken; evidence; show: His hesitation really indicates his doubt about the venture.
distance: the extent or amount of space between two things, points, lines, etc.
direction: the act or an instance of directing.
from: (used to specify a starting point in spatial movement): a train running west from Chicago.
separation: an act or instance of separating or the state of being separated.
within: in or into the interior or inner part; inside.
mile: Also called statute mile. a unit of distance on land in English-speaking countries equal to 5280 feet, or 1760 yards (1.609 kilometers).
church: a building for public Christian worship.
south: a cardinal point of the compass lying directly opposite north. Abbreviation:  S.
omaha: a city in E Nebraska, on the Missouri River.
be: to exist or live: Shakespeare's “To be or not to be” is the ultimate question.
money: any circulating medium of exchange, including coins, paper money, and demand deposits.
common: belonging equally to, or shared alike by, two or more or all in question: common property; common interests.
mineral: any of a class of substances occurring in nature, usually comprising inorganic substances, as quartz or feldspar, of definite chemical composition and usually of definite crystal structure, but sometimes also including rocks formed by these substances as well as certain natural products of organic origin, as asphalt or coal.
aluminum: Chemistry. a silver-white metallic element, light in weight, ductile, malleable, and not readily corroded or tarnished, occurring combined in nature in igneous rock, shale, clay, and most soil: used in alloys and for lightweight utensils, castings, airplane parts, etc. Symbol:  Al; atomic weight:  26.98; atomic number:  13; specific gravity:  2.70 at 20°C. Abbreviation:  alum.;
oxide: a compound in which oxygen is bonded to one or more electropositive atoms.
notable: worthy of note or notice; noteworthy: a notable success; a notable theory.
for: with the object or purpose of: to run for exercise.
its: the possessive form of it1. (used as an attributive adjective): The book has lost its jacket. I'm sorry about its being so late.
hardness: the state or quality of being hard: the hardness of ice.
transparent: having the property of transmitting rays of light through its substance so that bodies situated beyond or behind can be distinctly seen.
sapphire: any gem variety of corundum other than the ruby, especially one of the blue varieties.
are: present indicative plural and 2nd person singular of be.
other: additional or further: he and one other person.
often: many times; frequently: He visits his parents as often as he can.
made: simple past tense and past participle of make1 .
secondhand: not directly known or experienced; obtained from others or from books: Most of our knowledge is secondhand.
same: identical with what is about to be or has just been mentioned: This street is the same one we were on yesterday.
degree: any of a series of steps or stages, as in a process or course of action; a point in any scale.
amount: the sum total of two or more quantities or sums; aggregate.
extent: the space or degree to which a thing extends; length, area, volume, or scope: the extent of his lands; to be right to a certain extent.
equally: in an equal or identical manner: to treat rich and poor equally.
don: (initial capital letter) Mr.; Sir: a Spanish title prefixed to a man's given name.
think: to have a conscious mind, to some extent of reasoning, remembering experiences, making rational decisions, etc.
it: (used to represent an inanimate thing understood, previously mentioned, about to be mentioned, or present in the immediate context): It has whitewall tires and red upholstery. You can't tell a book by its cover.
hot: having or giving off heat; having a high temperature: a hot fire; hot coffee.
humid: containing a high amount of water or water vapor; noticeably moist: humid air; a humid climate.
today: this present day: Today is beautiful.
was: 1st and 3rd person singular pt. indicative of be.
yesterday: on the day preceding this day.
cut: to penetrate with or as if with a sharp-edged instrument or object: He cut his finger.
polished: made smooth and glossy: a figurine of polished mahogany.
precious: of high price or great value; very valuable or costly: precious metals.
stone: the hard substance, formed of mineral matter, of which rocks consist.
fine: of superior or best quality; of high or highest grade: fine wine.
enough: adequate for the want or need; sufficient for the purpose or to satisfy desire: enough water; noise enough to wake the dead.
use: to employ for some purpose; put into service; make use of: to use a knife.
in: (used to indicate inclusion within space, a place, or limits): walking in the park.
jewelry: articles of gold, silver, precious stones, etc., for personal adornment.
some: being an undetermined or unspecified one: Some person may object.
more: in greater quantity, amount, measure, degree, or number: I need more money.
without: with the absence, omission, or avoidance of; not with; with no or none of; lacking: without help; without shoes; without her helping me; without him to help.
identification: an act or instance of identifying; the state of being identified.
if: in case that; granting or supposing that; on condition that: Sing if you want to. Stay indoors if it rains. I'll go if you do.
you: the pronoun of the second person singular or plural, used of the person or persons being addressed, in the nominative or objective case: You are the highest bidder. It is you who are to blame. We can't help you. This package came for you. Did she give you the book?
have: to possess; own; hold for use; contain: He has property. The work has an index.
produce: to bring into existence; give rise to; cause: to produce steam.
them: the objective case of they, used as a direct or indirect object: We saw them yesterday. I gave them the books.
pick: to choose or select from among a group: to pick a contestant from the audience.
out: away from, or not in, the normal or usual place, position, state, etc.: out of alphabetical order; to go out to dinner.
six: a cardinal number, five plus one.
like: of the same form, appearance, kind, character, amount, etc.: I cannot remember a like instance.
different: not alike in character or quality; distinct in nature; dissimilar: The two brothers are very different, although they are identical twins.
another: being one more or more of the same; further; additional: another piece of cake.
not: (used to express negation, denial, refusal, or prohibition): You must not do that. It's not far from here.
his: the possessive form of he1. (used as an attributive or predicative adjective): His coat is the brown one. This brown coat is his. Do you mind his speaking first?
theory: a coherent group of tested general propositions, commonly regarded as correct, that can be used as principles of explanation and prediction for a class of phenomena: Einstein's theory of relativity.
resemble: to be like or similar to.
especially: particularly; exceptionally; markedly: Be especially watchful.
before: previous to; earlier or sooner than: Phone me before noon.
noun: See also noun adjunct, noun clause, noun phrase.
indefinite: not definite; without fixed or specified limit; unlimited: an indefinite number.
force: physical power or strength possessed by a living being: He used all his force in opening the window.
article: a written composition in prose, usually nonfiction, on a specific topic, forming an independent part of a book or other publication, as a newspaper or magazine.
book: a handwritten or printed work of fiction or nonfiction, usually on sheets of paper fastened or bound together within covers.
me: the objective case of I, used as a direct or indirect object: They asked me to the party. Give me your hand.
come: to approach or move toward a particular person or place: Come here. Don't come any closer!
into: to the inside of; in toward: He walked into the room. The train chugged into the station.
house: a building in which people live; residence for human beings.
quality: an essential or distinctive characteristic, property, or attribute: the chemical qualities of alcohol.
object: anything that is visible or tangible and is relatively stable in form.
substance: that of which a thing consists; physical matter or material: form and substance.
respect: a particular, detail, or point (usually preceded by in): to differ in some respect.
by: near to or next to: a home by a lake.
determined: resolute; staunch: the determined defenders of the Alamo.
visually: in a visual manner; with respect to sight; by sight.
hue: a gradation or variety of a color; tint: pale hues.
saturation: the act or process of saturating.
chroma: the purity of a color, or its freedom from white or gray.
fluid: a substance, as a liquid or gas, that is capable of flowing and that changes its shape at a steady rate when acted upon by a force tending to change its shape.
that: (used to indicate a person, thing, idea, state, event, time, remark, etc., as pointed out or present, mentioned before, supposed to be understood, or by way of emphasis): That is her mother. After that we saw each other.
principal: first or highest in rank, importance, value, etc.; chief; foremost.
vascular: pertaining to, composed of, or provided with vessels or ducts that convey fluids, as blood, lymph, or sap.
system: an assemblage or combination of things or parts forming a complex or unitary whole: a mountain system; a railroad system.
human: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or having the nature of people: human frailty.
plasma: Anatomy, Physiology. the liquid part of blood or lymph, as distinguished from the suspended elements.
which: what one?: Which of these do you want? Which do you want?
white: of the color of pure snow, of the margins of this page, etc.; reflecting nearly all the rays of sunlight or a similar light.
first: being before all others with respect to time, order, rank, importance, etc., used as the ordinal number of one: the first edition; the first vice president.
rank: a number of persons forming a separate class in a social hierarchy or in any graded body.
importance: the quality or state of being important; consequence; significance.
chief: the head or leader of an organized body of people; the person highest in authority: the chief of police.
life: the condition that distinguishes organisms from inorganic objects and dead organisms, being manifested by growth through metabolism, reproduction, and the power of adaptation to environment through changes originating internally.
point: a sharp or tapering end, as of a dagger.
place: a particular portion of space, whether of definite or indefinite extent.
space: the unlimited or incalculably great three-dimensional realm or expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.
on: so as to be or remain supported by or suspended from: Put your package down on the table; Hang your coat on the hook.
near: close; to a point or place not far away: Come near so I won't have to shout.
stand: (of a person) to be in an upright position on the feet.
door: a movable, usually solid, barrier for opening and closing an entranceway, cupboard, cabinet, or the like, commonly turning on hinges or sliding in grooves.
bottom: the lowest or deepest part of anything, as distinguished from the top: the bottom of a hill; the bottom of a page.
barrel: a cylindrical wooden container with slightly bulging sides made of staves hooped together, and with flat, parallel ends.
single: only one in number; one only; unique; sole: a single example.
individual: a single human being, as distinguished from a group.
entire: having all the parts or elements; whole; complete: He wrote the entire novel in only six weeks.
thing: a material object without life or consciousness; an inanimate object.
item: a separate article or particular: 50 items on the list.
rather: in a measure; to a certain extent; somewhat: rather good.
than: (used, as after comparative adjectives and adverbs, to introduce the second member of an unequal comparison): She's taller than I am.
woman: the female human being, as distinguished from a girl or a man.
nation: a large body of people, associated with a particular territory, that is sufficiently conscious of its unity to seek or to possess a government peculiarly its own: The president spoke to the nation about the new tax.
piece: a separate or limited portion or quantity of something: a piece of land; a piece of chocolate.
cake: a sweet, baked, breadlike food, made with or without shortening, and usually containing flour, sugar, baking powder or soda, eggs, and liquid flavoring.
character: the aggregate of features and traits that form the individual nature of some person or thing.
kind: of a good or benevolent nature or disposition, as a person: a kind and loving person.
removed: remote; separate; not connected with; distinct from.
ordinary: of no special quality or interest; commonplace; unexceptional: One novel is brilliant, the other is decidedly ordinary; an ordinary person.
average: a quantity, rating, or the like that represents or approximates an arithmetic mean: Her golf average is in the 90s. My average in science has gone from B to C this semester.
last: occurring or coming after all others, as in time, order, or place: the last line on a page.
part: a portion or division of a whole that is separate or distinct; piece, fragment, fraction, or section; constituent: the rear part of the house; to glue the two parts together.
extremity: the extreme or terminal point, limit, or part of something.
lengthwise: in the direction of the length.
anything: any thing whatever; something, no matter what: Do you have anything for a toothache?
is: 3rd person singular present indicative of be.
wide: having considerable or great extent from side to side; broad: a wide boulevard.
broad: of great breadth: The river was too broad to swim across.
street: a public thoroughfare, usually paved, in a village, town, or city, including the sidewalk or sidewalks.
rope: a strong, thick line or cord, commonly one composed of twisted or braided strands of hemp, flax, or the like, or of wire or other material.
can: to be able to; have the ability, power, or skill to: She can solve the problem easily, I'm sure.
perceptible: capable of being perceived; recognizable; appreciable: a perceptible change in his behavior.
eye: the organ of sight, in vertebrates typically one of a pair of spherical bodies contained in an orbit of the skull and in humans appearing externally as a dense, white, curved membrane, or sclera, surrounding a circular, colored portion, or iris, that is covered by a clear, curved membrane, or cornea, and in the center of which is an opening, or pupil, through which light passes to the retina.
this: (used to indicate a person, thing, idea, state, event, time, remark, etc., as present, near, just mentioned or pointed out, supposed to be understood, or by way of emphasis): This is my coat.
band: a company of persons or, sometimes, animals or things, joined, acting, or functioning together; aggregation; party; troop: a band of protesters.
series: a group or a number of related or similar things, events, etc., arranged or occurring in temporal, spatial, or other order or succession; sequence.
together: into or in one gathering, company, mass, place, or body: to call the people together.
but: on the contrary; yet: My brother went, but I did not.
studied: marked by or suggestive of conscious effort; not spontaneous or natural; affected: studied simplicity.
photography: the process or art of producing images of objects on sensitized surfaces by the chemical action of light or of other forms of radiant energy, as x-rays, gamma rays, or cosmic rays.
heat: the state of a body perceived as having or generating a relatively high degree of warmth.
dispersion: Also, dispersal. an act, state, or instance of dispersing or of being dispersed.
radiant: emitting rays of light; shining; bright: the radiant sun; radiant colors.
energy: the capacity for vigorous activity; available power: I eat chocolate to get quick energy.
compare: to examine (two or more objects, ideas, people, etc.) in order to note similarities and differences: to compare two pieces of cloth; to compare the governments of two nations.
electromagnetic: of or relating to electromagnetism or electromagnetic fields.
mass: a body of coherent matter, usually of indefinite shape and often of considerable size: a mass of dough.
form: external appearance of a clearly defined area, as distinguished from color or material; configuration: a triangular form.
initial: of, relating to, or occurring at the beginning; first: the initial step in a process.
vowel: (in a syllable) the sound of greatest sonority, as i in grill. Compare consonant (def 1b).
sound: the sensation produced by stimulation of the organs of hearing by vibrations transmitted through the air or other medium.
honor: honesty, fairness, or integrity in one's beliefs and actions: a man of honor.
sometimes: on some occasions; at times; now and then.
british: of or relating to Great Britain or its inhabitants.
english: of, relating to, or characteristic of England or its inhabitants, institutions, etc.
unstressed: without stress or emphasis, as a syllable in a word.
syllable: an uninterrupted segment of speech consisting of a vowel sound, a diphthong, or a syllabic consonant, with or without preceding or following consonant sounds: “Eye,” “sty,” “act,” and “should” are English words of one syllable. “Eyelet,” “stifle,” “enact,” and “shouldn't” are two-syllable words.
beginning: an act or circumstance of entering upon an action or state: the beginning of hostilities.
silent: making no sound; quiet; still: a silent motor.
weakly: weak or feeble in constitution; not robust; sickly.
pronounced: strongly marked: a pronounced fishy taste.
historian: an expert in history; authority on history.
something: some thing; a certain undetermined or unspecified thing: Something is wrong there. Something's happening.
agency: an organization, company, or bureau that provides some service for another: a welfare agency.
cause: a person or thing that acts, happens, or exists in such a way that some specific thing happens as a result; the producer of an effect: You have been the cause of much anxiety. What was the cause of the accident?
result: to spring, arise, or proceed as a consequence of actions, circumstances, premises, etc.; be the outcome.
consequence: the effect, result, or outcome of something occurring earlier: The accident was the consequence of reckless driving.
exposure: the act of exposing, laying open, or uncovering: the sudden exposure of objects that were hidden under the blanket.
sun: (often initial capital letter) the star that is the central body of the solar system, around which the planets revolve and from which they receive light and heat: its mean distance from the earth is about 93 million miles (150 million km), its diameter about 864,000 miles (1.4 million km), and its mass about 330,000 times that of the earth; its period of surface rotation is about 26 days at its equator but longer at higher latitudes.
had: simple past tense and past participle of have.
skin: the external covering or integument of an animal body, especially when soft and flexible.
illumination: an act or instance of illuminating.
all: the whole of (used in referring to quantity, extent, or duration): all the cake; all the way; all year.
depend: to rely; place trust (usually followed by on or upon): You may depend on the accuracy of the report.
will: am (is, are, etc.) about or going to: I will be there tomorrow. She will see you at dinner.
go: to move or proceed, especially to or from something: They're going by bus.
he: the male person or animal being discussed or last mentioned; that male.
fought: simple past tense and past participle of fight.
brother: a male offspring having both parents in common with another offspring; a male sibling.
against: in opposition to; contrary to; adverse or hostile to: twenty votes against ten; against reason.
enemy: a person who feels hatred for, fosters harmful designs against, or engages in antagonistic activities against another; an adversary or opponent.
physics: the science that deals with matter, energy, motion, and force.
measured: ascertained or apportioned by measure: The race was over the course of a measured mile.
wave: a disturbance on the surface of a liquid body, as the sea or a lake, in the form of a moving ridge or swell.
successive: following in order or in uninterrupted sequence; consecutive: three successive days.
phase: any of the major appearances or aspects in which a thing of varying modes or conditions manifests itself to the eye or mind.
oscillation: an act or instance of oscillating.
new: of recent origin, production, purchase, etc.; having but lately come or been brought into being: a new book.
york: a member of the royal house of England that ruled from 1461 to 1485.
chicago: Judy (Judy Cohen) born 1939, U.S. artist, author, and educator.
connect: to join, link, or fasten together; unite or bind: to connect the two cities by a bridge; Communication satellites connect the local stations into a network.
coordinate: of the same order or degree; equal in rank or importance.
along: through, on, beside, over, or parallel to the length or direction of; from one end to the other of: to walk along a highway; to run a border along a shelf.
well: in a good or satisfactory manner: Business is going well.
addition: the act or process of adding or uniting.
besides: moreover; furthermore; also: Besides, I promised her we would come.
also: in addition; too; besides; as well: He was thin, and he was also tall.
moreover: in addition to what has been said; further; besides.
nanometer: one billionth of a meter. Abbreviation:  nm.
condition: a particular mode of being of a person or thing; existing state; situation with respect to circumstances.
person: a human being, whether an adult or child: The table seats four persons.
health: the general condition of the body or mind with reference to soundness and vigor: good health; poor health.
fact: something that actually exists; reality; truth: Your fears have no basis in fact.
existence: the state or fact of existing; being.
diverse: of a different kind, form, character, etc.; unlike: a wide range of diverse opinions.
distinguished: made conspicuous by excellence; noted; eminent; famous: a distinguished scholar.
activity: the state or quality of being active: There was not much activity in the stock market today. He doesn't have enough physical activity in his life.
motion: the action or process of moving or of changing place or position; movement.
toward: in the direction of: to walk toward the river.
they: nominative plural of he, she, and it1 .
present: being, existing, or occurring at this time or now; current: increasing respect for the present ruler of the small country.
compensation: the act or state of compensating, as by rewarding someone for service or by making up for someone's loss, damage, or injury by giving the injured party an appropriate benefit.
bestow: to present as a gift; give; confer (usually followed by on or upon): The trophy was bestowed upon the winner.
food: any nourishing substance that is eaten, drunk, or otherwise taken into the body to sustain life, provide energy, promote growth, etc.
drink: to take water or other liquid into the mouth and swallow it; imbibe.
considered: thought about or decided upon with care: a considered opinion.
composition: the act of combining parts or elements to form a whole.
milk: an opaque white or bluish-white liquid secreted by the mammary glands of female mammals, serving for the nourishment of their young.
wholesome: conducive to moral or general well-being; salutary; beneficial: wholesome recreation; wholesome environment.
betoken: to give evidence of; indicate: to betoken one's fidelity with a vow; a kiss that betokens one's affection.
evidence: that which tends to prove or disprove something; ground for belief; proof.
show: to cause or allow to be seen; exhibit; display.
hesitation: the act of hesitating; a delay due to uncertainty of mind or fear: His hesitation cost him the championship.
doubt: to be uncertain about; consider questionable or unlikely; hesitate to believe.
about: of; concerning; in regard to: instructions about the work; a book about the Civil War.
venture: an undertaking involving uncertainty as to the outcome, especially a risky or dangerous one: a mountain-climbing venture.
act: anything done, being done, or to be done; deed; performance: a heroic act.
instance: a case or occurrence of anything: fresh instances of oppression.
specify: to mention or name specifically or definitely; state in detail: He did not specify the amount needed.
movement: the act, process, or result of moving.
train: Railroads. a self-propelled, connected group of rolling stock.
running: the act of a person, animal, or thing that runs.
west: a cardinal point of the compass, 90° to the left when facing north, corresponding to the point where the sun is seen to set. Abbreviation:  W.
interior: being within; inside of anything; internal; inner; further toward a center: the interior rooms of a house.
inner: situated within or farther within; interior: an inner door.
inside: on the inner side or part of; within: inside the circle; inside the envelope.
land: any part of the earth's surface not covered by a body of water; the part of the earth's surface occupied by continents and islands: Land was sighted from the crow's nest.
equal: as great as; the same as (often followed by to or with): The velocity of sound is not equal to that of light.
building: a relatively permanent enclosed construction over a plot of land, having a roof and usually windows and often more than one level, used for any of a wide variety of activities, as living, entertaining, or manufacturing.
public: of, relating to, or affecting a population or a community as a whole: public funds; a public nuisance.
christian: of, relating to, or derived from Jesus Christ or His teachings: a Christian faith.
worship: reverent honor and homage paid to God or a sacred personage, or to any object regarded as sacred.
cardinal: of prime importance; chief; principal: of cardinal significance.
compass: an instrument for determining directions, as by means of a freely rotating magnetized needle that indicates magnetic north.
lying: the telling of lies, or false statements; untruthfulness: From boyhood, he has never been good at lying.
directly: in a direct line, way, or manner; straight: The path leads directly to the lake.
opposite: situated, placed, or lying face to face with something else or each other, or in corresponding positions with relation to an intervening line, space, or thing: opposite ends of a room.
north: a cardinal point of the compass, lying in the plane of the meridian and to the left of a person facing the rising sun. Abbreviation:  N.
abbreviation: a shortened or contracted form of a word or phrase, used to represent the whole, as Dr. for Doctor, U.S. for United States, lb. for pound.
nebraska: a state in the central United States. 77,237 sq. mi. (200,044 sq. km). Capital:  Lincoln.
missouri: a state in the central United States. 69,674 sq. mi. (180,455 sq. km). Capital:  Jefferson City.
river: a natural stream of water of fairly large size flowing in a definite course or channel or series of diverging and converging channels.
exist: to have actual being; be: The world exists, whether you like it or not.
live: to have life, as an organism; be alive; be capable of vital functions: all things that live.
shakespeare: William ("the Bard"; "the Bard of Avon") 1564–1616, English poet and dramatist.
ultimate: last; furthest or farthest; ending a process or series: the ultimate point in a journey; the ultimate style in hats.
question: a sentence in an interrogative form, addressed to someone in order to get information in reply.
rob: to take something from (someone) by unlawful force or threat of violence; steal from.
medium: a middle state or condition; mean.
exchange: to give up (something) for something else; part with for some equivalent; change for another.
paper: a substance made from wood pulp, rags, straw, or other fibrous material, usually in thin sheets, used to bear writing or printing, for wrapping things, etc.
demand: to ask for with proper authority; claim as a right: He demanded payment of the debt.
alike: in the same manner or form; similarly: They treated all customers alike.
property: that which a person owns; the possession or possessions of a particular owner: They lost all their property in the fire.
class: a number of persons or things regarded as forming a group by reason of common attributes, characteristics, qualities, or traits; kind; sort: a class of objects used in daily living.
nature: the material world, especially as surrounding humankind and existing independently of human activities.
inorganic: not having the structure or organization characteristic of living bodies.
quartz: one of the commonest minerals, silicon dioxide, SiO 2 , having many varieties that differ in color, luster, etc., and occurring either in masses (as agate, bloodstone, chalcedony, jasper, etc.) or in crystals (as rock crystal, amethyst, citrine, etc.): the chief constituent of sand and sandstone, and an important constituent of many other rocks. It is piezoelectric and used to control the frequencies of radio transmitters.
feldspar: any of a group of minerals, principally aluminosilicates of potassium, sodium, and calcium, characterized by two cleavages at nearly right angles: one of the most important constituents of igneous rocks.
definite: clearly defined or determined; not vague or general; fixed; precise; exact: a definite quantity; definite directions.
chemical: a substance produced by or used in a chemical process.
crystal: a clear, transparent mineral or glass resembling ice.
structure: mode of building, construction, or organization; arrangement of parts, elements, or constituents: a pyramidal structure.
certain: free from doubt or reservation; confident; sure: I am certain he will come.
natural: existing in or formed by nature (opposed to artificial): a natural bridge.
organic: noting or pertaining to a class of chemical compounds that formerly comprised only those existing in or derived from plants or animals, but that now includes all other compounds of carbon.
origin: something from which anything arises or is derived; source; fountainhead: to follow a stream to its origin.
asphalt: any of various dark-colored, solid, bituminous substances, native in various areas of the earth and composed mainly of hydrocarbon mixtures.
silver: Chemistry. a white, ductile metallic element, used for making mirrors, coins, ornaments, table utensils, photographic chemicals, conductors, etc. Symbol:  Ag; atomic weight:  107.870; atomic number:  47; specific gravity:  10.5 at 20°C.
metallic: of, relating to, or consisting of metal.
element: a component or constituent of a whole or one of the parts into which a whole may be resolved by analysis: Bricks and mortar are elements of every masonry wall.
weight: the amount or quantity of heaviness or mass; amount a thing weighs.
ductile: capable of being hammered out thin, as certain metals; malleable.
malleable: capable of being extended or shaped by hammering or by pressure from rollers.
readily: promptly; quickly; easily: The information is readily available.
combined: made by combining; joined; united, as in a chemical compound.
igneous: Geology. produced under conditions involving intense heat, as rocks of volcanic origin or rocks crystallized from molten magma.
rock: a large mass of stone forming a hill, cliff, promontory, or the like.
shale: a rock of fissile or laminated structure formed by the consolidation of clay or argillaceous material.
clay: a natural earthy material that is plastic when wet, consisting essentially of hydrated silicates of aluminum: used for making bricks, pottery, etc.
most: in the greatest quantity, amount, measure, degree, or number: to win the most votes.
soil: the portion of the earth's surface consisting of disintegrated rock and humus.
airplane: a heavier-than-air aircraft kept aloft by the upward thrust exerted by the passing air on its fixed wings and driven by propellers, jet propulsion, etc.
symbol: something used for or regarded as representing something else; a material object representing something, often something immaterial; emblem, token, or sign.
atomic: of, pertaining to, resulting from, or using atoms, atomic energy, or atomic bombs: an atomic explosion.
number: a numeral or group of numerals.
specific: having a special application, bearing, or reference; specifying, explicit, or definite: to state one's specific purpose.
gravity: the force of attraction by which terrestrial bodies tend to fall toward the center of the earth.
alum: Also called potash alum, potassium alum. a crystalline solid, aluminum potassium sulfate, K 2 SO 4 ⋅Al 2 (SO 4) 3 ⋅24H 2 O, used in medicine as an astringent and styptic, in dyeing and tanning, and in many technical processes.
compound: composed of two or more parts, elements, or ingredients: Soap is a compound substance.
oxygen: a colorless, odorless, gaseous element constituting about one-fifth of the volume of the atmosphere and present in a combined state in nature. It is the supporter of combustion in air and was the standard of atomic, combining, and molecular weights until 1961, when carbon 12 became the new standard. Symbol:  O; atomic weight:  15.9994; atomic number:  8; density: 1.4290 g/l at 0°C and 760 mm pressure.
bonded: secured by or consisting of bonds: bonded debt.
electropositive: containing positive electricity; tending to migrate to the negative pole in electrolysis.
indian: Also called American Indian, Amerind, Amerindian, Native American. a member of the aboriginal people of America or of any of the aboriginal North or South American stocks, usually excluding the Eskimos.
mulberry: the edible, berrylike collective fruit of any tree of the genus Morus.
worthy: having adequate or great merit, character, or value: a worthy successor.
note: a brief record of something written down to assist the memory or for future reference.
notice: an announcement or intimation of something impending; warning: a day's notice.
noteworthy: worthy of notice or attention; notable; remarkable: a noteworthy addition to our collection of rare books.
success: the favorable or prosperous termination of attempts or endeavors; the accomplishment of one's goals.
purpose: the reason for which something exists or is done, made, used, etc.
run: to go quickly by moving the legs more rapidly than at a walk and in such a manner that for an instant in each step all or both feet are off the ground.
exercise: bodily or mental exertion, especially for the sake of training or improvement of health: Walking is good exercise.
possessive: jealously opposed to the personal independence of, or to any influence other than one's own upon, a child, spouse, etc.
attributive: pertaining to or having the character of attribution or an attribute.
adjective: Grammar. any member of a class of words that modify nouns and pronouns, primarily by describing a particular quality of the word they are modifying, as wise in a wise grandmother, or perfect in a perfect score, or handsome in He is extremely handsome. Other terms, as numbers (one cup; twelve months), certain demonstrative pronouns (this magazine; those questions), and terms that impose limits (each person; no mercy) can also function adjectivally, as can some nouns that are found chiefly in fixed phrases where they immediately precede the noun they modify, as bottle in bottle cap and bus in bus station. Synonyms: modifier, qualifier, identifier, describer, describing word.
has: a 3rd person singular present indicative of have.
lost: no longer possessed or retained: lost friends.
jacket: a short coat, in any of various forms, usually opening down the front.
sorry: feeling regret, compunction, sympathy, pity, etc.: to be sorry to leave one's friends; to be sorry for a remark; to be sorry for someone in trouble.
so: in the way or manner indicated, described, or implied: Do it so.
late: occurring, coming, or being after the usual or proper time: late frosts; a late spring.
hard: not soft; solid and firm to the touch; unyielding to pressure and impenetrable or almost impenetrable.
ice: the solid form of water, produced by freezing; frozen water.
through: in at one end, side, or surface and out at the other: to pass through a tunnel; We drove through Denver without stopping. Sun came through the window.
beyond: on, at, or to the farther side of: Beyond those trees you'll find his house.
behind: at or toward the rear of: Look behind the house.
distinctly: in a distinct manner; clearly: Speak more distinctly.
blue: the pure color of a clear sky; the primary color between green and violet in the visible spectrum, an effect of light with a wavelength between 450 and 500 nm.
indicative: showing, signifying, or pointing out; expressive or suggestive (usually followed by of): behavior indicative of mental disorder.
plural: consisting of, containing, or pertaining to more than one.
nd: North Dakota (approved especially for use with zip code).
singular: extraordinary; remarkable; exceptional: a singular success.
chamois: an agile, goatlike antelope, Rupicapra rupicapra, of high mountains of Europe: now rare in some areas.
def: definitely: Going to Europe this summer? But def!
further: at or to a greater distance; farther: I'm too tired to go further.
abrasive: any material or substance used for grinding, polishing, etc., as emery, pumice, or sandpaper.
many: constituting or forming a large number; numerous: many people.
times: multiplied by: Two times four is eight.
frequently: often; many times; at short intervals.
simple: easy to understand, deal with, use, etc.: a simple matter; simple tools.
past: gone by or elapsed in time: It was a bad time, but it's all past now.
tense: stretched tight, as a cord, fiber, etc.; drawn taut; rigid.
participle: an adjective or complement to certain auxiliaries that is regularly derived from the verb in many languages and refers to participation in the action or state of the verb; a verbal form used as an adjective. It does not specify person or number in English, but may have a subject or object, show tense, etc., as burning, in a burning candle, or devoted in his devoted friend.
make: to bring into existence by shaping or changing material, combining parts, etc.: to make a dress; to make a channel; to make a work of art.
synthetic: of, pertaining to, proceeding by, or involving synthesis (opposed to analytic).
previous: coming or occurring before something else; prior: the previous owner.
own: of, relating to, or belonging to oneself or itself (usually used after a possessive to emphasize the idea of ownership, interest, or relation conveyed by the possessive): He spent only his own money.
experienced: wise or skillful in a particular field through experience: an experienced teacher.
our: (a form of the possessive case of we used as an attributive adjective): Our team is going to win. Do you mind our going on ahead?
knowledge: acquaintance with facts, truths, or principles, as from study or investigation; general erudition: knowledge of many things.
identical: similar or alike in every way: The two cars are identical except for their license plates.
what: (used interrogatively as a request for specific information): What is the matter?
just: guided by truth, reason, justice, and fairness: We hope to be just in our understanding of such difficult situations.
were: a 2nd person singular pt. indicative, plural past indicative, and past subjunctive of be.
process: a systematic series of actions directed to some end: to devise a process for homogenizing milk.
course: a direction or route taken or to be taken.
action: the process or state of acting or of being active: The machine is not in action now.
sum: the aggregate of two or more numbers, magnitudes, quantities, or particulars as determined by or as if by the mathematical process of addition: The sum of 6 and 8 is 14.
total: constituting or comprising the whole; entire; whole: the total expenditure.
aggregate: formed by the conjunction or collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum; total; combined: the aggregate amount of indebtedness.
length: the longest extent of anything as measured from end to end: the length of a river.
area: any particular extent of space or surface; part: the dark areas in the painting; the dusty area of the room.
volume: a collection of written or printed sheets bound together and constituting a book.
scope: extent or range of view, outlook, application, operation, effectiveness, etc.: an investigation of wide scope.
right: in accordance with what is good, proper, or just: right conduct.
similar: having a likeness or resemblance, especially in a general way: two similar houses.
manner: a way of doing, being done, or happening; mode of action, occurrence, etc.: I don't like the manner in which he complained.
treat: to act or behave toward (a person) in some specified way: to treat someone with respect.
rich: having wealth or great possessions; abundantly supplied with resources, means, or funds; wealthy: a rich man; a rich nation.
poor: having little or no money, goods, or other means of support: a poor family living on welfare.
capital: the city or town that is the official seat of government in a country, state, etc.: Tokyo is the capital of Japan.
letter: a written or printed communication addressed to a person or organization and usually transmitted by mail.
sir: a respectful or formal term of address used to a man: No, sir.
spanish: of or relating to Spain, its people, or their language.
title: the distinguishing name of a book, poem, picture, piece of music, or the like.
man: an adult male person, as distinguished from a boy or a woman.
name: a word or a combination of words by which a person, place, or thing, a body or class, or any object of thought is designated, called, or known.
conscious: aware of one's own existence, sensations, thoughts, surroundings, etc.
mind: (in a human or other conscious being) the element, part, substance, or process that reasons, thinks, feels, wills, perceives, judges, etc.: the processes of the human mind.
reasoning: the act or process of a person who reasons.
making: the act of a person or thing that makes: The making of a violin requires great skill.
rational: agreeable to reason; reasonable; sensible: a rational plan for economic development.
understood: simple past tense and past participle of understand.
immediate: occurring or accomplished without delay; instant: an immediate reply.
context: the parts of a written or spoken statement that precede or follow a specific word or passage, usually influencing its meaning or effect: You have misinterpreted my remark because you took it out of context.
whitewall: a rubber tire for an automobile, bicycle, etc., whose sidewall is colored white.
upholstery: the materials used to cushion and cover furniture.
tell: to give an account or narrative of; narrate; relate (a story, tale, etc.): to tell the story of Lincoln's childhood.
cover: to be or serve as a covering for; extend over; rest on the surface of: Snow covered the fields.
off: so as to be no longer supported or attached: This button is about to come off.
high: having a great or considerable extent or reach upward or vertically; lofty; tall: a high wall.
temperature: a measure of the warmth or coldness of an object or substance with reference to some standard value. The temperature of two systems is the same when the systems are in thermal equilibrium.
fire: a state, process, or instance of combustion in which fuel or other material is ignited and combined with oxygen, giving off light, heat, and flame.
coffee: a beverage consisting of a decoction or infusion of the roasted ground or crushed seeds (coffee beans) of the two-seeded fruit (coffee berry) of certain coffee trees.
water: a transparent, odorless, tasteless liquid, a compound of hydrogen and oxygen, H 2 O, freezing at 32°F or 0°C and boiling at 212°F or 100°C, that in a more or less impure state constitutes rain, oceans, lakes, rivers, etc.: it contains 11.188 percent hydrogen and 88.812 percent oxygen, by weight.
vapor: a visible exhalation, as fog, mist, steam, smoke, or noxious gas, diffused through or suspended in the air: the vapors rising from the bogs.
air: a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen, and minute amounts of other gases that surrounds the earth and forms its atmosphere.
climate: the composite or generally prevailing weather conditions of a region, as temperature, air pressure, humidity, precipitation, sunshine, cloudiness, and winds, throughout the year, averaged over a series of years.
day: the interval of light between two successive nights; the time between sunrise and sunset: Since there was no artificial illumination, all activities had to be carried on during the day.
beautiful: having beauty; possessing qualities that give great pleasure or satisfaction to see, hear, think about, etc.; delighting the senses or mind: a beautiful dress; a beautiful speech.
preceding: that precedes; previous: Refer back to the footnote on the preceding page.
penetrate: to pierce or pass into or through: The bullet penetrated the wall. The fog lights penetrated the mist.
sharp: having a thin cutting edge or a fine point; well-adapted for cutting or piercing: a sharp knife.
instrument: a mechanical tool or implement, especially one used for delicate or precision work: surgical instruments.
finger: any of the terminal members of the hand, especially one other than the thumb.
smooth: free from projections or unevenness of surface; not rough: smooth wood; a smooth road.
glossy: having a shiny or lustrous surface.
figurine: a small ornamental figure of pottery, metal, plastic, etc.; statuette.
mahogany: any of several tropical American trees of the genus Swietenia, especially S. mahagoni and S. macrophylla, yielding hard, reddish-brown wood used for making furniture.
price: the sum or amount of money or its equivalent for which anything is bought, sold, or offered for sale.
great: unusually or comparatively large in size or dimensions: A great fire destroyed nearly half the city.
value: relative worth, merit, or importance: the value of a college education; the value of a queen in chess.
very: in a high degree; extremely; exceedingly: A giant is very tall.
valuable: having considerable monetary worth; costing or bringing a high price: a valuable painting; a valuable crop.
costly: costing much; expensive; high in price: a costly emerald bracelet; costly medical care.
matter: the substance or substances of which any physical object consists or is composed: the matter of which the earth is made.
consist: to be made up or composed (usually followed by of): This cake consists mainly of sugar, flour, and butter.
superior: higher in station, rank, degree, importance, etc.: a superior officer.
best: of the highest quality, excellence, or standing: the best work; the best students.
grade: a degree or step in a scale, as of rank, advancement, quality, value, or intensity: the best grade of paper.
wine: the fermented juice of grapes, made in many varieties, such as red, white, sweet, dry, still, and sparkling, for use as a beverage, in cooking, in religious rites, etc., and usually having an alcoholic content of 14 percent or less.
adequate: as much or as good as necessary for some requirement or purpose; fully sufficient, suitable, or fit (often followed by to or for): This car is adequate to our needs. adequate food for fifty people.
want: to feel a need or a desire for; wish for: to want one's dinner; always wanting something new.
need: a requirement, necessary duty, or obligation: There is no need for you to go there.
sufficient: adequate for the purpose; enough: sufficient proof; sufficient protection.
satisfy: to fulfill the desires, expectations, needs, or demands of (a person, the mind, etc.); give full contentment to: The hearty meal satisfied him.
desire: to wish or long for; crave; want.
noise: sound, especially of a loud, harsh, or confused kind: deafening noises.
wake: to become roused from sleep; awake; awaken; waken (often followed by up).
dead: no longer living; deprived of life: dead people; dead flowers; dead animals.
employ: to hire or engage the services of (a person or persons); provide employment for; have or keep in one's service: This factory employs thousands of people.
put: to move or place (anything) so as to get it into or out of a specific location or position: to put a book on the shelf.
service: an act of helpful activity; help; aid: to do someone a service.
knife: an instrument for cutting, consisting essentially of a thin, sharp-edged, metal blade fitted with a handle.
walking: considered as a person who can or does walk or something that walks: The hospital is caring for six walking patients. He's walking proof that people can lose weight quickly.
park: an area of land, usually in a largely natural state, for the enjoyment of the public, having facilities for rest and recreation, often owned, set apart, and managed by a city, state, or nation.
gold: a precious yellow metallic element, highly malleable and ductile, and not subject to oxidation or corrosion. Symbol:  Au; atomic weight:  196.967; atomic number:  79; specific gravity:  19.3 at 20°C.
personal: of, relating to, or coming as from a particular person; individual; private: a personal opinion.
adornment: something that adds attractiveness; ornament; accessory: the adornments and furnishings of a room.
may: (used to express possibility): It may rain.
greater: designating a city or country and its adjacent area: Greater New York; Greater Los Angeles.
quantity: a particular or indefinite amount of anything: a small quantity of milk; the ocean's vast quantity of fish.
measure: a unit or standard of measurement: weights and measures.
absence: state of being away or not being present: I acted as supervisor in his absence. Your absence was noted on the records.
avoidance: the act of avoiding or keeping away from: the avoidance of scandal; the avoidance of one's neighbors.
no: (a negative used to express dissent, denial, or refusal, as in response to a question or request)
none: no one; not one: None of the members is going.
lacking: being without; not having; wanting; less: Lacking equipment, the laboratory couldn't undertake the research project.
help: to give or provide what is necessary to accomplish a task or satisfy a need; contribute strength or means to; render assistance to; cooperate effectively with; aid; assist: He planned to help me with my work. Let me help you with those packages.
her: the objective case of she: We saw her this morning. Give this book to her.
helping: the act of a person or thing that helps.
him: the objective case of he, used as a direct or indirect object: I'll see him tomorrow. Give him the message.
case: an instance of the occurrence, existence, etc., of something: Sailing in such a storm was a case of poor judgment.
supposing: upon the supposition or premise that; in the event that.
sing: to utter words or sounds in succession with musical modulations of the voice; vocalize melodically.
stay: to spend some time in a place, in a situation, with a person or group, etc.: He stayed in the army for ten years.
indoors: in or into a house or building: We stayed indoors during the storm.
do: to perform (an act, duty, role, etc.): Do nothing until you hear the bell.
pronoun: any member of a small class of words found in many languages that are used as replacements or substitutes for nouns and noun phrases, and that have very general reference, as I, you, he, this, who, what. Pronouns are sometimes formally distinguished from nouns, as in English by the existence of special objective forms, as him for he or me for I, and by nonoccurrence with an article or adjective.
second: next after the first; being the ordinal number for two.
objective: something that one's efforts or actions are intended to attain or accomplish; purpose; goal; target: the objective of a military attack; the objective of a fund-raising drive.
who: what person or persons?: Who did it?
blame: to hold responsible; find fault with; censure: I don't blame you for leaving him.
package: a bundle of something, usually of small or medium size, that is packed and wrapped or boxed; parcel.
she: the female person or animal being discussed or last mentioned; that female.
possess: to have as belonging to one; have as property; own: to possess a house and a car.
hold: to have or keep in the hand; keep fast; grasp: She held the purse in her right hand. He held the child's hand in his.
contain: to hold or include within its volume or area: This glass contains water. This paddock contains our best horses.
work: exertion or effort directed to produce or accomplish something; labor; toil.
index: (in a nonfiction book, monograph, etc.) a more or less detailed alphabetical listing of names, places, and topics along with the numbers of the pages on which they are mentioned or discussed, usually included in or constituting the back matter.
witness: to see, hear, or know by personal presence and perception: to witness an accident.
bring: to carry, convey, conduct, or cause (someone or something) to come with, to, or toward the speaker: Bring the suitcase to my house. He brought his brother to my office.
rise: to get up from a lying, sitting, or kneeling posture; assume an upright position: She rose and walked over to greet me. With great effort he rose to his knees.
steam: water in the form of an invisible gas or vapor.
direct: to manage or guide by advice, helpful information, instruction, etc.: He directed the company through a difficult time.
indirect: not in a direct course or path; deviating from a straight line; roundabout: an indirect course in sailing.
saw: a tool or device for cutting, typically a thin blade of metal with a series of sharp teeth.
choose: to select from a number of possibilities; pick by preference: She chose Sunday for her departure.
select: to choose in preference to another or others; pick out.
among: in, into, or through the midst of; in association or connection with; surrounded by: He was among friends.
group: any collection or assemblage of persons or things; cluster; aggregation: a group of protesters; a remarkable group of paintings.
contestant: a person who takes part in a contest or competition.
audience: the group of spectators at a public event; listeners or viewers collectively, as in attendance at a theater or concert: The audience was respectful of the speaker's opinion.
away: from this or that place; off: to go away.
normal: conforming to the standard or the common type; usual; not abnormal; regular; natural.
usual: habitual or customary: her usual skill.
position: condition with reference to place; location; situation.
alphabetical: in the order of the letters of the alphabet: alphabetical arrangement.
order: an authoritative direction or instruction; command; mandate.
dinner: the main meal of the day, eaten in the evening or at midday.
five: a cardinal number, four plus one.
plus: more by the addition of; increased by: ten plus two is twelve.
appearance: the act or fact of appearing, as to the eye or mind or before the public: the unannounced appearance of dinner guests; the last appearance of Caruso in Aïda; her first appearance at a stockholders' meeting.
remember: to recall to the mind by an act or effort of memory; think of again: I'll try to remember the exact date.
distinct: distinguished as not being the same; not identical; separate (sometimes followed by from): His private and public lives are distinct.
although: in spite of the fact that; even though; though.
differ: to be unlike, dissimilar, or distinct in nature or qualities (often followed by from): The two writers differ greatly in their perceptions of the world. Each writer's style differs from that of another.
experiment: a test, trial, or tentative procedure; an act or operation for the purpose of discovering something unknown or of testing a principle, supposition, etc.: a chemical experiment; a teaching experiment; an experiment in living.
express: to put (thought) into words; utter or state: to express an idea clearly.
negation: the act of denying: He shook his head in negation of the charge.
denial: an assertion that something said, believed, alleged, etc., is false: Despite his denials, we knew he had taken the purse. The politician issued a denial of his opponent's charges.
refusal: an act or instance of refusing.
must: to be obliged or bound to by an imperative requirement: I must keep my word.
far: at or to a great distance; a long way off; at or to a remote point: We sailed far ahead of the fleet.
here: in this place; in this spot or locality (opposed to there): Put the pen here.
prove: to establish the truth or genuineness of, as by evidence or argument: to prove one's claim.
coat: an outer garment with sleeves, covering at least the upper part of the body: a new fur coat; a coat for formal wear.
brown: a dark tertiary color with a yellowish or reddish hue.
speaking: the act, utterance, or discourse of a person who speaks.
coherent: logically connected; consistent: a coherent argument.
general: of or relating to all persons or things belonging to a group or category: a general meeting of the employees.
correct: to set or make true, accurate, or right; remove the errors or faults from: The native guide corrected our pronunciation. The new glasses corrected his eyesight.
explanation: the act or process of explaining.
relativity: the state or fact of being relative.
particularly: in a particular or to an exceptional degree; especially: He read it with particularly great interest.
watchful: vigilant or alert; closely observant: The sentry remained watchful throughout the night.
sooner: a person who settles on government land before it is legally opened to settlers in order to gain the choice of location.
see: to perceive with the eyes; look at.
adjunct: something added to another thing but not essential to it.
clause: Grammar. a syntactic construction containing a subject and predicate and forming part of a sentence or constituting a whole simple sentence.
oppose: to act against or provide resistance to; combat.
fixed: fastened, attached, or placed so as to be firm and not readily movable; firmly implanted; stationary; rigid.
limit: the final, utmost, or furthest boundary or point as to extent, amount, continuance, procedure, etc.: the limit of his experience; the limit of vision.
unlimited: not limited; unrestricted; unconfined: unlimited trade.
generalize: to infer (a general principle, trend, etc.) from particular facts, statistics, or the like.
physical: of or relating to the body: physical exercise.
power: ability to do or act; capability of doing or accomplishing something.
strength: the quality or state of being strong; bodily or muscular power; vigor.
possessed: spurred or moved by a strong feeling, madness, or a supernatural power (often followed by by, of, or with): The army fought as if possessed. The village believed her to be possessed of the devil.
living: having life; being alive; not dead: living persons.
opening: an act or instance of making or becoming open.
window: an opening in the wall of a building, the side of a vehicle, etc., for the admission of air or light, or both, commonly fitted with a frame in which are set movable sashes containing panes of glass.
prose: the ordinary form of spoken or written language, without metrical structure, as distinguished from poetry or verse.
nonfiction: the branch of literature comprising works of narrative prose dealing with or offering opinions or conjectures upon facts and reality, including biography, history, and the essay (opposed to fiction and distinguished from poetry and drama).
topic: a subject of conversation or discussion: to provide a topic for discussion.
independent: not influenced or controlled by others in matters of opinion, conduct, etc.; thinking or acting for oneself: an independent thinker.
publication: the act of publishing a book, periodical, map, piece of music, engraving, or the like.
newspaper: a publication issued at regular and usually close intervals, especially daily or weekly, and commonly containing news, comment, features, and advertising.
magazine: a publication that is issued periodically, usually bound in a paper cover, and typically contains essays, stories, poems, etc., by many writers, and often photographs and drawings, frequently specializing in a particular subject or area, as hobbies, news, or sports.
fiction: the class of literature comprising works of imaginative narration, especially in prose form.
bound: simple past tense and past participle of bind.
party: a social gathering, as of invited guests at a private home, for conversation, refreshments, entertainment, etc.: a cocktail party.
your: (a form of the possessive case of you used as an attributive adjective): Your jacket is in that closet. I like your idea.
hand: the terminal, prehensile part of the upper limb in humans and other primates, consisting of the wrist, metacarpal area, fingers, and thumb.
approach: to come near or nearer to: The cars slowed down as they approached the intersection.
move: to pass from one place or position to another.
particular: of or relating to a single or specific person, thing, group, class, occasion, etc., rather than to others or all; special rather than general: one's particular interests in books.
closer: a person or thing that closes.
room: a portion of space within a building or other structure, separated by walls or partitions from other parts: a dining room.
station: a place or position in which a person or thing is normally located.
people: persons indefinitely or collectively; persons in general: to find it easy to talk to people; What will people think?
residence: the place, especially the house, in which a person lives or resides; dwelling place; home: Their residence is in New York City.
essential: absolutely necessary; indispensable: Discipline is essential in an army.
distinctive: serving to distinguish; characteristic; distinguishing: the distinctive stripes of the zebra.
characteristic: Also, characteristical. pertaining to, constituting, or indicating the character or peculiar quality of a person or thing; typical; distinctive: Red and gold are the characteristic colors of autumn.
attribute: to regard as resulting from a specified cause; consider as caused by something indicated (usually followed by to): She attributed his bad temper to ill health.
tangible: capable of being touched; discernible by the touch; material or substantial.
relatively: in a relative manner: a relatively small difference.
stable: a building for the lodging and feeding of horses, cattle, etc.
material: the substance or substances of which a thing is made or composed: Stone is a durable material.
detail: an individual or minute part; an item or particular.
reflect: to cast back (light, heat, sound, etc.) from a surface: The mirror reflected the light onto the wall.
next: immediately following in time, order, importance, etc.: the next day; the next person in line.
home: a house, apartment, or other shelter that is the usual residence of a person, family, or household.
lake: a body of fresh or salt water of considerable size, surrounded by land.
resolute: firmly resolved or determined; set in purpose or opinion: Her parents wanted her to marry, but she was focused on her education and remained resolute.
visual: of or relating to seeing or sight: a visual image.
sight: the power or faculty of seeing; perception of objects by use of the eyes; vision.
gradation: any process or change taking place through a series of stages, by degrees, or in a gradual manner.
tint: a color or a variety of a color; hue.
pale: lacking intensity of color; colorless or whitish: a pale complexion.
bright: radiating or reflecting light; luminous; shining: The bright coins shone in the gloom.
purity: the condition or quality of being pure; freedom from anything that debases, contaminates, pollutes, etc.: the purity of drinking water.
freedom: the state of being free or at liberty rather than in confinement or under physical restraint: He won his freedom after a retrial.
gray: of a color between white and black; having a neutral hue.
liquid: composed of molecules that move freely among themselves but do not tend to separate like those of gases; neither gaseous nor solid.
gas: Physics. a substance possessing perfect molecular mobility and the property of indefinite expansion, as opposed to a solid or liquid.
capable: having power and ability; efficient; competent: a capable instructor.
flowing: moving in or as in a stream: flowing water.
shape: the quality of a distinct object or body in having an external surface or outline of specific form or figure.
steady: firmly placed or fixed; stable in position or equilibrium: a steady ladder.
rate: the amount of a charge or payment with reference to some basis of calculation: a high rate of interest on loans.
when: at what time or period? how long ago? how soon?: When are they to arrive? When did the Roman Empire exist?
upon: up and on; upward so as to get or be on: He climbed upon his horse and rode off.
change: to make the form, nature, content, future course, etc., of (something) different from what it is or from what it would be if left alone: to change one's name; to change one's opinion; to change the course of history.
idea: any conception existing in the mind as a result of mental understanding, awareness, or activity.
event: something that happens or is regarded as happening; an occurrence, especially one of some importance.
time: the system of those sequential relations that any event has to any other, as past, present, or future; indefinite and continuous duration regarded as that in which events succeed one another.
remark: to say casually, as in making a comment: Someone remarked that tomorrow would be a warm day.
pointed: having a point or points: a pointed arch.
supposed: assumed as true, regardless of fact; hypothetical: a supposed case.
way: manner, mode, or fashion: a new way of looking at a matter; to reply in a polite way.
emphasis: special stress laid upon, or importance attached to, anything: The president's statement gave emphasis to the budgetary crisis.
after: behind in place or position; following behind: men lining up one after the other.
each: every one of two or more considered individually or one by one: each stone in a building; a hallway with a door at each end.
circulate: to move in a circle or circuit; move or pass through a circuit back to the starting point: Blood circulates throughout the body.
foremost: first in place, order, rank, etc.: the foremost surgeons.
composed: calm; tranquil; serene: His composed face reassured the nervous passengers.
provided: on the condition or understanding (that); providing: I'll go provided that the others go, too.
convey: to carry, bring, or take from one place to another; transport; bear.
lymph: Anatomy, Physiology. a clear yellowish, slightly alkaline, coagulable fluid, containing white blood cells in a liquid resembling blood plasma, that is derived from the tissues of the body and conveyed to the bloodstream by the lymphatic vessels.
sap: the juice or vital circulating fluid of a plant, especially of a woody plant.
assemblage: a group of persons or things gathered or collected; an assembly; collection; aggregate.
combination: the act of combining or the state of being combined.
complex: composed of many interconnected parts; compound; composite: a complex highway system.
unitary: of or relating to a unit or units.
whole: comprising the full quantity, amount, extent, number, etc., without diminution or exception; entire, full, or total: He ate the whole pie. They ran the whole distance.
mountain: a natural elevation of the earth's surface rising more or less abruptly to a summit, and attaining an altitude greater than that of a hill, usually greater than 2000 feet (610 meters).
railroad: a permanent road laid with rails, commonly in one or more pairs of continuous lines forming a track or tracks, on which locomotives and cars are run for the transportation of passengers, freight, and mail.
frailty: the quality or state of being frail.
vertebrate: having vertebrae; having a backbone or spinal column.
anatomy: the science dealing with the structure of animals and plants.
physiology: the branch of biology dealing with the functions and activities of living organisms and their parts, including all physical and chemical processes.
cell: a small room, as in a convent or prison.
pure: free from anything of a different, inferior, or contaminating kind; free from extraneous matter: pure gold; pure water.
snow: Compare ice crystals, snow grains, snow pellets.
page: one side of a leaf of something printed or written, as a book, manuscript, or letter.
nearly: all but; almost: nearly dead with cold.
sunlight: the light of the sun; sunshine.
platelet: a small platelike body, especially a blood platelet.
suspend: to hang by attachment to something above: to suspend a chandelier from the ceiling.
ordinal: of or relating to an order, as of animals or plants.
edition: one of a series of printings of the same book, newspaper, etc., each issued at a different time and differing from another by alterations, additions, etc. (distinguished from impression).
vice: an immoral or evil habit or practice. Synonyms: fault, failing, foible, weakness.
president: (often initial capital letter) the highest executive officer of a modern republic, as the Chief Executive of the United States.
separate: to keep apart or divide, as by an intervening barrier or space: to separate two fields by a fence.
social: pertaining to, devoted to, or characterized by friendly companionship or relations: a social club.
hierarchy: any system of persons or things ranked one above another.
body: the physical structure and material substance of an animal or plant, living or dead.
important: of much or great significance or consequence: an important event in world history.
significance: importance; consequence: the significance of the new treaty.
head: the upper part of the body in humans, joined to the trunk by the neck, containing the brain, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth.
leader: a person or thing that leads.
organized: affiliated in an organization, especially a union: organized dockworkers.
authority: the power to determine, adjudicate, or otherwise settle issues or disputes; jurisdiction; the right to control, command, or determine.
police: Also called police force. an organized civil force for maintaining order, preventing and detecting crime, and enforcing the laws.
goal: the result or achievement toward which effort is directed; aim; end.
growth: the act or process, or a manner of growing; development; gradual increase.
reproduction: the act or process of reproducing.
environment: the aggregate of surrounding things, conditions, or influences; surroundings; milieu.
dagger: a short, swordlike weapon with a pointed blade and a handle, used for stabbing.
portion: a part of any whole, either separated from or integrated with it: I read a portion of the manuscript.
whether: (used to introduce the first of two or more alternatives, and sometimes repeated before the second or later alternative, usually with the correlative or): It matters little whether we go or stay. Whether we go or whether we stay, the result is the same.
occupy: to take or fill up (space, time, etc.): I occupied my evenings reading novels.
realm: a royal domain; kingdom: the realm of England.
expanse: an uninterrupted space or area; a wide extent of anything: an expanse of water.
occur: to happen; take place; come to pass: When did the accident occur?
remain: to continue in the same state; continue to be as specified: to remain at peace.
down: from higher to lower; in descending direction or order; toward, into, or in a lower position: to come down the ladder.
table: an article of furniture consisting of a flat, slablike top supported on one or more legs or other supports: a kitchen table; an operating table; a pool table.
hang: to fasten or attach (a thing) so that it is supported only from above or at a point near its own top; suspend.
hook: a curved or angular piece of metal or other hard substance for catching, pulling, holding, or suspending something.
close: to put (something) in a position to obstruct an entrance, opening, etc.; shut.
won: simple past tense and past participle of win1 .
shout: to call or cry out loudly and vigorously.
upright: erect or vertical, as in position or posture.
movable: capable of being moved; not fixed in one place, position, or posture.
solid: having three dimensions (length, breadth, and thickness), as a geometrical body or figure.
barrier: anything built or serving to bar passage, as a railing, fence, or the like: People may pass through the barrier only when their train is announced.
closing: the end or conclusion, as of a speech.
cupboard: a closet with shelves for dishes, cups, etc.
cabinet: a piece of furniture with shelves, drawers, etc., for holding or displaying items: a curio cabinet; a file cabinet.
turning: the act of a person or thing that turns.
sliding: rising or falling, increasing or decreasing, according to a standard or to a set of conditions.
top: the highest or loftiest point or part of anything; apex; summit. Synonyms: zenith, acme, peak, pinnacle, vertex.
hill: a natural elevation of the earth's surface, smaller than a mountain.
cylindrical: of, relating to, or having the form of a cylinder.
wooden: consisting or made of wood; wood: a wooden ship.
container: anything that contains or can contain something, as a carton, box, crate, or can.
parallel: extending in the same direction, equidistant at all points, and never converging or diverging: parallel rows of trees.
only: without others or anything further; alone; solely; exclusively: This information is for your eyes only.
unique: existing as the only one or as the sole example; single; solitary in type or characteristics: a unique copy of an ancient manuscript.
sole: being the only one; only: the sole living relative.
example: one of a number of things, or a part of something, taken to show the character of the whole: This painting is an example of his early work.
complete: having all parts or elements; lacking nothing; whole; entire; full: a complete set of Mark Twain's writings.
wrote: a simple past tense of write.
