novel: a fictitious prose narrative of considerable length and complexity, portraying characters and usually presenting a sequential organization of action and scenes.
consciousness: the state of being conscious; awareness of one's own existence, sensations, thoughts, surroundings, etc.
list: a series of names or other items written or printed together in a meaningful grouping or sequence so as to constitute a record: a list of members.
somewhat: in some measure or degree; to some extent: not angry, just somewhat disturbed.
good: morally excellent; virtuous; righteous; pious: a good man.
introduce: to present (a person) to another so as to make acquainted.
member: a person, animal, plant, group, etc., that is part of a society, party, community, taxon, or other body.
unequal: not equal; not of the same quantity, quality, value, rank, ability, etc.: People are unequal in their capacities.
am: 1st person singular present indicative of be.
female: a person bearing two X chromosomes in the cell nuclei and normally having a vagina, a uterus and ovaries, and developing at puberty a relatively rounded body and enlarged breasts, and retaining a beardless face; a girl or woman.
girl: a female child, from birth to full growth.
large: of more than average size, quantity, degree, etc.; exceeding that which is common to a kind or class; big; great: a large house; a large number; in large measure; to a large extent.
territory: any tract of land; region or district.
unity: the state of being one; oneness.
seek: to go in search or quest of: to seek the truth.
government: the political direction and control exercised over the actions of the members, citizens, or inhabitants of communities, societies, and states; direction of the affairs of a state, community, etc.; political administration: Government is necessary to the existence of civilized society.
spoke: a simple past tense of speak.
tax: a sum of money demanded by a government for its support or for specific facilities or services, levied upon incomes, property, sales, etc.
limited: confined within limits; restricted or circumscribed: a limited space; limited resources.
chocolate: a preparation of the seeds of cacao, roasted, husked, and ground, often sweetened and flavored, as with vanilla.
sweet: having the taste or flavor characteristic of sugar, honey, etc.
shortening: butter, lard, or other fat, used to make pastry, bread, etc., short.
flour: the finely ground meal of grain, especially the finer meal separated by bolting.
powder: any solid substance reduced to a state of fine, loose particles by crushing, grinding, disintegration, etc.
flavoring: something that gives flavor; a substance or preparation used to give a particular flavor to food or drink: vanilla flavoring.
benevolent: characterized by or expressing goodwill or kindly feelings: a benevolent attitude; her benevolent smile.
disposition: the predominant or prevailing tendency of one's spirits; natural mental and emotional outlook or mood; characteristic attitude: a girl with a pleasant disposition.
loving: feeling or showing love; warmly affectionate; fond: loving glances.
distant: far off or apart in space; not near at hand; remote or removed (often followed by from): a distant place; a town three miles distant from here.
remote: far apart; far distant in space; situated at some distance away: the remote jungles of Brazil.
special: of a distinct or particular kind or character: a special kind of key.
interest: the feeling of a person whose attention, concern, or curiosity is particularly engaged by something: She has a great interest in the poetry of Donne.
commonplace: ordinary; undistinguished or uninteresting; without individuality: a commonplace person.
unexceptional: not exceptional; not unusual or extraordinary.
brilliant: shining brightly; sparkling; glittering; lustrous: the brilliant lights of the city.
rating: classification according to grade or rank.
arithmetic: the method or process of computation with figures: the most elementary branch of mathematics.
mean: to have in mind as one's purpose or intention; intend: I meant to compliment you on your work.
golf: a game in which clubs with wooden or metal heads are used to hit a small, white ball into a number of holes, usually 9 or 18, in succession, situated at various distances over a course having natural or artificial obstacles, the object being to get the ball into each hole in as few strokes as possible.
my: (a form of the possessive case of I used as an attributive adjective): My soup is cold.
science: a branch of knowledge or study dealing with a body of facts or truths systematically arranged and showing the operation of general laws: the mathematical sciences.
semester: (in many educational institutions) a division constituting half of the regular academic year, lasting typically from 15 to 18 weeks.
coming: approach; arrival; advent: His coming here was a mistake.
line: a mark or stroke long in proportion to its breadth, made with a pen, pencil, tool, etc., on a surface: a line down the middle of the page.
division: the act or process of dividing; state of being divided.
fragment: a part broken off or detached: scattered fragments of the broken vase.
section: a part that is cut off or separated.
constituent: serving to compose or make up a thing; component: the constituent parts of a motor.
rear: the back of something, as distinguished from the front: The porch is at the rear of the house.
glue: a hard, impure, protein gelatin, obtained by boiling skins, hoofs, and other animal substances in water, that when melted or diluted is a strong adhesive.
terminal: situated at or forming the end or extremity of something: a terminal feature of a vista.
whatever: anything that (usually used in relative clauses): Whatever you say is all right with me.
toothache: a pain in or about a tooth.
long: having considerable linear extent in space: a long distance; a long handle.
considerable: rather large or great in size, distance, extent, etc.: It cost a considerable amount. We took a considerable length of time to decide.
side: one of the surfaces forming the outside of or bounding a thing, or one of the lines bounding a geometric figure.
boulevard: a broad avenue in a city, usually having areas at the sides or center for trees, grass, or flowers.
breadth: the measure of the second largest dimension of a plane or solid figure; width.
too: in addition; also; furthermore; moreover: young, clever, and rich too.
swim: to move in water by movements of the limbs, fins, tail, etc.
across: from one side to the other of: a bridge across a river.
thoroughfare: a road, street, or the like, that leads at each end into another street.
village: a small community or group of houses in a rural area, larger than a hamlet and usually smaller than a town, and sometimes (as in parts of the U.S.) incorporated as a municipality.
town: a thickly populated area, usually smaller than a city and larger than a village, having fixed boundaries and certain local powers of government.
sidewalk: a walk, especially a paved one, at the side of a street or road.
strong: having, showing, or able to exert great bodily or muscular power; physically vigorous or robust: a strong boy.
thick: having relatively great extent from one surface or side to the opposite; not thin: a thick slice.
cord: a string or thin rope made of several strands braided, twisted, or woven together.
flax: any plant of the genus Linum, especially L. usitatissimum, a slender, erect, annual plant having narrow, lance-shaped leaves and blue flowers, cultivated for its fiber and seeds.
wire: a slender, stringlike piece or filament of relatively rigid or flexible metal, usually circular in section, manufactured in a great variety of diameters and metals depending on its application.
able: having necessary power, skill, resources, or qualifications; qualified: able to lift a two-hundred-pound weight; able to write music; able to travel widely; able to vote.
ability: power or capacity to do or act physically, mentally, legally, morally, financially, etc.
skill: the ability, coming from one's knowledge, practice, aptitude, etc., to do something well: Carpentry was one of his many skills.
solve: to find the answer or explanation for; clear up; explain: to solve the mystery of the missing books.
problem: any question or matter involving doubt, uncertainty, or difficulty.
easily: in an easy manner; with ease; without trouble: The traffic moved along easily.
sure: free from doubt as to the reliability, character, action, etc., of something: to be sure of one's data.
appreciable: sufficient to be readily perceived or estimated; considerable: There is an appreciable difference between socialism and communism.
organ: Also called pipe organ. a musical instrument consisting of one or more sets of pipes sounded by means of compressed air, played by means of one or more keyboards, and capable of producing a wide range of musical effects.
pair: two identical, similar, or corresponding things that are matched for use together: a pair of gloves; a pair of earrings.
spherical: having the form of a sphere; globular.
contained: showing restraint or calmness; controlled; poised: She was contained throughout the ordeal.
orbit: the curved path, usually elliptical, described by a planet, satellite, spaceship, etc., around a celestial body, as the sun.
skull: the bony framework of the head, enclosing the brain and supporting the face; the skeleton of the head.
dense: having the component parts closely compacted together; crowded or compact: a dense forest; dense population.
membrane: Anatomy. a thin, pliable sheet or layer of animal or vegetable tissue, serving to line an organ, connect parts, etc.
sclera: a dense, white, fibrous membrane that, with the cornea, forms the external covering of the eyeball.
circular: having the form of a circle; round: a circular tower.
iris: Anatomy. the contractile, circular diaphragm forming the colored portion of the eye and containing a circular opening, the pupil, in its center.
clear: free from darkness, obscurity, or cloudiness; light: a clear day.
cornea: the transparent anterior part of the external coat of the eye covering the iris and the pupil and continuous with the sclera.
center: Geometry. the middle point, as the point within a circle or sphere equally distant from all points of the circumference or surface, or the point within a regular polygon equally distant from the vertices.
pupil: a person, usually young, who is learning under the close supervision of a teacher at school, a private tutor, or the like; student.
retina: the innermost coat of the posterior part of the eyeball that receives the image produced by the lens, is continuous with the optic nerve, and consists of several layers, one of which contains the rods and cones that are sensitive to light.
company: a number of individuals assembled or associated together; group of people.
acting: serving temporarily, especially as a substitute during another's absence; not permanent; temporary: the acting mayor.
aggregation: a group or mass of distinct or varied things, persons, etc.: an aggregation of complainants.
troop: an assemblage of persons or things; company; band.
succession: the coming of one person or thing after another in order, sequence, or in the course of events: many troubles in succession.
sequence: the following of one thing after another; succession.
call: to cry out in a loud voice; shout: He called her name to see if she was home.
extension: an act or instance of extending, lengthening, stretching out, or enlarging the scope of something.
contrary: opposite in nature or character; diametrically or mutually opposed: contrary to fact; contrary propositions.
yet: at the present time; now: Don't go yet. Are they here yet?
marked: strikingly noticeable; conspicuous: with marked success.
suggestive: that suggests; referring to other thoughts, persons, etc.: His recommendation was suggestive of his boss's thinking.
effort: exertion of physical or mental power: It will take great effort to achieve victory.
spontaneous: coming or resulting from a natural impulse or tendency; without effort or premeditation; natural and unconstrained; unplanned: a spontaneous burst of applause.
simplicity: the state, quality, or an instance of being simple.
art: the quality, production, expression, or realm, according to aesthetic principles, of what is beautiful, appealing, or of more than ordinary significance.
gamma: the third letter of the Greek alphabet (Γ, γ).
cosmic: of or relating to the cosmos: cosmic laws.
warmth: the quality or state of being warm; moderate or gentle heat.
capacity: the ability to receive or contain: This hotel has a large capacity.
vigorous: full of or characterized by vigor: a vigorous effort.
available: suitable or ready for use; of use or service; at hand: I used whatever tools were available.
eat: to take into the mouth and swallow for nourishment; chew and swallow (food).
get: to receive or come to have possession, use, or enjoyment of: to get a birthday present; to get a pension.
quick: done, proceeding, or occurring with promptness or rapidity, as an action, process, etc.; prompt; immediate: a quick response.
examine: to inspect or scrutinize carefully: to examine a prospective purchase.
cloth: a fabric formed by weaving, felting, etc., from wool, hair, silk, flax, cotton, or other fiber, used for garments, upholstery, and many other items.
electromagnetism: the phenomena associated with electric and magnetic fields and their interactions with each other and with electric charges and currents.
fields: W. C (William Claude Dukenfield) 1880–1946, U.S. vaudeville and motion-picture comedian.
size: the spatial dimensions, proportions, magnitude, or bulk of anything: the size of a farm; the size of the fish you caught.
dough: flour or meal combined with water, milk, etc., in a mass for baking into bread, cake, etc.; paste of bread.
external: of or relating to the outside or outer part; outer: an external surface.
clearly: in a clear manner: It is difficult to explain complex matters clearly.
configuration: the relative disposition or arrangement of the parts or elements of a thing.
triangular: pertaining to or having the form of a triangle; three-cornered.
step: a movement made by lifting the foot and setting it down again in a new position, accompanied by a shifting of the weight of the body in the direction of the new position, as in walking, running, or dancing.
sonority: the condition or quality of being resonant or sonorous.
grill: a grated utensil for broiling meat, fish, vegetables, etc., over a fire; gridiron.
consonant: (in a syllable) any sound other than the sound of greatest sonority in the syllable, as b, r, and g in brig (opposed to sonant). Compare vowel (def 1b).
sensation: the operation or function of the senses; perception or awareness of stimuli through the senses.
hearing: the faculty or sense by which sound is perceived.
honesty: the quality or fact of being honest; uprightness and fairness.
fairness: the state, condition, or quality of being fair, or free from bias or injustice; evenhandedness: I have to admit, in all fairness, that she would only be paid for part of the work.
integrity: adherence to moral and ethical principles; soundness of moral character; honesty.
now: at the present time or moment: You are now using a dictionary.
then: at that time: Prices were lower then.
england: the largest division of the United Kingdom, constituting, with Scotland and Wales, the island of Great Britain. 50,327 sq. mi. (130,347 sq. km) Capital:  London.
stress: importance attached to a thing: to lay stress upon good manners.
word: a unit of language, consisting of one or more spoken sounds or their written representation, that functions as a principal carrier of meaning. Words are composed of one or more morphemes and are either the smallest units susceptible of independent use or consist of two or three such units combined under certain linking conditions, as with the loss of primary accent that distinguishes black·bird· from black· bird·. Words are usually separated by spaces in writing, and are distinguished phonologically, as by accent, in many languages.
segment: one of the parts into which something naturally separates or is divided; a division, portion, or section: a segment of an orange.
speech: the faculty or power of speaking; oral communication; ability to express one's thoughts and emotions by speech sounds and gesture: Losing her speech made her feel isolated from humanity.
diphthong: Phonetics. an unsegmentable, gliding speech sound varying continuously in phonetic quality but held to be a single sound or phoneme and identified by its apparent beginning and ending sound, as the oi- sound of toy or boil.
syllabic: of, relating to, or consisting of a syllable or syllables.
following: a body of followers, attendants, adherents, etc.
sty: a pen or enclosure for swine; pigpen.
eyelet: a small hole, usually round and finished along the edge, as in cloth or leather for the passage of a lace or cord or as in embroidery for ornamental effect.
stifle: to quell, crush, or end by force: to stifle a revolt; to stifle free expression.
enact: to make into an act or statute: Congress has enacted a new tax law.
circumstance: a condition, detail, part, or attribute, with respect to time, place, manner,agent, etc., that accompanies, determines, or modifies a fact or event; a modifying or influencing factor: Do not judge his behavior without considering every circumstance.
quiet: making no noise or sound, especially no disturbing sound: quiet neighbors.
still: remaining in place or at rest; motionless; stationary: to stand still.
motor: a comparatively small and powerful engine, especially an internal-combustion engine in an automobile, motorboat, or the like.
weak: not strong; liable to yield, break, or collapse under pressure or strain; fragile; frail: a weak fortress; a weak spot in armor.
feeble: physically weak, as from age or sickness; frail.
constitution: the system of fundamental principles according to which a nation, state, corporation, or the like, is governed.
robust: strong and healthy; hardy; vigorous: a robust young man; a robust faith; a robust mind.
fishy: like a fish in shape, smell, taste, or the like.
taste: to try or test the flavor or quality of (something) by taking some into the mouth: to taste food.
expert: a person who has special skill or knowledge in some particular field; specialist; authority: a language expert.
history: the branch of knowledge dealing with past events.
wrong: not in accordance with what is morally right or good: a wrong deed.
there: in or at that place (opposed to here): She is there now.
organization: the act or process of organizing.
bureau: a chest of drawers, often with a mirror at the top.
welfare: the good fortune, health, happiness, prosperity, etc., of a person, group, or organization; well-being: to look after a child's welfare; the physical or moral welfare of society.
such: of the kind, character, degree, extent, etc., of that or those indicated or implied: Such a man is dangerous.
much: great in quantity, measure, or degree: too much cake.
anxiety: distress or uneasiness of mind caused by fear of danger or misfortune: He felt anxiety about the possible loss of his job.
accident: an undesirable or unfortunate happening that occurs unintentionally and usually results in harm, injury, damage, or loss; casualty; mishap: automobile accidents.
spring: to rise, leap, move, or act suddenly and swiftly, as by a sudden dart or thrust forward or outward, or being suddenly released from a coiled or constrained position: to spring into the air; a tiger about to spring.
arise: to get up from sitting, lying, or kneeling; rise: He arose from his chair when she entered the room.
proceed: to move or go forward or onward, especially after stopping.
outcome: a final product or end result; consequence; issue.
reckless: utterly unconcerned about the consequences of some action; without caution; careless (usually followed by of): to be reckless of danger.
driving: demanding a high or unreasonable rate of work from subordinates.
open: not closed or barred at the time, as a doorway by a door, a window by a sash, or a gateway by a gate: to leave the windows open at night.
sudden: happening, coming, made, or done quickly, without warning, or unexpectedly: a sudden attack.
hidden: concealed; obscure; covert: hidden meaning; hidden hostility.
under: beneath and covered by: under a table; under a tree.
blanket: a large, rectangular piece of soft fabric, often with bound edges, used especially for warmth as a bed covering.
star: any of the heavenly bodies, except the moon, appearing as fixed luminous points in the sky at night.
central: of or forming the center: the central hut in the village.
solar: of or relating to the sun: solar phenomena.
around: in a circle, ring, or the like; so as to surround a person, group, thing, etc.: The crowd gathered around.
revolve: to move in a circular or curving course or orbit: The earth revolves around the sun.
receive: to take into one's possession (something offered or delivered): to receive many gifts.
earth: (often initial capital letter) the planet third in order from the sun, having an equatorial diameter of 7926 miles (12,755 km) and a polar diameter of 7900 miles (12,714 km), a mean distance from the sun of 92.9 million miles (149.6 million km), and a period of revolution of 365.26 days, and having one satellite.
million: a cardinal number, a thousand times one thousand.
period: a rather large interval of time that is meaningful in the life of a person, in history, etc., because of its particular characteristics: a period of illness; a period of great profitability for a company; a period of social unrest in Germany.
surface: the outer face, outside, or exterior boundary of a thing; outermost or uppermost layer or area.
rotation: the act of rotating; a turning around as on an axis.
days: in or during the day regularly: They slept days rather than nights.
equator: the great circle on a sphere or heavenly body whose plane is perpendicular to the axis, equidistant everywhere from the two poles of the sphere or heavenly body.
toughen: to make or become tough or tougher.
covering: something laid over or wrapped around a thing, especially for concealment, protection, or warmth.
integument: a natural covering, as a skin, shell, or rind.
animal: any member of the kingdom Animalia, comprising multicellular organisms that have a well-defined shape and usually limited growth, can move voluntarily, actively acquire food and digest it internally, and have sensory and nervous systems that allow them to respond rapidly to stimuli: some classification schemes also include protozoa and certain other single-celled eukaryotes that have motility and animallike nutritional modes.
soft: yielding readily to touch or pressure; easily penetrated, divided, or changed in shape; not hard or stiff: a soft pillow.
flexible: capable of being bent, usually without breaking; easily bent: a flexible ruler.
afford: to be able to do, manage, or bear without serious consequence or adverse effect: The country can't afford another drought.
duration: the length of time something continues or exists (often used with the).
rely: to depend confidently; put trust in (usually followed by on or upon): You can rely on her work.
trust: reliance on the integrity, strength, ability, surety, etc., of a person or thing; confidence.
accuracy: the condition or quality of being true, correct, or exact; freedom from error or defect; precision or exactness; correctness.
report: an account or statement describing in detail an event, situation, or the like, usually as the result of observation, inquiry, etc.: a report on the peace conference; a medical report on the patient.
accompany: to go along or in company with; join in action: to accompany a friend on a walk.
going: the act of leaving or departing; departure: a safe going and quick return.
tomorrow: the day following today: Tomorrow is supposed to be sunny.
bus: a large motor vehicle, having a long body, equipped with seats or benches for passengers, usually operating as part of a scheduled service; omnibus.
male: a person bearing an X and Y chromosome pair in the cell nuclei and normally having a penis, scrotum, and testicles, and developing hair on the face at adolescence; a boy or man.
offspring: children or young of a particular parent or progenitor.
both: one and the other; two together: He met both sisters. Both performances were canceled.
opposition: the action of opposing, resisting, or combating.
adverse: unfavorable or antagonistic in purpose or effect: adverse criticism.
hostile: of, relating to, or characteristic of an enemy: a hostile nation.
ten: a cardinal number, nine plus one.
reason: a basis or cause, as for some belief, action, fact, event, etc.: the reason for declaring war.
hatred: the feeling of one who hates; intense dislike or extreme aversion or hostility.
harmful: causing or capable of causing harm; injurious: a harmful idea; a harmful habit.
antagonistic: acting in opposition; opposing, especially mutually.
adversary: a person, group, or force that opposes or attacks; opponent; enemy; foe.
opponent: a person who is on an opposing side in a game, contest, controversy, or the like; adversary.
race: a contest of speed, as in running, riding, driving, or sailing.
over: above in place or position: the roof over one's head.
sea: the salt waters that cover the greater part of the earth's surface.
moving: capable of or having movement: a moving object.
ridge: a long, narrow elevation of land; a chain of hills or mountains.
swell: to grow in bulk, as by the absorption of moisture or the processes of growth.
consecutive: following one another in uninterrupted succession or order; successive: six consecutive numbers, such as 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
characterize: to mark or distinguish as a characteristic; be a characteristic of: Rich metaphors characterize his poetry.
major: a commissioned military officer ranking next below a lieutenant colonel and next above a captain.
itself: a reflexive form of it1 : The battery recharges itself.
recent: of late occurrence, appearance, or origin; lately happening, done, made, etc.: recent events; a recent trip.
production: the act of producing; creation; manufacture.
purchase: to acquire by the payment of money or its equivalent; buy.
lately: of late; recently; not long since: He has been very grouchy lately.
brought: simple past tense and past participle of bring.
royal: of or relating to a king, queen, or other sovereign: royal power; a royal palace.
judy: the wife of Punch in the puppet show called Punch and Judy.
cohen: Morris Raphael, 1880–1947, U.S. philosopher and educator, born in Russia.
artist: a person who produces works in any of the arts that are primarily subject to aesthetic criteria.
author: a person who writes a novel, poem, essay, etc.; the composer of a literary work, as distinguished from a compiler, translator, editor, or copyist.
educator: a person or thing that educates, especially a teacher, principal, or other person involved in planning or directing education.
join: to bring in contact, connect, or bring or put together: to join hands; to join pages with a staple.
link: one of the rings or separate pieces of which a chain is composed.
fasten: to attach firmly or securely in place; fix securely to something else.
unite: to join, combine, or incorporate so as to form a single whole or unit.
bind: to fasten or secure with a band or bond.
bridge: a structure spanning and providing passage over a river, chasm, road, or the like.
communication: the act or process of communicating; fact of being communicated.
local: pertaining to or characterized by place or position in space; spatial.
network: any netlike combination of filaments, lines, veins, passages, or the like: a network of arteries; a network of sewers under the city.
grammatical: of or relating to grammar: grammatical analysis.
beside: by or at the side of; near: Sit down beside me.
walk: to advance or travel on foot at a moderate speed or pace; proceed by steps; move by advancing the feet alternately so that there is always one foot on the ground in bipedal locomotion and two or more feet on the ground in quadrupedal locomotion.
highway: a main road, especially one between towns or cities: the highway between Los Angeles and Seattle.
border: the part or edge of a surface or area that forms its outer boundary.
shelf: a thin slab of wood, metal, etc., fixed horizontally to a wall or in a frame, for supporting objects.
satisfactory: giving or affording satisfaction; fulfilling all demands or requirements: a satisfactory solution.
business: an occupation, profession, or trade: His business is poultry farming.
furthermore: moreover; besides; in addition: Furthermore, he left orders not to be disturbed.
would: a simple past tense and past participle of will1 .
thin: having relatively little extent from one surface or side to the opposite; not thick: thin ice.
tall: having a relatively great height; of more than average stature: a tall woman; tall grass.
said: simple past tense and past participle of say1 .
pen: any of various instruments for writing or drawing with ink or a similar substance.
pencil: a slender tube of wood, metal, plastic, etc., containing a core or strip of graphite, a solid coloring material, or the like, used for writing or drawing.
meter: the fundamental unit of length in the metric system, equivalent to 39.37 U.S. inches, originally intended to be, and being very nearly, equal to one ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the pole measured on a meridian: defined from 1889 to 1960 as the distance between two lines on a platinum-iridium bar (the “International Prototype Meter”) preserved at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures near Paris; from 1960 to 1983 defined as 1,650,763.73 wavelengths of the orange-red radiation of krypton 86 under specified conditions; and now defined as 1/299,792,458 of the distance light travels in a vacuum in one second. Abbreviation:  m.
nm: New Mexico (approved especially for use with zip code).
mode: a manner of acting or doing; method; way: modern modes of transportation.
situation: manner of being situated; location or position with reference to environment: The situation of the house allowed for a beautiful view.
adult: having attained full size and strength; grown up; mature: an adult person, animal, or plant.
child: a person between birth and full growth; a boy or girl: books for children.
four: a cardinal number, three plus one.
reference: an act or instance of referring.
actually: as an actual or existing fact; really.
reality: the state or quality of being real.
truth: the true or actual state of a matter: He tried to find out the truth.
basis: the bottom or base of anything; the part on which something stands or rests.
exhibit: to offer or expose to view; present for inspection: to exhibit the latest models of cars.
unlike: different, dissimilar, or unequal; not alike: They contributed unlike sums to charity.
range: the extent to which or the limits between which variation is possible: the range of steel prices; a wide range of styles.
background: the ground or parts, as of a scene, situated in the rear (opposed to foreground).
re: the syllable used for the second tone of a diatonic scale.
alternative: a choice limited to one of two or more possibilities, as of things, propositions, or courses of action, the selection of which precludes any other possibility: You have the alternative of riding or walking.
conspicuous: easily seen or noticed; readily visible or observable: a conspicuous error.
excellence: the fact or state of excelling; superiority; eminence: his excellence in mathematics.
noted: well-known; celebrated; famous: a noted scholar.
eminent: high in station, rank, or repute; prominent; distinguished: eminent statesmen.
famous: having a widespread reputation, usually of a favorable nature; renowned; celebrated: a famous writer.
scholar: a learned or erudite person, especially one who has profound knowledge of a particular subject.
active: engaged in action; characterized by energetic work, participation, etc.; busy: an active life.
stock: a supply of goods kept on hand for sale to customers by a merchant, distributor, manufacturer, etc.; inventory.
market: an open place or a covered building where buyers and sellers convene for the sale of goods; a marketplace: a farmers' market.
reach: to get to or get as far as in moving, going, traveling, etc.: The boat reached the shore.
current: passing in time; belonging to the time actually passing: the current month.
increasing: growing larger or greater; enlarging; augmenting.
ruler: a person who rules or governs; sovereign.
small: of limited size; of comparatively restricted dimensions; not big; little: a small box.
country: a state or nation: What European countries have you visited?
voluntary: done, made, brought about, undertaken, etc., of one's own accord or by free choice: a voluntary contribution.
expect: to look forward to; regard as likely to happen; anticipate the occurrence or the coming of: I expect to read it. I expect him later. She expects that they will come.
rewarding: affording satisfaction, valuable experience, or the like; worthwhile.
up: to, toward, or in a more elevated position: to climb up to the top of a ladder.
loss: detriment, disadvantage, or deprivation from failure to keep, have, or get: to bear the loss of a robbery.
damage: injury or harm that reduces value or usefulness: The storm did considerable damage to the crops.
injury: harm or damage that is done or sustained: to escape without injury.
appropriate: suitable or fitting for a particular purpose, person, occasion, etc.: an appropriate example; an appropriate dress.
benefit: something that is advantageous or good; an advantage: He explained the benefits of public ownership of the postal system.
gift: something given voluntarily without payment in return, as to show favor toward someone, honor an occasion, or make a gesture of assistance; present.
confer: to consult together; compare opinions; carry on a discussion or deliberation.
trophy: anything taken in war, hunting, competition, etc., especially when preserved as a memento; spoil, prize, or award.
winner: a person or thing that wins; victor.
anniversary: the yearly recurrence of the date of a past event: the tenth anniversary of their marriage.
birth: an act or instance of being born: the day of his birth.
nourishing: promoting or sustaining life, growth, or strength: a nourishing diet.
drunk: being in a temporary state in which one's physical and mental faculties are impaired by an excess of alcoholic drink; intoxicated: The wine made him drunk.
otherwise: under other circumstances: Otherwise they may get broken.
sustain: to support, hold, or bear up from below; bear the weight of, as a structure.
provide: to make available; furnish: to provide employees with various benefits.
promote: to help or encourage to exist or flourish; further: to promote world peace.
take: to get into one's hold or possession by voluntary action: to take a cigarette out of a box; to take a pen and begin to write.
swallow: to take into the stomach by drawing through the throat and esophagus with a voluntary muscular action, as food, drink, or other substances.
imbibe: to consume (liquids) by drinking; drink: He imbibed great quantities of iced tea.
thought: the product of mental activity; that which one thinks: a body of thought.
decided: in no way uncertain or ambiguous; unquestionable; unmistakable: a decided victory.
care: a state of mind in which one is troubled; worry, anxiety, or concern: He was never free from care.
opinion: a belief or judgment that rests on grounds insufficient to produce complete certainty.
term: a word or group of words designating something, especially in a particular field, as atom in physics, quietism in theology, adze in carpentry, or district leader in politics.
opaque: not transparent or translucent; impenetrable to light; not allowing light to pass through.
mammary: of or relating to the mamma or breast.
serving: the act of a person or thing that serves.
nourishment: something that nourishes; food, nutriment, or sustenance.
their: a form of the possessive case of they used as an attributive adjective, before a noun: their home; their rights as citizens; their departure for Rome.
young: being in the first or early stage of life or growth; youthful; not old: a young woman.
conducive: tending to produce; contributive; helpful; favorable (usually followed by to): Good eating habits are conducive to good health.
moral: of, relating to, or concerned with the principles or rules of right conduct or the distinction between right and wrong; ethical: moral attitudes.
salutary: favorable to or promoting health; healthful.
beneficial: conferring benefit; advantageous; helpful: the beneficial effect of sunshine.
token: something serving to represent or indicate some fact, event, feeling, etc.; sign: Black is a token of mourning.
indication: anything serving to indicate or point out, as a sign or token.
fidelity: strict observance of promises, duties, etc.: a servant's fidelity.
vow: a solemn promise, pledge, or personal commitment: marriage vows; a vow of secrecy.
kiss: to touch or press with the lips slightly pursed, and then often to part them and to emit a smacking sound, in an expression of affection, love, greeting, reverence, etc.: He kissed his son on the cheek.
affection: fond attachment, devotion, or love: the affection of a parent for an only child.
disprove: to prove (an assertion, claim, etc.) to be false or wrong; refute; invalidate: I disproved his claim.
ground: the solid surface of the earth; firm or dry land: to fall to the ground.
belief: something believed; an opinion or conviction: a belief that the earth is flat.
proof: evidence sufficient to establish a thing as true, or to produce belief in its truth.
allow: to give permission to or for; permit: to allow a student to be absent; No swimming allowed.
display: to show or exhibit; make visible: to display a sign.
delay: to put off to a later time; defer; postpone: The pilot delayed the flight until the weather cleared.
due: owed at present; having reached the date for payment: This bill is due.
uncertainty: the state of being uncertain; doubt; hesitancy: His uncertainty gave impetus to his inquiry.
fear: a distressing emotion aroused by impending danger, evil, pain, etc., whether the threat is real or imagined; the feeling or condition of being afraid. Synonyms: foreboding, apprehension, consternation, dismay, dread, terror, fright, panic, horror, trepidation, qualm.
cost: the price paid to acquire, produce, accomplish, or maintain anything: the high cost of a good meal.
championship: the distinction or condition of being a champion: to win a championship.
uncertain: not definitely ascertainable or fixed, as in time of occurrence, number, dimensions, or quality.
consider: to think carefully about, especially in order to make a decision; contemplate; reflect on: He considered the cost before buying the new car.
questionable: of doubtful propriety, honesty, morality, respectability, etc.: questionable activities; in questionable taste.
unlikely: not likely to be or occur; improbable; marked by doubt.
hesitate: to be reluctant or wait to act because of fear, indecision, or disinclination: She hesitated to take the job.
believe: to have confidence in the truth, the existence, or the reliability of something, although without absolute proof that one is right in doing so: Only if one believes in something can one act purposefully.
concerning: relating to; regarding; about: a discussion concerning foreign aid.
regard: to look upon or think of with a particular feeling: to regard a person with favor.
civil: of, relating to, or consisting of citizens: civil life; civil society.
war: a conflict carried on by force of arms, as between nations or between parties within a nation; warfare, as by land, sea, or air.
undertaking: the act of a person who undertakes any task or responsibility.
risky: attended with or involving risk; hazardous: a risky undertaking.
dangerous: full of danger or risk; causing danger; perilous; risky; hazardous; unsafe.
deed: something that is done, performed, or accomplished; an act: Do a good deed every day.
performance: a musical, dramatic, or other entertainment presented before an audience.
heroic: Also, heroical. of, relating to, or characteristic of a hero or heroine.
occurrence: the action, fact, or instance of occurring.
fresh: newly made or obtained: fresh footprints.
oppression: the exercise of authority or power in a burdensome, cruel, or unjust manner.
mention: to refer briefly to; name, specify, or speak of: Don't forget to mention her contribution to the project.
definitely: in a clear and definite manner; unambiguously.
start: to begin or set out, as on a journey or activity.
self: a person or thing referred to with respect to complete individuality: one's own self.
rolling: the action, motion, or sound of anything that rolls.
left: of, relating to, or located on or near the side of a person or thing that is turned toward the west when the subject is facing north (opposed to right).
facing: a covering in front, for ornament, protection, etc., as an outer layer of stone on a brick wall.
corresponding: identical in all essentials or respects: corresponding fingerprints.
where: in or at what place?: Where is he? Where do you live?
set: to put (something or someone) in a particular place: to set a vase on a table.
deprive: to remove or withhold something from the enjoyment or possession of (a person or persons): to deprive a man of life; to deprive a baby of candy.
internal: situated or existing in the interior of something; interior.
farther: at or to a greater distance: He went farther down the road.
circle: a closed plane curve consisting of all points at a given distance from a point within it called the center. Equation: x 2 + y 2 = r 2 .
envelope: a flat paper container, as for a letter or thin package, usually having a gummed flap or other means of closure.
crow: any of several large oscine birds of the genus Corvus, of the family Corvidae, having a long, stout bill, lustrous black plumage, and a wedge-shaped tail, as the common C. brachyrhynchos, of North America.
nest: a pocketlike, usually more or less circular structure of twigs, grass, mud, etc., formed by a bird, often high in a tree, as a place in which to lay and incubate its eggs and rear its young; any protected place used by a bird for these purposes.
velocity: rapidity of motion or operation; swiftness; speed: a high wind velocity.
foot: (in vertebrates) the terminal part of the leg, below the ankle joint, on which the body stands and moves.
yard: a common unit of linear measure in English-speaking countries, equal to 3 feet or 36 inches, and equivalent to 0.9144 meter.
kilometer: a unit of length, the common measure of distances equal to 1000 meters, and equivalent to 3280.8 feet or 0.621 mile. Abbreviation:  km.
permanent: existing perpetually; everlasting, especially without significant change.
construction: the act or art of constructing.
plot: a secret plan or scheme to accomplish some purpose, especially a hostile, unlawful, or evil purpose: a plot to overthrow the government.
roof: the external upper covering of a house or other building.
windows: any of several personal computer operating systems or environments featuring a graphical user interface.
level: having no part higher than another; having a flat or even surface.
entertaining: affording entertainment; amusing; diverting: We spent an entertaining evening at the theater.
affecting: moving or exciting the feelings or emotions.
population: the total number of persons inhabiting a country, city, or any district or area.
community: a social group of any size whose members reside in a specific locality, share government, and often have a common cultural and historical heritage.
nuisance: an obnoxious or annoying person, thing, condition, practice, etc.: a monthly meeting that was more nuisance than pleasure.
jesus: Also called Jesus Christ, Christ Jesus, Jesus of Nazareth. born 4? b.c., crucified a.d. 29? the source of the Christian religion.
christ: Jesus of Nazareth, held by Christians to be the fulfillment of prophecies in the Old Testament regarding the eventual coming of a Messiah.
faith: confidence or trust in a person or thing: faith in another's ability.
reverent: feeling, exhibiting, or characterized by reverence; deeply respectful: a reverent greeting.
homage: respect or reverence paid or rendered: In his speech he paid homage to Washington and Jefferson.
paid: a simple past tense and past participle of pay1 .
god: the one Supreme Being, the creator and ruler of the universe.
sacred: devoted or dedicated to a deity or to some religious purpose; consecrated.
personage: a person of distinction or importance.
prime: of the first importance; demanding the fullest consideration: a prime requisite.
needle: a small, slender, rodlike instrument, usually of polished steel, with a sharp point at one end and an eye or hole for thread at the other, for passing thread through cloth to make stitches in sewing.
magnetic: of or relating to a magnet or magnetism.
telling: having force or effect; effective; striking: a telling blow.
false: not true or correct; erroneous: a false statement.
boyhood: the state or period of being a boy: Boyhood is a happy time of life.
never: not ever; at no time: Such an idea never occurred to me.
straight: without a bend, angle, or curve; not curved; direct: a straight path.
path: a way beaten, formed, or trodden by the feet of persons or animals.
face: the front part of the head, from the forehead to the chin.
else: other than the persons or things mentioned or implied: What else could I have done?
relation: an existing connection; a significant association between or among things: the relation between cause and effect.
rising: advancing, ascending, or mounting: rising smoke.
contracted: drawn together; reduced in compass or size; made smaller; shrunken.
doctor: a person licensed to practice medicine, as a physician, surgeon, dentist, or veterinarian.
united: made into or caused to act as a single entity: a united front.
pound: to strike repeatedly with great force, as with an instrument, the fist, heavy missiles, etc.
mi: the syllable used for the third tone of a diatonic scale.
lincoln: Abbey (Anna Marie Gaby Wooldridge; Aminata Moseka) born 1930, U.S. jazz singer, activist, and actress.
stream: a body of water flowing in a channel or watercourse, as a river, rivulet, or brook. Synonyms: rill, run, streamlet, runnel.
fairly: in a fair manner; justly or honestly; impartially.
channel: the bed of a stream, river, or other waterway.
actual: existing in act or fact; real: an actual case of heroism; actual expenses.
world: the earth or globe, considered as a planet.
organism: a form of life composed of mutually interdependent parts that maintain various vital processes.
alive: having life; living; existing; not dead or lifeless.
vital: of or relating to life: vital processes.
william: a word formerly used in communications to represent the letter W.
bard: (formerly) a person who composed and recited epic or heroic poems, often while playing the harp, lyre, or the like.
avon: a river in central England, flowing SE past Stratford-on-Avon to the Severn. 96 miles (155 km) long.
dramatist: a writer of dramas or dramatic poetry; playwright.
ending: a bringing or coming to an end; termination; close: Putting away the Christmas ornaments marked the ending of the season.
journey: a traveling from one place to another, usually taking a rather long time; trip: a six-day journey across the desert.
style: a particular kind, sort, or type, as with reference to form, appearance, or character: the baroque style; The style of the house was too austere for their liking.
sentence: Grammar. a grammatical unit of one or more words that expresses an independent statement, question, request, command, exclamation, etc., and that typically has a subject as well as a predicate, as in John is here. or Is John here? In print or writing, a sentence typically begins with a capital letter and ends with appropriate punctuation; in speech it displays recognizable, communicative intonation patterns and is often marked by preceding and following pauses.
interrogative: of, relating to, or conveying a question.
information: knowledge communicated or received concerning a particular fact or circumstance; news: information concerning a crime.
reply: to make answer in words or writing; answer; respond: to reply to a question.
unlawful: not lawful; contrary to law; illegal.
threat: a declaration of an intention or determination to inflict punishment, injury, etc., in retaliation for, or conditionally upon, some action or course; menace: He confessed under the threat of imprisonment.
violence: swift and intense force: the violence of a storm.
steal: to take (the property of another or others) without permission or right, especially secretly or by force: A pickpocket stole his watch.
middle: equally distant from the extremes or outer limits; central: the middle point of a line; the middle singer in a trio.
equivalent: equal in value, measure, force, effect, significance, etc.: His silence is equivalent to an admission of guilt.
include: to contain, as a whole does parts or any part or element: The package includes the computer, program, disks, and a manual.
coin: a piece of metal stamped and issued by the authority of a government for use as money.
wood: the hard, fibrous substance composing most of the stem and branches of a tree or shrub, and lying beneath the bark; the xylem.
pulp: the soft, juicy, edible part of a fruit.
straw: a single stalk or stem, especially of certain species of grain, chiefly wheat, rye, oats, and barley.
fibrous: containing, consisting of, or resembling fibers.
bear: to hold up; support: to bear the weight of the roof.
writing: the act of a person or thing that writes.
printing: the art, process, or business of producing books, newspapers, etc., by impression from movable types, plates, etc.
wrapping: Often, wrappings. the covering in which something is wrapped.
ask: to put a question to; inquire of: I asked him but he didn't answer.
proper: adapted or appropriate to the purpose or circumstances; fit; suitable: the proper time to plant strawberries.
claim: to demand by or as by virtue of a right; demand as a right or as due: to claim an estate by inheritance.
payment: something that is paid; an amount paid; compensation; recompense.
debt: something that is owed or that one is bound to pay to or perform for another: a debt of $50.
deposit: to place for safekeeping or in trust, especially in a bank account: He deposited his paycheck every Friday.
share: the full or proper portion or part allotted or belonging to or contributed or owed by an individual or group.
possession: the act or fact of possessing.
owner: a person who owns; possessor; proprietor.
sort: a particular kind, species, variety, class, or group, distinguished by a common character or nature: to develop a new sort of painting; nice people, of course, but not really our sort.
daily: of, done, occurring, or issued each day or each weekday: daily attendance; a daily newspaper.
humankind: human beings collectively; the human race.
comprise: to include or contain: The Soviet Union comprised several socialist republics.
silicon: a nonmetallic element, having amorphous and crystalline forms, occurring in a combined state in minerals and rocks and constituting more than one fourth of the earth's crust: used in steelmaking, alloys, etc. Symbol:  Si; atomic weight:  28.086; atomic number:  14; specific gravity:  2.4 at 20°C.
dioxide: an oxide containing two atoms of oxygen, each of which is bonded directly to an atom of a second element, as manganese dioxide, MnO 2 , or nitrogen dioxide, NO 2 .
luster: the state or quality of shining by reflecting light; glitter, sparkle, sheen, or gloss: the luster of satin.
either: one or the other of two: You may sit at either end of the table.
agate: a variegated chalcedony showing curved, colored bands or other markings.
bloodstone: a greenish variety of chalcedony with small bloodlike spots of red jasper scattered through it.
chalcedony: a microcrystalline, translucent variety of quartz, often milky or grayish.
jasper: a compact, opaque, cryptocrystalline variety of quartz, usually colored red: often used in decorative carvings.
amethyst: a purple or violet quartz, used as a gem.
sand: the more or less fine debris of rocks, consisting of small, loose grains, often of quartz.
sandstone: a common sedimentary rock consisting of sand, usually quartz, cemented together by various substances, as silica, calcium carbonate, iron oxide, or clay.
control: to exercise restraint or direction over; dominate; command: The car is difficult to control at high speeds. That zone is controlled by enemy troops.
radio: wireless telegraphy or telephony: speeches broadcast by radio.
potassium: a silvery-white metallic element that oxidizes rapidly in the air and whose compounds are used as fertilizer and in special hard glasses. Symbol:  K; atomic weight:  39.102; atomic number:  19; specific gravity:  0.86 at 20°C.
sodium: Chemistry. a soft, silver-white, metallic element that oxidizes rapidly in moist air, occurring in nature only in the combined state, and used in the synthesis of sodium peroxide, sodium cyanide, and tetraethyllead: a necessary element in the body for the maintenance of normal fluid balance and other physiological functions. Symbol:  Na; atomic weight:  22.9898; atomic number:  11; specific gravity:  0.97 at 20°C.
calcium: a silver-white divalent metal, occurring combined in limestone, chalk, gypsum, etc., occurring also in vertebrates and other animals, as a component of bone, skeletal mass, shell, etc., and as a necessary element in nerve conduction, heartbeat, muscle contraction, and many other physiological functions. Symbol:  Ca; atomic weight:  40.08; atomic number:  20; specific gravity:  1.55 at 20°C.
vague: not clearly or explicitly stated or expressed: vague promises.
precise: definitely or strictly stated, defined, or fixed: precise directions.
exact: strictly accurate or correct: an exact likeness; an exact description.
glass: a hard, brittle, noncrystalline, more or less transparent substance produced by fusion, usually consisting of mutually dissolved silica and silicates that also contain soda and lime, as in the ordinary variety used for windows and bottles.
arrangement: an act of arranging; state of being arranged.
pyramidal: of, relating to, or shaped like a pyramid: the pyramidal form.
free: enjoying personal rights or liberty, as a person who is not in slavery: a land of free people.
reservation: the act of keeping back, withholding, or setting apart.
confident: having strong belief or full assurance; sure: confident of fulfillment.
artificial: made by human skill; produced by humans (opposed to natural): artificial flowers.
product: a thing produced by labor: products of farm and factory; the product of his thought.
formerly: in time past; in an earlier period or age; previously: a custom formerly observed.
carbon: Chemistry. a widely distributed element that forms organic compounds in combination with hydrogen, oxygen, etc., and that occurs in a pure state as diamond and graphite, and in an impure state as charcoal. Symbol:  C; atomic weight:  12.011; atomic number:  6; specific gravity:  (of diamond) 3.51 at 20°C; (of graphite) 2.26 at 20°C.
source: any thing or place from which something comes, arises, or is obtained; origin: Which foods are sources of calcium?
fountainhead: a fountain or spring from which a stream flows; the head or source of a stream.
follow: to come after in sequence, order of time, etc.: The speech follows the dinner.
dark: having very little or no light: a dark room.
bituminous: resembling or containing bitumen: bituminous shale.
native: being the place or environment in which a person was born or a thing came into being: one's native land.
mainly: chiefly; principally; for the most part; in the main; to the greatest extent: Our success was due mainly to your efforts. The audience consisted mainly of students.
hydrocarbon: any of a class of compounds containing only hydrogen and carbon, as an alkane, methane, CH 4 , an alkene, ethylene, C 2 H 4 , an alkyne, acetylene, C 2 H 2 , or an aromatic compound, benzene, C 6 H 6 .
anthracite: a mineral coal containing little of the volatile hydrocarbons and burning almost without flame; hard coal.
lignite: a soft coal, usually dark brown, often having a distinct woodlike texture, and intermediate in density and carbon content between peat and bituminous coal.
ag: agriculture: ag courses; to major in ag.
metal: any of a class of elementary substances, as gold, silver, or copper, all of which are crystalline when solid and many of which are characterized by opacity, ductility, conductivity, and a unique luster when freshly fractured.
resolved: firm in purpose or intent; determined.
analysis: the separating of any material or abstract entity into its constituent elements (opposed to synthesis).
mortar: a receptacle of hard material, having a bowl-shaped cavity in which substances are reduced to powder with a pestle.
every: being one of a group or series taken collectively; each: We go there every day.
masonry: the craft or occupation of a mason.
wall: any of various permanent upright constructions having a length much greater than the thickness and presenting a continuous surface except where pierced by doors, windows, etc.: used for shelter, protection, or privacy, or to subdivide interior space, to support floors, roofs, or the like, to retain earth, to fence in an area, etc.
hammered: shaped, formed, or ornamented by a metalworker's hammer: a hammered bowl of brass; hammered gold.
shaped: of a definite form, shape, or character (often used in combination): a U -shaped driveway.
pressure: the exertion of force upon a surface by an object, fluid, etc., in contact with it: the pressure of earth against a wall.
corrode: to eat or wear away gradually as if by gnawing, especially by chemical action.
tarnish: to dull the luster of (a metallic surface), especially by oxidation; discolor.
geology: the science that deals with the dynamics and physical history of the earth, the rocks of which it is composed, and the physical, chemical, and biological changes that the earth has undergone or is undergoing.
intense: existing or occurring in a high or extreme degree: intense heat.
volcanic: of or relating to a volcano: a volcanic eruption.
magma: Geology. molten material beneath or within the earth's crust, from which igneous rock is formed.
cliff: a high steep face of a rock.
promontory: a high point of land or rock projecting into the sea or other water beyond the line of coast; a headland.
fissile: capable of being split or divided; cleavable.
laminated: formed of or set in thin layers or laminae.
consolidation: an act or instance of consolidating; the state of being consolidated; unification: consolidation of companies.
argillaceous: Geology, Petrology. of the nature of or resembling clay; clayey.
earthy: of the nature of or consisting of earth or soil.
plastic: Often, plastics. any of a group of synthetic or natural organic materials that may be shaped when soft and then hardened, including many types of resins, resinoids, polymers, cellulose derivatives, casein materials, and proteins: used in place of other materials, as glass, wood, and metals, in construction and decoration, for making many articles, as coatings, and, drawn into filaments, for weaving. They are often known by trademark names, as Bakelite, Vinylite, or Lucite.
wet: moistened, covered, or soaked with water or some other liquid: wet hands.
hydrated: chemically combined with water in its molecular form.
pottery: ceramic ware, especially earthenware and stoneware.
win: to finish first in a race, contest, or the like.
humus: the dark organic material in soils, produced by the decomposition of vegetable or animal matter and essential to the fertility of the earth.
alloy: a substance composed of two or more metals, or of a metal or metals with a nonmetal, intimately mixed, as by fusion or electrodeposition.
utensil: any of the instruments or vessels commonly used in a kitchen, dairy, etc.: eating utensils; baking utensils.
casting: the act or process of a person or thing that casts.
aircraft: any machine supported for flight in the air by buoyancy or by the dynamic action of air on its surfaces, especially powered airplanes, gliders, and helicopters.
kept: simple past tense and past participle of keep.
aloft: high up; far above the ground.
upward: toward a higher place or position: The birds flew upward.
thrust: to push forcibly; shove; put or drive with force: He thrust his way through the crowd. She thrust a dagger into his back.
passing: going by or past; elapsing: He was feeling better with each passing day.
wings: Also called aviation badge. Military Informal. a badge bearing the image of a spread pair of bird's wings with a distinctive center design, awarded to an aircrewman on completion of certain requirements.
jet: a stream of a liquid, gas, or small solid particles forcefully shooting forth from a nozzle, orifice, etc.
propulsion: the act or process of propelling.
emblem: an object or its representation, symbolizing a quality, state, class of persons, etc.; symbol: The olive branch is an emblem of peace.
explosion: an act or instance of exploding; a violent expansion or bursting with noise, as of gunpowder or a boiler (opposed to implosion).
numeral: a word, letter, symbol, or figure, etc., expressing a number; number: the Roman numerals.
application: the act of putting to a special use or purpose: the application of common sense to a problem.
bearing: the manner in which one conducts or carries oneself, including posture and gestures: a man of dignified bearing.
explicit: fully and clearly expressed or demonstrated; leaving nothing merely implied; unequivocal: explicit instructions; an explicit act of violence; explicit language.
attraction: the act, power, or property of attracting.
terrestrial: pertaining to, consisting of, or representing the earth as distinct from other planets.
tend: to be disposed or inclined in action, operation, or effect to do something: The particles tend to unite.
fall: to drop or descend under the force of gravity, as to a lower place through loss or lack of support.
potash: potassium carbonate, especially the crude impure form obtained from wood ashes.
crystalline: of or like crystal; clear; transparent.
sulfate: Chemistry. a salt or ester of sulfuric acid.
medicine: any substance or substances used in treating disease or illness; medicament; remedy.
styptic: serving to contract organic tissue; astringent; binding.
dyeing: process of coloring fibers, yarns, or fabrics.
tanning: the process or art of converting hides or skins into leather.
technical: belonging or pertaining to an art, science, or the like: technical skill.
soap: a substance used for washing and cleansing purposes, usually made by treating a fat with an alkali, as sodium or potassium hydroxide, and consisting chiefly of the sodium or potassium salts of the acids contained in the fat.
colorless: without color: Pure water is colorless.
gaseous: existing in the state of a gas; not solid or liquid.
atmosphere: the gaseous envelope surrounding the earth; the air.
supporter: a person or thing that supports.
combustion: the act or process of burning.
standard: something considered by an authority or by general consent as a basis of comparison; an approved model.
molecular: of or relating to or caused by molecules: molecular structure.
until: up to the time that or when; till: He read until his guests arrived.
density: the state or quality of being dense; compactness; closely set or crowded condition.
positive: explicitly stated, stipulated, or expressed: a positive acceptance of the agreement.
migrate: to go from one country, region, or place to another. Synonyms: move, resettle, relocate.
negative: expressing or containing negation or denial: a negative response to the question.
pole: a long, cylindrical, often slender piece of wood, metal, etc.: a telephone pole; a fishing pole.
electrolysis: Physical Chemistry. the passage of an electric current through an electrolyte with subsequent migration of positively and negatively charged ions to the negative and positive electrodes.
atom: an atom with one of the electrons replaced by some other particle: muonic atom; kaonic atom.
american: of or relating to the United States of America or its inhabitants: an American citizen.
aboriginal: of, relating to, or typical of aborigines: aboriginal customs.
edible: fit to be eaten as food; eatable; esculent.
fruit: any product of plant growth useful to humans or animals.
tree: a plant having a permanently woody main stem or trunk, ordinarily growing to a considerable height, and usually developing branches at some distance from the ground.
genus: Biology. the usual major subdivision of a family or subfamily in the classification of organisms, usually consisting of more than one species.
morus: genus of mulberry trees, from Latin morus "mulberry tree."
merit: claim to respect and praise; excellence; worth.
successor: a person or thing that succeeds or follows.
brief: lasting or taking a short time; of short duration: a brief walk; a brief stay in the country.
record: to set down in writing or the like, as for the purpose of preserving evidence.
assist: to give support or aid to; help: Please assist him in moving the furniture.
memory: the mental capacity or faculty of retaining and reviving facts, events, impressions, etc., or of recalling or recognizing previous experiences.
future: time that is to be or come hereafter.
announcement: public or formal notice announcing something: The announcement appeared in the newspapers.
intimation: the act of intimating, or making known indirectly.
impending: about to happen; imminent: their impending marriage.
warning: the act or utterance of one who warns or the existence, appearance, sound, etc., of a thing that warns.
attention: the act or faculty of attending, especially by directing the mind to an object.
remarkable: notably or conspicuously unusual; extraordinary: a remarkable change.
rare: coming or occurring far apart in time; unusual; uncommon: a rare disease; His visits are rare occasions.
favorable: characterized by approval or support; positive: a favorable report.
prosperous: having or characterized by financial success or good fortune; flourishing; successful: a prosperous business.
accomplishment: an act or instance of carrying into effect; fulfillment: the accomplishment of our desires.
instant: an infinitesimal or very short space of time; a moment: They arrived not an instant too soon.
bodily: of or relating to the body.
mental: of or relating to the mind: mental powers; mental suffering.
exertion: vigorous action or effort: physical and mental exertion.
sake: cause, account, interest, or benefit: for the sake of all students.
training: the education, instruction, or discipline of a person or thing that is being trained: He's in training for the Olympics.
improvement: an act of improving or the state of being improved.
independence: Also, independency. the state or quality of being independent.
influence: the capacity or power of persons or things to be a compelling force on or produce effects on the actions, behavior, opinions, etc., of others: He used family influence to get the contract.
spouse: either member of a married pair in relation to the other; one's husband or wife.
grammar: the study of the way the sentences of a language are constructed; morphology and syntax.
modify: to change somewhat the form or qualities of; alter partially; amend: to modify a contract.
primarily: essentially; mostly; chiefly; principally: They live primarily from farming.
wise: having the power of discerning and judging properly as to what is true or right; possessing discernment, judgment, or discretion.
grandmother: the mother of one's father or mother.
perfect: conforming absolutely to the description or definition of an ideal type: a perfect sphere; a perfect gentleman.
score: the record of points or strokes made by the competitors in a game or match.
handsome: having an attractive, well-proportioned, and imposing appearance suggestive of health and strength; good-looking: a handsome man; a handsome woman.
extremely: in an extreme degree; exceedingly: extremely cold.
numbers: the fourth book of the Old Testament, containing the census of the Israelites after the Exodus from Egypt. Abbreviation:  Num.
cup: a small, open container made of china, glass, metal, etc., usually having a handle and used chiefly as a receptable from which to drink tea, soup, etc.
demonstrative: characterized by or given to open exhibition or expression of one's emotions, attitudes, etc., especially of love or affection: She wished her fiancé were more demonstrative.
impose: to lay on or set as something to be borne, endured, obeyed, fulfilled, paid, etc.: to impose taxes.
mercy: compassionate or kindly forbearance shown toward an offender, an enemy, or other person in one's power; compassion, pity, or benevolence: Have mercy on the poor sinner.
function: the kind of action or activity proper to a person, thing, or institution; the purpose for which something is designed or exists; role.
found: simple past tense and past participle of find.
chiefly: primarily; essentially: He phoned chiefly to let us know he was feeling better.
immediately: without lapse of time; without delay; instantly; at once: Please telephone him immediately.
precede: to go before, as in place, order, rank, importance, or time.
bottle: a portable container for holding liquids, characteristically having a neck and mouth and made of glass or plastic.
cap: a close-fitting covering for the head, usually of soft supple material and having no visor or brim.
modifier: a person or thing that modifies.
qualifier: a person or thing that qualifies.
front: the foremost part or surface of anything.
feeling: the function or the power of perceiving by touch.
regret: to feel sorrow or remorse for (an act, fault, disappointment, etc.): He no sooner spoke than he regretted it.
compunction: a feeling of uneasiness or anxiety of the conscience caused by regret for doing wrong or causing pain; contrition; remorse.
sympathy: harmony of or agreement in feeling, as between persons or on the part of one person with respect to another.
pity: sympathetic or kindly sorrow evoked by the suffering, distress, or misfortune of another, often leading one to give relief or aid or to show mercy: to feel pity for astarving child.
leave: to go out of or away from, as a place: to leave the house.
trouble: to disturb the mental calm and contentment of; worry; distress; agitate.
implied: involved, indicated, or suggested without being directly or explicitly stated; tacitly understood: an implied rebuke; an implied compliment.
firm: not soft or yielding when pressed; comparatively solid, hard, stiff, or rigid: firm ground; firm texture.
touch: to put the hand, finger, etc., on or into contact with (something) to feel it: He touched the iron cautiously.
unyielding: unable to bend or be penetrated under pressure; hard: trees so unyielding that they broke in the harsh north winds.
impenetrable: not penetrable; that cannot be penetrated, pierced, entered, etc.
almost: very nearly; all but: almost every house; almost the entire symphony; to pay almost nothing for a car; almost twice as many books.
freezing: (of temperatures) approaching, at, or below the freezing point.
transmit: to send or forward, as to a recipient or destination; dispatch; convey.
pass: to move past; go by: to pass another car on the road.
stopping: a barrier erected to prevent the flow of air or gas.
find: to come upon by chance; meet with: He found a nickel in the street.
look: to turn one's eyes toward something or in some direction in order to see: He looked toward the western horizon and saw the returning planes.
speak: to utter words or articulate sounds with the ordinary voice; talk: He was too ill to speak.
sky: the region of the clouds or the upper air; the upper atmosphere of the earth: airplanes in the sky; cloudy skies.
green: of the color of growing foliage, between yellow and blue in the spectrum: green leaves.
pointing: (in masonry) mortar used as a finishing touch to brickwork.
expressive: full of expression; meaningful: an expressive shrug.
disorder: lack of order or regular arrangement; confusion: Your room is in utter disorder.
dakota: a former territory in the United States: divided into the states of North Dakota and South Dakota in 1889.
zip: a sudden, brief hissing sound, as of a bullet.
code: a system for communication by telegraph, heliograph, etc., in which long and short sounds, light flashes, etc., are used to symbolize the content of a message: Morse code.
extraordinary: beyond what is usual, ordinary, regular, or established: extraordinary costs.
exceptional: forming an exception or rare instance; unusual; extraordinary: The warm weather was exceptional for January.
agile: quick and well-coordinated in movement; lithe: an agile leap.
antelope: any of several ruminants of the family Bovidae, chiefly of Africa and Asia, having permanent, hollow, unbranched horns.
europe: a continent in the W part of the landmass lying between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, separated from Asia by the Ural Mountains on the E and the Caucasus Mountains and the Black and Caspian seas on the SE. In British usage, Europe sometimes contrasts with England. About 4,017,000 sq. mi. (10,404,000 sq. km).
summer: the season between spring and autumn, in the Northern Hemisphere from the summer solstice to the autumnal equinox, and in the Southern Hemisphere from the winter solstice to the vernal equinox.
supplementary: Also, supplemental. of the nature of or forming a supplement; additional.
tired: exhausted, as by exertion; fatigued or sleepy: a tired runner.
emery: a granular mineral substance consisting typically of corundum mixed with magnetite or hematite, used powdered, crushed, or consolidated for grinding and polishing.
pumice: Also called pumice stone. a porous or spongy form of volcanic glass, used as an abrasive.
sandpaper: strong paper coated with a layer of sand or other abrasive, used for smoothing or polishing.
numerous: very many; being or existing in great quantity: numerous visits; numerous fish.
eight: a cardinal number, seven plus one.
visit: to go to and stay with (a person or family) or at (a place) for a short time for reasons of sociability, politeness, business, curiosity, etc.: to visit a friend; to visit clients; to visit Paris.
easy: not hard or difficult; requiring no great labor or effort: a book that is easy to read; an easy victory.
understand: to perceive the meaning of; grasp the idea of; comprehend: to understand Spanish; I didn't understand your question.
deal: to occupy oneself or itself (usually followed by with or in): Botany deals with the study of plants. He deals in generalities.
bad: not good in any manner or degree.
tight: firmly or closely fixed in place; not easily moved; secure: a tight knot.
fiber: a fine, threadlike piece, as of cotton, jute, or asbestos.
rigid: stiff or unyielding; not pliant or flexible; hard: a rigid strip of metal.
complement: something that completes or makes perfect: A good wine is a complement to a good meal.
verb: any member of a class of words that function as the main elements of predicates, that typically express action, state, or a relation between two things, and that may be inflected for tense, aspect, voice, mood, and to show agreement with their subject or object.
participation: an act or instance of participating.
verbal: of or relating to words: verbal ability.
subject: that which forms a basic matter of thought, discussion, investigation, etc.: a subject of conversation.
candle: a long, usually slender piece of tallow or wax with an embedded wick that is burned to give light.
devoted: zealous or ardent in attachment, loyalty, or affection: a devoted friend.
friend: a person attached to another by feelings of affection or personal regard.
dress: an outer garment for women and girls, consisting of bodice and skirt in one piece.
proceeding: a particular action or course or manner of action.
synthesis: the combining of the constituent elements of separate material or abstract entities into a single or unified entity (opposed to analysis, ) the separating of any material or abstract entity into its constituent elements.
analytic: pertaining to or proceeding by analysis (opposed to synthetic).
prior: preceding in time or in order; earlier or former; previous: A prior agreement prevents me from accepting this.
oneself: a person's self (used for emphasis or reflexively): One often hurts oneself accidentally.
emphasize: to give emphasis to; lay stress upon; stress: to emphasize a point; to emphasize the eyes with mascara.
ownership: the state or fact of being an owner.
spent: simple past tense and past participle of spend.
know: to perceive or understand as fact or truth; to apprehend clearly and with certainty: I know the situation fully.
skillful: having or exercising skill: a skillful juggler.
field: an expanse of open or cleared ground, especially a piece of land suitable or used for pasture or tillage.
experience: a particular instance of personally encountering or undergoing something: My encounter with the bear in the woods was a frightening experience.
teacher: a person who teaches or instructs, especially as a profession; instructor.
obtain: to come into possession of; get, acquire, or procure, as through an effort or by a request: to obtain permission; to obtain a better income.
team: a number of persons forming one of the sides in a game or contest: a football team.
ahead: in or to the front; in advance of; before: Walk ahead of us.
acquaintance: a person known to one, but usually not a close friend.
study: application of the mind to the acquisition of knowledge, as by reading, investigation, or reflection: long hours of study.
investigation: the act or process of investigating or the condition of being investigated.
erudition: knowledge acquired by study, research, etc.; learning; scholarship.
hybrid: the offspring of two animals or plants of different breeds, varieties, species, or genera, especially as produced through human manipulation for specific genetic characteristics.
except: with the exclusion of; excluding; save; but: They were all there except me.
license: formal permission from a governmental or other constituted authority to do something, as to carry on some business or profession.
request: the act of asking for something to be given or done, especially as a favor or courtesy; solicitation or petition: At his request, they left.
guided: accompanied by a guide: a guided tour.
justice: the quality of being just; righteousness, equitableness, or moral rightness: to uphold the justice of a cause.
hope: the feeling that what is wanted can be had or that events will turn out for the best: to give up hope.
