understanding: mental process of a person who comprehends; comprehension; personal interpretation: My understanding of the word does not agree with yours.
difficult: not easily or readily done; requiring much labor, skill, or planning to be performed successfully; hard: a difficult job.
stage: a single step or degree in a process; a particular phase, period, position, etc., in a process, development, or series.
systematic: having, showing, or involving a system, method, or plan: a systematic course of reading; systematic efforts.
directed: guided, regulated, or managed: a carefully directed program.
devise: to contrive, plan, or elaborate; invent from existing principles or ideas: to devise a method.
route: a course, way, or road for passage or travel: What's the shortest route to Boston?
machine: an apparatus consisting of interrelated parts with separate functions, used in the performance of some kind of work: a sewing machine.
mathematical: of, relating to, or of the nature of mathematics: mathematical truth.
expenditure: the act of expending something, especially funds; disbursement; consumption.
conjunction: Libra Blame it on a Moon-Saturn conjunction opposing a pack of planets this week, when issues with collaborators come to a head.
extend: to stretch out; draw out to the full length: He extended the measuring tape as far as it would go.
painting: a picture or design executed in paints.
dusty: filled, covered, or clouded with or as with dust.
view: an instance of seeing or beholding; visual inspection.
outlook: the view or prospect from a particular place.
operation: an act or instance, process, or manner of functioning or operating.
accordance: agreement; conformity: in accordance with the rules.
conduct: personal behavior; way of acting; bearing or deportment.
likeness: a representation, picture, or image, especially a portrait: to draw a good likeness of Churchill.
resemblance: the state or fact of resembling; similarity.
doing: action; performance; execution: Your misfortune is not of my doing.
behave: to act in a particular way; conduct or comport oneself or itself: The ship behaves well.
wealth: a great quantity or store of money, valuable possessions, property, or other riches: the wealth of a city.
wealthy: having great wealth; rich; affluent: a wealthy person; a wealthy nation.
little: small in size; not big; not large; tiny: a little desk in the corner of the room.
support: to bear or hold up (a load, mass, structure, part, etc.); serve as a foundation for.
family: a basic social unit consisting of parents and their children, considered as a group, whether dwelling together or not: the traditional family.
official: a person appointed or elected to an office or charged with certain duties.
seat: something designed to support a person in a sitting position, as a chair, bench, or pew; a place on or in which one sits.
tokyo: a seaport in and the capital of Japan, on Tokyo Bay: one of the world's largest cities; destructive earthquake and fire 1923; signing of the Japanese surrender document aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, September 2, 1945.
japan: any of various hard, durable, black varnishes, originally from Japan, for coating wood, metal, or other surfaces.
mail: letters, packages, etc., that are sent or delivered by means of the postal system: Storms delayed delivery of the mail.
motivation: the act or an instance of motivating, or providing with a reason to act in a certain way: I don't understand what her motivation was for quitting her job.
respectful: full of, characterized by, or showing politeness or deference: a respectful reply.
formal: being in accordance with the usual requirements, customs, etc.; conventional: to pay one's formal respects.
address: a speech or written statement, usually formal, directed to a particular group of persons: the president's address on the state of the economy.
spain: a kingdom in SW Europe. Including the Balearic and Canary islands, 194,988 sq. mi. (505,019 sq. km). Capital:  Madrid.
language: a body of words and the systems for their use common to a people who are of the same community or nation, the same geographical area, or the same cultural tradition: the two languages of Belgium; a Bantu language; the French language; the Yiddish language.
distinguishing: distinctive; characteristic, as a definitive feature of an individual or group: Intricate rhyming is a distinguishing feature of her poetry.
poem: a composition in verse, especially one that is characterized by a highly developed artistic form and by the use of heightened language and rhythm to express an intensely imaginative interpretation of the subject.
picture: a visual representation of a person, object, or scene, as a painting, drawing, photograph, etc.: I carry a picture of my grandchild in my wallet.
music: an art of sound in time that expresses ideas and emotions in significant forms through the elements of rhythm, melody, harmony, and color.
prefix: Grammar. an affix placed before a word, base, or another prefix to modify a term's meaning, as by making the term negative, as un- in unkind, by signaling repetition, as re- in reinvent, or by indicating support, as pro- in proabolition. Compatible prefixes can work together, as un- and re- in unrefundable.
boy: a male child, from birth to full growth, especially one less than 18 years of age.
aware: having knowledge; conscious; cognizant: aware of danger.
judges: a book of the Bible containing the history of Israel under the judges and covering the period between the death of Joshua and the accession to the throne by Saul. Abbreviation:  Jud.
violin: the treble instrument of the family of modern bowed instruments, held nearly horizontal by the player's arm with the lower part supported against the collarbone or shoulder.
agreeable: to one's liking; pleasing: agreeable manners; an agreeable sensation.
reasonable: agreeable to reason or sound judgment; logical: a reasonable choice for chairman.
sensible: having, using, or showing good sense or sound judgment: a sensible young woman.
plan: a scheme or method of acting, doing, proceeding, making, etc., developed in advance: battle plans.
economic: pertaining to the production, distribution, and use of income, wealth, and commodities.
development: the act or process of developing; growth; progress: child development; economic development.
decision: the act or process of deciding; determination, as of a question or doubt, by making a judgment: They must make a decision between these two contestants.
animate: to give life to; make alive: God animated the dust.
lifeless: not endowed with life; having no life; inanimate: lifeless matter.
accomplished: completed; done; effected: an accomplished fact.
passage: a portion or section of a written work; a paragraph, verse, etc.: a passage of Scripture.
meaning: what is intended to be, or actually is, expressed or indicated; signification; import: the three meanings of a word.
because: for the reason that; due to the fact that: The boy was absent because he was ill.
rubber: Also called India rubber, natural rubber, gum elastic, caoutchouc. a highly elastic solid substance, light cream or dark amber in color, polymerized by the drying and coagulation of the latex or milky juice of rubber trees and plants, especially Hevea and Ficus species.
tire: to reduce or exhaust the strength of, as by exertion; make weary; fatigue: The long walk tired him.
bicycle: a vehicle with two wheels in tandem, usually propelled by pedals connected to the rear wheel by a chain, and having handlebars for steering and a saddlelike seat.
whose: (the possessive case of who used as an adjective): Whose umbrella did I take? Whose is this one?
sidewall: the part of a pneumatic tire between the edge of the tread and the rim of the wheel.
cushion: a soft bag of cloth, leather, or rubber, filled with feathers, air, foam rubber, etc., on which to sit, kneel, or lie.
furniture: the movable articles, as tables, chairs, desks or cabinets, required for use or ornament in a house, office, or the like.
account: an oral or written description of particular events or situations; narrative: an account of the meetings; an account of the trip.
narrative: a story or account of events, experiences, or the like, whether true or fictitious.
narrate: to give an account or tell the story of (events, experiences, etc.).
relate: to tell; give an account of (an event, circumstance, etc.).
story: a narrative, either true or fictitious, in prose or verse, designed to interest, amuse, or instruct the hearer or reader; tale.
tale: a narrative that relates the details of some real or imaginary event, incident, or case; story: a tale about Lincoln's dog.
childhood: the state or period of being a child.
rest: the refreshing quiet or repose of sleep: a good night's rest.
button: a small disk, knob, or the like for sewing or otherwise attaching to an article, as of clothing, serving as a fastening when passed through a buttonhole or loop.
lofty: extending high in the air; of imposing height; towering: lofty mountains.
thermal: Also, thermic. of, relating to, or caused by heat or temperature: thermal capacity.
equilibrium: a state of rest or balance due to the equal action of opposing forces.
fuel: combustible matter used to maintain fire, as coal, wood, oil, or gas, in order to create heat or power.
flame: burning gas or vapor, as from wood or coal, that is undergoing combustion; a portion of ignited gas or vapor.
beverage: any potable liquid, especially one other than water, as tea, coffee, beer, or milk: The price of the meal includes a beverage.
infusion: the act or process of infusing.
berry: any small, usually stoneless, juicy fruit, irrespective of botanical structure, as the huckleberry, strawberry, or hackberry.
tasteless: having no taste or flavor; insipid.
hydrogen: a colorless, odorless, flammable gas that combines chemically with oxygen to form water: the lightest of the known elements. Symbol:  H; atomic weight:  1.00797; atomic number:  1; density: 0.0899 g/l at 0°C and 760 mm pressure.
boiling: having reached the boiling point; steaming or bubbling up under the action of heat: boiling water.
less: to a smaller extent, amount, or degree: less exact.
impure: not pure; mixed with extraneous matter, especially of an inferior or contaminating nature: impure water and air.
percent: Also called per centum. one one-hundredth part; 1/100.
mist: a cloudlike aggregation of minute globules of water suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface, reducing visibility to a lesser degree than fog.
smoke: the visible vapor and gases given off by a burning or smoldering substance, especially the gray, brown, or blackish mixture of gases and suspended carbon particles resulting from the combustion of wood, peat, coal, or other organic matter.
noxious: harmful or injurious to health or physical well-being: noxious fumes.
noticeable: attracting notice or attention; capable of being noticed: a noticeable lack of interest.
damp: slightly wet; moist: damp weather; a damp towel.
nitrogen: a colorless, odorless, gaseous element that constitutes about four-fifths of the volume of the atmosphere and is present in combined form in animal and vegetable tissues, especially in proteins: used chiefly in the manufacture of ammonia, nitric acid, cyanide, explosives, fertilizer, dyes, as a cooling agent, etc. Symbol:  N; atomic weight:  14.0067; atomic number:  7; density: 1.2506 g/l at 0°C and 760 mm pressure.
minute: the sixtieth part (1/60) of an hour; sixty seconds.
composite: made up of disparate or separate parts or elements; compound: a composite drawing; a composite philosophy.
generally: usually; commonly; ordinarily: He generally comes home at noon.
weather: the state of the atmosphere with respect to wind, temperature, cloudiness, moisture, pressure, etc.
region: an extensive, continuous part of a surface, space, or body: a region of the earth.
precipitation: the act of precipitating; state of being precipitated.
sunshine: the shining of the sun; direct light of the sun.
throughout: in or to every part of; everywhere in: They searched throughout the house.
interval: an intervening period of time: an interval of 50 years.
nights: at or during the night regularly or frequently: He worked during the day and wrote nights.
sunrise: the rise or ascent of the sun above the horizon in the morning.
sunset: the setting or descent of the sun below the horizon in the evening.
since: from then till now (often preceded by ever): He was elected in 1978 and has been president ever since.
during: throughout the duration, continuance, or existence of: He lived in Florida during the winter.
beauty: the quality present in a thing or person that gives intense pleasure or deep satisfaction to the mind, whether arising from sensory manifestations (as shape, color, sound, etc.), a meaningful design or pattern, or something else (as a personality in which high spiritual qualities are manifest).
pleasure: the state or feeling of being pleased.
satisfaction: an act of satisfying; fulfillment; gratification.
hear: to perceive by the ear: Didn't you hear the doorbell?
septic: pertaining to or of the nature of sepsis; infected.
tank: a large receptacle, container, or structure for holding a liquid or gas: tanks for storing oil.
radium: Chemistry. a highly radioactive metallic element whose decay yields radon gas and alpha rays. Symbol:  Ra; atomic weight:  226; atomic number:  88.
platinum: Chemistry. a heavy, grayish-white, highly malleable and ductile metallic element, resistant to most chemicals, practically unoxidizable except in the presence of bases, and fusible only at extremely high temperatures: used for making chemical and scientific apparatus, as a catalyst in the oxidation of ammonia to nitric acid, and in jewelry. Symbol:  Pt; atomic weight:  195.09; atomic number:  78; specific gravity:  21.5 at 20°C.
refer: to direct for information or anything required: He referred me to books on astrology.
back: the rear part of the human body, extending from the neck to the lower end of the spine.
footnote: an explanatory or documenting note or comment at the bottom of a page, referring to a specific part of the text on the page.
pierce: to penetrate into or run through (something), as a sharp, pointed dagger, object, or instrument does.
bullet: a small metal projectile, part of a cartridge, for firing from small arms.
lights: the lungs, especially of sheep, pigs, etc.
cutting: the act of a person or thing that cuts.
edge: a line or border at which a surface terminates: Grass grew along the edges of the road. The paper had deckle edges.
piercing: loud or shrill, as the quality of a voice.
mechanical: having to do with machinery: a mechanical failure.
tool: an implement, especially one held in the hand, as a hammer, saw, or file, for performing or facilitating mechanical operations.
implement: any article used in some activity, especially an instrument, tool, or utensil: agricultural implements.
delicate: fine in texture, quality, construction, etc.: a delicate lace collar.
precision: the state or quality of being precise.
surgical: pertaining to or involving surgery or surgeons.
thumb: the short, thick, inner digit of the human hand, next to the forefinger.
rough: having a coarse or uneven surface, as from projections, irregularities, or breaks; not smooth: rough, red hands; a rough road.
road: a long, narrow stretch with a smoothed or paved surface, made for traveling by motor vehicle, carriage, etc., between two or more points; street or highway.
lustrous: having luster; shining; luminous: lustrous eyes.
ornamental: used or grown for ornament: ornamental plants.
figure: a numerical symbol, especially an Arabic numeral.
several: being more than two but fewer than many in number or kind: several ways of doing it.
tropical: pertaining to, characteristic of, occurring in, or inhabiting the tropics, especially the humid tropics: tropical flowers.
yielding: inclined to give in; submissive; compliant: a timid, yielding man.
reddish: somewhat red; tending to red; tinged with red.
bought: simple past tense and past participle of buy.
sold: simple past tense and past participle of sell1 .
half: one of two equal or approximately equal parts of a divisible whole, as an object, or unit of measure or time; a part of a whole equal or almost equal to the remainder.
relative: a person who is connected with another or others by blood or marriage.
worth: good or important enough to justify (what is specified): advice worth taking; a place worth visiting.
education: the act or process of imparting or acquiring general knowledge, developing the powers of reasoning and judgment, and generally of preparing oneself or others intellectually for mature life.
chess: a game played on a chessboard by two people who maneuver sixteen pieces each according to rules governing movement of the six kinds of pieces (pawn, rook, knight, bishop, queen, king), the object being to bring the opponent's king into checkmate.
exceedingly: to an unusual degree; very; extremely: The children were doing exceedingly well in school.
giant: (in folklore) a being with human form but superhuman size, strength, etc.
monetary: of or relating to the coinage or currency of a country.
crop: the cultivated produce of the ground, while growing or when gathered: the wheat crop.
expensive: entailing great expense; very high-priced; costly: an expensive party.
emerald: a rare variety of beryl that is colored green by chromium and valued as a gem.
bracelet: an ornamental band or circlet for the wrist or arm or, sometimes, for the ankle.
medical: of or relating to the science or practice of medicine: medical history; medical treatment.
butter: the fatty portion of milk, separating as a soft whitish or yellowish solid when milk or cream is agitated or churned.
refined: having or showing well-bred feeling, taste, etc.: refined people.
officer: a person who holds a position of rank or authority in the army, navy, air force, or any similar organization, especially one who holds a commission.
standing: rank or status, especially with respect to social, economic, or personal position, reputation, etc.: He had little standing in the community.
intensity: the quality or condition of being intense.
juice: the natural fluid, fluid content, or liquid part that can be extracted from a plant or one of its parts, especially of a fruit: orange juice.
dry: free from moisture or excess moisture; not moist; not wet: a dry towel; dry air.
cooking: the act of a person or thing that cooks.
religious: of, relating to, or concerned with religion: a religious holiday.
alcoholic: of, relating to, or of the nature of alcohol.
content: something that is contained: the contents of a box.
necessary: being essential, indispensable, or requisite: a necessary part of the motor.
requirement: that which is required; a thing demanded or obligatory: One of the requirements of the job is accuracy.
fully: entirely or wholly: You should be fully done with the work by now.
suitable: such as to suit; appropriate; fitting; becoming.
fit: adapted or suited; appropriate: This water isn't fit for drinking. A long-necked giraffe is fit for browsing treetops.
needs: of necessity; necessarily (usually preceded or followed by must): It must needs be so. It needs must be.
fifty: a cardinal number, ten times five.
feel: to perceive or examine by touch.
wish: to want; desire; long for (usually followed by an infinitive or a clause): I wish to travel. I wish that it were morning.
always: every time; on every occasion; without exception: He always works on Saturday.
wanting: lacking or absent: a motor with some of the parts wanting.
duty: something that one is expected or required to do by moral or legal obligation.
obligation: something by which a person is bound or obliged to do certain things, and which arises out of a sense of duty or results from custom, law, etc.
protection: the act of protecting or the state of being protected; preservation from injury or harm.
fulfill: to carry out, or bring to realization, as a prophecy or promise.
full: completely filled; containing all that can be held; filled to utmost capacity: a full cup.
contentment: the state of being contented; satisfaction; ease of mind.
hearty: warm-hearted; affectionate; cordial; jovial: a hearty welcome.
meal: the food served and eaten especially at one of the customary, regular occasions for taking food during the day, as breakfast, lunch, or supper.
crave: to long for; want greatly; desire eagerly: to crave sweets; to crave affection.
loud: (of sound) strongly audible; having exceptional volume or intensity: loud talking; loud thunder; loud whispers.
harsh: ungentle and unpleasant in action or effect: harsh treatment; harsh manners.
become: to come, change, or grow to be (as specified): He became tired.
sleep: to take the rest afforded by a suspension of voluntary bodily functions and the natural suspension, complete or partial, of consciousness; cease being awake.
awake: to wake up; rouse from sleep: I awoke at six with a feeling of dread.
waken: to rouse from sleep; wake; awake; awaken.
deprived: marked by deprivation; lacking the necessities of life, as adequate food and shelter: a deprived childhood.
hire: to engage the services of (a person or persons) for wages or other payment: to hire a clerk.
engage: to occupy the attention or efforts of (a person or persons): He engaged her in conversation.
employment: an act or instance of employing someone or something.
keep: to hold or retain in one's possession; hold as one's own: If you like it, keep it. Keep the change.
factory: a building or group of buildings with facilities for the manufacture of goods.
location: a place of settlement, activity, or residence: This town is a good location for a young doctor.
helpful: giving or rendering aid or assistance; of service: Your comments were very helpful.
aid: to provide support for or relief to; help: to aid the homeless victims of the fire.
blade: the flat cutting part of a sword, knife, etc.
fitted: made so as to follow closely the contours of a form or shape: fitted clothes; fitted sheets.
handle: a part of a thing made specifically to be grasped or held by the hand.
hospital: an institution in which sick or injured persons are given medical or surgical treatment.
lose: to come to be without (something in one's possession or care), through accident, theft, etc., so that there is little or no prospect of recovery: I'm sure I've merely misplaced my hat, not lost it.
largely: to a great extent; in great part; generally; chiefly: The plan depends largely on his willingness to cooperate. That is largely incorrect.
apart: into pieces or parts; to pieces: to take a watch apart; an old barn falling apart from decay.
yellow: a color like that of egg yolk, ripe lemons, etc.; the primary color between green and orange in the visible spectrum, an effect of light with a wavelength between 570 and 590 nm.
highly: in or to a high degree; extremely: highly amusing; highly seasoned food.
oxidation: the process or result of oxidizing.
corrosion: the act or process of corroding; condition of being corroded.
au: to the; at the; with the.
private: belonging to some particular person: private property.
ornament: an accessory, article, or detail used to beautify the appearance of something to which it is added or of which it is a part: architectural ornaments.
accessory: a subordinate or supplementary part, object, or the like, used mainly for convenience, attractiveness, safety, etc., as a spotlight on an automobile or a lens cover on a camera.
possibility: the state or fact of being possible: the possibility of error.
adjacent: lying near, close, or contiguous; adjoining; neighboring: a motel adjacent to the highway.
angeles: a city in the Philippines, on S central Luzon.
ocean: the vast body of salt water that covers almost three fourths of the earth's surface.
vast: of very great area or extent; immense: the vast reaches of outer space.
fish: any of various cold-blooded, aquatic vertebrates, having gills, commonly fins, and typically an elongated body covered with scales.
supervisor: a person who supervises workers or the work done by others; superintendent.
keeping: agreement or conformity in things or elements associated together: His actions are not in keeping with his words.
scandal: a disgraceful or discreditable action, circumstance, etc.
dissent: to differ in sentiment or opinion, especially from the majority; withhold assent; disagree (often followed by from): Two of the justices dissented from the majority decision.
response: an answer or reply, as in words or in some action.
equipment: anything kept, furnished, or provided for a specific purpose.
laboratory: a building, part of a building, or other place equipped to conduct scientific experiments, tests, investigations, etc., or to manufacture chemicals, medicines, or the like.
undertake: to take upon oneself, as a task, performance, etc.; attempt: She undertook the job of answering all the mail.
project: something that is contemplated, devised, or planned; plan; scheme.
accomplish: to bring to its goal or conclusion; carry out; perform; finish: to accomplish one's mission.
task: a definite piece of work assigned to, falling to, or expected of a person; duty.
contribute: to give (money, time, knowledge, assistance, etc.) to a common supply, fund, etc., as for charitable purposes.
render: to cause to be or become; make: to render someone helpless.
assistance: the act of assisting; help; aid; support.
cooperate: to work or act together or jointly for a common purpose or benefit.
let: to allow or permit: to let him escape.
shoe: an external covering for the human foot, usually of leather and consisting of a more or less stiff or heavy sole and a lighter upper part ending a short distance above, at, or below the ankle.
morning: the first part or period of the day, extending from dawn, or from midnight, to noon.
message: a communication containing some information, news, advice, request, or the like, sent by messenger, telephone, email, or other means.
identify: to recognize or establish as being a particular person or thing; verify the identity of: to identify handwriting; to identify the bearer of a check.
sailing: the activity of a person or thing that sails.
storm: a disturbance of the normal condition of the atmosphere, manifesting itself by winds of unusual force or direction, often accompanied by rain, snow, hail, thunder, and lightning, or flying sand or dust.
judgment: an act or instance of judging.
grant: to bestow or confer, especially by a formal act: to grant a charter.
premise: Also, premiss. Logic. a proposition supporting or helping to support a conclusion.
utter: to give audible expression to; speak or pronounce: unable to utter her feelings; Words were uttered in my hearing.
musical: of, relating to, or producing music: a musical instrument.
voice: the sound or sounds uttered through the mouth of living creatures, especially of human beings in speaking, shouting, singing, etc.
vocalize: to make vocal; utter; articulate; sing.
spend: to pay out, disburse, or expend; dispose of (money, wealth, resources, etc.): resisting the temptation to spend one's money.
army: the military forces of a nation, exclusive of the navy and in some countries the air force.
perform: to carry out; execute; do: to perform miracles.
role: a part or character played by an actor or actress.
nothing: no thing; not anything; naught: to say nothing.
bell: a hollow instrument of cast metal, typically cup-shaped with a flaring mouth, suspended from the vertex and rung by the strokes of a clapper, hammer, or the like.
formally: in a formal manner: The store was formally opened on Tuesday.
intended: purposed; designed; intentional: an intended snub.
attain: to reach, achieve, or accomplish; gain; obtain: to attain one's goals.
target: an object, usually marked with concentric circles, to be aimed at in shooting practice or contests.
military: of, for, or pertaining to the army or armed forces, often as distinguished from the navy: from civilian to military life.
attack: to set upon in a forceful, violent, hostile, or aggressive way, with or without a weapon; begin fighting with: He attacked him with his bare hands.
fund: a supply of money or pecuniary resources, as for some purpose: a fund for his education; a retirement fund.
drive: to send, expel, or otherwise cause to move by force or compulsion: to drive away the flies; to drive back an attacking army; to drive a person to desperation.
bid: to command; order; direct: to bid them depart.
responsible: answerable or accountable, as for something within one's power, control, or management (often followed by to or for): He is responsible to the president for his decisions.
fault: a defect or imperfection; flaw; failing: a fault in the brakes; a fault in one's character.
censure: strong or vehement expression of disapproval: The newspapers were unanimous in their censure of the tax proposal.
bundle: several objects or a quantity of material gathered or bound together: a bundle of hay.
packed: filled to capacity; full: They've had a packed theater for every performance.
parcel: an object, article, container, or quantity of something wrapped or packed up; small package; bundle.
fast: moving or able to move, operate, function, or take effect quickly; quick; swift; rapid: a fast horse; a fast pain reliever; a fast thinker.
grasp: to seize and hold by or as if by clasping with the fingers or arms.
held: simple past tense and a past participle of hold1 .
paddock: a small, usually enclosed field near a stable or barn for pasturing or exercising animals.
labor: productive activity, especially for the sake of economic gain.
toil: hard and continuous work; exhausting labor or effort.
monograph: a treatise on a particular subject, as a biographical study or study of the works of one artist.
detailed: having many details: a detailed problem.
included: being part of the whole; contained; covered: Breakfast is included in the price of the room.
presence: the state or fact of being present, as with others or in a place.
perception: the act or faculty of perceiving, or apprehending by means of the senses or of the mind; cognition; understanding.
carry: to take or support from one place to another; convey; transport: He carried her for a mile in his arms. This elevator cannot carry more than ten people.
speaker: a person who speaks.
suitcase: a usually rectangular piece of luggage especially for carrying clothes while traveling.
office: a room, set of rooms, or building where the business of a commercial or industrial organization or of a professional person is conducted: the main office of an insurance company; a doctor's office.
sitting: the act of a person or thing that sits.
posture: the relative disposition of the parts of something.
assume: to take for granted or without proof: to assume that everyone wants peace.
greet: to address with some form of salutation; welcome.
invisible: not visible; not perceptible by the eye: invisible fluid.
manage: to bring about or succeed in accomplishing, sometimes despite difficulty or hardship: She managed to see the governor. How does she manage it on such a small income?
guide: to assist (a person) to travel through, or reach a destination in, an unfamiliar area, as by accompanying or giving directions to the person: He guided us through the forest.
advice: an opinion or recommendation offered as a guide to action, conduct, etc.: I shall act on your advice.
instruction: the act or practice of instructing or teaching; education.
roundabout: circuitous or indirect, as a road, journey, method, statement or person.
device: a thing made for a particular purpose; an invention or contrivance, especially a mechanical or electrical one.
sunday: the first day of the week, observed as the Sabbath by most Christian sects.
departure: an act or instance of departing: the time of departure; a hasty departure.
midst: the position of anything surrounded by other things or parts, or occurring in the middle of a period of time, course of action, etc. (usually preceded by the): a familiar face in the midst of the crowd; in the midst of the performance.
association: an organization of people with a common purpose and having a formal structure.
connection: the act or state of connecting.
cluster: a number of things of the same kind, growing or held together; a bunch: a cluster of grapes.
contest: a race, conflict, or other competition between rivals, as for a prize.
competition: the act of competing; rivalry for supremacy, a prize, etc.: The competition between the two teams was bitter.
theater: a building, part of a building, or outdoor area for housing dramatic presentations, stage entertainments, or motion-picture shows.
concert: a public musical performance in which a number of singers or instrumentalists, or both, participate.
type: a number of things or persons sharing a particular characteristic, or set of characteristics, that causes them to be regarded as a group, more or less precisely defined or designated; class; category: a criminal of the most vicious type.
abnormal: not normal, average, typical, or usual; deviating from a standard: abnormal powers of concentration; an abnormal amount of snow; abnormal behavior.
regular: usual; normal; customary: to put something in its regular place.
habitual: of the nature of a habit; fixed by or resulting from habit: habitual courtesy.
customary: according to or depending on custom; usual; habitual.
alphabet: the letters of a language in their customary order.
authoritative: having due authority; having the sanction or weight of authority: an authoritative opinion.
command: to direct with specific authority or prerogative; order: The captain commanded his men to attack.
mandate: a command or authorization to act in a particular way on a public issue given by the electorate to its representative: The president had a clear mandate to end the war.
main: chief in size, extent, or importance; principal; leading: the company's main office; the main features of a plan.
evening: the latter part of the day and early part of the night.
midday: the middle of the day; noon or the time centering around noon.
meeting: the act of coming together: a chance meeting in the park.
recall: to bring back from memory; recollect; remember: Can you recall what she said?
again: once more; another time; anew; in addition: Will you spell your name again, please?
try: to attempt to do or accomplish: Try it before you say it's simple.
date: a particular month, day, and year at which some event happened or will happen: July 4, 1776 was the date of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.
spite: a malicious, usually petty, desire to harm, annoy, frustrate, or humiliate another person; bitter ill will; malice.
even: level; flat; without surface irregularities; smooth: an even road.
though: (used in introducing a subordinate clause, which is often marked by ellipsis) notwithstanding that; in spite of the fact that; although: Though he tried very hard, he failed the course.
twin: either of two children or animals brought forth at a birth.
greatly: in or to a great degree; much: greatly improved in health.
writer: a person engaged in writing books, articles, stories, etc., especially as an occupation or profession; an author or journalist.
test: the means by which the presence, quality, or genuineness of anything is determined; a means of trial.
trial: The judge decided on Sunday not to broadcast the trial live for security reasons.
tentative: of the nature of or made or done as a trial, experiment, or attempt; experimental: a tentative report on her findings.
procedure: an act or a manner of proceeding in any action or process; conduct.
unknown: not known; not within the range of one's knowledge, experience, or understanding; strange; unfamiliar.
principle: an accepted or professed rule of action or conduct: a person of good moral principles.
teaching: the act or profession of a person who teaches.
shook: a set of staves and headings sufficient for one hogshead, barrel, or the like.
charge: to impose or ask as a price or fee: That store charges $25 for leather gloves.
assertion: a positive statement or declaration, often without support or reason: a mere assertion; an unwarranted assertion.
alleged: declared or stated to be as described; asserted: The alleged murderer could not be located for questioning.
politician: a person who is active in party politics.
imperative: absolutely necessary or required; unavoidable: It is imperative that we leave.
fleet: the largest organized unit of naval ships grouped for tactical or other purposes.
spot: a rounded mark or stain made by foreign matter, as mud, blood, paint, ink, etc.; a blot or speck.
locality: a place, spot, or district, with or without reference to things or persons in it or to occurrences there: They moved to another locality.
establish: to found, institute, build, or bring into being on a firm or stable basis: to establish a university; to establish a medical practice.
argument: an oral disagreement; verbal opposition; contention; altercation: a violent argument.
outer: situated on or toward the outside; external; exterior: outer garments; an outer wall.
garment: any article of clothing: dresses, suits, and other garments.
least: smallest in size, amount, degree, etc.; slightest: He gave the least amount of money of anyone.
upper: higher, as in place, position, pitch, or in a scale: the upper stories of a house; the upper register of a singer's voice.
fur: the fine, soft, thick, hairy coat of the skin of a mammal.
wear: to carry or have on the body or about the person as a covering, equipment, ornament, or the like: to wear a coat; to wear a saber; to wear a disguise.
tertiary: of the third order, rank, stage, formation, etc.; third.
yellowish: somewhat yellow; tinged with yellow; yellowy.
utterance: an act of uttering; vocal expression.
discourse: communication of thought by words; talk; conversation: earnest and intelligent discourse.
consistent: agreeing or accordant; compatible; not self-contradictory: His views and actions are consistent.
category: any general or comprehensive division; a class.
proposition: the act of offering or suggesting something to be considered, accepted, adopted, or done.
ordinarily: most of the time; generally; usually: Ordinarily he wakes at seven.
true: being in accordance with the actual state or conditions; conforming to reality or fact; not false: a true story.
accurate: free from error or defect; consistent with a standard, rule, or model; precise; exact.
remove: to move from a place or position; take away or off: to remove the napkins from the table.
pronunciation: the act or result of producing the sounds of speech, including articulation, stress, and intonation, often with reference to some standard of correctness or acceptability: They are arguing about the pronunciation of “forte” again. His pronunciation retains charming traces of his early years in Ireland.
eyesight: the power or faculty of seeing.
phenomenon: a fact, occurrence, or circumstance observed or observable: to study the phenomena of nature.
albert: Carl (Bert) 1908–2000, U.S. politician: Speaker of the House 1971–77.
read: to look at carefully so as to understand the meaning of (something written, printed, etc.): to read a book; to read music.
vigilant: keenly watchful to detect danger; wary: a vigilant sentry.
alert: fully aware and attentive; wide-awake; keen: an alert mind.
observant: quick to notice or perceive; alert.
sentry: a soldier stationed at a place to stand guard and prevent the passage of unauthorized persons, watch for fires, etc., especially a sentinel stationed at a pass, gate, opening in a defense work, or the like.
night: the period of darkness between sunset and sunrise.
early: in or during the first part of a period of time, a course of action, a series of events, etc.: early in the year.
gain: to get (something desired), especially as a result of one's efforts: to gain possession of an object; to gain permission to enter a country.
choice: an act or instance of choosing; selection: Her choice of a computer was made after months of research. His parents were not happy with his choice of friends.
telephone: an apparatus, system, or process for transmission of sound or speech to a distant point, especially by an electric device.
perceive: to become aware of, know, or identify by means of the senses: I perceived an object looming through the mist.
syntactic: of or relating to syntax: syntactic errors in English; the syntactic rules for computer source code.
resistance: the act or power of resisting, opposing, or withstanding.
combat: to fight or contend against; oppose vigorously: to combat crime.
final: pertaining to or coming at the end; last in place, order, or time: the final meeting of the year.
utmost: of the greatest or highest degree, quantity, or the like; greatest: of the utmost importance.
boundary: something that indicates bounds or limits; a limiting or bounding line.
continuance: an act or instance of continuing; continuation: a continuance of war.
vision: the act or power of sensing with the eyes; sight.
trade: the act or process of buying, selling, or exchanging commodities, at either wholesale or retail, within a country or between countries: domestic trade; foreign trade.
infer: to derive by reasoning; conclude or judge from premises or evidence: They inferred his displeasure from his cool tone of voice.
trend: the general course or prevailing tendency; drift: trends in the teaching of foreign languages; the trend of events.
statistics: (used with a singular verb) the science that deals with the collection, classification, analysis, and interpretation of numerical facts or data, and that, by use of mathematical theories of probability, imposes order and regularity on aggregates of more or less disparate elements.
capability: the quality of being capable; capacity; ability: His capability was unquestionable.
muscular: of or relating to muscle or the muscles: muscular strain.
madness: the state of being mad; insanity.
supernatural: of, relating to, or being above or beyond what is natural; unexplainable by natural law or phenomena; abnormal.
devil: As  Marcus says, the devil is often in the details in cases like this, “some decimal point in the wrong place.”
becoming: that suits or gives a pleasing effect or attractive appearance, as to a person or thing: a becoming dress; a becoming hairdo.
vehicle: any means in or by which someone travels or something is carried or conveyed; a means of conveyance or transport: a motor vehicle; space vehicles.
admission: the act of allowing to enter; entrance granted by permission, by provision or existence of pecuniary means, or by the removal of obstacles: the admission of aliens into a country.
frame: a border or case for enclosing a picture, mirror, etc.
write: to trace or form (characters, letters, words, etc.) on the surface of some material, as with a pen, pencil, or other instrument or means; inscribe: Write your name on the board.
metrical: pertaining to meter or poetic measure.
poetry: the art of rhythmical composition, written or spoken, for exciting pleasure by beautiful, imaginative, or elevated thoughts.
branch: a division or subdivision of the stem or axis of a tree, shrub, or other plant.
literature: writings in which expression and form, in connection with ideas of permanent and universal interest, are characteristic or essential features, as poetry, novels, history, biography, and essays.
dealing: Usually, dealings. relations; business: frequent dealings; commercial dealings.
offering: something offered in worship or devotion, as to a deity; an oblation or sacrifice.
biography: a written account of another person's life: the biography of Byron by Marchand.
essay: a short literary composition on a particular theme or subject, usually in prose and generally analytic, speculative, or interpretative.
drama: a composition in prose or verse presenting in dialogue or pantomime a story involving conflict or contrast of character, especially one intended to be acted on the stage; a play.
conversation: informal interchange of thoughts, information, etc., by spoken words; oral communication between persons; talk; colloquy.
discussion: an act or instance of discussing; consideration or examination by argument, comment, etc., especially to explore solutions; informal debate.
thinking: rational; reasoning: People are thinking animals.
thinker: a person who thinks, as in a specified way or manner: a slow thinker.
publishing: the activities or business of a publisher, especially of books or periodicals: He plans to go into publishing after college.
periodical: a magazine or other journal that is issued at regularly recurring intervals.
map: a representation, usually on a flat surface, as of the features of an area of the earth or a portion of the heavens, showing them in their respective forms, sizes, and relationships according to some convention of representation: a map of Canada.
engraving: the act or art of a person who or thing that engraves.
weekly: done, happening, appearing, etc., once a week, or every week: a weekly appointment with an analyst.
news: a report of a recent event; intelligence; information: His family has had no news of his whereabouts for months.
comment: a remark, observation, or criticism: a comment about the weather.
advertising: the act or practice of calling public attention to one's product, service, need, etc., especially by paid announcements in newspapers and magazines, over radio or television, on billboards, etc.: to get more customers by advertising.
sports: of or relating to a sport or sports, especially of the open-air or athletic kind: a sports festival.
print: to produce (a text, picture, etc.) by applying inked types, plates, blocks, or the like, to paper or other material either by direct pressure or indirectly by offsetting an image onto an intermediate roller.
imaginative: characterized by or bearing evidence of imagination: an imaginative tale.
narration: something narrated; an account, story, or narrative.
sheet: a large rectangular piece of cotton, linen, or other material used as an article of bedding, commonly spread in pairs so that one is immediately above and the other immediately below the sleeper.
entertainment: the act of entertaining; agreeable occupation for the mind; diversion; amusement: Solving the daily crossword puzzle is an entertainment for many.
cocktail: any of various short mixed drinks, consisting typically of gin, whiskey, rum, vodka, or brandy, with different admixtures, as vermouth, fruit juices, or flavorings, usually chilled and frequently sweetened.
closet: a small room, enclosed recess, or cabinet for storing clothing, food, utensils, etc.
prehensile: adapted for seizing, grasping, or taking hold of something: a prehensile tail.
limb: a part or member of an animal body distinct from the head and trunk, as a leg, arm, or wing: the lower limbs; artificial limbs.
wrist: the carpus or lower part of the forearm where it joins the hand.
metacarpal: of or relating to the metacarpus.
intersection: a place where two or more roads meet, especially when at least one is a major highway; junction.
occasion: a particular time, especially as marked by certain circumstances or occurrences: They met on three occasions.
chug: a short, dull, explosive sound: the steady chug of an engine.
normally: in a normal or regular way: The wound is healing normally.
talk: to communicate or exchange ideas, information, etc., by speaking: to talk about poetry.
dwelling: a building or place of shelter to live in; place of residence; abode; home.
absolutely: without exception; completely; wholly; entirely: You are absolutely right.
indispensable: absolutely necessary, essential, or requisite: an indispensable member of the staff.
discipline: training to act in accordance with rules; drill: military discipline.
distinguish: to mark off as different (often followed by from or by): He was distinguished from the other boys by his height.
zebra: any of several horselike African mammals of the genus Equus, each species having a characteristic pattern of black or dark-brown stripes on a whitish background: all zebra species are threatened or endangered.
typical: of the nature of or serving as a type or representative specimen.
autumn: the season between summer and winter; fall. In the Northern Hemisphere it is from the September equinox to the December solstice; in the Southern Hemisphere it is from the March equinox to the June solstice.
temper: a particular state of mind or feelings.
ill: of unsound physical or mental health; unwell; sick: She felt ill, so her teacher sent her to the nurse.
touched: moved; stirred: They were very touched by your generosity.
substantial: of ample or considerable amount, quantity, size, etc.: a substantial sum of money.
difference: the state or relation of being different; dissimilarity: There is a great difference between the two.
lodging: accommodation in a house, especially in rooms for rent: to furnish board and lodging.
feeding: the act of a person or thing that feeds.
cattle: bovine animals, especially domesticated members of the genus Bos.
durable: able to resist wear, decay, etc., well; lasting; enduring.
cast: to throw or hurl; fling: The gambler cast the dice.
mirror: a reflecting surface, originally of polished metal but now usually of glass with a silvery, metallic, or amalgam backing.
onto: to a place or position on; upon; on: to get onto a horse.
apartment: a room or a group of related rooms, among similar sets in one building, designed for use as a dwelling.
shelter: something beneath, behind, or within which a person, animal, or thing is protected from storms, missiles, adverse conditions, etc.; refuge.
household: the people of a house collectively; a family including its servants.
salt: a crystalline compound, sodium chloride, NaCl, occurring as a mineral, a constituent of seawater, etc., and used for seasoning food, as a preservative, etc.
marry: to take in marriage: After dating for five years, I finally asked her to marry me.
stanch: to stop the flow of (a liquid, especially blood).
defend: to ward off attack from; guard against assault or injury (usually followed by from or against): The sentry defended the gate against sudden attack.
poplar: any of the rapidly growing, salicaceous trees of the genus Populus, usually characterized by the columnar or spirelike manner of growth of its branches.
seeing: in view of the fact that; considering; inasmuch as.
image: a physical likeness or representation of a person, animal, or thing, photographed, painted, sculptured, or otherwise made visible.
faculty: an ability, natural or acquired, for a particular kind of action: a faculty for making friends easily.
taking: the act of a person or thing that takes.
gradual: taking place, changing, moving, etc., by small degrees or little by little: gradual improvement in health.
complexion: the natural color, texture, and appearance of the skin, especially of the face: a clear, smooth, rosy complexion.
saturate: to cause (a substance) to unite with the greatest possible amount of another substance, through solution, chemical combination, or the like.
luminous: radiating or reflecting light; shining; bright.
shone: a simple past tense and past participle of shine1 .
drinking: suitable or safe to drink: drinking water.
liberty: freedom from arbitrary or despotic government or control.
restraint: a restraining action or influence: freedom from restraint.
black: lacking hue and brightness; absorbing light without reflecting any of the rays composing it.
neutral: not taking part or giving assistance in a dispute or war between others: a neutral nation during World War II.
themselves: an emphatic form of them or they: The authors themselves left the theater. The contract was written by the partners themselves.
neither: not either, as of persons or things specified (usually followed by nor): Neither John nor Betty is at home.
nor: (used in negative phrases, especially after neither, to introduce the second member in a series, or any subsequent member): Neither he nor I will be there. They won't wait for you, nor for me, nor for anybody.
expansion: the act or process of expanding.
efficient: performing or functioning in the best possible manner with the least waste of time and effort; having and using requisite knowledge, skill, and industry; competent; capable: a reliable, efficient assistant.
competent: having suitable or sufficient skill, knowledge, experience, etc., for some purpose; properly qualified: He is perfectly competent to manage the bank branch.
outline: the line by which a figure or object is defined or bounded; contour.
ladder: a structure of wood, metal, or rope, commonly consisting of two sidepieces between which a series of bars or rungs are set at suitable distances, forming a means of climbing up or down.
calculation: the act or process of calculating; computation.
how: in what way or manner; by what means?: How did the accident happen?
ago: gone; gone by; past (usually preceded by a noun): five days ago.
soon: within a short period after this or that time, event, etc.: We shall know soon after he calls.
arrive: to come to a certain point in the course of travel; reach one's destination: He finally arrived in Rome.
roman: a metrical narrative, especially in medieval French literature.
empire: a group of nations or peoples ruled over by an emperor, empress, or other powerful sovereign or government: usually a territory of greater extent than a kingdom, as the former British Empire, French Empire, Russian Empire, Byzantine Empire, or Roman Empire.
horse: a large, solid-hoofed, herbivorous quadruped, Equus caballus, domesticated since prehistoric times, bred in a number of varieties, and used for carrying or pulling loads, for riding, and for racing.
rode: a simple past tense of ride.
alone: separate, apart, or isolated from others: I want to be alone.
conception: the act of conceiving; the state of being conceived.
awareness: the state or condition of being aware; having knowledge; consciousness: The object of the information drive is to raise awareness of what spreads HIV/AIDS.
sequential: characterized by regular sequence of parts.
continuous: uninterrupted in time; without cessation: continuous coughing during the concert.
succeed: to happen or terminate according to desire; turn out successfully; have the desired result: Our efforts succeeded.
say: to utter or pronounce; speak: What did you say? I said “Hello!”.
warm: having or giving out a moderate degree of heat, as perceived by the senses: a warm bath.
assumed: adopted in order to deceive; fictitious; pretended; feigned: an assumed name; an assumed air of humility.
regardless: having or showing no regard; heedless; unmindful (often followed by of).
hypothetical: assumed by hypothesis; supposed: a hypothetical case.
fashion: a prevailing custom or style of dress, etiquette, socializing, etc.: the latest fashion in dresses.
polite: showing good manners toward others, as in behavior, speech, etc.; courteous; civil: a polite reply.
laid: simple past tense and past participle of lay1 .
crisis: a stage in a sequence of events at which the trend of all future events, especially for better or for worse, is determined; turning point.
lining: something that is used to line another thing; a layer of material on the inner side or surface of something.
individually: one at a time; separately: The delegates were introduced individually.
hallway: a corridor, as in a building.
circuit: an act or instance of going or moving around.
pertain: to have reference or relation; relate: documents pertaining to the lawsuit.
calm: without rough motion; still or nearly still: a calm sea.
tranquil: free from commotion or tumult; peaceful; quiet; calm: a tranquil country place.
serene: calm, peaceful, or tranquil; unruffled: a serene landscape; serene old age.
nervous: highly excitable; unnaturally or acutely uneasy or apprehensive: to become nervous under stress.
providing: on the condition or understanding (that); provided: He can stay here providing he works.
vessel: a craft for traveling on water, now usually one larger than an ordinary rowboat; a ship or boat.
duct: any tube, canal, pipe, or conduit by which a fluid, air, or other substance is conducted or conveyed.
transport: to carry, move, or convey from one place to another.
bloodstream: the blood flowing through a circulatory system.
lymphatic: pertaining to, containing, or conveying lymph.
plant: any member of the kingdom Plantae, comprising multicellular organisms that typically produce their own food from inorganic matter by the process of photosynthesis and that have more or less rigid cell walls containing cellulose, including vascular plants, mosses, liverworts, and hornworts: some classification schemes may include fungi, algae, bacteria, blue-green algae, and certain single-celled eukaryotes that have plantlike qualities, as rigid cell walls or photosynthesis.
collected: having control of one's faculties; self-possessed: Despite all the turmoil around him, Bob remained calm and collected.
assembly: an assembling or coming together of a number of persons, usually for a particular purpose: The principal will speak to all the students at Friday's assembly.
diminution: the act, fact, or process of diminishing; lessening; reduction.
exception: the act of excepting or the fact of being excepted.
pie: a baked food having a filling of fruit, meat, pudding, etc., prepared in a pastry-lined pan or dish and often topped with a pastry crust: apple pie; meat pie.
elevation: the height to which something is elevated or to which it rises: The elevation of the tower is 80 feet.
summit: the highest point or part, as of a hill, a line of travel, or any object; top; apex.
altitude: the height of anything above a given planetary reference plane, especially above sea level on earth.
track: a structure consisting of a pair of parallel lines of rails with their crossties, on which a railroad train, trolley, or the like runs.
freight: goods, cargo, or lading transported for pay, whether by water, land, or air.
frail: having delicate health; not robust; weak: My grandfather is rather frail now.
spinal: of, relating to, or belonging to a spine or thornlike structure, especially to the backbone.
column: A version of this column first appeared in the Boston Globe 20 years ago.
biology: the science of life or living matter in all its forms and phenomena, especially with reference to origin, growth, reproduction, structure, and behavior.
convent: a community of persons devoted to religious life under a superior.
prison: a building for the confinement of persons held while awaiting trial, persons sentenced after conviction, etc.
inferior: lower in station, rank, degree, or grade (often followed by to): a rank inferior to colonel.
extraneous: introduced or coming from without; not belonging or proper to a thing; external; foreign: extraneous substances in our water.
grains: an iron instrument with barbed prongs, for spearing or harpooning fish.
margin: the space around the printed or written matter on a page.
leaf: one of the expanded, usually green organs borne by the stem of a plant.
manuscript: the original text of an author's work, handwritten or now usually typed, that is submitted to a publisher.
cold: having a relatively low temperature; having little or no warmth: cold water; a cold day.
attachment: an act of attaching or the state of being attached.
above: in, at, or to a higher place.
chandelier: a decorative, sometimes ornate, light fixture suspended from a ceiling, usually having branched supports for a number of lights.
ceiling: the overhead interior surface of a room.
impression: a strong effect produced on the intellect, feelings, conscience, etc.
immoral: violating moral principles; not conforming to the patterns of conduct usually accepted or established as consistent with principles of personal and social ethics.
evil: morally wrong or bad; immoral; wicked: evil deeds; an evil life.
habit: an acquired behavior pattern regularly followed until it has become almost involuntary: the habit of looking both ways before crossing the street.
practice: habitual or customary performance; operation: office practice.
failing: an act or instance of failing; failure: His failing is due to general incompetence.
foible: a minor weakness or failing of character; slight flaw or defect: an all-too-human foible.
weakness: the state or quality of being weak; lack of strength, firmness, vigor, or the like; feebleness.
executive: a person or group of persons having administrative or supervisory authority in an organization.
modern: of or relating to present and recent time; not ancient or remote: modern city life.
republic: a state in which the supreme power rests in the body of citizens entitled to vote and is exercised by representatives chosen directly or indirectly by them.
divide: to separate into parts, groups, sections, etc.
fence: a barrier enclosing or bordering a field, yard, etc., usually made of posts and wire or wood, used to prevent entrance, to confine, or to mark a boundary.
friendly: characteristic of or befitting a friend; showing friendship: a friendly greeting.
club: a heavy stick, usually thicker at one end than at the other, suitable for use as a weapon; a cudgel.
treaty: a formal agreement between two or more states in reference to peace, alliance, commerce, or other international relations.
trunk: the main stem of a tree, as distinct from the branches and roots.
neck: the part of the body of an animal or human being that connects the head and the trunk.
brain: Anatomy, Zoology. the part of the central nervous system enclosed in the cranium of humans and other vertebrates, consisting of a soft, convoluted mass of gray and white matter and serving to control and coordinate the mental and physical actions.
nose: the part of the face or facial region in humans and certain animals that contains the nostrils and the organs of smell and functions as the usual passageway for air in respiration: in humans it is a prominence in the center of the face formed of bone and cartilage, serving also to modify or modulate the voice.
affiliated: being in close formal or informal association; related: a letter sent to all affiliated clubs; a radio network and its affiliated local stations.
union: the act of uniting two or more things.
determine: to settle or decide (a dispute, question, etc.) by an authoritative or conclusive decision.
adjudicate: to pronounce or decree by judicial sentence.
settle: to appoint, fix, or resolve definitely and conclusively; agree upon (as time, price, or conditions).
jurisdiction: the right, power, or authority to administer justice by hearing and determining controversies.
crime: an action or an instance of negligence that is deemed injurious to the public welfare or morals or to the interests of the state and that is legally prohibited.
achievement: something accomplished, especially by superior ability, special effort, great courage, etc.; a great or heroic deed: his remarkable achievements in art.
aim: to position or direct (a firearm, ball, arrow, rocket, etc.) so that, on firing or release, the discharged projectile will hit a target or travel along a certain path.
manifest: readily perceived by the eye or the understanding; evident; obvious; apparent; plain: a manifest error.
growing: becoming greater in quantity, size, extent, or intensity: growing discontent among industrial workers.
increase: to make greater, as in number, size, strength, or quality; augment; add to: to increase taxes.
anabolism: constructive metabolism; the synthesis in living organisms of more complex substances from simpler ones (opposed to catabolism).
catabolism: destructive metabolism; the breaking down in living organisms of more complex substances into simpler ones, with the release of energy (opposed to anabolism).
milieu: surroundings, especially of a social or cultural nature: a snobbish milieu.
originate: to take its origin or rise; begin; start; arise: The practice originated during the Middle Ages.
taper: to become smaller or thinner toward one end.
weapon: any instrument or device for use in attack or defense in combat, fighting, or war, as a sword, rifle, or cannon.
integrated: combining or coordinating separate elements so as to provide a harmonious, interrelated whole: an integrated plot; an integrated course of study.
repeated: done, made, or said again and again: repeated attempts.
correlative: so related that each implies or complements the other.
fill: to make full; put as much as can be held into: to fill a jar with water.
evenings: in or during the evening regularly: She worked days and studied evenings.
reading: the action or practice of a person who reads.
domain: a field of action, thought, influence, etc.: the domain of science.
kingdom: a state or government having a king or queen as its head.
locate: to identify or discover the place or location of: to locate the bullet wound.
happen: to take place; come to pass; occur: Something interesting is always happening in New York.
continue: to go on after suspension or interruption: The program continued after an intermission.
peace: the normal, nonwarring condition of a nation, group of nations, or the world.
lower: to cause to descend; let or put down: to lower a flag.
kitchen: a room or place equipped for cooking.
operating: used or engaged in performing operations: an operating surgeon.
pool: a small body of standing water; pond.
attach: to fasten or affix; join; connect: to attach a photograph to an application with a staple.
catching: tending to be transmitted from one person to another; contagious or infectious: a disease that is catching; His enthusiasm is catching.
holding: the act of a person or thing that holds.
obstruct: to block or close up with an obstacle; make difficult to pass: Debris obstructed the road.
entrance: an act of entering, as into a place or upon new duties.
shut: to put (a door, cover, etc.) in position to close or obstruct.
cry: to utter inarticulate sounds, especially of lamentation, grief, or suffering, usually with tears.
erect: upright in position or posture: to stand or sit erect.
vertical: being in a position or direction perpendicular to the plane of the horizon; upright; plumb.
thickness: the state or quality of being thick.
built: simple past tense and past participle of build.
bar: a relatively long, evenly shaped piece of some solid substance, as metal or wood, used as a guard or obstruction or for some mechanical purpose: the bars of a cage.
railing: a fencelike barrier composed of one or more horizontal rails supported by widely spaced uprights; balustrade.
conclusion: the end or close; final part.
curio: any unusual article, object of art, etc., valued as a curiosity.
file: a folder, cabinet, or other container in which papers, letters, etc., are arranged in convenient order for storage or reference.
hinge: a jointed device or flexible piece on which a door, gate, shutter, lid, or other attached part turns, swings, or moves.
according: agreeing: according voices raised in censure.
groove: a long, narrow cut or indentation in a surface, as the cut in a board to receive the tongue of another board (tongue-and-groove joint) a furrow, or a natural indentation on an organism.
low: situated, placed, or occurring not far above the ground, floor, or base: a low shelf.
deep: extending far down from the top or surface: a deep well; a deep valley.
apex: the tip, point, or vertex; summit.
acme: the highest point; summit; peak: The empire was at the acme of its power.
peak: the pointed top of a mountain or ridge.
vertex: the highest point of something; apex; summit; top: the vertex of a mountain.
cylinder: Geometry. a surface or solid bounded by two parallel planes and generated by a straight line moving parallel to the given planes and tracing a curve bounded by the planes and lying in a plane perpendicular or oblique to the given planes.
ship: a vessel, especially a large oceangoing one propelled by sails or engines.
carton: a cardboard or plastic box used typically for storage or shipping.
box: a container, case, or receptacle, usually rectangular, of wood, metal, cardboard, etc., and often with a lid or removable cover.
crate: a slatted wooden box or framework for packing, shopping, or storing fruit, furniture, glassware, crockery, etc.
slight: small in amount, degree, etc.: a slight increase; a slight odor.
bulge: a rounded projection, bend, or protruding part; protuberance; hump: a bulge in a wall.
staff: a group of persons, as employees, charged with carrying out the work of an establishment or executing some undertaking.
hoop: a circular band or ring of metal, wood, or other stiff material.
solely: as the only one or ones: solely responsible.
solitary: alone; without companions; unattended: a solitary passer-by.
copy: an imitation, reproduction, or transcript of an original: a copy of a famous painting.
ancient: of or in time long past, especially before the end of the Western Roman Empire a.d. 476: ancient history.
mark: a visible impression or trace on something, as a line, cut, dent, stain, or bruise: a small mark on his arm.
fictitious: created, taken, or assumed for the sake of concealment; not genuine; false: fictitious names.
complexity: the state or quality of being complex; intricacy: the complexity of urban life.
week: a period of seven successive days, usually understood as beginning with Sunday and ending with Saturday.
meaningful: full of meaning, significance, purpose, or value; purposeful; significant: a meaningful wink; a meaningful choice.
grouping: an act or process of placing in groups.
constitute: to compose; form: mortar constituted of lime and sand.
angry: feeling or showing anger or strong resentment (usually followed by at, with, or about): to be angry at the dean; to be angry about the snub.
disturbed: marked by symptoms of mental illness: a disturbed personality.
excellent: possessing outstanding quality or superior merit; remarkably good.
virtuous: conforming to moral and ethical principles; morally excellent; upright: Lead a virtuous life.
righteous: characterized by uprightness or morality: a righteous observance of the law.
pious: having or showing a dutiful spirit of reverence for God or an earnest wish to fulfill religious obligations.
acquainted: having personal knowledge as a result of study, experience, etc.; informed (usually followed by with): to be acquainted with law.
society: an organized group of persons associated together for religious, benevolent, cultural, scientific, political, patriotic, or other purposes.
taxon: a taxonomic category, as a species or genus.
vagina: the passage leading from the uterus to the vulva in certain female mammals. Compare oviduct.
uterus: the enlarged, muscular, expandable portion of the oviduct in which the fertilized ovum implants and develops or rests during prenatal development; the womb of certain mammals.
puberty: the period or age at which a person is first capable of sexual reproduction of offspring: in common law, presumed to be 14 years in the male and 12 years in the female.
rounded: reduced to simple curves; made round.
beardless: having no beard or one shaved close to the skin.
big: large, as in size, height, width, or amount: a big house; a big quantity.
associate: to connect or bring into relation, as thought, feeling, memory, etc.: Many people associate dark clouds with depression and gloom.
tract: an expanse or area of land, water, etc.; region; stretch.
district: a division of territory, as of a country, state, or county, marked off for administrative, electoral, or other purposes.
oneness: the quality of being one; singleness.
search: to go or look through (a place, area, etc.) carefully in order to find something missing or lost: They searched the woods for the missing child. I searched the desk for the letter.
quest: a search or pursuit made in order to find or obtain something: a quest for uranium mines; a quest for knowledge.
political: of, relating to, or concerned with politics: political writers.
administration: the management of any office, business, or organization; direction.
civilized: having an advanced or humane culture, society, etc.
preparation: a proceeding, measure, or provision by which one prepares for something: preparations for a journey.
cacao: a small tropical American evergreen tree, Theobroma cacao, cultivated for its seeds, the source of cocoa, chocolate, etc.
vanilla: any tropical, climbing orchid of the genus Vanilla, especially V. planifolia, bearing podlike fruit yielding an extract used in flavoring food, in perfumery, etc.
flavor: taste, especially the distinctive taste of something as it is experienced in the mouth.
honey: a sweet, viscid fluid produced by bees from the nectar collected from flowers, and stored in nests or hives as food.
bake: to cook by dry heat in an oven or on heated metal or stones.
lard: the rendered fat of hogs, especially the internal fat of the abdomen.
fat: having too much flabby tissue; corpulent; obese: a fat person.
pastry: a sweet baked food made of dough, especially the shortened paste used for pie crust and the like.
bread: a kind of food made of flour or meal that has been mixed with milk or water, made into a dough or batter, with or without yeast or other leavening agent, and baked.
finely: in a fine manner; excellently; elegantly; delicately; minutely; nicely; subtly.
grain: a small, hard seed, especially the seed of a food plant such as wheat, corn, rye, oats, rice, or millet.
finer: of or relating to a topology or a topological space whose open sets include all the open sets of a second specified topology on the space.
cane: a stick or short staff used to assist one in walking; walking stick.
reduced: that is or has been reduced.
loose: free or released from fastening or attachment: a loose end.
disintegration: the act or process of disintegrating.
hydroxide: a chemical compound containing the hydroxyl group.
egg: the roundish reproductive body produced by the female of certain animals, as birds and most reptiles, consisting of an ovum and its envelope of albumen, jelly, membranes, egg case, or shell, according to species.
feature: a prominent or conspicuous part or characteristic: Tall buildings were a new feature on the skyline.
trait: a distinguishing characteristic or quality, especially of one's personal nature: bad traits of character.
kindly: having, showing, or proceeding from a benevolent disposition or spirit; kindhearted: kindly people.
attitude: manner, disposition, feeling, position, etc., with regard to a person or thing; tendency or orientation, especially of the mind: a negative attitude; group attitudes.
smile: to assume a facial expression indicating pleasure, favor, or amusement, but sometimes derision or scorn, characterized by an upturning of the corners of the mouth.
predominant: having ascendancy, power, authority, or influence over others; preeminent.
tendency: a natural or prevailing disposition to move, proceed, or act in some direction or toward some point, end, or result: the tendency of falling bodies toward the earth.
emotional: pertaining to or involving emotion or the emotions.
mood: a state or quality of feeling at a particular time: What's the boss' mood today?
pleasant: pleasing, agreeable, or enjoyable; giving pleasure: pleasant news.
love: a profoundly tender, passionate affection for another person.
affectionate: showing, indicating, or characterized by affection or love; fondly tender: an affectionate embrace.
fond: having a liking or affection for (usually followed by of): to be fond of animals.
key: a small metal instrument specially cut to fit into a lock and move its bolt.
concern: to relate to; be connected with; be of interest or importance to; affect: The water shortage concerns us all.
curiosity: the desire to learn or know about anything; inquisitiveness.
engaged: busy or occupied; involved: deeply engaged in conversation.
undistinguished: having no distinguishing marks or features.
individuality: the particular character, or aggregate of qualities, that distinguishes one person or thing from others; sole and personal nature: a person of marked individuality.
unusual: not usual, common, or ordinary; uncommon in amount or degree; exceptional: an unusual sound; an unusual hobby; an unusual response.
approximate: near or approaching a certain state, condition, goal, or standard.
method: a procedure, technique, or way of doing something, especially in accordance with a definite plan: There are three possible methods of repairing this motor.
computation: an act, process, or method of computing; calculation.
elementary: pertaining to or dealing with elements, rudiments, or first principles: an elementary grammar.
mathematics: (used with a singular verb) the systematic treatment of magnitude, relationships between figures and forms, and relations between quantities expressed symbolically.
intention: an act or instance of determining mentally upon some action or result.
intend: to have in mind as something to be done or brought about; plan: We intend to leave in a month.
meant: simple past tense and past participle of mean1 .
compliment: an expression of praise, commendation, or admiration: A sincere compliment boosts one's morale.
game: an amusement or pastime: children's games.
heads: (of a coin) with the top, or obverse, facing up: On the first toss, the coin came up heads.
hit: to deal a blow or stroke to: Hit the nail with the hammer.
ball: a spherical or approximately spherical body or shape; sphere: He rolled the piece of paper into a ball.
hole: an opening through something; gap; aperture: a hole in the roof; a hole in my sock.
few: not many but more than one: Few artists live luxuriously.
possible: that may or can be, exist, happen, be done, be used, etc.: a disease with no possible cure.
soup: a liquid food made by boiling or simmering meat, fish, or vegetables with various added ingredients.
academic: of or relating to a college, academy, school, or other educational institution, especially one for higher education: academic requirements.
lasting: continuing or enduring a long time; permanent; durable: a lasting friendship.
arrival: an act of arriving; a coming: His arrival was delayed by traffic.
advent: a coming into place, view, or being; arrival: the advent of the holiday season.
mistake: an error in action, calculation, opinion, or judgment caused by poor reasoning, carelessness, insufficient knowledge, etc.
stroke: the act or an instance of striking, as with the fist, a weapon, or a hammer; a blow.
proportion: comparative relation between things or magnitudes as to size, quantity, number, etc.; ratio.
detached: not attached; separated: a detached ticket stub.
scattered: distributed or occurring at widely spaced and usually irregular intervals: scattered villages; scattered showers.
vase: a vessel, as of glass, porcelain, earthenware, or metal, usually higher than it is wide, used chiefly to hold cut flowers or for decoration.
compose: to make or form by combining things, parts, or elements: He composed his speech from many research notes.
porch: an exterior appendage to a building, forming a covered approach or vestibule to a doorway.
