protein: Biochemistry. any of numerous, highly varied organic molecules constituting a large portion of the mass of every life form and necessary in the diet of all animals and other nonphotosynthesizing organisms, composed of 20 or more amino acids linked in a genetically controlled linear sequence into one or more long polypeptide chains, the final shape and other properties of each protein being determined by the side chains of the amino acids and their chemical attachments: proteins include such specialized forms as collagen for supportive tissue, hemoglobin for transport, antibodies for immune defense, and enzymes for metabolism.
gelatin: a nearly transparent, faintly yellow, odorless, and almost tasteless glutinous substance obtained by boiling in water the ligaments, bones, skin, etc., of animals, and forming the basis of jellies, glues, and the like.
adhesive: coated with glue, paste, mastic, or other sticky substance: adhesive bandages.
vista: a view or prospect, especially one seen through a long, narrow avenue or passage, as between rows of trees or houses.
pain: physical suffering or distress, as due to injury, illness, etc.
tooth: (in most vertebrates) one of the hard bodies or processes usually attached in a row to each jaw, serving for the prehension and mastication of food, as weapons of attack or defense, etc., and in mammals typically composed chiefly of dentin surrounding a sensitive pulp and covered on the crown with enamel.
linear: of, consisting of, or using lines: linear design.
decide: to solve or conclude (a question, controversy, or struggle) by giving victory to one side: The judge decided the case in favor of the plaintiff.
outside: the outer side, surface, or part; exterior: The outside of the house needs painting.
geometric: of or relating to geometry or to the principles of geometry.
avenue: a wide street or main thoroughfare.
dimension: a property of space; extension in a given direction: A straight line has one dimension, a parallelogram has two dimensions, and a parallelepiped has three dimensions.
width: extent from side to side; breadth; wideness.
clever: mentally bright; having sharp or quick intelligence; able.
tail: the hindmost part of an animal, especially that forming a distinct, flexible appendage to the trunk.
pave: to cover or lay (a road, walk, etc.) with concrete, stones, bricks, tiles, wood, or the like, so as to make a firm, level surface.
rural: of, relating to, or characteristic of the country, country life, or country people; rustic: rural tranquillity.
incorporated: formed or constituted as a legal corporation.
municipality: a city, town, or other district possessing corporate existence and usually its own local government.
exert: to put forth or into use, as power; exercise, as ability or influence; put into vigorous action: to exert every effort.
slice: a thin, flat piece cut from something: a slice of bread.
string: a slender cord or thick thread used for binding or tying; line.
twist: to combine, as two or more strands or threads, by winding together; intertwine.
braid: to weave together strips or strands of; plait: to braid the hair.
strand: to drive or leave (a ship, fish, etc.) aground or ashore: The receding tide stranded the whale.
linum: any of numerous plants of the genus Linum, including flax, L. usitatissimum, and various other species grown as ornamentals.
slender: having a circumference that is small in proportion to the height or length: a slender post.
annual: of, for, or pertaining to a year; yearly: annual salary.
narrow: of little breadth or width; not broad or wide; not as wide as usual or expected: a narrow path.
lance: a long wooden shaft with a pointed metal head, used as a weapon by knights and cavalry soldiers in charging.
cultivated: prepared and used for raising crops; tilled: cultivated land.
filament: a very fine thread or threadlike structure; a fiber or fibril: filaments of gold.
qualified: having the qualities, accomplishments, etc., that fit a person for some function, office, or the like.
lift: to move or bring (something) upward from the ground or other support to a higher position; hoist.
travel: to go from one place to another, as by car, train, plane, or ship; take a trip; journey: to travel for pleasure.
vote: a formal expression of opinion or choice, either positive or negative, made by an individual or body of individuals.
mentally: in or with the mind or intellect; intellectually.
aptitude: capability; ability; innate or acquired capacity for something; talent: She has a special aptitude for mathematics.
carpentry: the trade of a carpenter: He earned his living at carpentry.
answer: a spoken or written reply or response to a question, request, letter, etc.: He sent an answer to my letter promptly.
explain: to make plain or clear; render understandable or intelligible: to explain an obscure point.
mystery: anything that is kept secret or remains unexplained or unknown: the mysteries of nature.
missing: absent, not found, or lost: a missing person.
difficulty: the fact or condition of being difficult.
ease: freedom from labor, pain, or physical annoyance; tranquil rest; comfort: to enjoy one's ease.
traffic: the movement of vehicles, ships, persons, etc., in an area, along a street, through an air lane, over a water route, etc.: the heavy traffic on Main Street.
reliability: the ability to be relied on or depended on, as for accuracy, honesty, or achievement.
recognize: to identify as something or someone previously seen, known, etc.: He had changed so much that one could scarcely recognize him.
socialism: a theory or system of social organization that advocates the vesting of the ownership and control of the means of production and distribution, of capital, land, etc., in the community as a whole.
communism: a theory or system of social organization based on the holding of all property in common, actual ownership being ascribed to the community as a whole or to the state.
pipe: a hollow cylinder of metal, wood, or other material, used for the conveyance of water, gas, steam, petroleum, etc.
compressed: pressed into less space; condensed: compressed gases.
sphere: The decision was, instead, an intervention by a force of order into a sphere of mounting (and potentially catastrophic) disorder.
poised: (of a person) composed, dignified, and self-assured.
ordeal: any extremely severe or trying test, experience, or trial.
elliptical: pertaining to or having the form of an ellipse.
planet: Michael was the single greatest donor to charities of any man on the planet in history.
satellite: Astronomy. a natural body that revolves around a planet; a moon.
celestial: pertaining to the sky or visible heaven, or to the universe beyond the earth’s atmosphere, as in celestial body.
framework: a skeletal structure designed to support or enclose something.
skeleton: Anatomy, Zoology. the bones of a human or an animal considered as a whole, together forming the framework of the body.
appear: to come into sight; become visible: A man suddenly appeared in the doorway.
compact: joined or packed together; closely and firmly united; dense; solid: compact soil.
forest: a large tract of land covered with trees and underbrush; woodland.
curve: a continuously bending line, without angles.
pliable: easily bent; flexible; supple: pliable leather.
layer: a thickness of some material laid on or spread over a surface: a layer of soot on the window sill; two layers of paint.
vegetable: any plant whose fruit, seeds, roots, tubers, bulbs, stems, leaves, or flower parts are used as food, as the tomato, bean, beet, potato, onion, asparagus, spinach, or cauliflower.
tissue: Biology. an aggregate of similar cells and cell products forming a definite kind of structural material with a specific function, in a multicellular organism.
eyeball: the ball or globe of the eye.
round: having a flat, circular surface, as a disk.
tower: a building or structure high in proportion to its lateral dimensions, either isolated or forming part of a building.
contractile: capable of contracting or causing contraction.
diaphragm: The blade pierced his liver and diaphragm, missing his heart and aorta by a fraction of an inch.
darkness: the state or quality of being dark: The room was in total darkness.
obscurity: the state or quality of being obscure.
anterior: situated before or at the front of; fore (opposed to posterior).
geometry: the branch of mathematics that deals with the deduction of the properties, measurement, and relationships of points, lines, angles, and figures in space from their defining conditions by means of certain assumed properties of space.
circumference: the outer boundary, especially of a circular area; perimeter: the circumference of a circle.
polygon: a figure, especially a closed plane figure, having three or more, usually straight, sides.
learning: knowledge acquired by systematic study in any field of scholarly application.
supervision: the act or function of supervising; superintendence.
school: an institution where instruction is given, especially to persons under college age: The children are at school.
tutor: a person employed to instruct another in some branch or branches of learning, especially a private instructor.
student: a person formally engaged in learning, especially one enrolled in a school or college; pupil: a student at Yale.
posterior: situated behind or at the rear of; hinder (opposed to anterior).
lens: a piece of transparent substance, usually glass, having two opposite surfaces either both curved or one curved and one plane, used in an optical device in changing the convergence of light rays, as for magnification, or in correcting defects of vision.
optic: of or relating to the eye or sight.
nerve: one or more bundles of fibers forming part of a system that conveys impulses of sensation, motion, etc., between the brain or spinal cord and other parts of the body.
sensitive: endowed with sensation; having perception through the senses.
assembled: noting an artificial gem formed of two or more parts, as a doublet or triplet, at least one of which is a true gemstone.
substitute: a person or thing acting or serving in place of another.
temporary: lasting, existing, serving, or effective for a time only; not permanent: a temporary need; a temporary job.
mayor: the chief executive official, usually elected, of a city, village, or town.
protest: an expression or declaration of objection, disapproval, or dissent, often in opposition to something a person is powerless to prevent or avoid: a protest against increased taxation.
arrange: to place in proper, desired, or convenient order; adjust properly: to arrange books on a shelf.
boss: a person who employs or superintends workers; manager.
achieve: to bring to a successful end; carry through; accomplish: The police crackdown on speeders achieved its purpose.
victory: a success or triumph over an enemy in battle or war.
impulse: the influence of a particular feeling, mental state, etc.: to act under a generous impulse; to strike out at someone from an angry impulse.
premeditation: an act or instance of premeditating.
burst: to break, break open, or fly apart with sudden violence: The bitter cold caused the pipes to burst.
applause: hand clapping as a demonstration of approval, appreciation, acclamation, or the like.
expression: the act of expressing or setting forth in words: the free expression of political opinions.
aesthetic: relating to the philosophy of aesthetics; concerned with notions such as the beautiful and the ugly.
appealing: evoking or attracting interest, desire, curiosity, sympathy, or the like; attractive.
third: next after the second; being the ordinal number for three.
greek: of or relating to Greece, the Greeks, or their language.
cosmos: the world or universe regarded as an orderly, harmonious system.
generate: to bring into existence; cause to be; produce.
moderate: kept or keeping within reasonable or proper limits; not extreme, excessive, or intense: a moderate price.
disperse: to drive or send off in various directions; scatter: to disperse a crowd.
emit: to send forth (liquid, light, heat, sound, particles, etc.); discharge.
hotel: a commercial establishment offering lodging to travelers and sometimes to permanent residents, and often having restaurants, meeting rooms, stores, etc., that are available to the general public.
ready: completely prepared or in fit condition for immediate action or use: troops ready for battle; Dinner is ready.
chew: to crush or grind with the teeth; masticate.
pension: a fixed amount, other than wages, paid at regular intervals to a person or to the person's surviving dependents in consideration of past services, age, merit, poverty, injury or loss sustained, etc.: a retirement pension.
rapidity: a rapid state or quality; quickness; celerity.
prompt: done, performed, delivered, etc., at once or without delay: a prompt reply.
beam: any of various relatively long pieces of metal, wood, stone, etc., manufactured or shaped especially for use as rigid members or parts of structures or machines.
inspect: to look carefully at or over; view closely and critically: to inspect every part of the motor.
scrutinize: to examine in detail with careful or critical attention.
prospective: of or in the future: prospective earnings.
similarity: the state of being similar; likeness; resemblance.
fabric: a cloth made by weaving, knitting, or felting fibers: woolen fabrics.
felting: felted material, either woven or felt fabric.
wool: the fine, soft, curly hair that forms the fleece of sheep and certain other animals, characterized by minute, overlapping surface scales that give it its felting property.
hair: any of the numerous fine, usually cylindrical, keratinous filaments growing from the skin of humans and animals; a pilus.
silk: the soft, lustrous fiber obtained as a filament from the cocoon of the silkworm.
cotton: a soft, white, downy substance consisting of the hairs or fibers attached to the seeds of plants belonging to the genus Gossypium, of the mallow family, used in making fabrics, thread, wadding, etc.
electric: pertaining to, derived from, produced by, or involving electricity: an electric shock.
claude: Albert, 1899–1983, U.S. biologist, born in Belgium: Nobel Prize in Medicine 1974.
comedian: a professional entertainer who amuses by relating anecdotes, acting out comical situations, engaging in humorous repartee, etc.
magnitude: size; extent; dimensions: to determine the magnitude of an angle.
bulk: magnitude in three dimensions: a ship of great bulk.
farm: a tract of land, usually with a house, barn, silo, etc., on which crops and often livestock are raised for livelihood.
caught: simple past tense and past participle of catch.
paste: a mixture of flour and water, often with starch or the like, used for causing paper or other material to adhere to something.
define: to state or set forth the meaning of (a word, phrase, etc.): They disagreed on how to define “liberal.”.
triangle: a closed plane figure having three sides and three angles.
setting: the act of a person or thing that sets.
resonant: resounding or echoing, as sounds: the resonant thundering of cannons being fired.
sonorous: giving out or capable of giving out a sound, especially a deep, resonant sound, as a thing or place: a sonorous cavern.
meat: the flesh of animals as used for food.
brig: Manning was forced to strip and remain on a suicide-risk regime against the recommendations of brig mental-health professionals.
stimulate: to rouse to action or effort, as by encouragement or pressure; spur on; incite: to stimulate his interest in mathematics.
sense: any of the faculties, as sight, hearing, smell, taste, or touch, by which humans and animals perceive stimuli originating from outside or inside the body: My sense of smell tells me that dinner is ready.
honest: honorable in principles, intentions, and actions; upright and fair: an honest person.
fair: free from bias, dishonesty, or injustice: a fair decision; a fair judge.
bias: a particular tendency, trend, inclination, feeling, or opinion, especially one that is preconceived or unreasoned: illegal bias against older job applicants; the magazine’s bias toward art rather than photography; our strong bias in favor of the idea.
injustice: the quality or fact of being unjust; inequity.
admit: to allow to enter; grant or afford entrance to: to admit a student to college.
adherence: the quality of adhering; steady devotion, support, allegiance, or attachment: adherence to a party; rigid adherence to rules.
ethical: pertaining to or dealing with morals or the principles of morality; pertaining to right and wrong in conduct.
moment: an indefinitely short period of time; instant: I'll be with you in a moment.
dictionary: a book, optical disc, mobile device, or online lexical resource (such as Dictionary.com) containing a selection of the words of a language, giving information about their meanings, pronunciations, etymologies, inflected forms, derived forms, etc., expressed in either the same or another language; lexicon; glossary. Print dictionaries of various sizes, ranging from small pocket dictionaries to multivolume books, usually sort entries alphabetically, as do typical CD or DVD dictionary applications, allowing one to browse through the terms in sequence. All electronic dictionaries, whether online or installed on a device, can provide immediate, direct access to a search term, its meanings, and ancillary information: an unabridged dictionary of English; a Japanese-English dictionary.
inhabitant: a person or animal that inhabits a place, especially as a permanent resident.
scotland: a division of the United Kingdom in the N part of Great Britain. 30,412 sq. mi. (78,772 sq. km). Capital:  Edinburgh.
wales: a division of the United Kingdom, in SW Great Britain. 8016 sq. mi. (20,760 sq. km).
island: a tract of land completely surrounded by water, and not large enough to be called a continent.
london: Jack, 1876–1916, U.S. short-story writer and novelist.
institution: an organization, establishment, foundation, society, or the like, devoted to the promotion of a particular cause or program, especially one of a public, educational, or charitable character: This college is the best institution of its kind.
lay: to put or place in a horizontal position or position of rest; set down: to lay a book on a desk.
carrier: a person or thing that carries.
susceptible: admitting or capable of some specified treatment: susceptible of a high polish; susceptible to various interpretations.
accent: prominence of a syllable in terms of differential loudness, or of pitch, or length, or of a combination of these.
bird: any warm-blooded vertebrate of the class Aves, having a body covered with feathers, forelimbs modified into wings, scaly legs, a beak, and no teeth, and bearing young in a hard-shelled egg.
interrupted: having an irregular or discontinuous arrangement, as of leaflets along a stem.
naturally: in a natural or normal manner.
orange: a globose, reddish-yellow, bitter or sweet, edible citrus fruit.
oral: uttered by the mouth; spoken: oral testimony.
gesture: a movement or position of the hand, arm, body, head, or face that is expressive of an idea, opinion, emotion, etc.: the gestures of an orator; a threatening gesture.
isolated: separated from other persons or things; alone; solitary.
humanity: all human beings collectively; the human race; humankind.
phonetics: Compare acoustic phonetics, articulatory phonetics, auditory phonetics, physiological phonetics.
phonetic: Also, phonetical. of or relating to speech sounds, their production, or their transcription in written symbols.
apparent: readily seen; exposed to sight; open to view; visible: The crack in the wall was readily apparent.
toy: an object, often a small representation of something familiar, as an animal or person, for children or others to play with; plaything.
boil: to change from a liquid to a gaseous state, producing bubbles of gas that rise to the surface of the liquid, agitating it as they rise.
enclosure: something that encloses, as a fence or wall.
shall: plan to, intend to, or expect to: I shall go later.
leather: the skin of an animal, with the hair removed, prepared for use by tanning or a similar process designed to preserve it against decay and make it pliable or supple when dry.
lace: a netlike ornamental fabric made of threads by hand or machine.
embroidery: the art of working raised and ornamental designs in threads of silk, cotton, gold, silver, or other material, upon any woven fabric, leather, paper, etc., with a needle.
quell: to suppress; put an end to; extinguish: The troops quelled the rebellion quickly.
crush: to press or squeeze with a force that destroys or deforms.
revolt: to break away from or rise against constituted authority, as by open rebellion; cast off allegiance or subjection to those in authority; rebel; mutiny: to revolt against the present government.
congress: this body as it exists for a period of two years during which it has the same membership: the Ninety-Seventh Congress.
law: the principles and regulations established in a community by some authority and applicable to its people, whether in the form of legislation or of custom and policies recognized and enforced by judicial decision.
factor: one of the elements contributing to a particular result or situation: Poverty is only one of the factors in crime.
judge: a public officer authorized to hear and decide cases in a court of law; a magistrate charged with the administration of justice.
considering: taking into account; in view of: The campaign was a great success, considering the strong opposition.
enter: to come or go in: Knock before you enter.
hostility: a hostile state, condition, or attitude; enmity; antagonism; unfriendliness.
disturbing: upsetting or disquieting; dismaying: a disturbing increase in the crime rate.
powerful: having or exerting great power or force.
engine: a machine for converting thermal energy into mechanical energy or power to produce force and motion.
motorboat: a boat propelled by an inboard or outboard motor.
liable: legally responsible: You are liable for the damage caused by your action.
yield: to give forth or produce by a natural process or in return for cultivation: This farm yields enough fruit to meet all our needs.
break: to smash, split, or divide into parts violently; reduce to pieces or fragments: He broke a vase.
collapse: to fall or cave in; crumble suddenly: The roof collapsed and buried the crowd.
strain: to draw tight or taut, especially to the utmost tension; stretch to the full: to strain a rope.
fragile: easily broken, shattered, or damaged; delicate; brittle; frail: a fragile ceramic container; a very fragile alliance.
fortress: a large fortified place; a fort or group of forts, often including a town; citadel.
armor: any covering worn as a defense against weapons.
age: the length of time during which a being or thing has existed; length of life or existence to the time spoken of or referred to: trees of unknown age; His age is 20 years.
fundamental: serving as, or being an essential part of, a foundation or basis; basic; underlying: fundamental principles; the fundamental structure.
corporation: See also municipal corporation, public corporation.
healthy: possessing or enjoying good health or a sound and vigorous mentality: a healthy body; a healthy mind.
hardy: capable of enduring fatigue, hardship, exposure, etc.; sturdy; strong: hardy explorers of northern Canada.
unhealthy: not in a state of good or normal health; in an unsound, weak, or morbid condition.
smell: to perceive the odor or scent of through the nose by means of the olfactory nerves; inhale the odor of: I smell something burning.
specialist: a person who devotes himself or herself to one subject or to one particular branch of a subject or pursuit.
chest: Anatomy. the trunk of the body from the neck to the abdomen; thorax.
fortune: position in life as determined by wealth: to make one's fortune.
happiness: the quality or state of being happy.
prosperity: a successful, flourishing, or thriving condition, especially in financial respects; good fortune.
distress: great pain, anxiety, or sorrow; acute physical or mental suffering; affliction; trouble.
danger: liability or exposure to harm or injury; risk; peril.
felt: simple past tense and past participle of feel.
job: a piece of work, especially a specific task done as part of the routine of one's occupation or for an agreed price: She gave him the job of mowing the lawn.
undesirable: not desirable or attractive; objectionable: undesirable qualities.
unfortunate: suffering from bad luck: an unfortunate person.
harm: physical injury or mental damage; hurt: to do him bodily harm.
casualty: Saul is out—a casualty of Lockhart's new regime—but he'll almost certainly get roped back in.
leap: to spring through the air from one point or position to another; jump: to leap over a ditch.
dart: a small, slender missile that is pointed at one end and usually feathered at the other and is propelled by hand, as in the game of darts, or by a blowgun when used as a weapon.
forward: toward or at a place, point, or time in advance; onward; ahead: to move forward; from this day forward; to look forward.
outward: proceeding or directed toward the outside or exterior, or away from a central point: the outward flow of gold; the outward part of a voyage.
constrained: forced, compelled, or obliged: a constrained confession.
tiger: a large, carnivorous, tawny-colored and black-striped feline, Panthera tigris, of Asia, ranging in several subspecies from India and the Malay Peninsula to Siberia: the entire species is endangered, with some subspecies thought to be extinct.
chair: a seat, especially for one person, usually having four legs for support and a rest for the back and often having rests for the arms.
onward: toward a point ahead or in front; forward, as in space or time.
issue: the act of sending out or putting forth; promulgation; distribution: the issue of food and blankets to flood victims.
utterly: in an utter manner; completely; absolutely.
caution: alertness and prudence in a hazardous situation; care; wariness: Landslides ahead—proceed with caution.
careless: not paying enough attention to what one does: a careless typist.
demanding: requiring or claiming more than is generally felt by others to be due: a demanding teacher.
unreasonable: not reasonable or rational; acting at variance with or contrary to reason; not guided by reason or sound judgment; irrational: an unreasonable person.
expose: to lay open to danger, attack, harm, etc.: to expose soldiers to gunfire; to expose one's character to attack.
closed: having or forming a boundary or barrier: He was blocked by a closed door. The house had a closed porch.
barred: provided with one or more bars: a barred prison window.
doorway: the passage or opening into a building, room, etc., commonly closed and opened by a door; portal.
sash: a long band or scarf worn over one shoulder or around the waist, as by military officers as a part of the uniform or by women and children for ornament.
gateway: an entrance or passage that may be closed by a gate.
gate: a movable barrier, usually on hinges, closing an opening in a fence, wall, or other enclosure.
obscure: (of meaning) not clear or plain; ambiguous, vague, or uncertain: an obscure sentence in the contract.
beneath: below; in or to a lower place, position, state, or the like.
bed: a piece of furniture upon which or within which a person sleeps, rests, or stays when not well.
heavenly: of or in the heavens: the heavenly bodies.
moon: the earth's natural satellite, orbiting the earth at a mean distance of 238,857 miles (384,393 km) and having a diameter of 2160 miles (3476 km).
hut: a small or humble dwelling of simple construction, especially one made of natural materials, as of logs or grass.
ring: a typically circular band of metal or other durable material, especially one of gold or other precious metal, often set with gems, for wearing on the finger as an ornament, a token of betrothal or marriage, etc.
surround: to enclose on all sides; encompass: She was surrounded by reporters.
crowd: a large number of persons gathered closely together; throng: a crowd of angry people.
equatorial: of, relating to, or near an equator, especially the equator of the earth.
polar: of or relating to the North or South Pole.
revolution: an overthrow or repudiation and the thorough replacement of an established government or political system by the people governed.
nelson: a hold in which pressure is applied to the head, back of the neck, and one or both arms of the opponent.
appleton: Sir Edward Victor, 1892–1965, British physicist: Nobel Prize 1947.
illness: unhealthy condition; poor health; indisposition; sickness.
unrest: lack of rest; a restless, troubled, or uneasy state; disquiet: the unrest within himself.

outermost: farthest out; remotest from the interior or center: the outermost limits.

pillow: a bag or case made of cloth that is filled with feathers, down, or other soft material, and is used to cushion the head during sleep or rest.
bent: curved; crooked: a bent bow; a bent stick.
breaking: Phonology. the change of a pure vowel to a diphthong, especially in certain environments, as, in Old English, the change of a vowel to a diphthong under the influence of a following consonant or combination of consonants, as the change of -a- to -ea- and of -e- to -eo- before preconsonantal r or l and before h, as in earm “arm” developed from arm, and eorthe “earth” from erthe.
serious: of, showing, or characterized by deep thought.
drought: a period of dry weather, especially a long one that is injurious to crops.
surety: security against loss or damage or for the fulfillment of an obligation, the payment of a debt, etc.; a pledge, guaranty, or bond.
confidence: full trust; belief in the powers, trustworthiness, or reliability of a person or thing: We have every confidence in their ability to succeed.
error: a deviation from accuracy or correctness; a mistake, as in action or speech: His speech contained several factual errors.
defect: a shortcoming, fault, or imperfection: a defect in an argument; a defect in a machine.
observation: an act or instance of noticing or perceiving.
inquiry: a seeking or request for truth, information, or knowledge.
conference: a meeting for consultation or discussion: a conference between a student and his adviser.
patient: a person who is under medical care or treatment.
safe: secure from liability to harm, injury, danger, or risk: a safe place.
return: to go or come back, as to a former place, position, or state: to return from abroad; to return to public office; to return to work.
sunny: abounding in sunshine: a sunny day.
chromosome: any of several threadlike bodies, consisting of chromatin, that carry the genes in a linear order: the human species has 23 pairs, designated 1 to 22 in order of decreasing size and X and Y for the female and male sex chromosomes respectively.
penis: the male organ of copulation and, in mammals, of urinary excretion.
scrotum: the pouch of skin that contains the testes.
adolescence: the transitional period between puberty and adulthood in human development, extending mainly over the teen years and terminating legally when the age of majority is reached; youth.
discuss: to consider or examine by argument, comment, etc.; talk over or write about, especially to explore solutions; debate: to discuss the proposed law on taxes.
battle: a hostile encounter or engagement between opposing military forces: the battle of Waterloo.
progenitor: a biologically related ancestor: a progenitor of the species.
met: simple past tense and past participle of meet1 .
sister: a female offspring having both parents in common with another offspring; female sibling.
unfavorable: not favorable; contrary; adverse: an unfavorable wind.
criticism: the act of passing judgment as to the merits of anything.
nine: a cardinal number, eight plus one.
dislike: to regard with displeasure, antipathy, or aversion: I dislike working. I dislike oysters.
aversion: a strong feeling of dislike, opposition, repugnance, or antipathy (usually followed by to): a strong aversion to snakes and spiders.
foster: to promote the growth or development of; further; encourage: to foster new ideas.
injurious: harmful, hurtful, or detrimental, as in effect: injurious eating habits.
design: to prepare the preliminary sketch or the plans for (a work to be executed), especially to plan the form and structure of: to design a new bridge.
foe: a person who feels enmity, hatred, or malice toward another; enemy: a bitter foe.
controversy: a prolonged public dispute, debate, or contention; disputation concerning a matter of opinion.
ascertain: to find out definitely; learn with certainty or assurance; determine: to ascertain the facts.
apportion: to distribute or allocate proportionally; divide and assign according to some rule of proportional distribution: to apportion expenses among the three men.
speed: rapidity in moving, going, traveling, proceeding, or performing; swiftness; celerity: the speed of light; the speed of sound.
riding: the act of a person or thing that rides.
propagate: to cause (an organism) to multiply by any process of natural reproduction from the parent stock.
chain: a series of objects connected one after the other, usually in the form of a series of metal rings passing through one another, used either for various purposes requiring a flexible tie with high tensile strength, as for hauling, supporting, or confining, or in various ornamental and decorative forms.
grow: to increase by natural development, as any living organism or part by assimilation of nutriment; increase in size or substance.
moisture: condensed or diffused liquid, especially water: moisture in the air.
ranking: senior or superior in rank, position, etc.: a ranking diplomat.
below: in or toward a lower place: Look out below!
lieutenant: He then beat a very popular and savvy Democrat John Sharp in a razor-close race for lieutenant governor in 1998.
colonel: an officer in the U.S. Army, Air Force, or Marine Corps ranking between lieutenant colonel and brigadier general: corresponding to a captain in the U.S. Navy.
captain: a person who is at the head of or in authority over others; chief; leader.
aspect: appearance to the eye or mind; look: the physical aspect of the country.
vary: to change or alter, as in form, appearance, character, or substance: to vary one's methods.
reflexive: His reflexive impulse in the moments after the blast had been to stand even though he had lost both his legs.
battery: Surely Congress would say, "No aircraft should crash because of battery fires."
oscillate: to swing or move to and fro, as a pendulum does.
trip: a journey or voyage: to win a trip to Paris.
creation: the act of producing or causing to exist; the act of creating; engendering.
manufacture: the making of goods or wares by manual labor or by machinery, especially on a large scale: the manufacture of television sets.
buy: to acquire the possession of, or the right to, by paying or promising to pay an equivalent, especially in money; purchase.
king: a male sovereign or monarch; a man who holds by life tenure, and usually by hereditary right, the chief authority over a country and people.
sovereign: a monarch; a king, queen, or other supreme ruler.
palace: the official residence of a king, queen, bishop, or other sovereign or exalted personage.
rule: a principle or regulation governing conduct, action, procedure, arrangement, etc.: the rules of chess.
wife: a married woman, especially when considered in relation to her partner in marriage.
punch: a thrusting blow, especially with the fist.
morris: Esther Hobart McQuigg Slack  [muh-kwig slak]  /məˈkwɪg ˈslæk/  (Show IPA), 1814–1902, U.S. suffragist.
philosopher: a person who offers views or theories on profound questions in ethics, metaphysics, logic, and other related fields.
russia: Also called Russian Empire. Russian Rossiya. a former empire in E Europe and N and W Asia: overthrown by the Russian Revolution 1917. Capital:  St. Petersburg (1703–1917).
forth: onward or outward in place or space; forward: to come forth; go forth.
composer: a person or thing that composes.
literary: pertaining to or of the nature of books and writings, especially those classed as literature: literary history.
translator: Also, translater. a person who translates.
editor: a person having managerial and sometimes policy-making responsibility related to the writing, compilation, and revision of content for a publishing firm or for a newspaper, magazine, or other publication: She was offered a managing editor position at a small press.
copyist: a person who transcribes copies, especially of documents.
involved: very intricate or complex: an involved reply.
planning: the act or process of making a plan or plans.
contact: the act or state of touching; a touching or meeting, as of two things or people.
staple: a short piece of wire bent so as to bind together papers, sections of a book, or the like, by driving the ends through the sheets and clinching them on the other side.
combine: to bring into or join in a close union or whole; unite: She combined the ingredients to make the cake. They combined the two companies.
incorporate: to form into a legal corporation.
secure: free from or not exposed to danger or harm; safe.
bond: something that binds, fastens, confines, or holds together.
chasm: a yawning fissure or deep cleft in the earth's surface; gorge.
sit: to rest with the body supported by the buttocks or thighs; be seated.
advance: to move or bring forward: The general advanced his troops to the new position.
pace: a rate of movement, especially in stepping, walking, etc.: to walk at a brisk pace of five miles an hour.
locomotion: the act or power of moving from place to place.
seattle: (Seatlh) c1790–1866, Suquamish leader: Seattle, Washington, named after him.
slab: a broad, flat, somewhat thick piece of stone, wood, or other solid material.
solution: the act of solving a problem, question, etc.: The situation is approaching solution.
occupation: a person's usual or principal work or business, especially as a means of earning a living; vocation: Her occupation was dentistry.
profession: a vocation requiring knowledge of some department of learning or science: the profession of teaching.
poultry: domesticated fowl collectively, especially those valued for their meat and eggs, as chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese, and guinea fowl.
farming: the business of operating a farm.
add: to unite or join so as to increase the number, quantity, size, or importance: to add two cups of sugar; to add a postscript to her letter; to add insult to injury.
promise: a declaration that something will or will not be done, given, etc., by one: unkept political promises.
height: extent or distance upward: The balloon stopped rising at a height of 500 feet.
stature: the height of a human or animal body.
drawing: the act of a person or thing that draws.
ink: a fluid or viscous substance used for writing or printing.

core: the central part of a fleshy fruit, containing the seeds.

graphite: a very common mineral, soft native carbon, occurring in black to dark-gray foliated masses, with metallic luster and greasy feel: used for pencil leads, as a lubricant, and for making crucibles and other refractories; plumbago; black lead.

radiation: The most fearful thing for us is to expose our children to the radiation.
krypton: an inert, monatomic gaseous element, present in very small amounts in the atmosphere: used in high-power, tungsten-filament light bulbs. Symbol:  Kr; atomic weight:  83.80; atomic number:  36.

mexico: a republic in S North America. 761,530 sq. mi. (1,972,363 sq. km). . Capital: Mexico City.
allowed: Physics. involving a change in quantum numbers, permitted by the selection rules: allowed transition.
grown: advanced in growth: a grown boy.
mature: complete in natural growth or development, as plant and animal forms: a mature rose bush.
real: true; not merely ostensible, nominal, or apparent: the real reason for an act.
tried: simple past tense and past participle of try.
base: the bottom support of anything; that on which a thing stands or rests: a metal base for the table.
offer: to present for acceptance or rejection; proffer: He offered me a cigarette.
inspection: the act of inspecting or viewing, especially carefully or critically: an inspection of all luggage on the plane.
charity: generous actions or donations to aid the poor, ill, or helpless: to devote one's life to charity.
variation: the act, process, or accident of varying in condition, character, or degree: Prices are subject to variation.

scene: the place where some action or event occurs: He returned to the scene of the murder.
foreground: the ground or parts situated, or represented as situated, in the front; the portion of a scene nearest to the viewer (opposed to background).
tone: any sound considered with reference to its quality, pitch, strength, source, etc.: shrill tones.
diatonic: noting those scales that contain five whole tones and two semitones, as the major, minor, and certain modal scales.
selection: an act or instance of selecting or the state of being selected; choice.
observable: capable of being or liable to be observed; noticeable; visible; discernible: an observable change in attitude.

month: Also called calendar month. any of the twelve parts, as January or February, into which the calendar year is divided.
european: of or relating to Europe or its inhabitants.
accord: to be in agreement or harmony; agree.
likely: probably or apparently destined (usually followed by an infinitive): something not likely to happen.

disadvantage: absence or deprivation of advantage or equality.
failure: an act or instance of failing or proving unsuccessful; lack of success: His effort ended in failure. The campaign was a failure.

advantage: any state, circumstance, opportunity, or means specially favorable to success, interest, or any desired end: the advantage of a good education.

yearly: pertaining to a year or to each year.
recurrence: an act or instance of recurring.
tenth: next after ninth; being the ordinal number for ten.
marriage: (broadly) any of the diverse forms of interpersonal union established in various parts of the world to form a familial bond that is recognized legally, religiously, or socially, granting the participating partners mutual conjugal rights and responsibilities and including, for example, opposite-sex marriage, same-sex marriage, plural marriage,  and arranged marriage:  Anthropologists say that some type of marriage has been found in every known human society since ancient times.
impaired: weakened, diminished, or damaged: impaired hearing; to rebuild an impaired bridge.
excess: the fact of exceeding something else in amount or degree: His strength is in excess of yours.

furnish: to supply (a house, room, etc.) with necessary furniture, carpets, appliances, etc.

stomach: Sara says Hubbard, while he was writing Dianetics, kicked her stomach several times to attempt to cause a miscarriage.

consume: to destroy or expend by use; use up.
tea: the dried and prepared leaves of a shrub, Camellia sinensis, from which a somewhat bitter, aromatic beverage is prepared by infusion in hot water.
ambiguous: open to or having several possible meanings or interpretations; equivocal: an ambiguous answer.

translucent: permitting light to pass through but diffusing it so that persons, objects, etc., on the opposite side are not clearly visible: Frosted window glass is translucent but not transparent.

breast: Anatomy, Zoology. (in bipeds) the outer, front part of the thorax, or the front part of the body from the neck to the abdomen; chest.
gland: The gland substance may be cut and freely dilated by the finger.
mammal: any vertebrate of the class Mammalia, having the body more or less covered with hair, nourishing the young with milk from the mammary glands, and, with the exception of the egg-laying monotremes, giving birth to live young.
nutriment: any substance or matter that, taken into a living organism, serves to sustain it in its existence, promoting growth, replacing loss, and providing energy.
rights: (used with a plural verb) civil rights.
old: far advanced in the years of one's or its life: an old man; an old horse; an old tree.
eating: the act of a person or thing that eats.
distinction: a marking off or distinguishing as different: His distinction of sounds is excellent.
healthful: conducive to health; wholesome or salutary: a healthful diet.
mourning: the act of a person who mourns; sorrowing or lamentation.

observance: an act or instance of following, obeying, or conforming to: the observance of traffic laws.

press: to act upon with steadily applied weight or force.
smacking: smart, brisk, or strong, as a breeze.
greeting: the act or words of a person who greets.
reverence: a feeling or attitude of deep respect tinged with awe; veneration.
son: a male child or person in relation to his parents.
cheek: either side of the face below the eye and above the jaw.
refute: to prove to be false or erroneous, as an opinion or charge.
conviction: a fixed or firm belief: No clever argument, no persuasive fact or theory could make a dent in his conviction in the rightness of his position.
permission: authorization granted to do something; formal consent: to ask permission to leave the room.
permit: to allow to do something: Permit me to explain.
absent: not in a certain place at a given time; away, missing (opposed to present): absent from class.
swimming: the act of a person or thing that swims.

flight: the act, manner, or power of flying.
bill: a statement of money owed for goods or services supplied: He paid the hotel bill when he checked out.
impetus: a moving force; impulse; stimulus: The grant for building the opera house gave impetus to the city's cultural life.
emotion: an affective state of consciousness in which joy, sorrow, fear, hate, or the like, is experienced, as distinguished from cognitive and volitional states of consciousness.
afraid: feeling fear; filled with apprehension: afraid to go.
apprehension: anticipation of adversity or misfortune; suspicion or fear of future trouble or evil.
consternation: a sudden, alarming amazement or dread that results in utter confusion; dismay.

fright: sudden and extreme fear; a sudden terror.

horror: an overwhelming and painful feeling caused by something frightfully shocking, terrifying, or revolting; a shuddering fear: to shrink back from a mutilated corpse in horror.
trepidation: tremulous fear, alarm, or agitation; perturbation.

champion: a person who has defeated all opponents in a competition or series of competitions, so as to hold first place: the heavyweight boxing champion.
contemplate: to look at or view with continued attention; observe or study thoughtfully: to contemplate the stars.

morality: conformity to the rules of right conduct; moral or virtuous conduct.
respectability: the state or quality of being respectable.
improbable: not probable; unlikely to be true or to happen: Rain is improbable tonight.
wait: to remain inactive or in a state of repose, as until something expected happens (often followed by for, till, or until): to wait for the bus to arrive.
disinclination: the absence of inclination; reluctance; unwillingness.
absolute: free from imperfection; complete; perfect: absolute liberty.
regarding: with regard to; respecting; concerning: He said nothing regarding the lost watch.
foreign: of, relating to, or derived from another country or nation; not native: foreign cars.

warfare: the process of military struggle between two nations or groups of nations; war.
responsibility: the state or fact of being responsible, answerable, or accountable for something within one's power, control, or management.

risk: exposure to the chance of injury or loss; a hazard or dangerous chance: It's not worth the risk.

hero: a man of distinguished courage or ability, admired for his brave deeds and noble qualities.
heroine: a woman of distinguished courage or ability, admired for her brave deeds and noble qualities.
newly: recently; lately: a newly married couple.
cruel: willfully or knowingly causing pain or distress to others.
unjust: not just; lacking in justice or fairness: unjust criticism; an unjust ruler.
briefly: for a short duration: He stopped over briefly in Chicago.
forget: to cease or fail to remember; be unable to recall: to forget someone's name.
brick: a block of clay hardened by drying in the sun or burning in a kiln, and used for building, paving, etc.: traditionally, in the U.S., a rectangle 2.25 × 3.75 × 8 inches (5.7 × 9.5 × 20.3 cm), red, brown, or yellow in color.
withhold: to hold back; restrain or check.
baby: an infant or very young child.
candy: any of a variety of confections made with sugar, syrup, etc., often combined with chocolate, fruit, nuts, etc.
equation: the act of equating or making equal; equalization: the symbolic equation of darkness with death.
flap: to swing or sway back and forth loosely, especially with noise: A loose shutter flapped outside the window.

functional: of or relating to a function or functions: functional difficulties in the administration.
blind: unable to see; lacking the sense of sight; sightless: a blind man.

corvus: the Crow, a southern constellation between Virgo and Hydra.
stout: bulky in figure; heavily built; corpulent; thickset; fat: She is getting too stout for her dresses.

wind: air in natural motion, as that moving horizontally at any velocity along the earth's surface: A gentle wind blew through the valley. High winds were forecast.
