necessity: something necessary or indispensable: food, shelter, and other necessities of life.
necessarily: by or of necessity; as a matter of compulsion or requirement: You don't necessarily have to attend.
infinitive: a verb form found in many languages that functions as a noun or is used with auxiliary verbs, and that names the action or state without specifying the subject, as French venir “to come,” Latin esse “to be,” fuisse “to have been.”.
saturday: the seventh day of the week, following Friday.
legal: permitted by law; lawful: Such acts are not legal.
realization: the making or being made real of something imagined, planned, etc.
prophecy: the foretelling or prediction of what is to come.
expectation: the act or the state of expecting: to wait in expectation.
cordial: courteous and gracious; friendly; warm: a cordial reception.
jovial: endowed with or characterized by a hearty, joyous humor or a spirit of good-fellowship: a wonderfully jovial host.
welcome: (a word of kindly greeting, as to one whose arrival gives pleasure): Welcome, stranger!
breakfast: the first meal of the day; morning meal: A hearty breakfast was served at 7 a.m.
lunch: a light midday meal between breakfast and dinner; luncheon.
supper: the evening meal, often the principal meal of the day.
audible: capable of being heard; loud enough to be heard; actually heard.
thunder: a loud, explosive, resounding noise produced by the explosive expansion of air heated by a lightning discharge.
unpleasant: not pleasant; displeasing; disagreeable; offensive: an unpleasant taste; an unpleasant situation; an unpleasant manner.
confuse: to perplex or bewilder: The flood of questions confused me.
deadening: a device or material employed to deaden or render dull.
rouse: to bring out of a state of sleep, unconsciousness, inactivity, fancied security, apathy, depression, etc.: He was roused to action by courageous words.
partial: being such in part only; not total or general; incomplete: partial blindness; a partial payment of a debt.
cease: to stop; discontinue: Not all medieval beliefs have ceased to exist.
awoke: a simple past tense and past participle of awake.
clerk: a person employed, as in an office, to keep records, file, type, or perform other general office tasks.
settlement: the act or state of settling or the state of being settled.
rendering: an act or instance of interpretation, rendition, or depiction, as of a dramatic part or a musical composition: her rendering of the part of Hedda.
homeless: without a home: a homeless child.
sword: a weapon having various forms but consisting typically of a long, straight or slightly curved blade, sharp-edged on one or both sides, with one end pointed and the other fixed in a hilt or handle.
clothes: garments for the body; articles of dress; wearing apparel.
sick: afflicted with ill health or disease; ailing.
theft: the act of stealing; the wrongful taking and carrying away of the personal goods or property of another; larceny.
incorrect: not correct as to fact; inaccurate; wrong: an incorrect statement.
facility: something designed, built, installed, etc., to serve a specific function affording a convenience or service: transportation facilities; educational facilities; a new research facility.
barn: a building for storing hay, grain, etc., and often for housing livestock.
yolk: the yellow and principal substance of an egg, as distinguished from the white.
ripe: having arrived at such a stage of growth or development as to be ready for reaping, gathering, eating, or use, as grain or fruit; completely matured.
architectural: of or relating to architecture: architectural metals.
subordinate: placed in or belonging to a lower order or rank.
convenience: the quality of being convenient; suitability.
safety: the state of being safe; freedom from the occurrence or risk of injury, danger, or loss.
spotlight: a strong, focused light thrown upon a particular spot, as on a small area of a stage or in a television studio, for making some object, person, or group especially conspicuous.
camera: a boxlike device for holding a film or plate sensitive to light, having an aperture controlled by a shutter that, when opened, admits light enabling an object to be focused, usually by means of a lens, on the film or plate, thereby producing a photographic image.
furnishing: articles or accessories of dress: men's furnishings.
adjoining: being in contact at some point or line; located next to another; bordering; contiguous: the adjoining room; a row of adjoining town houses.
neighboring: situated or living near; adjacent: to visit the neighboring towns.
motel: a hotel providing travelers with lodging and free parking facilities, typically a roadside hotel having rooms adjacent to an outside parking area or an urban hotel offering parking within the building.
philippines: an archipelago of 7083 islands in the Pacific, SE of China: formerly (1898–1946) under the guardianship of the U.S.; now an independent republic. 114,830 sq. mi. (297,410 sq. km). Capital:  Manila.
luzon: the chief island of the Philippines, in the N part of the group. 40,420 sq. mi. (104,688 sq. km). Capital:  Manila.
immense: vast; huge; very great: an immense territory.
aquatic: of, in, or pertaining to water.
superintendent: a person who oversees or directs some work, enterprise, establishment, organization, district, etc.; supervisor.
omit: to leave out; fail to include or mention: to omit a name from a list.
avoid: to keep away from; keep clear of; shun: to avoid a person; to avoid taxes; to avoid danger.
disgraceful: bringing or deserving disgrace; shameful; dishonorable; disreputable.
discreditable: bringing or liable to bring discredit.
neighbor: a person who lives near another.
sentiment: an attitude toward something; regard; opinion.
majority: the greater part or number; the number larger than half the total (opposed to minority): the majority of the population.
assent: to agree or concur; subscribe to (often followed by to): to assent to a statement.
disagree: to fail to agree; differ: The conclusions disagree with the facts. The theories disagree in their basic premises.
mission: a group or committee of persons sent to a foreign country to conduct negotiations, establish relations, provide scientific and technical assistance, or the like.
charitable: generous in donations or gifts to relieve the needs of indigent, ill, or helpless persons, or of animals: a charitable man giving much money to feed the poor.
helpless: unable to help oneself; weak or dependent: a helpless invalid.
jointly: together; in combination or partnership; in common: My brother and I own the farm jointly.
lighter: a person or thing that lights or ignites.
dawn: the first appearance of daylight in the morning: Dawn broke over the valley.
midnight: the middle of the night; twelve o'clock at night.
messenger: a person who carries a message or goes on an errand for another, especially as a matter of duty or business.
email: a system for sending messages from one individual to another via telecommunications links between computers or terminals using dedicated software: Communication by email is almost instantaneous.
verify: to prove the truth of, as by evidence or testimony; confirm; substantiate: Events verified his prediction.
identity: the state or fact of remaining the same one or ones, as under varying aspects or conditions: The identity of the fingerprints on the gun with those on file provided evidence that he was the killer.
handwriting: writing done with a pen or pencil in the hand; script.
bearer: a person or thing that carries, upholds, or brings: dozens of bearers on the safari.
check: to stop or arrest the motion of suddenly or forcibly: He checked the horse at the edge of the cliff.
hail: to cheer, salute, or greet; welcome.
lightning: a brilliant electric spark discharge in the atmosphere, occurring within a thundercloud, between clouds, or between a cloud and the ground.
flying: making flight or passing through the air; that flies: a flying insect; an unidentified flying object.
charter: a document, issued by a sovereign or state, outlining the conditions under which a corporation, colony, city, or other corporate body is organized, and defining its rights and privileges.
logic: the science that investigates the principles governing correct or reliable inference.
pronounce: to enunciate or articulate (sounds, words, sentences, etc.).
vocal: of, relating to, or uttered with the voice: the vocal mechanism; vocal criticism.
disburse: to pay out (money), especially for expenses; expend.
expend: to use up: She expended energy, time, and care on her work.
dispose: to give a tendency or inclination to; incline: His temperament disposed him to argue readily with people.
temptation: the act of tempting; enticement or allurement.
exclusive: not admitting of something else; incompatible: mutually exclusive plans of action.
execute: to carry out; accomplish: to execute a plan or order.
rung: simple past tense and past participle of ring2 .
tuesday: the third day of the week, following Monday.
intentional: done with intention or on purpose; intended: an intentional insult.
snub: to treat with disdain or contempt, especially by ignoring.
concentric: having a common center, as circles or spheres.
armed: bearing firearms; having weapons: a heavily armed patrol.
civilian: a person who is not on active duty with a military, naval, police, or fire fighting organization.
forceful: full of force; powerful; vigorous; effective: a forceful plea for peace.
aggressive: characterized by or tending toward unprovoked offensives, attacks, invasions, or the like; militantly forward or menacing: aggressive acts against a neighboring country.
fighting: fit to fight: a boxer who's no longer in fighting shape.
bare: without covering or clothing; naked; nude: bare legs.
pecuniary: of or relating to money: pecuniary difficulties.
retirement: the act of retiring, withdrawing, or leaving; the state of being retired.
expel: to drive or force out or away; discharge or eject: to expel air from the lungs; to expel an invader from a country.
compulsion: the act of compelling; constraint; coercion.
desperation: the state of being desperate or of having the recklessness of despair.
depart: to go away; leave: She departed from Paris today. The train departs at 10:52.
answerable: liable to be asked to give account; responsible: He is answerable to a committee for all his decisions.
accountable: subject to the obligation to report, explain, or justify something; responsible; answerable.
management: the act or manner of managing; handling, direction, or control.
imperfection: an imperfect detail; flaw: a law full of imperfections.
flaw: a feature that mars the perfection of something; defect; fault: beauty without flaw; the flaws in our plan.
vehement: zealous; ardent; impassioned: a vehement defense; vehement enthusiasm.
disapproval: the act or state of disapproving; a condemnatory feeling, look, or utterance; censure: stern disapproval.
unanimous: of one mind; in complete agreement; agreed.
proposal: the act of offering or suggesting something for acceptance, adoption, or performance.
residue: something that remains after a part is removed, disposed of, or used; remainder; rest; remnant.
hay: grass, clover, alfalfa, etc., cut and dried for use as forage.
wrap: to enclose in something wound or folded about (often followed by up): She wrapped her head in a scarf.
operate: to work, perform, or function, as a machine does: This engine does not operate properly.
reliever: a person or thing that relieves.
seize: to take hold of suddenly or forcibly; grasp: to seize a weapon.
clasping: (of a leaf) partly or wholly surrounding the stem.
handbag: a bag or box of leather, fabric, plastic, or the like, held in the hand or carried by means of a handle or strap, commonly used by women for holding money, toilet articles, small purchases, etc.
productive: having the power of producing; generative; creative: a productive effort.
exhausting: producing or tending to produce fatigue, weariness, or the like: an exhausting day; an exhausting child.
treatise: a formal and systematic exposition in writing of the principles of a subject, generally longer and more detailed than an essay.
biographical: of or relating to a person's life: He's gathering biographical data for his book on Milton.
catalog: a list or record, as of items for sale or courses at a university, systematically arranged and often including descriptive material: a stamp catalog.
cognition: the act or process of knowing; perception.
elevator: a person or thing that elevates or raises.
commercial: of, relating to, or characteristic of commerce.
industrial: of, pertaining to, of the nature of, or resulting from industry: industrial production; industrial waste.
professional: following an occupation as a means of livelihood or for gain: a professional builder.
insurance: the act, system, or business of insuring property, life, one's person, etc., against loss or harm arising in specified contingencies, as fire, accident, death, disablement, or the like, in consideration of a payment proportionate to the risk involved.
knee: Anatomy. the joint of the leg that allows for movement between the femur and tibia and is protected by the patella; the central area of the leg between the thigh and the lower leg.
hardship: a condition that is difficult to endure; suffering; deprivation; oppression: a life of hardship.
governor: the executive head of a state in the U.S.
unfamiliar: not familiar; not acquainted with or conversant about: to be unfamiliar with a subject.
deviate: to turn aside, as from a route, way, course, etc.
circuitous: roundabout; not direct: a circuitous route; a circuitous argument.
contrivance: something contrived; a device, especially a mechanical one.
sabbath: the seventh day of the week, Saturday, as the day of rest and religious observance among Jews and some Christians. Ex. 20:8–11.
hasty: moving or acting with haste; speedy; quick; hurried.
familiar: commonly or generally known or seen: a familiar sight.
bunch: a connected group; cluster: a bunch of grapes.
rivalry: the action, position, or relation of a rival or rivals; competition: rivalry between Yale and Harvard.
bitter: having a harsh, disagreeably acrid taste, like that of aspirin, quinine, wormwood, or aloes.
spectator: a person who looks on or watches; onlooker; observer.
listen: to give attention with the ear; attend closely for the purpose of hearing; give ear.
viewer: a person or thing that views.
outdoor: Also, outdoors. characteristic of, located, occurring, or belonging outdoors: an outdoor barbecue; outdoor sports.
housing: any shelter, lodging, or dwelling place.
participate: to take or have a part or share, as with others; partake; share (usually followed by in): to participate in profits; to participate in a play.
conform: to act in accordance or harmony; comply (usually followed by to): to conform to rules.
criminal: of the nature of or involving crime.
vicious: addicted to or characterized by vice; grossly immoral; depraved; profligate: a vicious life.
concentration: the act of concentrating; the state of being concentrated.
sanction: authoritative permission or approval, as for an action.
prerogative: an exclusive right, privilege, etc., exercised by virtue of rank, office, or the like: the prerogatives of a senator.
electorate: the body of persons entitled to vote in an election.
representative: a person or thing that represents another or others.
latter: being the second mentioned of two (distinguished from former): I prefer the latter offer to the former one.
centering: a temporary framework for supporting a masonry arch during construction until it is able to stand by itself.
announce: to make known publicly or officially; proclaim; give notice of: to announce a special sale.
guest: a person who spends some time at another person's home in some social activity, as a visit, dinner, or party.
enrico: a male given name: Italian form of Henry.
stockholder: Also called stockowner. a holder or owner of stock in a corporation.
anew: over again; again; once more: to play the tune anew.
spell: to name, write, or otherwise give the letters, in order, of (a word, syllable, etc.): Did I spell your name right?
july: the seventh month of the year, containing 31 days. Abbreviation:  Jul.
malicious: full of, characterized by, or showing malice; intentionally harmful; spiteful: malicious gossip.
petty: of little or no importance or consequence: petty grievances.
annoy: to disturb or bother (a person) in a way that displeases, troubles, or slightly irritates.
frustrate: to make (plans, efforts, etc.) worthless or of no avail; defeat; nullify: The student's indifference frustrated the teacher's efforts to help him.
humiliate: to cause (a person) a painful loss of pride, self-respect, or dignity; mortify.
malice: desire to inflict injury, harm, or suffering on another, either because of a hostile impulse or out of deep-seated meanness: the malice and spite of a lifelong enemy.
ellipsis: But I noticed that when you quoted this section on page 116, you left “general welfare” out and put an ellipsis in its place.
notwithstanding: in spite of; without being opposed or prevented by: Notwithstanding a brilliant defense, he was found guilty. She went to the game anyway, doctor's orders notwithstanding.
journalist: a person who practices the occupation or profession of journalism.
security: freedom from danger, risk, etc.; safety.
experimental: pertaining to, derived from, or founded on experiment: an experimental science.
discover: to see, get knowledge of, learn of, find, or find out; gain sight or knowledge of (something previously unseen or unknown): to discover America; to discover electricity.
strange: unusual, extraordinary, or curious; odd; queer: a strange remark to make.
accepted: generally approved; usually regarded as normal, right, etc.: an accepted pronunciation of a word; an accepted theory.
deny: to state that (something declared or believed to be true) is not true: to deny an accusation.
hogshead: a large cask, especially one containing from 63 to 140 gallons (238 to 530 liters).
fee: a charge or payment for professional services: a doctor's fee.
mere: being nothing more nor better than: a mere pittance; He is still a mere child.
declared: publicly avowed or professed; self-confessed: a declared liberal.
asserted: resting on a statement or claim unsupported by evidence or proof; alleged: The asserted value of the property was twice the amount anyone offered.
questioning: indicating or implying a question: a questioning tone in her voice.
refuse: to decline to accept (something offered): to refuse an award.
prohibit: to forbid (an action, activity, etc.) by authority or law: Smoking is prohibited here.
oblige: to require or constrain, as by law, command, conscience, or force of necessity.
unavoidable: unable to be avoided; inevitable: an unavoidable delay.
sail: an area of canvas or other fabric extended to the wind in such a way as to transmit the force of the wind to an assemblage of spars and rigging mounted firmly on a hull, raft, iceboat, etc., so as to drive it along.
naval: of or relating to warships: a naval battle; naval strength.
tactical: of or relating to tactics, especially military or naval tactics.
stain: a discoloration produced by foreign matter having penetrated into or chemically reacted with a material; a spot not easily removed.
paint: a substance composed of solid coloring matter suspended in a liquid medium and applied as a protective or decorative coating to various surfaces, or to canvas or other materials in producing a work of art.
blot: a spot or stain, especially of ink on paper.
speck: a small spot differing in color or substance from that of the surface or material upon which it appears or lies: Specks of soot on the window sill.
institute: to set up; establish; organize: to institute a government.
build: to construct (especially something complex) by assembling and joining parts or materials: to build a house.
genuine: possessing the claimed or attributed character, quality, or origin; not counterfeit; authentic; real: genuine sympathy; a genuine antique.
disagreement: the act, state, or fact of disagreeing.
contention: a struggling together in opposition; strife.
altercation: a heated or angry dispute; noisy argument or controversy.
proclaim: to announce or declare in an official or formal manner: to proclaim war.
declare: to make known or state clearly, especially in explicit or formal terms: to declare one's position in a controversy.
affirm: to state or assert positively; maintain as true: to affirm one's loyalty to one's country; He affirmed that all was well.
assert: to state with assurance, confidence, or force; state strongly or positively; affirm; aver: He asserted his innocence of the crime.
sleeve: the part of a garment that covers the arm, varying in form and length but commonly tubular.
anyone: any person at all; anybody: Did anyone see the accident?
pitch: to erect or set up (a tent, camp, or the like).
register: a book in which records of acts, events, names, etc., are kept.
hairy: covered with hair; having much hair.
saber: a heavy, one-edged sword, usually slightly curved, used especially by cavalry.
disguise: to change the appearance or guise of so as to conceal identity or mislead, as by means of deceptive garb: The king was disguised as a peasant.
formation: the act or process of forming or the state of being formed: the formation of ice.
uttering: the crime of knowingly tendering or showing a forged instrument or counterfeit coin to another with intent to defraud.
earnest: serious in intention, purpose, or effort; sincerely zealous: an earnest worker.
intelligent: having good understanding or a high mental capacity; quick to comprehend, as persons or animals: an intelligent student.
comprehensive: of large scope; covering or involving much; inclusive: a comprehensive study of world affairs.
employee: a person working for another person or a business firm for pay.
articulation: an act or the process of articulating: the articulation of a form; the articulation of a new thought.
forte: a person's strong suit, or most highly developed characteristic, talent, or skill; something that one excels in: I don't know what her forte is, but it's not music.
ireland: John, 1838–1918, U.S. Roman Catholic clergyman and social reformer, born in Ireland: archbishop of St. Paul, Minn., 1888–1918.
predict: to declare or tell in advance; prophesy; foretell: to predict the weather; to predict the fall of a civilization.
carl: But poor carl is still trudging along as if his assault never happened.
bert: a male given name, form of Albert, Bertram, Herbert, Hubert, etc.
detect: to discover or catch (a person) in the performance of some act: to detect someone cheating.
wary: watchful; being on one's guard against danger.
attentive: characterized by or giving attention; observant: an attentive audience.
keen: finely sharpened, as an edge; so shaped as to cut or pierce substances readily: a keen razor.
soldier: a person who serves in an army; a person engaged in military service.
guard: to keep safe from harm or danger; protect; watch over: to guard the ruler.
sentinel: a person or thing that watches or stands as if watching.
defense: resistance against attack; protection: Two more regiments are needed for the defense of the city.
settler: a person or thing that settles.
transmission: the act or process of transmitting.
looming: a mirage in which objects below the horizon seem to be raised above their true positions.
contend: to struggle in opposition: to contend with the enemy for control of the port.
implant: to put or fix firmly: to implant sound principles in a child's mind.
limiting: serving to restrict or restrain; restrictive; confining.
continuation: the act or state of continuing; the state of being continued.
wholesale: the sale of goods in quantity, as to retailers or jobbers, for resale (opposed to retail).
retail: the sale of goods to ultimate consumers, usually in small quantities (opposed to wholesale).
domestic: of or relating to the home, the household, household affairs, or the family: domestic pleasures.
conclude: to bring to an end; finish; terminate: to conclude a speech with a quotation from the Bible.
cool: moderately cold; neither warm nor cold: a rather cool evening.
drift: a driving movement or force; impulse; impetus; pressure.
probability: the quality or fact of being probable.
spur: a U -shaped device that slips over and straps to the heel of a boot and has a blunt, pointed, or roweled projection at the back for use by a mounted rider to urge a horse forward.
insanity: the condition of being insane; a derangement of the mind. Synonyms: dementia, lunacy, madness, craziness, mania, aberration.
marcus: Saint. Also, Mark, died a.d. 336, pope 336.
says: 3rd person singular present ind. of say1 .
decimal: pertaining to tenths or to the number 10.
hairdo: the style in which a person's hair is cut, arranged, and worn; coiffure.
conveyance: the act of conveying; transmission; communication.
provision: a clause in a legal instrument, a law, etc., providing for a particular matter; stipulation; proviso.
pane: one of the divisions of a window or the like, consisting of a single plate of glass in a frame.
trace: a surviving mark, sign, or evidence of the former existence, influence, or action of some agent or event; vestige: traces of an advanced civilization among the ruins.
inscribe: to address or dedicate (a book, photograph, etc.) informally to a person, especially by writing a brief personal note in or on it.
board: a piece of wood sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth compared with the thickness.
poetic: possessing the qualities or charm of poetry: poetic descriptions of nature.
rhythmical: periodic, as motion, or a drumbeat.
stanza: an arrangement of a certain number of lines, usually four or more, sometimes having a fixed length, meter, or rhyme scheme, forming a division of a poem.
universal: of, relating to, or characteristic of all or the whole: universal experience.
frequent: happening or occurring at short intervals: to make frequent trips to Tokyo.
oblation: the offering to God of the elements of bread and wine in the Eucharist.
sacrifice: the offering of animal, plant, or human life or of some material possession to a deity, as in propitiation or homage.
conjecture: the formation or expression of an opinion or theory without sufficient evidence for proof.
byron: George Gordon, Lord (6th Baron Byron) 1788–1824, English poet.
theme: a subject of discourse, discussion, meditation, or composition; topic: The need for world peace was the theme of the meeting.
speculative: pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by speculation, contemplation, conjecture, or abstract reasoning: a speculative approach.
dialogue: conversation between two or more persons.
pantomime: the art or technique of conveying emotions, actions, feelings, etc., by gestures without speech.
contrast: to compare in order to show unlikeness or differences; note the opposite natures, purposes, etc., of: Contrast the political rights of Romans and Greeks.
play: a dramatic composition or piece; drama.
interchange: to put each in the place of the other: to interchange pieces of modular furniture.
examination: the act of examining; inspection; inquiry; investigation.
explore: to traverse or range over (a region, area, etc.) for the purpose of discovery: to explore the island.
debate: a discussion, as of a public question in an assembly, involving opposing viewpoints: a debate in the Senate on farm price supports.
slow: moving or proceeding with little or less than usual speed or velocity: a slow train.
publisher: a person or company whose business is the publishing of books, periodicals, engravings, computer software, etc.
journal: a daily record, as of occurrences, experiences, or observations: She kept a journal during her European trip.
respective: pertaining individually or severally to each of a number of persons, things, etc.; particular: I will now discuss the respective merits of the candidates.
convention: a meeting or formal assembly, as of representatives or delegates, for discussion of and action on particular matters of common concern.
appointment: a fixed mutual agreement for a meeting; engagement: We made an appointment to meet again.
analyst: a person who analyzes or who is skilled in analysis.
intelligence: capacity for learning, reasoning, understanding, and similar forms of mental activity; aptitude in grasping truths, relationships, facts, meanings, etc.
calling: the act of a person or thing that calls.
television: the broadcasting of a still or moving image via radiowaves to receivers that project a view of the image on a picture tube.
periodic: recurring at intervals of time: periodic revivals of an interest in handicrafts.
specialize: to pursue some special line of study, work, etc.; have a specialty: The doctor specializes in gastroenterology.
hobby: an activity or interest pursued for pleasure or relaxation and not as a main occupation: Her hobbies include stamp-collecting and woodcarving.
sport: an athletic activity requiring skill or physical prowess and often of a competitive nature, as racing, baseball, tennis, golf, bowling, wrestling, boxing, hunting, fishing, etc.
athletic: physically active and strong; good at athletics or sports: an athletic child.
festival: a day or time of religious or other celebration, marked by feasting, ceremonies, or other observances: the festival of Christmas; a Roman festival.
imagination: the faculty of imagining, or of forming mental images or concepts of what is not actually present to the senses.
bedding: blankets, sheets, etc., used on a bed; bedclothes.
sleeper: a person or thing that sleeps.
invite: to request the presence or participation of in a kindly, courteous, or complimentary way, especially to request to come or go to some place, gathering, entertainment, etc., or to do something: to invite friends to dinner.
refreshment: something that refreshes, especially food or drink.
diversion: the act of diverting or turning aside, as from a course or purpose: a diversion of industry into the war effort.
puzzle: a toy, problem, or other contrivance designed to amuse by presenting difficulties to be solved by ingenuity or patient effort.
gin: an alcoholic liquor obtained by distilling grain mash with juniper berries.
whiskey: an alcoholic liquor distilled from a fermented mash of grain, as barley, rye, or corn, and usually containing from 43 to 50 percent alcohol.
rum: an alcoholic liquor or spirit distilled from molasses or some other fermented sugar-cane product.
vodka: an unaged, colorless, distilled spirit, originally made in Russia.
brandy: a spirit distilled from wine or from the fermented juice of grapes or of apples, peaches, plums, etc.
vermouth: an aromatized white wine in which herbs, roots, barks, bitters, and other flavorings have been steeped.
recess: temporary withdrawal or cessation from the usual work or activity.
seizing: the act of a person or thing that seizes.
grasping: greedy; avaricious: a sly, grasping man.
wing: either of the two forelimbs of most birds and of bats, corresponding to the human arms, that are specialized for flight.
carpus: the part of the upper extremity between the hand and the forearm; wrist.
forearm: Anatomy. the part of the arm between the elbow and the wrist.
metacarpus: the part of a hand or forelimb, especially of its bony structure, included between the wrist, or carpus, and the fingers, or phalanges.
partition: a division into or distribution in portions or shares.
dine: to eat the principal meal of the day; have dinner.
explosive: tending or serving to explode: an explosive temper; Nitroglycerin is an explosive substance.
wound: an injury, usually involving division of tissue or rupture of the integument or mucous membrane, due to external violence or some mechanical agency rather than disease.
healing: curing or curative; prescribed or helping to heal.
communicate: to impart knowledge of; make known: to communicate information; to communicate one's happiness.
abode: a place in which a person resides; residence; dwelling; habitation; home.
drill: Benjamin Tupper on doing the job at drill and the anxiety-ridden behaviors it triggers.
stripe: a relatively long, narrow band of a different color, appearance, weave, material, or nature from the rest of a surface or thing: the stripes of a zebra.
african: Also, Africa. of or from Africa; belonging to the black peoples of Africa.
endangered: threatened with a danger: endangered lives of trapped coal miners.
queer: strange or odd from a conventional viewpoint; unusually different; singular: a queer notion of justice.
odd: differing in nature from what is ordinary, usual, or expected: an odd choice.
specimen: a part or an individual taken as exemplifying a whole mass or number; a typical animal, plant, mineral, part, etc.
december: the twelfth month of the year, containing 31 days. Abbreviation:  Dec.
march: to walk with regular and measured tread, as soldiers on parade; advance in step in an organized body.
june: the sixth month of the year, containing 30 days. Abbreviation:  Jun.
unsound: not sound; unhealthy, diseased, or disordered, as the body or mind.
nurse: Compare nurse-midwife, nurse-practitioner, physician's assistant, practical nurse, registered nurse.
denature: to deprive (something) of its natural character, properties, etc.
ample: fully sufficient or more than adequate for the purpose or needs; plentiful; enough: an ample supply of water; ample time to finish.
accommodation: the act of accommodating; state or process of being accommodated; adaptation.
rent: a simple past tense and past participle of reave2 .
bovine: of or relating to the subfamily Bovinae, which includes cattle, buffalo, and kudus.
resist: to withstand, strive against, or oppose: to resist infection; to resist temptation.
enduring: lasting; permanent: a poet of enduring greatness.
throw: to propel or cast in any way, especially to project or propel from the hand by a sudden forward motion or straightening of the arm and wrist: to throw a ball.
hurl: to throw or fling with great force or vigor.
fling: to throw, cast, or hurl with force or violence: to fling a stone.
dice: small cubes of plastic, ivory, bone, or wood, marked on each side with one to six spots, usually used in pairs in games of chance or in gambling.
amalgam: an alloy of mercury with another metal or metals.
backing: aid or support of any kind.
refuge: shelter or protection from danger, trouble, etc.: to take refuge from a storm.
chloride: a salt of hydrochloric acid consisting of two elements, one of which is chlorine, as sodium chloride, NaCl.
seawater: the salt water in or from the sea.
seasoning: salt or an herb, spice, or the like, for heightening or improving the flavor of food.
preservative: something that preserves or tends to preserve.
finally: at the final point or moment; in the end.
focus: a central point, as of attraction, attention, or activity: The need to prevent a nuclear war became the focus of all diplomatic efforts.
stop: to cease from, leave off, or discontinue: to stop running.
ward: a division or district of a city or town, as for administrative or political purposes.
assault: a sudden, violent attack; onslaught: an assault on tradition.
salicaceous: belonging to the Salicaceae, the willow family of plants.
inasmuch: contraction of in as much, first attested c.1300 as in als mikel, a Northern form. First contracted to in asmuch, then, beginning 14c. and especially since 17c., to one word.
painted: reproduced or represented in paint: a painted image.
sculptured: having a surface or shape molded, marked, carved, indented, etc., by or as if by sculpture: sculptured leather belts.
radiate: to extend, spread, or move like rays or radii from a center.
shine: to give forth or glow with light; shed or cast light.
debase: to reduce in quality or value; adulterate: They debased the value of the dollar.
contaminate: to make impure or unsuitable by contact or mixture with something unclean, bad, etc.: to contaminate a lake with sewage.
pollute: to make foul or unclean, especially with harmful chemical or waste products; dirty: to pollute the air with smoke.
arbitrary: subject to individual will or judgment without restriction; contingent solely upon one's discretion: an arbitrary decision.
despotic: of, relating to, or of the nature of a despot or despotism; autocratic; tyrannical.
absorbing: extremely interesting; deeply engrossing: an absorbing drama.
dispute: to engage in argument or debate.
molecule: Chemistry, Physics. the smallest physical unit of an element or compound, consisting of one or more like atoms in an element and two or more different atoms in a compound.
emphatic: uttered, or to be uttered, with emphasis; strongly expressive.
authors: a card game for two or more persons that is played with a 52-card pack, the object being to take the largest number of tricks consisting of four cards of the same denomination.
mobile: capable of moving or being moved readily.
waste: to consume, spend, or employ uselessly or without adequate return; use to no avail or profit; squander: to waste money; to waste words.
industry: the aggregate of manufacturing or technically productive enterprises in a particular field, often named after its principal product: the automobile industry; the steel industry.
reliable: that may be relied on or trusted; dependable in achievement, accuracy, honesty, etc.: reliable information.
assistant: a person who assists or gives aid and support; helper.
perfectly: in a perfect manner or to a perfect degree: to sing an aria perfectly.
contour: the outline of a figure or body; the edge or line that defines or bounds a shape or object.
calculating: capable of or made for performing calculations, especially arithmetical calculations: a calculating machine.
loan: the act of lending; a grant of the temporary use of something: the loan of a book.
medieval: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or in the style of the Middle Ages: medieval architecture.
emperor: the male sovereign or supreme ruler of an empire: the emperors of Rome.
empress: a female ruler of an empire.
russian: of or relating to Russia, its people, or their language.
prehistoric: of or relating to the time or a period prior to recorded history: The dinosaur is a prehistoric beast.
bred: simple past tense and past participle of breed.
ride: to sit on and manage a horse or other animal in motion; be carried on the back of an animal.
raise: to move to a higher position; lift up; elevate: to raise one's hand; sleepy birds raising their heads and looking about.
cessation: a temporary or complete stopping; discontinuance: a cessation of hostilities.
terminate: to bring to an end; put an end to: to terminate a contract.
hello: (used to express a greeting, answer a telephone, or attract attention.)
casual: happening by chance; fortuitous: a casual meeting.
bath: a washing or immersion of something, especially the body, in water, steam, etc., as for cleansing or medical treatment: I take a bath every day. Give the dog a bath.
deceive: to mislead by a false appearance or statement; delude: They deceived the enemy by disguising the destroyer as a freighter.
pretended: insincerely or falsely professed: a pretended interest in art.
humility: the quality or condition of being humble; modest opinion or estimate of one's own importance, rank, etc.
heedless: careless; thoughtless; unmindful: Heedless of the danger, he returned to the burning building to save his dog.
unmindful: not mindful; unaware; heedless; forgetful; careless; neglectful: unmindful of obligations.
hypothesis: a proposition, or set of propositions, set forth as an explanation for the occurrence of some specified group of phenomena, either asserted merely as a provisional conjecture to guide investigation (working hypothesis) or accepted as highly probable in the light of established facts.
etiquette: conventional requirements as to social behavior; proprieties of conduct as established in any class or community or for any occasion.
courteous: having or showing good manners; polite.
budget: an estimate, often itemized, of expected income and expense for a given period in the future.
worse: bad or ill in a greater or higher degree; inferior in excellence, quality, or character.
corridor: a gallery or passage connecting parts of a building; hallway.
lawsuit: a case in a court of law involving a claim, complaint, etc., by one party against another; suit at law.
commotion: violent or tumultuous motion; agitation; noisy disturbance: What's all the commotion in the hallway?
tumult: violent and noisy commotion or disturbance of a crowd or mob; uproar: The tumult reached its height during the premier's speech.
peaceful: characterized by peace; free from war, strife, commotion, violence, or disorder: a peaceful reign; a peaceful demonstration.
unruffled: calm; not emotionally upset or agitated; steady; unflustered: He became all excited, but she remained unruffled.
landscape: a section or expanse of rural scenery, usually extensive, that can be seen from a single viewpoint.
reassure: to restore to assurance or confidence: His praise reassured me.
excitable: easily excited: Prima donnas had the reputation of being excitable and temperamental.
uneasy: not easy in body or mind; uncomfortable; restless; disturbed; perturbed.
apprehensive: uneasy or fearful about something that might happen: apprehensive for the safety of the mountain climbers.
passenger: a person who is traveling in an automobile, bus, train, airplane, or other conveyance, especially one who is not the driver, pilot, or the like.
rowboat: a small boat designed for rowing.
canal: an artificial waterway for navigation, irrigation, etc.
conduit: a pipe, tube, or the like, for conveying water or other fluid.
plantae: the taxonomic kingdom comprising all plants.
photosynthesis: the complex process by which carbon dioxide, water, and certain inorganic salts are converted into carbohydrates by green plants, algae, and certain bacteria, using energy from the sun and chlorophyll.
algae: any of numerous groups of chlorophyll-containing, mainly aquatic eukaryotic organisms ranging from microscopic single-celled forms to multicellular forms 100 feet (30 meters) or more long, distinguished from plants by the absence of true roots, stems, and leaves and by a lack of nonreproductive cells in the reproductive structures: classified into the six phyla Euglenophyta, Crysophyta, Pyrrophyta, Chlorophyta, Phaeophyta, and Rhodophyta.
bacteria: ubiquitous one-celled organisms, spherical, spiral, or rod-shaped and appearing singly or in chains, comprising the Schizomycota, a phylum of the kingdom Monera (in some classification systems the plant class Schizomycetes), various species of which are involved in fermentation, putrefaction, infectious diseases, or nitrogen fixation.
wooded: covered with or abounding in woods or trees.
gather: to bring together into one group, collection, or place: to gather firewood; to gather the troops.
turmoil: a state of great commotion, confusion, or disturbance; tumult; agitation; disquiet: mental turmoil caused by difficult decisions.
bob: a short, jerky motion: a bob of the head.
reduction: the act of reducing or the state of being reduced.
excepting: excluding; barring; saving; with the exception of; except: Excepting the last chapter, the book is finished.
filling: an act or instance of filling.
pudding: a thick, soft dessert, typically containing flour or some other thickener, milk, eggs, a flavoring, and sweetener: tapioca pudding.
prepared: properly expectant, organized, or equipped; ready: prepared for a hurricane.
pan: a broad, shallow container of metal, usually having sides flaring outward toward the top, used in various forms for frying, baking, washing, etc.
dish: an open, relatively shallow container of pottery, glass, metal, wood, etc., used for various purposes, especially for holding or serving food.
apple: the usually round, red or yellow, edible fruit of a small tree, Malus sylvestris, of the rose family.
abrupt: sudden or unexpected: an abrupt departure.
planetary: of, relating to, or resembling a planet or the planets.
rail: a bar of wood or metal fixed horizontally for any of various purposes, as for a support, barrier, fence, or railing.
locomotive: a self-propelled, vehicular engine, powered by steam, a diesel, or electricity, for pulling or, sometimes, pushing a train or individual railroad cars.
cargo: the lading or freight of a ship, airplane, etc.
transported: emotionally moved; ecstatic: transported by the music.
grandfather: the father of one's father or mother.
vertebra: any of the bones or segments composing the spinal column, consisting typically of a cylindrical body and an arch with various processes, and forming a foramen, or opening, through which the spinal cord passes.
version: a particular account of some matter, as from one person or source, contrasted with some other account: two different versions of the accident.
spearing: an illegal check in which a player jabs an opponent with the end of the stick blade or the top end of the stick, resulting in a penalty.
pellet: a small, rounded or spherical body, as of food or medicine.
expanded: increased in area, bulk, or volume; enlarged: an expanded version of a story.
original: belonging or pertaining to the origin or beginning of something, or to a thing at its beginning: The book still has its original binding.
ornate: elaborately or sumptuously adorned, often excessively or showily so: They bought an ornate Louis XIV sofa.
fixture: something securely, and usually permanently, attached or appended, as to a house, apartment building, etc.: a light fixture; kitchen fixtures.
overhead: over one's head; aloft; up in the air or sky, especially near the zenith: There was a cloud overhead.
alteration: the act or process of altering; the state of being altered: Alteration will improve the dress.
intellect: the power or faculty of the mind by which one knows or understands, as distinguished from that by which one feels and that by which one wills; the understanding; the faculty of thinking and acquiring knowledge.
ethics: (used with a singular or plural verb) a system of moral principles: the ethics of a culture.
wicked: evil or morally bad in principle or practice; sinful; iniquitous: wicked people; wicked habits.
involuntary: not voluntary; independent of one's will; not by one's own choice: an involuntary listener; involuntary servitude.
crossing: the act of a person or thing that crosses.
incompetence: the quality or condition of being incompetent; lack of ability.
minor: lesser, as in size, extent, or importance, or being or noting the lesser of two: a minor share.
administrative: pertaining to administration; executive: administrative ability.
supervisory: of, relating to, or having supervision.
confine: to enclose within bounds; limit or restrict: She confined her remarks to errors in the report. Confine your efforts to finishing the book.
befitting: suitable; proper; becoming: planned with a befitting sense of majesty.
friendship: the state of being a friend; association as friends: to value a person's friendship.
companion: a person who is frequently in the company of, associates with, or accompanies another: my son and his two companions.
fellowship: the condition or relation of being a fellow: the fellowship of humankind.
stick: a branch or shoot of a tree or shrub that has been cut or broken off.
cudgel: a short, thick stick used as a weapon; club.
alliance: the act of allying or state of being allied.
commerce: an interchange of goods or commodities, especially on a large scale between different countries (foreign commerce) or between different parts of the same country (domestic commerce) trade; business.
zoology: the science or branch of biology dealing with animals.
passageway: a way for passing into, through, or out of something, as within a building or between buildings; a corridor, hall, alley, catwalk, or the like.
respiration: the act of respiring; inhalation and exhalation of air; breathing.
prominence: Also, prominency. the state of being prominent; conspicuousness.
cartilage: a firm, elastic, flexible type of connective tissue of a translucent whitish or yellowish color; gristle.
modulate: to regulate by or adjust to a certain measure or proportion; soften; tone down.
dockworker: a person employed on the docks of a port, as in loading and unloading vessels.
conclusive: serving to settle or decide a question; decisive; convincing: conclusive evidence.
decree: a formal and authoritative order, especially one having the force of law: a presidential decree.
judicial: pertaining to judgment in courts of justice or to the administration of justice: judicial proceedings; the judicial system.
appoint: to name or assign to a position, an office, or the like; designate: to appoint a new treasurer; to appoint a judge to the bench.
resolve: to come to a definite or earnest decision about; determine (to do something): I have resolved that I shall live to the full.
administer: to manage (affairs, a government, etc.); have executive charge of: to administer the law.
negligence: the quality, fact, or result of being negligent; neglect: negligence in discharging one's responsibilities.
enforce: to put or keep in force; compel obedience to: to enforce a rule; Traffic laws will be strictly enforced.
courage: the quality of mind or spirit that enables a person to face difficulty, danger, pain, etc., without fear; bravery.
firearm: a small arms weapon, as a rifle or pistol, from which a projectile is fired by gunpowder.
arrow: a slender, straight, generally pointed missile or weapon made to be shot from a bow and equipped with feathers at the end of the shaft near the nock, for controlling flight.
rocket: any of various simple or complex tubelike devices containing combustibles that on being ignited liberate gases whose action propels the tube through the air: used for pyrotechnic effect, signaling, carrying a lifeline, hurling explosives at an enemy, putting a space vehicle into orbit, etc.
evident: plain or clear to the sight or understanding: His frown made it evident to all that he was displeased. It was evident that the project was a total failure.
obvious: easily seen, recognized, or understood; open to view or knowledge; evident: an obvious advantage.
plain: clear or distinct to the eye or ear: a plain trail to the river; to stand in plain view.
augment: to make larger; enlarge in size, number, strength, or extent; increase: His salary is augmented by a small inheritance.
constructive: constructing or tending to construct; helping to improve; promoting further development or advancement (opposed to destructive): constructive criticism.
reproduce: to make a copy, representation, duplicate, or close imitation of: to reproduce a picture.
adapt: to make suitable to requirements or conditions; adjust or modify fittingly: They adapted themselves to the change quickly. He adapted the novel for movies.
snobbish: of, relating to, or characteristic of a snob: snobbish ideas about rank.
thinner: a volatile liquid, as turpentine, used to dilute paint, varnish, rubber cement, etc., to the desired or proper consistency.
rifle: a shoulder firearm with spiral grooves cut in the inner surface of the gun barrel to give the bullet a rotatory motion and thus a more precise trajectory.
cannon: a mounted gun for firing heavy projectiles; a gun, howitzer, or mortar.
penetrating: able or tending to penetrate; piercing; sharp: a penetrating shriek; a penetrating glance.
harmonious: marked by agreement in feeling, attitude, or action: a harmonious group.
jar: a broad-mouthed container, usually cylindrical and of glass or earthenware: a cookie jar.
interesting: engaging or exciting and holding the attention or curiosity: an interesting book.
interruption: an act or instance of interrupting.
continued: lasting or enduring without interruption: continued good health.
intermission: a short interval between the acts of a play or parts of a public performance, usually a period of approximately 10 or 15 minutes, allowing the performers and audience a rest.
flag: a piece of cloth, varying in size, shape, color, and design, usually attached at one edge to a staff or cord, and used as the symbol of a nation, state, or organization, as a means of signaling, etc.; ensign; standard; banner; pennant.
pond: a body of water smaller than a lake, sometimes artificially formed, as by damming a stream.
contagious: capable of being transmitted by bodily contact with an infected person or object: contagious diseases.
infectious: communicable by infection, as from one person to another or from one part of the body to another: infectious diseases.
enthusiasm: absorbing or controlling possession of the mind by any interest or pursuit; lively interest: He shows marked enthusiasm for his studies.
pull: to draw or haul toward oneself or itself, in a particular direction, or into a particular position: to pull a sled up a hill.
block: a solid mass of wood, stone, etc., usually with one or more flat or approximately flat faces.
obstacle: something that obstructs or hinders progress.
inarticulate: lacking the ability to express oneself, especially in clear and effective speech: an inarticulate public speaker.
lamentation: the act of lamenting or expressing grief.
grief: keen mental suffering or distress over affliction or loss; sharp sorrow; painful regret.
obstruction: something that obstructs, blocks, or closes up with an obstacle or obstacles; obstacle or hindrance: obstructions to navigation.
cage: a boxlike enclosure having wires, bars, or the like, for confining and displaying birds or animals.
drawer: a sliding, lidless, horizontal compartment, as in a piece of furniture, that may be drawn out in order to gain access to it.
folder: a person or thing that folds.
convenient: suitable or agreeable to the needs or purpose; well-suited with respect to facility or ease in use; favorable, easy, or comfortable for use.
storage: the act of storing; state or fact of being stored: All my furniture is in storage.
shutter: a solid or louvered movable cover for a window.
lid: a removable or hinged cover for closing the opening, usually at the top, of a pot, jar, trunk, etc.; a movable cover.
raised: fashioned or made as a surface design in relief.
indentation: a cut, notch, or deep recess: various bays and indentations.
tongue: Anatomy. the usually movable organ in the floor of the mouth in humans and most vertebrates, functioning in eating, in tasting, and, in humans, in speaking.
furrow: a narrow groove made in the ground, especially by a plow.
floor: that part of a room, hallway, or the like, that forms its lower enclosing surface and upon which one walks.
valley: an elongated depression between uplands, hills, or mountains, especially one following the course of a stream.
tip: a slender or pointed end or extremity, especially of anything long or tapered: the tips of the fingers.
nadir: Astronomy. the point on the celestial sphere directly beneath a given position or observer and diametrically opposite the zenith.
tracing: the act of a person or thing that traces.
oblique: neither perpendicular nor parallel to a given line or surface; slanting; sloping.
oceangoing: (of a ship) designed and equipped to travel on the open sea.
cardboard: a thin, stiff pasteboard, used for signs, boxes, etc.
shipping: the act or business of a person or thing that ships.
packing: the act or work of a person or thing that packs.
shopping: the act of a person who shops.
glassware: articles of glass, especially drinking glasses.
protuberance: the condition, state, or quality of being protuberant.
hump: a rounded protuberance, especially a fleshy protuberance on the back, as that due to abnormal curvature of the spine in humans, or that normally present in certain animals, as the camel or bison.
establishment: the act or an instance of establishing.
row: a number of persons or things arranged in a line, especially a straight line: a row of apple trees.
unattended: without attendance; lacking an audience, spectators, etc.: an unattended meeting.
passer: a person or thing that passes or causes something to pass.
imitation: a result or product of imitating.
transcript: a written, typewritten, or printed copy; something transcribed or made by transcribing.
dent: a hollow or depression in a surface, as from a blow.
bruise: to injure by striking or pressing, without breaking the skin: The blow bruised his arm. Her pinching bruised the peaches.
urban: of, relating to, or designating a city or town.
portray: to make a likeness of by drawing, painting, carving, or the like.
wink: to close and open one or both eyes quickly.
anger: a strong feeling of displeasure and belligerence aroused by a wrong; wrath; ire.
resentment: the feeling of displeasure or indignation at some act, remark, person, etc., regarded as causing injury or insult.
dean: the head of a faculty, school, or administrative division in a university or college: the dean of admissions.
outstanding: prominent; conspicuous; striking: an outstanding example of courage.
dutiful: performing the duties expected or required of one; characterized by doing one's duty: a dutiful citizen; a dutiful child.
spirit: the principle of conscious life; the vital principle in humans, animating the body or mediating between body and soul.
informed: having or prepared with information or knowledge; apprised: an informed audience that asked intelligent questions.
patriotic: of, like, suitable for, or characteristic of a patriot.
nucleus: a central part about which other parts are grouped or gathered; core: A few faithful friends formed the nucleus of the club.
oviduct: either of a pair of tubes that transport the ova from the ovary to the exterior, the distal ends of which form the uterus and vagina in higher mammals.
ovum: The mode of nutrition of the ovum may be very instructively studied in this type.
prenatal: previous to birth or to giving birth: prenatal care for mothers.
womb: the uterus of the human female and certain higher mammals.
ovary: Anatomy, Zoology. the female gonad or reproductive gland, in which the ova and the hormones that regulate female secondary sex characteristics develop.
sexual: of, relating to, or for sex: sexual matters; sexual aids.
enlarge: to make larger; increase in extent, bulk, or quantity; add to: They enlarged the house by adding an east wing.
beard: the growth of hair on the face of an adult man, often including a mustache.
county: the largest administrative division of a U.S. state: Miami, Florida, is in Dade County.
singleness: the state or quality of being single.
pursuit: the act of pursuing: in pursuit of the fox.
uranium: a white, lustrous, radioactive, metallic element, occurring in pitchblende, and having compounds that are used in photography and in coloring glass. The 235 isotope is used in atomic and hydrogen bombs and as a fuel in nuclear reactors. Symbol:  U; atomic weight:  238.03; atomic number:  92; specific gravity:  19.07.
affair: anything done or to be done; anything requiring action or effort; business; concern: an affair of great importance.
advanced: placed ahead or forward: with one foot advanced.
humane: characterized by tenderness, compassion, and sympathy for people and animals, especially for the suffering or distressed: humane treatment of prisoners.
culture: the quality in a person or society that arises from a concern for what is regarded as excellent in arts, letters, manners, scholarly pursuits, etc.
levy: an imposing or collecting, as of a tax, by authority or force.
circumscribe: to draw a line around; encircle: to circumscribe a city on a map.
evergreen: (of trees, shrubs, etc.) having green leaves throughout the entire year, the leaves of the past season not being shed until after the new foliage has been completely formed.
cocoa: a powder made from roasted, husked, and ground seeds of the cacao, Theobroma cacao, from which much of the fat has been removed.
husk: the dry external covering of certain fruits or seeds, especially of an ear of corn.
sweeten: to make sweet, as by adding sugar.
extract: to get, pull, or draw out, usually with special effort, skill, or force: to extract a tooth.
viscid: having a glutinous consistency; sticky; adhesive; viscous.
nectar: the saccharine secretion of a plant, which attracts the insects or birds that pollinate the flower.
hives: any of various eruptive conditions of the skin, as the wheals of urticaria.
cook: to prepare (food) by the use of heat, as by boiling, baking, or roasting.
oven: a chamber or compartment, as in a stove, for baking, roasting, heating, drying, etc.
abdomen: Prince Philip, 92, had an operation on his abdomen in June and spent 11 nights at the private London Clinic.
flabby: hanging loosely or limply, as flesh or muscles; flaccid.
corpulent: large or bulky of body; portly; stout; fat.
batter: to beat persistently or hard; pound repeatedly.
yeast: any of various small, single-celled fungi of the phylum Ascomycota that reproduce by fission or budding, the daughter cells often remaining attached, and that are capable of fermenting carbohydrates into alcohol and carbon dioxide.
leavening: Also called leavening agent. a substance used to produce fermentation in dough or batter; leaven.
corn: Also called Indian corn; especially technical and British, maize. a tall cereal plant, Zea mays, cultivated in many varieties, having a jointed, solid stem and bearing the grain, seeds, or kernels on large ears.
rice: the starchy seeds or grain of an annual marsh grass, Oryza sativa, cultivated in warm climates and used for food.
millet: a cereal grass, Setaria italica, extensively cultivated in the East and in southern Europe for its small seed, or grain, used as food for humans and fowls, but in the U.S. grown chiefly for fodder.
topology: the study of those properties of geometric forms that remain invariant under certain transformations, as bending or stretching.
bolt: a movable bar or rod that when slid into a socket fastens a door, gate, etc.
roundish: somewhat round: a roundish man; roundish furniture.
jelly: a food preparation of a soft, elastic consistency due to the presence of gelatin, pectin, etc., especially fruit juice boiled down with sugar and used as a sweet spread for bread and toast, as a filling for cakes or doughnuts, etc.
skyline: the boundary line between earth and sky; the apparent horizon: A sail appeared against the skyline.
kindness: the state or quality of being kind: kindness to animals.
kindhearted: having or showing sympathy or kindness: a kindhearted woman.
orientation: the act or process of orienting.
derision: ridicule; mockery: The inept performance elicited derision from the audience.
scorn: open or unqualified contempt; disdain: His face and attitude showed the scorn he felt.
ascendancy: the state of being in the ascendant; governing or controlling influence; domination.
preeminent: eminent above or before others; superior; surpassing: He is preeminent in his profession.
enjoyable: giving or capable of giving joy or pleasure: a very enjoyable film.
tender: soft or delicate in substance; not hard or tough: a tender steak.
passionate: having, compelled by, or ruled by intense emotion or strong feeling; fervid: a passionate advocate of socialism.
fondly: in a fond manner; lovingly or affectionately: He looked fondly at his child.
embrace: to take or clasp in the arms; press to the bosom; hug.
jungle: a wild land overgrown with dense vegetation, often nearly impenetrable, especially tropical vegetation or a tropical rain forest.
brazilwood: any of several tropical trees of the genus Caesalpinia, as C. echinata, having wood from which a red dye is obtained.
gene: the basic physical unit of heredity; a linear sequence of nucleotides along a segment of DNA that provides the coded instructions for synthesis of RNA, which, when translated into protein, leads to the expression of hereditary character.
linkage: the act of linking; state or manner of being linked.
lock: a device for securing a door, gate, lid, drawer, or the like in position when closed, consisting of a bolt or system of bolts propelled and withdrawn by a mechanism operated by a key, dial, etc.
affect: to act on; produce an effect or change in: Cold weather affected the crops.
shortage: a deficiency in quantity: a shortage of cash.
learn: to acquire knowledge of or skill in by study, instruction, or experience: to learn French; to learn to ski.
technique: the manner and ability with which an artist, writer, dancer, athlete, or the like employs the technical skills of a particular art or field of endeavor.
computing: the use of a computer to process data or perform calculations.
commendation: the act of commending; recommendation; praise: commendation for a job well done.
admiration: a feeling of wonder, pleasure, or approval.
sincere: free of deceit, hypocrisy, or falseness; earnest: a sincere apology.
morale: emotional or mental condition with respect to cheerfulness, confidence, zeal, etc., especially in the face of opposition, hardship, etc.: the morale of the troops.
pastime: something that serves to make time pass agreeably; a pleasant means of amusement, recreation, or sport: to play cards as a pastime.
obverse: the side of a coin, medal, flag, etc., that bears the principal design (opposed to reverse).
toss: to throw, pitch, or fling, especially to throw lightly or carelessly: to toss a piece of paper into the wastebasket.
nail: a slender, typically rod-shaped rigid piece of metal, usually in any of numerous standard lengths from a fraction of an inch to several inches and having one end pointed and the other enlarged and flattened, for hammering into or through wood, other building materials, etc., as used in building, in fastening, or in holding separate pieces together.
gap: a break or opening, as in a fence, wall, or military line; breach: We found a gap in the enemy's line of fortifications.
aperture: an opening, as a hole, slit, crack, gap, etc.
sock: a short stocking usually reaching to the calf or just above the ankle.
cure: a means of healing or restoring to health; remedy.
academy: a secondary or high school, especially a private one.
ratio: the relation between two similar magnitudes with respect to the number of times the first contains the second: the ratio of 5 to 2, written 5:2 or 5/2.
ticket: a slip, usually of paper or cardboard, serving as evidence that the holder has paid a fare or admission or is entitled to some service, right, or the like: a railroad ticket; a theater ticket.
irregular: without symmetry, even shape, formal arrangement, etc.: an irregular pattern.
porcelain: a strong, vitreous, translucent ceramic material, biscuit-fired at a low temperature, the glaze then fired at a very high temperature.
appendage: a subordinate part attached to something; an auxiliary part; addition.
vestibule: a passage, hall, or antechamber between the outer door and the interior parts of a house or building.
biochemistry: the science dealing with the chemistry of living matter.
polypeptide: a chain of amino acids linked together by peptide bonds and having a molecular weight of up to about 10,000.
collagen: any of a class of extracellular proteins abundant in higher animals, especially in the skin, bone, cartilage, tendon, and teeth, forming strong insoluble fibers and serving as connective tissue between cells, yielding gelatin when denatured by boiling.
hemoglobin: the oxygen-carrying pigment of red blood cells that gives them their red color and serves to convey oxygen to the tissues: occurs in reduced form (deoxyhemoglobin) in venous blood and in combination with oxygen (oxyhemoglobin) in arterial blood. Symbol:  Hb.
immune: protected from a disease or the like, as by inoculation.
glutinous: of the nature of glue; gluey; viscid; sticky.
hoof: the horny covering protecting the ends of the digits or encasing the foot in certain animals, as the ox and horse.
dilute: to make (a liquid) thinner or weaker by the addition of water or the like.
mastic: Also called mastic tree, lentisk. a small Mediterranean tree, Pistacia lentiscus, of the cashew family, that is the source of an aromatic resin used in making varnish and adhesives.
sticky: having the property of adhering, as glue; adhesive.
jaw: either of two bones, the mandible or maxilla, forming the framework of the mouth.
prehension: the act of seizing or grasping.
dentin: the hard, calcareous tissue, similar to but denser than bone, that forms the major portion of a tooth, surrounds the pulp cavity, and is situated beneath the enamel and cementum.
crown: any of various types of headgear worn by a monarch as a symbol of sovereignty, often made of precious metal and ornamented with valuable gems.
enamel: a glassy substance, usually opaque, applied by fusion to the surface of metal, pottery, etc., as an ornament or for protection.
struggle: to contend with an adversary or opposing force.
plaintiff: a person who brings suit in a court (opposed to defendant).
parallelogram: a quadrilateral having both pairs of opposite sides parallel to each other.
parallelepiped: a prism with six faces, all parallelograms.
fin: a membranous, winglike or paddlelike organ attached to any of various parts of the body of fishes and certain other aquatic animals, used for propulsion, steering, or balancing.
hindmost: furtherest behind or nearest the rear; last.
concrete: constituting an actual thing or instance; real: a concrete proof of his sincerity.
rustic: of, relating to, or living in the country, as distinguished from towns or cities; rural.
tranquillity: quality or state of being tranquil; calmness; peacefulness; quiet; serenity.
corporate: of, for, or belonging to a corporation or corporations: a corporate executive; She considers the new federal subsidy just corporate welfare.
populate: to inhabit; live in; be the inhabitants of.
hiram: a king of Tyre in the 10th century b.c. I Kings 5.
sculptor: a person who practices the art of sculpture.
weave: to interlace (threads, yarns, strips, fibrous material, etc.) so as to form a fabric or material.
winding: the act of a person or thing that winds.
plait: a braid, especially of hair or straw.
aground: on or into the ground; in a stranded condition or state: The ship ran aground.
ashore: to the shore; onto the shore: The schooner was driven ashore.
tide: the periodic rise and fall of the waters of the ocean and its inlets, produced by the attraction of the moon and sun, and occurring about every 12 hours.
stranded: composed of a specified number or kind of strands (usually used in combination): a five-stranded rope.
whale: any of the larger marine mammals of the order Cetacea, especially as distinguished from the smaller dolphins and porpoises, having a fishlike body, forelimbs modified into flippers, and a head that is horizontally flattened.
post: a strong piece of timber, metal, or the like, set upright as a support, a point of attachment, a place for displaying notices, etc.
salary: a fixed compensation periodically paid to a person for regular work or services.
shaft: a long pole forming the body of various weapons, as lances, halberds, or arrows.
cavalry: He spent Thanksgiving this year with his son, who "rode in like the cavalry" when Reeger needed him, he says.
raising: a rule of transformational grammar that shifts the subject or object of an embedded clause into the subject or object position of the main clause, as in the derivation of The suspect appears to be innocent from It appears that the suspect is innocent.
fibril: a small or fine fiber or filament.
qualification: a quality, accomplishment, etc., that fits a person for some function, office, or the like.
hoist: to raise or lift, especially by some mechanical appliance: to hoist a flag; to hoist the mainsail.
innate: existing in one from birth; inborn; native: innate musical talent.
talent: a special natural ability or aptitude: a talent for drawing.
carpenter: a person who builds or repairs wooden structures, as houses, scaffolds, or shelving.
intelligible: capable of being understood; comprehensible; clear: an intelligible response.
annoyance: a person or thing that annoys; nuisance: Unwanted visitors are an annoyance.
comfort: to soothe, console, or reassure; bring cheer to: They tried to comfort her after her loss.
enjoy: to experience with joy; take pleasure in: He enjoys Chinese food.
lane: a narrow way or passage between hedges, fences, walls, or houses.
datum: a single piece of information, as a fact, statistic, or code; an item of data.
scarcely: barely; hardly; not quite: The light is so dim we can scarcely see.
estimate: to form an approximate judgment or opinion regarding the worth, amount, size, weight, etc., of; calculate approximately: to estimate the cost of a college education.
vesting: cloth that is usually of medium or heavy weight and has figures or ridges, as piqué, jacquard, dobby silk, or Bedford cord, originally used for decorative vests and now also for a variety of other garments.
petroleum: an oily, thick, flammable, usually dark-colored liquid that is a form of bitumen or a mixture of various hydrocarbons, occurring naturally in various parts of the world and commonly obtained by drilling: used in a natural or refined state as fuel, or separated by distillation into gasoline, naphtha, benzene, kerosene, paraffin, etc.
condensed: reduced in volume, area, length, or scope; shortened: a condensed version of the book.
keyboard: the row or set of keys on a piano, organ, or the like.
glove: a covering for the hand made with a separate sheath for each finger and for the thumb.
earring: an ornament worn on or hanging from the lobe of the ear.
instead: as a substitute or replacement; in the place or stead of someone or something: We ordered tea but were served coffee instead.
intervention: the act or fact of intervening.
potentially: possibly but not yet actually: potentially useful information.
catastrophic: of the nature of a catastrophe, or disastrous event; calamitous: a catastrophic failure of the dam.
severe: harsh; unnecessarily extreme: severe criticism; severe laws.
trying: extremely annoying, difficult, or the like; straining one's patience and goodwill to the limit: a trying day; a trying experience.
ellipse: a plane curve such that the sums of the distances of each point in its periphery from two fixed points, the foci, are equal. It is a conic section formed by the intersection of a right circular cone by a plane that cuts the axis and the surface of the cone. Typical equation: (x 2 / a 2) + (y 2 / b 2) = 1. If a = b the ellipse is a circle.
donor: a person who gives or donates.
astronomy: the science that deals with the material universe beyond the earth's atmosphere.
spacecraft: a vehicle designed for travel or operation in space beyond the earth's atmosphere or in orbit around the earth.
heaven: the abode of God, the angels, and the spirits of the righteous after death; the place or state of existence of the blessed after the mortal life.
underbrush: shrubs, saplings, low vines, etc., growing under the large trees in a wood or forest.
woodland: land covered with woods or trees.
soot: a black, carbonaceous substance produced during incomplete combustion of coal, wood, oil, etc., rising in fine particles and adhering to the sides of the chimney or pipe conveying the smoke: also conveyed in the atmosphere to other locations.
sill: a horizontal timber, block, or the like serving as a foundation of a wall, house, etc.
tomato: any of several plants belonging to the genus Lycopersicon, of the nightshade family, native to Mexico and Central and South America, especially the widely cultivated species L. lycopersicum, bearing a mildly acid, pulpy, usually red fruit eaten raw or cooked as a vegetable.
potato: Also called Irish potato, white potato. the edible tuber of a cultivated plant, Solanum tuberosum, of the nightshade family.
onion: a plant, Allium cepa, of the amaryllis family, having an edible, succulent, pungent bulb.
asparagus: any plant of the genus Asparagus, of the lily family, especially A. officianalis, cultivated for its edible shoots.
spinach: a plant, Spinacia oleracea, cultivated for its edible, crinkly or flat leaves.
structural: of or relating to structure; pertaining or essential to a structure.
lateral: of or relating to the side; situated at, proceeding from, or directed to a side: a lateral view.
liver: Anatomy. a large, reddish-brown, glandular organ located in the upper right side of the abdominal cavity, divided by fissures into five lobes and functioning in the secretion of bile and various metabolic processes.
heart: Anatomy. a hollow, pumplike organ of blood circulation, composed mainly of rhythmically contractile smooth muscle, located in the chest between the lungs and slightly to the left and consisting of four chambers: a right atrium that receives blood returning from the body via the superior and inferior vena cavae, a right ventricle that pumps the blood through the pulmonary artery to the lungs for oxygenation, a left atrium that receives the oxygenated blood via the pulmonary veins and passes it through the mitral valve, and a left ventricle that pumps the oxygenated blood, via the aorta, throughout the body.
aorta: the main trunk of the arterial system, conveying blood from the left ventricle of the heart to all of the body except the lungs.
inch: a unit of length, 1/12 (0.0833) foot, equivalent to 2.54 centimeters.
fore: situated at or toward the front, as compared with something else.
deduction: the act or process of deducting; subtraction.
defining: decisive; critically important: Taking a course in architecture was a defining turn in her life.
perimeter: the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure.
scholarly: of, like, or befitting a scholar: scholarly habits.
yale: Elihu, 1648–1721, English colonial official, born in America: governor of Madras 1687–92; principal benefactor of the Collegiate School at Saybrook, Connecticut (now Yale University).
inward: toward the inside, interior, or center, as of a place, space, or body.
inmost: situated farthest within: the inmost recesses of the forest.
hinder: to cause delay, interruption, or difficulty in; hamper; impede: The storm hindered our progress.
optical: of, relating to, or applying optics or the principles of optics.
convergence: an act or instance of converging.
magnification: the act of magnifying or the state of being magnified.
rod: a stick, wand, staff, or the like, of wood, metal, or other material.
cone: From cone bras at Jean-Paul Gaultier to Doc Martens and crop-tops on Lindsay Lohan and Agyness Deyn, grunge-era fashion is back.
doublet: a close-fitting outer garment, with or without sleeves and sometimes having a short skirt, worn by men in the Renaissance.
triplet: one of three children or offspring born at the same birth.
gemstone: a precious or semiprecious stone that can be cut and polished for use as a gem.
complainant: a person, group, or company that makes a complaint, as in a legal action.
objection: a reason or argument offered in disagreement, opposition, refusal, or disapproval.
powerless: unable to produce an effect: a disease against which modern medicine is virtually powerless.
adjust: to change (something) so that it fits, corresponds, or conforms; adapt; accommodate: to adjust expenses to income.
