lengthen: to make longer; make greater in length.
diametrical: of, relating to, or along a diameter.
mutual: possessed, experienced, performed, etc., by each of two or more with respect to the other; reciprocal: to have mutual respect.
suggest: to mention or introduce (an idea, proposition, plan, etc.) for consideration or possible action: The architect suggested that the building be restored.
manager: a person who has control or direction of an institution, business, etc., or of a part, division, or phase of it.
crackdown: the severe or stern enforcement of regulations, laws, etc., as to root out abuses or correct a problem.
triumph: the act, fact, or condition of being victorious or triumphant; victory; conquest.
generous: liberal in giving or sharing; unselfish: a generous patron of the arts; a generous gift.
fly: to move through the air using wings.
demonstration: the act or circumstance of proving or being proved conclusively, as by reasoning or a show of evidence: a belief incapable of demonstration.
appreciation: gratitude; thankful recognition: They showed their appreciation by giving him a gold watch.
acclamation: a loud shout or other demonstration of welcome, goodwill, or approval.
aesthetics: the branch of philosophy dealing with such notions as the beautiful, the ugly, the sublime, the comic, etc., as applicable to the fine arts, with a view to establishing the meaning and validity of critical judgments concerning works of art, and the principles underlying or justifying such judgments.
ugly: very unattractive or unpleasant to look at; offensive to the sense of beauty; displeasing in appearance.
greece: Ancient Greek Hellas. Modern Greek Ellas. a republic in S Europe at the S end of the Balkan Peninsula. 50,147 sq. mi. (129,880 sq. km). Capital:  Athens.
orderly: arranged or disposed in a neat, tidy manner or in a regular sequence: an orderly desk.
excessive: going beyond the usual, necessary, or proper limit or degree; characterized by excess: excessive charges; excessive criticism.
amiable: having or showing pleasant, good-natured personal qualities; affable: an amiable disposition.
scatter: to throw loosely about; distribute at irregular intervals: to scatter seeds.
discharge: to relieve of a charge or load; unload: to discharge a ship.
gleam: a flash or beam of light: the gleam of a lantern in the dark.
poverty: the state or condition of having little or no money, goods, or means of support; condition of being poor. Synonyms: privation, neediness, destitution, indigence, pauperism, penury.
careful: cautious in one's actions: Be careful when you cross the street.
critical: inclined to find fault or to judge with severity, often too readily.
knitting: the act of a person or thing that knits.
woolen: any cloth of carded wool yarn of which the fibers vary in length: bulkier, looser, and less regular than worsted.
curly: curling or tending to curl: curly blond hair.
fleece: the coat of wool that covers a sheep or a similar animal.
keratinous: composed of or resembling keratin; horny.
cocoon: the silky envelope spun by the larvae of many insects, as silkworms, serving as a covering while they are in the pupal stage.
silkworm: the larva of the Chinese silkworm moth, Bombyx mori, which spins a cocoon of commercially valuable silk.
downy: of the nature of or resembling down; fluffy; soft.
mallow: any of various plants of the genus Malva, including several popular garden plants, as the musk mallow.
wadding: any fibrous or soft material for stuffing, padding, packing, etc., especially carded cotton in specially prepared sheets.
shock: a sudden and violent blow or impact; collision.
entertainer: a singer, comedian, dancer, reciter, or the like, especially a professional one.
comical: producing laughter; amusing; funny: a comical fellow.
engaging: winning; attractive; pleasing: an engaging smile.
humorous: characterized by humor; funny; comical: a humorous anecdote.
silo: a structure, typically cylindrical, in which fodder or forage is kept.
livestock: the horses, cattle, sheep, and other useful animals kept or raised on a farm or ranch.
livelihood: a means of supporting one's existence, especially financially or vocationally; living: to earn a livelihood as a tenant farmer.
catch: to seize or capture, especially after pursuit: to catch a criminal; to catch a runaway horse.
starch: a white, tasteless, solid carbohydrate, (C 6 H 1 0 O 5) n , occurring in the form of minute granules in the seeds, tubers, and other parts of plants, and forming an important constituent of rice, corn, wheat, beans, potatoes, and many other vegetable foods.
adhere: to stay attached; stick fast; cleave; cling (usually followed by to): The mud adhered to his shoes.
liberal: favorable to progress or reform, as in political or religious affairs.
shift: to put (something) aside and replace it by another or others; change or exchange: to shift friends; to shift ideas.
dance: to move one's feet or body, or both, rhythmically in a pattern of steps, especially to the accompaniment of music.
resounding: making an echoing sound: a resounding thud.
thundering: of, relating to, or accompanied by thunder.
cavern: a cave, especially one that is large and mostly underground.
broil: to cook by direct heat, as on a gridiron over the heat or in an oven under the heat; grill: to broil a steak.
flesh: the soft substance of a human or other animal body, consisting of muscle and fat.
manning: Henry Edward, 1808–92, English prelate and ecclesiastical writer: cardinal 1875–92.
suicide: the intentional taking of one's own life.
regime: a mode or system of rule or government: a dictatorial regime.
stimulus: something that incites to action or exertion or quickens action, feeling, thought, etc.: The approval of others is a potent stimulus.
incite: to stir, encourage, or urge on; stimulate or prompt to action: to incite a crowd to riot.
honorable: in accordance with or characterized by principles of honor; upright: They were all honorable men.
dishonesty: lack of honesty; a disposition to lie, cheat, or steal.
inclination: a disposition or bent, especially of the mind or will; a liking or preference: Much against his inclination, he was forced to resign.
inequity: lack of equity; unfairness; favoritism or bias.
allegiance: the loyalty of a citizen to his or her government or of a subject to his or her sovereign.
online: operating under the direct control of, or connected to, a main computer.
lexical: of or relating to the words or vocabulary of a language, especially as distinguished from its grammatical and syntactical aspects.
lexicon: a wordbook or dictionary, especially of Greek, Latin, or Hebrew.
glossary: a list of terms in a special subject, field, or area of usage, with accompanying definitions.
pocket: a shaped piece of fabric attached inside or outside a garment and forming a pouch used especially for carrying small articles.
multivolume: consisting of or encompassing several volumes: a multivolume encyclopedia.
dvd: an optical disk that can store a very large amount of digital data, as text, music, or images.
browse: to eat, nibble at, or feed on (leaves, tender shoots, or other soft vegetation).
electronic: of or relating to electronics or to devices, circuits, or systems developed through electronics.
access: the ability, right, or permission to approach, enter, speak with, or use; admittance: They have access to the files.
unabridged: not abridged or shortened, as a book.
resident: a person who resides in a place.
jack: any of various portable devices for raising or lifting heavy objects short heights, using various mechanical, pneumatic, or hydraulic methods.
differential: of or relating to difference or diversity.
aves: a class of vertebrates comprising the birds.
scaly: covered with or abounding in scales or scale.
beak: the bill of a bird; neb.
phonology: the study of the distribution and patterning of speech sounds in a language and of the tacit rules governing pronunciation.
discontinuous: not continuous; broken; interrupted; intermittent: a discontinuous chain of mountains; a discontinuous argument.
globose: having the shape of a globe; globelike.
citrus: any small tree or spiny shrub of the genus Citrus, of the rue family, including the lemon, lime, orange, tangerine, grapefruit, citron, kumquat, and shaddock, widely cultivated for fruit or grown as an ornamental.
testimony: Law. the statement or declaration of a witness under oath or affirmation, usually in court.
orator: a person who delivers an oration; a public speaker, especially one of great eloquence: Demosthenes was one of the great orators of ancient Greece.
threatening: tending or intended to menace: threatening gestures.
acoustic: pertaining to the sense or organs of hearing, to sound, or to the science of sound.
auditory: Anatomy, Physiology. pertaining to hearing, to the sense of hearing, or to the organs of hearing.
glide: to move smoothly and continuously along, as if without effort or resistance, as a flying bird, a boat, or a skater.
transcription: the act or process of transcribing.
exposed: left or being without shelter or protection: The house stood on a windy, exposed cliff.
crack: to break without complete separation of parts; become fissured: The plate cracked when I dropped it, but it was still usable.
oy: (used to express dismay, pain, annoyance, grief, etc.)
plaything: a thing to play with; toy.
follower: a person or thing that follows.
attendant: a person who attends another, as to perform a service.
adherent: a person who follows or upholds a leader, cause, etc.; supporter; follower.
hog: a hoofed mammal of the family Suidae, order Artiodactyla, comprising boars and swine.
pig: a young swine of either sex, especially a domestic hog, Sus scrofa, weighing less than 120 pounds (220 kg)
wild: living in a state of nature; not tamed or domesticated: a wild animal; wild geese.
preserve: to keep alive or in existence; make lasting: to preserve our liberties as free citizens.
working: the act of a person or thing that works.
suppress: to put an end to the activities of (a person, body of persons, etc.): to suppress the Communist and certain left-leaning parties.
extinguish: to put out (a fire, light, etc.); put out the flame of (something burning or lighted): to extinguish a candle.
rebellion: open, organized, and armed resistance to one's government or ruler.
rebel: a person who refuses allegiance to, resists, or rises in arms against the government or ruler of his or her country.
mutiny: revolt or rebellion against constituted authority, especially by sailors against their officers.
membership: the state of being a member, as of a society or club.
ninety: a cardinal number, ten times nine.
applicable: applying or capable of being applied; relevant; suitable; appropriate: an applicable rule; a solution that is applicable to the problem.
legislation: the act of making or enacting laws.
authorized: given or endowed with authority: an authorized agent.
court: Now news has emerged he may be forced to testify in court over a stolen BlackBerry, Tom Sykes reports.
magistrate: a civil officer charged with the administration of the law.
campaign: She also insisted that no matter the results in Iowa, her campaign will go on.
knock: to strike a sounding blow with the fist, knuckles, or anything hard, especially on a door, window, or the like, as in seeking admittance, calling attention, or giving a signal: to knock on the door before entering.
enmity: a feeling or condition of hostility; hatred; ill will; animosity; antagonism.
antagonism: an active hostility or opposition, as between unfriendly or conflicting groups: the antagonism between the liberal and the conservative parties.
upsetting: tending to disturb or upset: an upsetting experience.
disquieting: causing anxiety or uneasiness; disturbing: disquieting news.
inboard: located nearer the longitudinal axis or center, as of an airplane: the inboard section of a wing.
outboard: located on the exterior of a hull or aircraft.
cultivation: the act or art of cultivating.
smash: to break to pieces with violence and often with a crashing sound, as by striking, letting fall, or dashing against something; shatter: He smashed the vase against the wall.
cave: a hollow in the earth, especially one opening more or less horizontally into a hill, mountain, etc.
crumble: to break into small fragments or crumbs.
tension: the act of stretching or straining.
fort: a strong or fortified place occupied by troops and usually surrounded by walls, ditches, and other defensive works; a fortress; fortification.
citadel: a fortress that commands a city and is used in the control of the inhabitants and in defense during attack or siege.
malady: any disorder or disease of the body, especially one that is chronic or deepseated.
underlying: lying or situated beneath, as a substratum.
municipal: of or relating to a town or city or its local government: municipal elections.
govern: to rule over by right of authority: to govern a nation.
mentality: mental capacity or endowment: a person of average mentality.
sturdy: strongly built; stalwart; robust: sturdy young athletes.
morbid: suggesting an unhealthy mental state or attitude; unwholesomely gloomy, sensitive, extreme, etc.: a morbid interest in death.
scent: a distinctive odor, especially when agreeable: the scent of roses.
olfactory: of or relating to the sense of smell: olfactory organs.
inhale: to breathe in; draw in by breathing: to inhale the polluted air.
himself: an emphatic appositive of him or he1 : He himself spoke to the men.
herself: an emphatic appositive of her or she: She herself wrote the letter.
organize: to form as or into a whole consisting of interdependent or coordinated parts, especially for united action: to organize a committee.
thorax: Anatomy. the part of the trunk in humans and higher vertebrates between the neck and the abdomen, containing the cavity, enclosed by the ribs, sternum, and certain vertebrae, in which the heart, lungs, etc., are situated; chest.
acute: sharp or severe in effect; intense: acute sorrow; an acute pain.
affliction: a state of pain, distress, or grief; misery: They sympathized with us in our affliction.
liability: Thus the transaction was all geared to assuming a specific layer of liability, avoiding an open-ended assumption.
peril: exposure to injury, loss, or destruction; grave risk; jeopardy; danger: They faced the peril of falling rocks.
luck: the force that seems to operate for good or ill in a person's life, as in shaping circumstances, events, or opportunities: With my luck I'll probably get pneumonia.
routine: a customary or regular course of procedure.
agreed: arranged or set by common consent: They met at the agreed time.
mowing: the act of leveling or cutting down grass, grain, etc., with a mowing machine or scythe.
lawn: a stretch of open, grass-covered land, especially one closely mowed, as near a house, on an estate, or in a park.
desirable: worth having or wanting; pleasing, excellent, or fine: a desirable apartment.
objectionable: causing or tending to cause an objection, disapproval, or protest.
unintentional: not intentional or deliberate: an unintentional omission from the list.
hurt: to cause bodily injury to; injure: He was badly hurt in the accident.
lockhart: John Gibson, 1794–1854, Scottish biographer and novelist.
certainly: with certainty; without doubt; assuredly: I'll certainly be there.
jump: to spring clear of the ground or other support by a sudden muscular effort; leap: to jump into the air; to jump out a window.
ditch: a long, narrow excavation made in the ground by digging, as for draining or irrigating land; trench.
missile: an object or weapon for throwing, hurling, or shooting, as a stone, bullet, or arrow.
feathered: clothed, covered, or provided with feathers, as a bird or an arrow.
blowgun: a pipe or tube through which darts or other missiles are blown by the breath.
voyage: a course of travel or passage, especially a long journey by water to a distant place.
coil: to wind into continuous, regularly spaced rings one above the other: to coil a wire around a pencil.
confession: acknowledgment; avowal; admission: a confession of incompetence.
carnivorous: flesh-eating: A dog is a carnivorous animal.
tawny: of a dark yellowish or dull yellowish-brown color.
feline: belonging or pertaining to the cat family, Felidae.
panthera: a genus of chiefly large cats that includes the snow leopard, tiger, leopard, jaguar, and lion, most having the ability to roar.
tigris: a river in SW Asia, flowing SE from SE Turkey through Iraq, joining the Euphrates to form the Shatt-al-Arab. 1150 miles (1850 km) long.
subspecies: a subdivision of a species, especially a geographical or ecological subdivision.
malay: of, relating to, or characteristic of a racially intermixed people who are the dominant population of the Malay Peninsula and adjacent islands.
peninsula: an area of land almost completely surrounded by water except for an isthmus connecting it with the mainland.
siberia: Russian Sibirʾ. an extensive region in the Russian Federation in N Asia, extending from the Ural Mountains to the Pacific.
extinct: no longer in existence; that has ended or died out: an extinct species of fish.
flood: a great flowing or overflowing of water, especially over land not usually submerged.
interested: having an interest in something; concerned: Interested members will meet at noon.
disinterested: unbiased by personal interest or advantage; not influenced by selfish motives: a disinterested decision by the referee.
prudence: the quality or fact of being prudent, or wise in practical affairs, as by providing for the future.
wariness: the state or quality of being wary.
typist: a person who operates a typewriter.
variance: the state, quality, or fact of being variable, divergent, different, or anomalous.
irrational: without the faculty of reason; deprived of reason.
gunfire: the firing of a gun or guns.
portal: a door, gate, or entrance, especially one of imposing appearance, as to a palace.
scarf: a long, broad strip of wool, silk, lace, or other material worn about the neck, shoulders, or head, for ornament or protection against cold, drafts, etc.; muffler.
waist: the part of the body in humans between the ribs and the hips, usually the narrowest part of the torso.
uniform: identical or consistent, as from example to example, place to place, or moment to moment: uniform spelling; a uniform building code.
disclose: to make known; reveal or uncover: to disclose a secret.
reveal: to make known; disclose; divulge: to reveal a secret.
unexpected: not expected; unforeseen; surprising: an unexpected pleasure; an unexpected development.
conceal: to hide; withdraw or remove from observation; cover or keep from sight: He concealed the gun under his coat.
rectangle: a parallelogram having four right angles.
humble: not proud or arrogant; modest: to be humble although successful.
wearing: gradually impairing or wasting: Reading small print can be wearing on the eyes.
betrothal: the act or state of being betrothed; engagement.
encompass: to form a circle about; encircle; surround: He built a moat to encompass the castle.
throng: a multitude of people crowded or assembled together; crowd.
deliver: to carry and turn over (letters, goods, etc.) to the intended recipient or recipients: to deliver mail; to deliver a package.
thorough: executed without negligence or omissions: a thorough search.
applied: having a practical purpose or use; derived from or involved with actual phenomena (distinguished from theoretical, opposed to pure): applied mathematics; applied science.
edward: Prince of Wales and Duke of Cornwall ("The Black Prince") 1330–76, English military leader (son of Edward III).
physicist: a scientist who specializes in physics.
profitable: yielding profit; remunerative: a profitable deal.
restless: characterized by or showing inability to remain at rest: a restless mood.
disquiet: lack of calm, peace, or ease; anxiety; uneasiness.
east: a cardinal point of the compass, 90° to the right of north. Abbreviation:  E.
berlin: a large, four-wheeled, closed carriage hung between two perches and having two interior seats.
mollusk: any invertebrate of the phylum Mollusca, typically having a calcareous shell of one, two, or more pieces that wholly or partly enclose the soft, unsegmented body, including the chitons, snails, bivalves, squids, and octopuses.
bivalve: Also called lamellibranch. Zoology. any mollusk, as the oyster, clam, scallop, or mussel, of the class Bivalvia, having two shells hinged together, a soft body, and lamellate gills.
watermelon: the large, roundish or elongated fruit of a trailing vine, Citrullus lanata, of the gourd family, having a hard, green rind and a sweet, juicy, usually pink or red pulp.
bacon: the back and sides of the hog, salted and dried or smoked, usually sliced thin and fried for food.
convert: to change (something) into a different form or properties; transmute; transform.
alimentary: concerned with the function of nutrition; nutritive.
assimilation: the act or process of assimilating, or of absorbing information, experiences, etc.: the need for quick assimilation of the facts.
superphylum: a category of related phyla within a kingdom.
protista: a taxonomic kingdom comprising the protists.
eukaryote: any organism having as its fundamental structural unit a cell type that contains specialized organelles in the cytoplasm, a membrane-bound nucleus enclosing genetic material organized into chromosomes, and an elaborate system of division by mitosis or meiosis, characteristic of all life forms except bacteria, blue-green algae, and other primitive microorganisms.
motile: Biology. moving or capable of moving spontaneously: motile cells; motile spores.
nutrition: the act or process of nourishing or of being nourished.
impossible: not possible; unable to be, exist, happen, etc.
flex: to bend, as a part of the body: He flexed his arms to show off his muscles.
crooked: not straight; bending; curved: a crooked path.
bow: to bend the knee or body or incline the head, as in reverence, submission, salutation, recognition, or acknowledgment.
ea: the Akkadian god of wisdom, the son of Apsu and father of Marduk: the counterpart of Enki.
trustful: full of trust; free of distrust, suspicion, or the like; confiding: a trustful friend.
dependence: the state of relying on or needing someone or something for aid, support, or the like.
guaranty: a warrant, pledge, or formal assurance given as security that another's debt or obligation will be fulfilled.
factual: of or relating to facts; concerning facts: factual accuracy.
shortcoming: a failure, defect, or deficiency in conduct, condition, thought, ability, etc.: a social shortcoming; a shortcoming of his philosophy.
abroad: in or to a foreign country or countries: famous at home and abroad.
equip: to furnish or provide with whatever is needed for use or for any undertaking; fit out, as a ship or army: They spent several thousand dollars to equip their boat.
schedule: a plan of procedure, usually written, for a proposed objective, especially with reference to the sequence of and time allotted for each item or operation necessary to its completion: The schedule allows three weeks for this stage.
chromatin: the readily stainable substance of a cell nucleus, consisting of DNA, RNA, and various proteins, that forms chromosomes during cell division.
sex: either the male or female division of a species, especially as differentiated with reference to the reproductive functions.
respectively: in precisely the order given; sequentially.
pouch: a bag, sack, or similar receptacle, especially one for small articles or quantities: a tobacco pouch.
engagement: the act of engaging or the state of being engaged.
waterloo: a village in central Belgium, south of Brussels: Napoleon decisively defeated here on June 18, 1815.
ancestor: a person from whom one is descended; forebear; progenitor.
cancel: to make void; revoke; annul: to cancel a reservation.
hate: to dislike intensely or passionately; feel extreme aversion for or extreme hostility toward; detest: to hate the enemy; to hate bigotry.
antipathy: a natural, basic, or habitual repugnance; aversion.
hurtful: causing hurt or injury; injurious; harmful.
detrimental: causing detriment, as loss or injury; damaging; harmful.
prepare: to put in proper condition or readiness: to prepare a patient for surgery.
preliminary: preceding and leading up to the main part, matter, or business; introductory; preparatory: preliminary examinations.
sketch: a simply or hastily executed drawing or painting, especially a preliminary one, giving the essential features without the details.
disputation: the act of disputing or debating; verbal controversy; discussion or debate.
distribute: to divide and give out in shares; deal out; allot.
allocate: to set apart for a particular purpose; assign or allot: to allocate funds for new projects.
assign: to give or allocate; allot: to assign rooms at a hotel.
ethel: a female given name: from a Germanic word meaning “noble.”.
tie: to bind, fasten, or attach with a cord, string, or the like, drawn together and knotted: to tie a tin can on a dog's tail.
tensile: of or relating to tension: tensile strain.
senior: older or elder (designating the older of two men bearing the same name, as a father whose son is named after him, often written as Sr. or sr. following the name): I'd like to speak with the senior Mr. Hansen, please. I'm privileged to introduce Mr. Edward Andrew Hansen, Sr.
diplomat: a person appointed by a national government to conduct official negotiations and maintain political, economic, and social relations with another country or countries.
beat: to strike violently or forcefully and repeatedly.
popular: regarded with favor, approval, or affection by people in general: a popular preacher.
razor: a sharp-edged instrument used especially for shaving the face or trimming the hair.
marine: of or relating to the sea; existing in or produced by the sea: marine vegetation.
corps: a military organization consisting of officers and enlisted personnel or of officers alone: the U.S. Marine Corps; corps of cadets.
brigadier: British Military. a rank between colonel and major general.
blast: a sudden and violent gust of wind: Wintry blasts chilled us to the marrow.
surely: firmly; unerringly; without missing, slipping, etc.
crash: to make a loud, clattering noise, as of something dashed to pieces.
swing: to cause to move to and fro, sway, or oscillate, as something suspended from above: to swing one's arms in walking.
pendulum: a body so suspended from a fixed point as to move to and fro by the action of gravity and acquired momentum.
promising: giving favorable promise; likely to turn out well: a promising young man; a promising situation.
discontented: not content or satisfied; dissatisfied; restlessly unhappy: For all their wealth, or perhaps because of it, they were discontented.
sulky: marked by or given to sulking; sullen.
morose: gloomily or sullenly ill-humored, as a person or mood.
tenure: the holding or possessing of anything: the tenure of an office.
hereditary: passing, or capable of passing, naturally from parent to offspring through the genes: Blue eyes are hereditary in our family.
exalted: raised or elevated, as in rank or character; of high station: an exalted personage.
regulation: a law, rule, or other order prescribed by authority, especially to regulate conduct.
partner: a person who shares or is associated with another in some action or endeavor; sharer; associate.
marionette: a puppet manipulated from above by strings attached to its jointed limbs.
suffragist: an advocate of the grant or extension of political suffrage, especially to women.
italian: of or relating to Italy, its people, or their language.
metaphysics: the branch of philosophy that treats of first principles, includes ontology and cosmology, and is intimately connected with epistemology.
petersburg: a city in SE Virginia: besieged by Union forces 1864–65.
criterion: a standard of judgment or criticism; a rule or principle for evaluating or testing something.
managerial: pertaining to management or a manager: managerial functions; the managerial class of society.
policy: a definite course of action adopted for the sake of expediency, facility, etc.: We have a new company policy.
compilation: the act of compiling: the compilation of documents.
revision: the act or work of revising.
educate: to develop the faculties and powers of (a person) by teaching, instruction, or schooling. Synonyms: instruct, school, drill, indoctrinate.
touching: affecting; moving; pathetic: a touching scene of farewell.
repair: to restore to a good or sound condition after decay or damage; mend: to repair a motor.
mend: to make (something broken, worn, torn, or otherwise damaged) whole, sound, or usable by repairing: to mend old clothes; to mend a broken toy.
span: the distance between the tip of the thumb and the tip of the little finger when the hand is fully extended.
yawning: being or standing wide open; gaping: the yawning mouth of a cave.
fissure: a narrow opening produced by cleavage or separation of parts.
cleft: a space or opening made by cleavage; a split.
gorge: a narrow cleft with steep, rocky walls, especially one through which a stream runs.
net: a bag or other contrivance of strong thread or cord worked into an open, meshed fabric, for catching fish, birds, or other animals: a butterfly net.
vein: one of the system of branching vessels or tubes conveying blood from various parts of the body to the heart.
artery: Anatomy. a blood vessel that conveys blood from the heart to any part of the body.
sewer: an artificial conduit, usually underground, for carrying off waste water and refuse, as in a town or city.
brisk: quick and active; lively: brisk trading; a brisk walk.
alternate: to interchange repeatedly and regularly with one another in time or place; rotate (usually followed by with): Day alternates with night.
suquamish: a member of a Salishan-speaking North American Indian people of Washington, near Puget Sound.
vocation: a particular occupation, business, or profession; calling.
dentistry: the profession or science dealing with the prevention and treatment of diseases and malformations of the teeth, gums, and oral cavity, and the removal, correction, and replacement of decayed, damaged, or lost parts, including such operations as the filling and crowning of teeth, the straightening of teeth, and the construction of artificial dentures.
department: a distinct part of anything arranged in divisions; a division of a complex whole or organized system.
guinea: a coastal region in W Africa, extending from the Gambia River to the Gabon estuary.
postscript: a paragraph, phrase, etc., added to a letter that has already been concluded and signed by the writer.
insult: to treat or speak to insolently or with contemptuous rudeness; affront.
balloon: a bag made of thin rubber or other light material, usually brightly colored, inflated with air or with some lighter-than-air gas and used as a children's plaything or as a decoration.
viscous: of a glutinous nature or consistency; sticky; thick; adhesive.
foliated: shaped like a leaf or leaves: foliated ornaments.
greasy: smeared, covered, or soiled with grease.
lubricant: a substance, as oil or grease, for lessening friction, especially in the working parts of a mechanism.
california: a state in the W United States, on the Pacific coast. 158,693 sq. mi. (411,015 sq. km). Capital:  Sacramento.
matthew: one of the four Evangelists, a customs collector from Capernaum, summoned to be one of the 12 apostles: originally called Levi. Matt. 9:9–13.
fearful: causing or apt to cause fear; frightening: a fearful apparition.
inert: having no inherent power of action, motion, or resistance (opposed to active): inert matter.
monatomic: having one atom in the molecule.
tungsten: a rare, metallic element having a bright-gray color, a metallic luster, and a high melting point, 3410° C, and found in wolframite, tungstite, and other minerals: used in alloys of high-speed cutting tools, electric-lamp filaments, etc. Symbol:  W; atomic weight:  183.85; atomic number:  74; specific gravity:  19.3.
devoid: not possessing, untouched by, void, or destitute (usually followed by of).
quantum: quantity or amount: the least quantum of evidence.
transition: movement, passage, or change from one position, state, stage, subject, concept, etc., to another; change: the transition from adolescence to adulthood.
bush: a low plant with many branches that arise from or near the ground.
ostensible: outwardly appearing as such; professed; pretended: an ostensible cheerfulness concealing sadness.
nominal: being such in name only; so-called; putative: a nominal treaty; the nominal head of the country.
rejection: the act or process of rejecting.
proffer: to put before a person for acceptance; offer.
viewing: an act, ceremony, or occasion of seeing, watching, or inspecting: the viewing of a corpse.
devote: to give up or appropriate to or concentrate on a particular pursuit, occupation, purpose, cause, etc.: to devote one's time to reading.
wrought: Archaic except in some senses. a simple past tense and past participle of work.
elasticity: the state or quality of being elastic.
murder: Law. the killing of another human being under conditions specifically covered in law. In the U.S., special statutory definitions include murder committed with malice aforethought, characterized by deliberation or premeditation or occurring during the commission of another serious crime, as robbery or arson (first-degree murder) and murder by intent but without deliberation or premeditation (second-degree murder)
modal: of or relating to mode, manner, or form.
preclude: to prevent the presence, existence, or occurrence of; make impossible: The insufficiency of the evidence precludes a conviction.
excel: to surpass others or be superior in some respect or area; do extremely well: to excel in math.
estimation: judgment or opinion: In my estimation the boy is guilty.
statesman: a person who is experienced in the art of government or versed in the administration of government affairs.
professor: a teacher of the highest academic rank in a college or university, who has been awarded the title Professor in a particular branch of learning; a full professor: a professor of Spanish literature.
commentary: a series of comments, explanations, or annotations: a commentary on the Bible; news followed by a commentary.
insight: an instance of apprehending the true nature of a thing, especially through intuitive understanding: an insight into 18th-century life.
abundance: an extremely plentiful or oversufficient quantity or supply: an abundance of grain.
profit: pecuniary gain resulting from the employment of capital in any transaction. Compare gross profit, net profit.
dealer: a person who buys and sells articles without altering their condition; trader or merchant, especially a wholesaler: I got a dealer's discount on this coat.
trader: a person who trades; a merchant or businessperson.
merchandise: the manufactured goods bought and sold in any business.
raw: uncooked, as articles of food: a raw carrot.
seller: a person who sells; salesperson or vender.
assemble: to bring together or gather into one place, company, body, or whole.
farmer: a person who farms; person who operates a farm or cultivates land.
stability: the state or quality of being stable.
calendar: a table or register with the days of each month and week in a year: He marked the date on his calendar.
february: the second month of the year, ordinarily containing 28 days, but containing 29 days in leap years. Abbreviation:  Feb.
probably: in all likelihood; very likely: He will probably attend.
destined: bound for a certain destination: a freighter destined for the Orient.
beforehand: in anticipation; in advance; ahead of time: We should have made reservations beforehand. I hope to be beforehand with my report.
foretaste: a slight and partial experience, knowledge, or taste of something to come in the future; anticipation.
foresee: to have prescience of; to know in advance; foreknow.
repay: to pay back or refund, as money.
platform: a horizontal surface or structure with a horizontal surface raised above the level of the surrounding area.
pulse: the regular throbbing of the arteries, caused by the successive contractions of the heart, especially as may be felt at an artery, as at the wrist.
ascend: to move, climb, or go upward; mount; rise: The airplane ascended into the clouds.
equality: the state or quality of being equal; correspondence in quantity, degree, value, rank, or ability: promoting equality of opportunity in the workplace.
unsuccessful: not achieving or not attended with success: an unsuccessful person; an unsuccessful venture.
slip: to move, flow, pass, or go smoothly or easily; glide; slide: Water slips off a smooth surface.
regain: to get again; recover: to regain one's health.
jail: a prison, especially one for the detention of persons awaiting trial or convicted of minor offenses.
impair: to make or cause to become worse; diminish in ability, value, excellence, etc.; weaken or damage: to impair one's health; to impair negotiations.
opportunity: an appropriate or favorable time or occasion: Their meeting afforded an opportunity to exchange views.
guidance: the act or function of guiding; leadership; direction.
lawyer: a person whose profession is to represent clients in a court of law or to advise or act for clients in other legal matters.
remind: to cause (a person) to remember; cause (a person) to think (of someone or something): Remind me to phone him tomorrow. That woman reminds me of my mother.
keepsake: anything kept, or given to be kept, as a token of friendship or affection; remembrance.
souvenir: a usually small and relatively inexpensive article given, kept, or purchased as a reminder of a place visited, an occasion, etc.; memento.
reward: a sum of money offered for the detection or capture of a criminal, the recovery of lost or stolen property, etc.
overcome: to get the better of in a struggle or conflict; conquer; defeat: to overcome the enemy.
conqueror: a person who conquers or vanquishes; victor.
ninth: next after the eighth; being the ordinal number for nine.
interpersonal: of or pertaining to the relations between persons: He has strong interpersonal skills.
familial: of, relating to, or characteristic of a family: familial ties.
conjugal: of, relating to, or characteristic of marriage: conjugal vows.
rebuild: to repair, especially to dismantle and reassemble with new parts: to rebuild an old car.
inspire: to fill with an animating, quickening, or exalting influence: His courage inspired his followers.
coach: a large, horse-drawn, four-wheeled carriage, usually enclosed.
marathon: a foot race over a course measuring 26 mi. 385 yards (42 km 195 meters).
thrive: to prosper; be fortunate or successful.
roll: to move along a surface by revolving or turning over and over, as a ball or a wheel.
tobacco: any of several plants belonging to the genus Nicotiana, of the nightshade family, especially one of those species, as N. tabacum, whose leaves are prepared for smoking or chewing or as snuff.
considerably: to a noteworthy or marked extent; much; noticeably; substantially; amply.
sara: a member of a people of the Central African Republic.
hubbard: Elbert Green, 1856–1915, U.S. author, editor, and printer.
dianetics: a theory devised by L.Ron Hubbard to explain the functions of the human mind and the relief of psychosomatic illness, based on the concept of an engram; it was published in 1950 and is also called dianetic therapy
pharynx: the tube or cavity, with its surrounding membrane and muscles, that connects the mouth and nasal passages with the esophagus.
larynx: Anatomy. a muscular and cartilaginous structure lined with mucous membrane at the upper part of the trachea in humans, in which the vocal cords are located.
trachea: Anatomy, Zoology. the tube in humans and other air-breathing vertebrates extending from the larynx to the bronchi, serving as the principal passage for conveying air to and from the lungs; the windpipe.
invertebrate: It has always been out of joint, a great slipshod Leviathan, at sixes and sevens, invertebrate and fungus-brained.
dried: simple past tense and past participle of dry.
camellia: any of several shrubs of the genus Camellia, especially C. japonica, native to Asia, having glossy evergreen leaves and white, pink, red, or variegated roselike flowers.
equivocal: allowing the possibility of several different meanings, as a word or phrase, especially with intent to deceive or misguide; susceptible of double interpretation; deliberately ambiguous: an equivocal answer.
indisputable: not disputable or deniable; uncontestable. indisputable evidence.
undeniable: incapable of being denied or disputed: undeniable evidence of arson.
mistakable: capable of being or liable to be mistaken or misunderstood.
torment: to afflict with great bodily or mental suffering; pain: to be tormented with violent headaches.
suffer: to undergo or feel pain or distress: The patient is still suffering.
fret: to feel or express worry, annoyance, discontent, or the like: Fretting about the lost ring isn't going to help.
mysticism: the beliefs, ideas, or mode of thought of mystics.
taught: simple past tense and past participle of teach.
priest: a person whose office it is to perform religious rites, and especially to make sacrificial offerings.
withdrawal: Also, withdrawment. the act or condition of withdrawing.
worldly: of or relating to this world as contrasted with heaven, spiritual life, etc.; earthly; mundane.
passive: not reacting visibly to something that might be expected to produce manifestations of an emotion or feeling.
divine: of or relating to a god, especially the Supreme Being.
molinism: the theological doctrine, formulated by Luis Molina, that the consent of the human will is necessary for divine grace to be effective.
divinity: the quality of being divine; divine nature.
adz: an axlike tool, for dressing timbers roughly, with a curved, chisellike steel head mounted at a right angle to the wooden handle.
secretion: (in a cell or gland) the act or process of separating, elaborating, and releasing a substance that fulfills some function within the organism or undergoes excretion.
mammalia: 1773, from Modern Latin (Linnaeus), from neuter plural of Late Latin mammalis, from mamma (see mammal).
nourish: to sustain with food or nutriment; supply with what is necessary for life, health, and growth.
jacob: the second son of Isaac, the twin brother of Esau, and father of the 12 patriarchs. Gen. 25:24–34.
lyricist: a person who writes the lyrics for songs.
marking: a mark, or a number or pattern of marks: birds with colorful markings.
grave: an excavation made in the earth in which to bury a dead body.
refrain: to abstain from an impulse to say or do something (often followed by from): I refrained from telling him what I thought.
lip: either of the two fleshy parts or folds forming the margins of the mouth and functioning in speech.
smart: to be a source of sharp, local, and usually superficial pain, as a wound.
breeze: a wind or current of air, especially a light or moderate one.
awe: an overwhelming feeling of reverence, admiration, fear, etc., produced by that which is grand, sublime, extremely powerful, or the like: in awe of God; in awe of great political figures.
consecration: the act of consecrating; dedication to the service and worship of a deity.
discredit: to injure the credit or reputation of; defame: an effort to discredit honest politicians.
persuasive: able, fitted, or intended to persuade: a very persuasive argument.
duly: in a due manner; properly; fittingly.
steer: to guide the course of (something in motion) by a rudder, helm, wheel, etc.: to steer a bicycle.
harbor: a part of a body of water along the shore deep enough for anchoring a ship and so situated with respect to coastal features, whether natural or artificial, as to provide protection from winds, waves, and currents.
neutron: an elementary particle having no charge, mass slightly greater than that of a proton, and spin of ½: a constituent of the nuclei of all atoms except those of hydrogen. Symbol:  n.
excited: stirred emotionally; agitated: An excited crowd awaited the arrival of the famed rock group.
nuclear: pertaining to or involving atomic weapons: nuclear war.
reaction: a reverse movement or tendency; an action in a reverse direction or manner.
emission: an act or instance of emitting: the emission of poisonous fumes.
owe: to be under obligation to pay or repay: to owe money to the bank; to owe the bank interest on a mortgage.
checked: having a pattern of squares; checkered (def 3): a checked shirt.
affective: of, caused by, or expressing emotion or feeling; emotional.
joy: the emotion of great delight or happiness caused by something exceptionally good or satisfying; keen pleasure; elation: She felt the joy of seeing her son's success.
cognitive: of or relating to cognition; concerned with the act or process of knowing, perceiving, etc. : cognitive development; cognitive functioning.
arouse: to stir to action or strong response; excite: to arouse a crowd; to arouse suspicion.
imagine: to form a mental image of (something not actually present to the senses).
portent: an indication or omen of something about to happen, especially something momentous.
anticipation: the act of anticipating or the state of being anticipated.
adversity: adverse or unfavorable fortune or fate; a condition marked by misfortune, calamity, or distress: Friends will show their true colors in times of adversity.
alarming: causing alarm or fear: an alarming case of pneumonia; an alarming lack of respect.
dishearten: to depress the hope, courage, or spirits of; discourage.
daunt: to overcome with fear; intimidate: to daunt one's adversaries.
surprise: to strike or occur to with a sudden feeling of wonder or astonishment, as through unexpectedness: Her beauty surprised me.
frantic: desperate or wild with excitement, passion, fear, pain, etc.; frenzied.
overwhelming: that overwhelms; overpowering: The temptation to despair may become overwhelming.
hysterical: of, relating to, or characterized by hysteria.
painful: affected with, causing, or characterized by pain: a painful wound; a painful night; a painful memory.
shocking: causing intense surprise, disgust, horror, etc.
shuddering: trembling or quivering with fear, dread, cold, etc.
shrink: to draw back, as in retreat or avoidance: to shrink from danger; to shrink from contact.
corpse: a dead body, usually of a human being.
tremulous: (of persons, the body, etc.) characterized by trembling, as from fear, nervousness, or weakness.
alarm: a sudden fear or distressing suspense caused by an awareness of danger; apprehension; fright.
agitation: the act or process of agitating; state of being agitated: She left in great agitation.
pang: a sudden feeling of mental or emotional distress or longing: a pang of remorse; a pang of desire.
boxing: the material used to make boxes or casings.
observe: to see, watch, perceive, or notice: He observed the passersby in the street.
respectable: worthy of respect or esteem; estimable; worthy: a respectable citizen.
probable: likely to occur or prove true: He foresaw a probable business loss. He is the probable writer of the article.
tonight: this present or coming night; the night of this present day.
unwilling: not willing; reluctant; loath; averse: an unwilling partner in the crime.
disinclined: lacking desire or willingness; unwilling; averse: I'm disinclined to go to the movies tonight.
candidate: a person who seeks an office, honor, etc.: a candidate for governor.
inability: lack of ability; lack of power, capacity, or means: his inability to make decisions.
reluctance: unwillingness; disinclination: reluctance to speak in public.
collision: the act of colliding; a coming violently into contact; crash: the collision of two airplanes.
contradictory: asserting the contrary or opposite; contradicting; inconsistent; logically opposite: contradictory statements.
clash: to make a loud, harsh noise: The gears of the old car clashed and grated.
eyewitness: a person who actually sees some act, occurrence, or thing and can give a firsthand account of it: There were two eyewitnesses to the murder.
conflicted: full of conflicting emotions or impulses: a situation that makes one feel very conflicted.
imply: to indicate or suggest without being explicitly stated: His words implied a lack of faith.
entail: to cause or involve by necessity or as a consequence: a loss entailing no regret.
attend: to be present at: to attend a lecture; to attend church.
hazard: an unavoidable danger or risk, even though often foreseeable: The job was full of hazards.
brave: possessing or exhibiting courage or courageous endurance.
couple: two of the same sort considered together; pair.
footprint: a mark left by the shod or unshod foot, as in earth or sand.
onerous: burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome; causing hardship: onerous duties.
fail: to fall short of success or achievement in something expected, attempted, desired, or approved: The experiment failed because of poor planning.
unambiguous: not ambiguous, or unclear; distinct; unequivocal: The object of the experiment was to reach an unambiguous conclusion about climate change.
kiln: a furnace or oven for burning, baking, or drying something, especially one for firing pottery, calcining limestone, or baking bricks.
fingerprint: an impression of the markings of the inner surface of the last joint of the thumb or other finger.
infant: a child during the earliest period of its life, especially before he or she can walk; baby.
syrup: any of various thick, sweet liquids prepared for table use from molasses, glucose, etc., water, and often a flavoring agent.
nuts: Also, nerts, nertz. (used to express disgust, defiance, disapproval, despair).
symbolic: serving as a symbol of something (often followed by of).
gummy: of, resembling, or of the consistency of gum; viscid; mucilaginous.
sway: to move or swing to and fro, as something fixed at one end or resting on a support.
australia: a continent SE of Asia, between the Indian and the Pacific oceans. 2,948,366 sq. mi. (7,636,270 sq. km).
antarctica: the continent surrounding the South Pole: almost entirely covered by an ice sheet. About 5,000,000 sq. mi. (12,950,000 sq. km).
suborder: a category of related families within an order.
constellation: By the end of the book the stars converge into a constellation.
virgo: Astronomy. the Virgin, a zodiacal constellation between Leo and Libra, containing the bright star Spica.
hydra: (often initial capital letter) Classical Mythology. a water or marsh serpent with nine heads, each of which, if cut off, grew back as two; Hercules killed this serpent by cauterizing the necks as he cut off the heads.
bulky: of relatively large and cumbersome bulk or size.
heavily: with a great weight or burden: a heavily loaded wagon.
thickset: set thickly or in close arrangement; dense: a thickset hedge.
feathery: clothed or covered with feathers; feathered.
twig: a slender shoot of a tree or other plant.
mire: a tract or area of wet, swampy ground; bog; marsh.
protect: to defend or guard from attack, invasion, loss, annoyance, insult, etc.; cover or shield from injury or danger.
forecast: to predict (a future condition or occurrence); calculate in advance: to forecast a heavy snowfall; to forecast lower interest rates.
arthropod: any invertebrate of the phylum Arthropoda, having a segmented body, jointed limbs, and usually a chitinous shell that undergoes moltings, including the insects, spiders and other arachnids, crustaceans, and myriapods.
juncture: a point of time, especially one made critical or important by a concurrence of circumstances: At this juncture, we must decide whether to stay or to walk out.
forever: without ever ending; eternally: to last forever.
eternal: without beginning or end; lasting forever; always existing (opposed to temporal): eternal life.
hem: to fold back and sew down the edge of (cloth, a garment, etc.); form an edge or border on or around.
construct: to build or form by putting together parts; frame; devise.
depose: to remove from office or position, especially high office: The people deposed the dictator.
defeat: to overcome in a contest, election, battle, etc.; prevail over; vanquish: They defeated the enemy. She defeated her brother at tennis.
vanquish: to conquer or subdue by superior force, as in battle.
tyrant: a sovereign or other ruler who uses power oppressively or unjustly.
digital: displaying a readout in numerical digits rather than by a pointer or hands on a dial: a digital speedometer; a digital watch.
graphic: giving a clear and effective picture; vivid: a graphic account of an earthquake.
divert: to turn aside or from a path or course; deflect.
stirring: rousing, exciting, or thrilling: a stirring speech.
thrilling: producing sudden, strong, and deep emotion or excitement.
tibet: Also, Thibet. Also called Sitsang, Xizang. Official name Tibet Autonomous Region. an administrative division of China, N of the Himalayas: prior to 1950 a theocracy under the Dalai Lama; the highest country in the world, average elevation about 16,000 feet (4877 meters). 471,660 sq. mi. (1,221,599 sq. km). Capital:  Lhasa.
inhabit: to live or dwell in (a place), as people or animals: Small animals inhabited the woods.
lot: one of a set of objects, as straws or pebbles, drawn or thrown from a container to decide a question or choice by chance.
national: of, relating to, or maintained by a nation as an organized whole or independent political unit: national affairs.
pride: a high or inordinate opinion of one's own dignity, importance, merit, or superiority, whether as cherished in the mind or as displayed in bearing, conduct, etc.
offensive: causing resentful displeasure; highly irritating, angering, or annoying: offensive television commercials.
odious: deserving or causing hatred; hateful; detestable.
crucify: to put to death by nailing or binding the hands and feet to a cross.
ritual: an established or prescribed procedure for a religious or other rite.
dream: a succession of images, thoughts, or emotions passing through the mind during sleep.
adage: a traditional saying expressing a common experience or observation; proverb.
led: simple past tense and past participle of lead1 .
dismissal: an act or instance of dismissing.
jewish: of, relating to, or characteristic of the Jews or Judaism: Jewish customs.
downward: Also, downwards. from a higher to a lower place or condition.
paramount: chief in importance or impact; supreme; preeminent: a point of paramount significance.
totality: something that is total or constitutes a total; the total amount; a whole.
macrocosm: the great world or universe; the universe considered as a whole (opposed to microcosm).
consecrate: to make or declare sacred; set apart or dedicate to the service of a deity: to consecrate a new church building.
engineer: a person trained and skilled in the design, construction, and use of engines or machines, or in any of various branches of engineering: a mechanical engineer; a civil engineer.
impart: to make known; tell; relate; disclose: to impart a secret.
spun: a simple past tense and past participle of spin.
stitch: one complete movement of a threaded needle through a fabric or material such as to leave behind it a single loop or portion of thread, as in sewing, embroidery, or the surgical closing of wounds.
impressive: having the ability to impress the mind; arousing admiration, awe, respect, etc.; moving; admirable: an impressive ceremony; an impressive appearance.
deliberate: carefully weighed or considered; studied; intentional: a deliberate lie.
untruth: the state or character of being untrue.
falsehood: a false statement; lie. Synonyms: fabrication, prevarication, falsification, canard, invention, fiction, story.
prevarication: the act of prevaricating, or lying: Seeing the expression on his mother's face, Nathan realized this was no time for prevarication.
mistaken: wrongly conceived, held, or done: a mistaken antagonism.
truthful: telling the truth, especially habitually: a truthful person.
veracity: habitual observance of truth in speech or statement; truthfulness: He was not noted for his veracity.
glad: feeling joy or pleasure; delighted; pleased: glad about the good news; glad that you are here.
obama: Barack (Hussein), Jr  [buh-rahk hoo-seyn]  /bəˈrɑk huˈseɪn/  (Show IPA), born 1961, 44th president of the U.S. since 2009.
escort: a group of persons, or a single person, accompanying another or others for protection, guidance, or courtesy: An escort of sailors accompanied the queen.
cross: a structure consisting essentially of an upright and a transverse piece, used to execute persons in ancient times.
hike: to walk or march a great distance, especially through rural areas, for pleasure, exercise, military training, or the like.
brow: Anatomy. the ridge over the eye.
intercede: to act or interpose in behalf of someone in difficulty or trouble, as by pleading or petition: to intercede with the governor for a condemned man.
mediate: to settle (disputes, strikes, etc.) as an intermediary between parties; reconcile.
landed: owning land, especially an estate: landed gentry.
corporeal: of the nature of the physical body; bodily.
palm: the part of the inner surface of the hand that extends from the wrist to the bases of the fingers.
monastery: a house or place of residence occupied by a community of persons, especially monks, living in seclusion under religious vows.
abbot: a man who is the head or superior, usually elected, of a monastery.
abbess: a woman who is the superior of a convent of nuns.
cupronickel: any of various alloys of copper containing up to 40 percent nickel.
pakistan: Islamic Republic of, a republic in S Asia, between India and Afghanistan: formerly part of British India; known as West Pakistan from 1947–71 to distinguish it from East Pakistan (now Bangladesh). 310,403 sq. mi. (803,881 sq. km). Capital:  Islamabad.
rupee: a cupronickel coin and monetary unit of India, Nepal, and Pakistan, equal to 100 paise. Abbreviation:  R., Re.
alexandra: 1844–1925, queen consort of Edward VII of England.
victoria: the ancient Roman goddess of victory, identified with the Greek goddess Nike.
romania: a republic in SE Europe, bordering on the Black Sea. 91,699 sq. mi. (237,500 sq. km). Capital:  Bucharest.
fool: a silly or stupid person; a person who lacks judgment or sense.
polyphonic: consisting of many voices or sounds.
ensemble: all the parts of a thing taken together, so that each part is considered only in relation to the whole.
improvisatory: of, relating to, or characteristic of an improvisation or improvisator.
harmonic: pertaining to harmony, as distinguished from melody and rhythm.
idiom: an expression whose meaning is not predictable from the usual meanings of its constituent elements, as kick the bucket or hang one's head, or from the general grammatical rules of a language, as the table round for the round table, and that is not a constituent of a larger expression of like characteristics.
diatonicism: the use of diatonic harmony; composition in a diatonic idiom.
atonality: the absence of key or tonal center.
advocate: to speak or write in favor of; support or urge by argument; recommend publicly: He advocated higher salaries for teachers.
eleventh: next after the tenth; being the ordinal number for 11.
rachel: Jacob's favorite wife, the mother of Joseph and Benjamin. Gen. 29–35.
impartial: not partial or biased; fair; just: an impartial judge.
incline: to deviate from the vertical or horizontal; slant.
dependent: relying on someone or something else for aid, support, etc.
recite: to repeat the words of, as from memory, especially in a formal manner: to recite a lesson.
centered: having a central axis: a centered arc.
iliad: (italics) a Greek epic poem describing the siege of Troy, ascribed to Homer.
soundbox: a chamber in a musical instrument, as the body of a violin, for increasing the sonority of its tone.
pillar: an upright shaft or structure, of stone, brick, or other material, relatively slender in proportion to its height, and of any shape in section, used as a building support, or standing alone, as for a monument: Gothic pillars; a pillar to commemorate Columbus.
turtle: any reptile of the order Testudines, comprising aquatic and terrestrial species having the trunk enclosed in a shell consisting of a dorsal carapace and a ventral plastron.
southeast: the point or direction midway between south and east. Abbreviation:  SE.
connecticut: a state in the NE United States. 5009 sq. mi. (12,975 sq. km). Capital:  Hartford.
bridgeport: a seaport in SW Connecticut, on Long Island Sound.
bristol: a seaport in Avon, in SW England, on the Avon River near its confluence with the Severn estuary.
arid: being without moisture; extremely dry; parched: arid land; an arid climate.
rainfall: a fall or shower of rain.
sparse: thinly scattered or distributed: a sparse population.
vegetation: all the plants or plant life of a place, taken as a whole: the vegetation of the Nile valley.
sahara: a desert in N Africa, extending from the Atlantic to the Nile valley. About 3,500,000 sq. mi. (9,065,000 sq. km).
sandy: of the nature of or consisting of sand.
architecture: the profession of designing buildings, open areas, communities, and other artificial constructions and environments, usually with some regard to aesthetic effect. Architecture often includes design or selection of furnishings and decorations, supervision of construction work, and the examination, restoration, or remodeling of existing buildings.
italy: a republic in S Europe, comprising a peninsula S of the Alps, and Sicily, Sardinia, Elba, and other smaller islands: a kingdom 1870–1946. 116,294 sq. mi. (301,200 sq. km). Capital:  Rome.
prevalent: widespread; of wide extent or occurrence; in general use or acceptance.
classical: of, relating to, or characteristic of Greek and Roman antiquity: classical literature; classical languages.
sculpture: the art of carving, modeling, welding, or otherwise producing figurative or abstract works of art in three dimensions, as in relief, intaglio, or in the round.
uncompromising: not admitting of compromise or adjustment of differences; making no concessions; inaccessible to flexible bargaining; unyielding: an uncompromising attitude.
forbidding: grim; unfriendly; hostile; sinister: his forbidding countenance.
outdoors: out of doors; in the open air: He's happiest when he's outdoors.
outcry: a strong and usually public expression of protest, indignation, or the like.
complaint: an expression of discontent, regret, pain, censure, resentment, or grief; lament; faultfinding: his complaint about poor schools.
continually: very often; at regular or frequent intervals; habitually.
rude: discourteous or impolite, especially in a deliberate way: a rude reply.
toilet: a bathroom fixture consisting of a bowl, usually with a detachable, hinged seat and lid, and a device for flushing with water, used for defecation and urination.
bathroom: a room equipped for taking a bath or shower.
talkative: inclined to talk a great deal: One drink and she became very talkative.
pause: a temporary stop or rest, especially in speech or action: a short pause after each stroke of the oar.
enterprise: a project undertaken or to be undertaken, especially one that is important or difficult or that requires boldness or energy: To keep the peace is a difficult enterprise.
dividend: Mathematics. a number that is to be divided by a divisor.
fixing: the act of a person or thing that fixes.
settling: the act of a person or thing that settles.
punishing: causing or characterized by harsh or injurious treatment; severe; brutal: The storm was accompanied by punishing winds.
reprisal: (in warfare) retaliation against an enemy, for injuries received, by the infliction of equal or greater injuries.
conditional: imposing, containing, subject to, or depending on a condition or conditions; not absolute; made or allowed on certain terms: conditional acceptance.
pollution: the act of polluting or the state of being polluted.
confess: to acknowledge or avow (a fault, crime, misdeed, weakness, etc.) by way of revelation.
imprison: to confine in or as if in a prison.
lookout: the act of looking out or keeping watch.
offense: a violation or breaking of a social or moral rule; transgression; sin.
penal: of, relating to, or involving punishment, as for crimes or offenses.
culpability: guilt or blame that is deserved; blameworthiness.
stamp: to strike or beat with a forcible, downward thrust of the foot.
root: a part of the body of a plant that develops, typically, from the radicle and grows downward into the soil, anchoring the plant and absorbing nutriment and moisture.
multiple: consisting of, having, or involving several or many individuals, parts, elements, relations, etc.; manifold.
parenchyma: Botany. the fundamental tissue of plants, composed of thin-walled cells able to divide.
pear: the edible fruit, typically rounded but elongated and growing smaller toward the stem, of a tree, Pyrus communis, of the rose family.
worthless: without worth; of no use, importance, or value; good-for-nothing: a worthless person; a worthless contract.
cereal: any plant of the grass family yielding an edible grain, as wheat, rye, oats, rice, or corn.
triticum: any annual cereal grass of the genus Triticum, which includes the wheats
culinary: of, relating to, or used in cooking or the kitchen.
oat: a cereal grass, Avena sativa, cultivated for its edible seed.
goodness: the state or quality of being good.
heir: a person who inherits or has a right of inheritance in the property of another following the latter's death.
legacy: Law. a gift of property, especially personal property, as money, by will; a bequest.
remunerate: to pay, recompense, or reward for work, trouble, etc.
pile: an assemblage of things laid or lying one upon the other: a pile of papers; a pile of bricks.
heap: a group of things placed, thrown, or lying one on another; pile: a heap of stones.
sixth: next after the fifth; being the ordinal number for six.
thursday: the fifth day of the week, following Wednesday. Abbreviation:  Th., Thur., Thurs.
columbus: Christopher (Sp. Cristóbal Colón; It. Cristoforo Colombo) 1446?–1506, Italian navigator in Spanish service: traditionally considered the discoverer of America 1492.
allot: to divide or distribute by share or portion; distribute or parcel out; apportion: to allot the available farmland among the settlers.
patron: a person who is a customer, client, or paying guest, especially a regular one, of a store, hotel, or the like.
delightful: giving great pleasure or delight; highly pleasing: a delightful surprise.
worried: having or characterized by worry; concerned; anxious: Their worried parents called the police.
formless: lacking a definite or regular form or shape; shapeless.
loaf: a portion of bread or cake baked in a mass, usually oblong with a rounded top.
crumb: a small particle of bread, cake, etc., that has broken off.
seventh: next after the sixth; being the ordinal number for seven.

valence: On his return to France he began his garrison life at valence, where he showed some of the finer qualities of his character.
ferrous: of or containing iron, especially in the bivalent state.

The valence of an ion is equal to the number of electrons lost or gained and is indicated by a plus sign for cations and a minus sign for anions, thus: Na + , Cl−, Ca ++ , S = .

powdery: consisting of or resembling powder: powdery sand; powdery clouds.

thompson: Benjamin, Count Rumford, 1753–1814, English physicist and diplomat, born in the U.S.
pulsation: the act of pulsating; beating or throbbing.
splitting: being split or causing something to split.
descriptive: having the quality of describing; characterized by description: a descriptive passage in an essay.
fracture: Compare comminuted fracture, complete fracture, compound fracture, greenstick fracture, simple fracture.
dissolve: to make a solution of, as by mixing with a liquid; pass into solution: to dissolve salt in water.
burnt: a simple past tense and past participle of burn1 .

calx: the oxide or ashy substance that remains after metals, minerals, etc., have been thoroughly roasted or burned.

slave: a person who is the property of and wholly subject to another; a bond servant.

solvent: able to pay all just debts.
fats: (used with a plural verb) cattle fattened and ready for market.
acetone: a colorless, volatile, water-soluble, flammable liquid, C 3 H 6 O, usually derived by oxidation of isopropyl alcohol or by bacterial fermentation of carbohydrates: used chiefly in paints and varnishes, as a general solvent, and in organic synthesis.
tactile: of, pertaining to, endowed with, or affecting the sense of touch.
marshy: like a marsh; soft and wet; boggy.

bronze: Fire is represented by bronze sculptures, but the most unique representation is found in “air.”

trash: anything worthless, useless, or discarded; rubbish.

bonding: We became friends immediately, bonding over cold shrimp and funny stories at a variety of local dives.

electron: Also called negatron. Physics, Chemistry. an elementary particle that is a fundamental constituent of matter, having a negative charge of 1.602 × 10 −19 coulombs, a mass of 9.108 × 10 −31 kilograms, and spin of ½, and existing independently or as the component outside the nucleus of an atom.

bit: He got the bit between the teeth with Rebekah Brooks when she had a go at him and realized he had nothing to lose.

blake: Hector ("Toe") 1912–1995, Canadian ice hockey player and coach.
enable: to make able; give power, means, competence, or ability to; authorize: This document will enable him to pass through the enemy lines unmolested.

subway: Also called, especially British, tube, underground. an underground electric railroad, usually in a large city.
inductance: Compare inductive coupling, mutual inductance, self-inductance.

volt: the standard unit of potential difference and electromotive force in the International System of Units (SI), formally defined to be the difference of electric potential between two points of a conductor carrying a constant current of one ampere, when the power dissipated between these points is equal to one watt. Abbreviation:  V.
ampere: the basic unit of electrical current in the International System of Units (SI), equivalent to one coulomb per second, formally defined to be the constant current which if maintained in two straight parallel conductors of infinite length, of negligible circular cross section, and placed one meter apart in vacuum, would produce between these conductors a force equal to 2 × 10 −7 newton per meter of length. Abbreviation:  A, amp.
avert: to turn away or aside: to avert one's eyes.

cloud: a visible collection of particles of water or ice suspended in the air, usually at an elevation above the earth's surface.
