gregarious: fond of the company of others; sociable.
mounted: seated or riding on a horse or other animal.
feudal: of, relating to, or like the feudal system, or its political, military, social, and economic structure.
diocese: an ecclesiastical district under the jurisdiction of a bishop.
catholic: broad or wide-ranging in tastes, interests, or the like; having sympathies with all; broad-minded; liberal.
anglican: of or relating to the Church of England.
ministry: the service, functions, or profession of a minister of religion.
leak: an unintended hole, crack, or the like, through which liquid, gas, light, etc., enters or escapes: a leak in the roof.
lore: the body of knowledge, especially of a traditional, anecdotal, or popular nature, on a particular subject: the lore of herbs.
bookkeeping: the work or skill of keeping account books or systematic records of money transactions (distinguished from accounting).
beryllium: a steel-gray, bivalent, hard, light, metallic element, the salts of which are sweet: used chiefly in copper alloys for better fatigue endurance, in springs, and in electrical contacts. Symbol:  Be; atomic weight:  9.0122; atomic number:  4; specific gravity:  1.8 at 20° C.
golden: bright, metallic, or lustrous like gold; of the color of gold; yellow: golden hair.
aquamarine: a transparent, light-blue or greenish-blue variety of beryl, used as a gem.
plating: a thin coating of gold, silver, etc.
churn: a container or machine in which cream or milk is agitated to make butter.
pulpy: pertaining to, characteristic of, or resembling pulp; fleshy or soft.
baptism: Ecclesiastical. a ceremonial immersion in water, or application of water, as an initiatory rite or sacrament of the Christian church.
sacrificial: pertaining to or concerned with sacrifice.
mandatory: authoritatively ordered; obligatory; compulsory: It is mandatory that all students take two years of math.
architect: a person who engages in the profession of architecture.
altogether: wholly; entirely; completely; quite: altogether fitting.
quite: completely, wholly, or entirely: quite the reverse; not quite finished.
spotted: marked with or characterized by a spot or spots.
camelopardalis: the Giraffe, a northern constellation between Ursa Major and Perseus.
treetop: the top or uppermost branches of a tree.
reception: the act of receiving or the state of being received.
joyous: joyful; happy; jubilant: the joyous sounds of children at play.
humor: a comic, absurd, or incongruous quality causing amusement: the humor of a situation.
host: a person who receives or entertains guests at home or elsewhere: the host at a theater party.
stranger: a person with whom one has had no personal acquaintance: He is a perfect stranger to me.
luncheon: lunch, especially a formal lunch held in connection with a meeting or other special occasion: the alumni luncheon.
whisper: to speak with soft, hushed sounds, using the breath, lips, etc., but with no vibration of the vocal cords.
disagreeable: contrary to one's taste or liking; unpleasant; offensive; repugnant.
perplex: to cause to be puzzled or bewildered over what is not understood or certain; confuse mentally: Her strange response perplexed me.
bewilder: to confuse or puzzle completely; perplex: These shifting attitudes bewilder me.
deaden: to make less sensitive, active, energetic, or forcible; weaken: to deaden sound; to deaden the senses; to deaden the force of a blow.
apathy: absence or suppression of passion, emotion, or excitement.
courageous: possessing or characterized by courage; brave: a courageous speech against the dictator.
discontinue: to put an end to; stop; terminate: to discontinue nuclear testing.
blossom: the flower of a plant, especially of one producing an edible fruit.
depiction: representation in image form, as in a painting or illustration: Picasso's painting Guernica is an accurate depiction of the horrors of war.
victim: a person who suffers from a destructive or injurious action or agency: a victim of an automobile accident.
hilt: the handle of a sword or dagger.
stealing: the act of a person who steals.
wrongful: unjust or unfair: a wrongful act; a wrongful charge.
larceny: the wrongful taking and carrying away of the personal goods of another from his or her possession with intent to convert them to the taker's own use.
misplace: to put in a wrong place.
willing: disposed or consenting; inclined: willing to go along.
studio: the workroom or atelier of an artist, as a painter or sculptor.
enabling: conferring new legal powers or capacities, especially by removing a disability; having the right to license or regulate: an enabling act; enabling power.
thereby: by that; by means of that.
parking: the act of a person or thing that parks, especially a vehicle.
roadside: the side or border of the road; wayside.
archipelago: a large group or chain of islands: the Malay Archipelago.
guardianship: the position and responsibilities of a guardian, especially toward a ward.
manila: a seaport in and the capital of the Philippines, on W central Luzon. Abbreviation:  Man.
huge: extraordinarily large in bulk, quantity, or extent: a huge ship; a huge portion of ice cream.
gill: the respiratory organ of aquatic animals, as fish, that breathe oxygen dissolved in water.
elongate: to draw out to greater length; lengthen; extend.
supervise: to oversee (a process, work, workers, etc.) during execution or performance; superintend; have the oversight and direction of.
worker: a person or thing that works.
shun: to keep away from (a place, person, object, etc.), from motives of dislike, caution, etc.; take pains to avoid.
deserving: qualified for or having a claim to reward, assistance, etc., because of one's actions, qualities, or situation: the deserving poor; a deserving applicant.
disgrace: the loss of respect, honor, or esteem; ignominy; shame: the disgrace of criminals.
dishonorable: showing lack of honor or integrity; ignoble; base; disgraceful; shameful: Cheating is dishonorable.
disreputable: not reputable; having a bad reputation: a disreputable barroom.
concur: to accord in opinion; agree: Do you concur with his statement?
subscribe: to pledge, as by signing an agreement, to give or pay (a sum of money) as a contribution, gift, or investment: He subscribed $6,000 for the new church.
relieve: to ease or alleviate (pain, distress, anxiety, need, etc.).
indigent: lacking food, clothing, and other necessities of life because of poverty; needy; poor; impoverished.
feed: to give food to; supply with nourishment: to feed a child.
partnership: the state or condition of being a partner; participation; association; joint interest.
daylight: the light of day: At the end of the tunnel they could see daylight.
goes: 3rd person singular present indicative of go1 .
errand: a short and quick trip to accomplish a specific purpose, as to buy something, deliver a package, or convey a message, often for someone else.
via: by a route that touches or passes through; by way of: to fly to Japan via the North Pole.
telecommunications: Sometimes, telecommunication. (used with a singular verb) the transmission of information, as words, sounds, or images, usually over great distances, in the form of electromagnetic signals, as by telegraph, telephone, radio, or television.
instantaneous: occurring, done, or completed in an instant: an instantaneous response.
confirm: to establish the truth, accuracy, validity, or genuineness of; corroborate; verify: This report confirms my suspicions.
substantiate: to establish by proof or competent evidence: to substantiate a charge.
verified: confirmed as to accuracy or truth by acceptable evidence, action, etc.
killer: a person or thing that kills.
script: the letters or characters used in writing by hand; handwriting, especially cursive writing.
safari: a journey or expedition, for hunting, exploration, or investigation, especially in eastern Africa.
cheer: a shout of encouragement, approval, congratulation, etc.: The cheers of the fans filled the stadium.
salute: Military. to pay respect to or honor by some formal act, as by raising the right hand to the side of the headgear, presenting arms, firing cannon, dipping colors, etc.
spark: an ignited or fiery particle such as is thrown off by burning wood or produced by one hard body striking against another.
insect: any animal of the class Insecta, comprising small, air-breathing arthropods having the body divided into three parts (head, thorax, and abdomen), and having three pairs of legs and usually two pairs of wings.
enunciate: to utter or pronounce (words, sentences, etc.), especially in an articulate or a particular manner: He enunciates his words distinctly.
creature: an animal, especially a nonhuman: the creatures of the woods and fields; a creature from outer space.
mechanism: an assembly of moving parts performing a complete functional motion, often being part of a large machine; linkage.
melodious: of the nature of or characterized by melody; tuneful.
temperament: the combination of mental, physical, and emotional traits of a person; natural predisposition.
argue: to present reasons for or against a thing: He argued in favor of capital punishment.
enticement: the act or practice of enticing, especially to evil.
incompatible: not compatible; unable to exist together in harmony: She asked for a divorce because they were utterly incompatible.
miracle: an effect or extraordinary event in the physical world that surpasses all known human or natural powers and is ascribed to a supernatural cause.
blazing: burning brightly and with great heat, force, etc.
monday: the second day of the week, following Sunday.
contempt: the feeling with which a person regards anything considered mean, vile, or worthless; disdain; scorn.
patrol: (of a police officer, soldier, etc.) to pass along a road, beat, etc., or around or through a specified area in order to maintain order and security.
plea: an appeal or entreaty: a plea for mercy.
boxer: a person who fights as a sport, usually with gloved fists, according to set rules; prize-fighter; pugilist.
naked: being without clothing or covering; nude: naked children swimming in the lake.
nude: naked or unclothed, as a person or the body.
retired: withdrawn from or no longer occupied with one's business or profession: a retired banker.
eject: to drive or force out; expel, as from a place or position: The police ejected the hecklers from the meeting.
coercion: the act of coercing; use of force or intimidation to obtain compliance.
desperate: reckless or dangerous because of despair, hopelessness, or urgency: a desperate killer.
imperfect: of, relating to, or characterized by defects or weaknesses: imperfect vision.
mars: the ancient Roman god of war and agriculture, identified with the Greek god Ares.
brake: a device for slowing or stopping a vehicle or other moving mechanism by the absorption or transfer of the energy of momentum, usually by means of friction.
adoption: the act of adopting: the adoption of a new amendment.
remnant: a remaining, usually small part, quantity, number, or the like.
clover: any of various plants of the genus Trifolium, of the legume family, having trifoliolate leaves and dense flower heads, many species of which, as T. pratense, are cultivated as forage plants.
alfalfa: a plant, Medicago sativa, of the legume family, usually having bluish-purple flowers, originating in the Near East and widely cultivated as a forage crop.
forage: food for horses or cattle; fodder; provender.
partly: in part; to some extent or degree; partially; not wholly: His statement is partly true.
strap: a narrow strip of flexible material, especially leather, as for fastening or holding things together.
creative: having the quality or power of creating.
exposition: a large-scale public exhibition or show, as of art or manufactured products: an exposition of 19th-century paintings; an automobile exposition.
baggage: trunks, suitcases, etc., used in traveling; luggage.
proportionate: proportioned; being in due proportion; proportional.
femur: Anatomy. a bone in the human leg extending from the pelvis to the knee, that is the longest, largest, and strongest in the body; thighbone.
tibia: Anatomy. the inner of the two bones of the leg, that extend from the knee to the ankle and articulate with the femur and the talus; shinbone.
patella: Anatomy. the flat, movable bone at the front of the knee; kneecap.
thigh: the part of the lower limb in humans between the hip and the knee.
conversant: familiar by use or study (usually followed by with): conversant with Spanish history.
aside: on or to one side; to or at a short distance apart; away from some position or direction: to turn aside; to move the chair aside.
prefer: to set or hold before or above other persons or things in estimation; like better; choose rather than: to prefer beef to chicken.
ex: Finance. without, not including, or without the right to have: ex interest; ex rights.
sect: a body of persons adhering to a particular religious faith; a religious denomination.
haste: swiftness of motion; speed; celerity: He performed his task with great haste. They felt the need for haste.
speedy: characterized by speed; rapid; swift; fast.
hurried: moving or working rapidly, especially forced or required to hurry, as a person.
rival: a person who is competing for the same object or goal as another, or who tries to equal or outdo another; competitor.
compete: to strive to outdo another for acknowledgment, a prize, supremacy, profit, etc.; engage in a contest; vie: to compete in a race; to compete in business.
harvard: John, 1607–38, English clergyman in the U.S.: principal benefactor of Harvard College, now Harvard University.
acrid: sharp or biting to the taste or smell; bitterly pungent; irritating to the eyes, nose, etc.: acrid smoke from burning rubber.
aspirin: Pharmacology. a white, crystalline substance, C 9 H 8 O 4 , derivative of salicylic acid, used as an anti-inflammatory agent and to relieve the pain of headache, rheumatism, gout, neuralgia, etc.; acetylsalicylic acid.
quinine: a white, bitter, slightly water-soluble alkaloid, C 2 0 H 2 4 N 2 O 2 , having needlelike crystals, obtained from cinchona bark: used in medicine chiefly in the treatment of resistant forms of malaria.
wormwood: any composite herb or low shrub of the genus Artemisia.
barbecue: pieces of beef, fowl, fish, or the like, roasted over an open hearth, especially when basted in a barbecue sauce.
instrumentalist: a person who plays a musical instrument.
partake: to take or have a part or share along with others; participate (usually followed by in): He won't partake in the victory celebration.
addicted: devoted or given up to a practice or habit or to something psychologically or physically habit-forming (usually followed by to): to be addicted to drugs.
profligate: utterly and shamelessly immoral or dissipated; thoroughly dissolute.
concentrated: applied with all one's attention, energy, etc.: their concentrated efforts to win the election.
privilege: a right, immunity, or benefit enjoyed only by a person beyond the advantages of most: the privileges of the very rich.
election: the selection of a person or persons for office by vote.
publicly: in a public or open manner or place.
holder: something that holds or secures: a pencil holder.
tune: a succession of musical sounds forming an air or melody, with or without the harmony accompanying it.
spiteful: full of spite or malice; showing spite; malicious; malevolent; venomous: a spiteful child.
gossip: idle talk or rumor, especially about the personal or private affairs of others: the endless gossip about Hollywood stars.
bother: to give trouble to; annoy; pester; worry: His baby sister bothered him for candy.
avail: to be of use or value to; profit; advantage: All our efforts availed us little in trying to effect a change.
nullify: to render or declare legally void or inoperative: to nullify a contract.
frustrated: disappointed; thwarted: an announcer who was a frustrated actor.
mortify: to humiliate or shame, as by injury to one's pride or self-respect.
meanness: the state or quality of being mean.
lifelong: lasting or continuing through all or much of one's life: lifelong regret.
guilty: having committed an offense, crime, violation, or wrong, especially against moral or penal law; justly subject to a certain accusation or penalty; culpable: The jury found her guilty of murder.
anyway: in any case; anyhow; nonetheless; regardless: Whether you like it or not, I'm going anyway.
journalism: the occupation of reporting, writing, editing, photographing, or broadcasting news or of conducting any news organization as a business.
finding: the act of a person or thing that finds; discovery.
curious: eager to learn or know; inquisitive.
acknowledged: widely recognized; generally accepted: an acknowledged authority on Chinese art.
accusation: a charge of wrongdoing; imputation of guilt or blame.
heading: something that serves as a head, top, or front.
cask: a container made and shaped like a barrel, especially one larger and stronger, for holding liquids.
forbid: to command (a person) not to do something, have something, etc., or not to enter some place: to forbid him entry to the house.
constrain: to force, compel, or oblige: He was constrained to admit the offense.
inevitable: unable to be avoided, evaded, or escaped; certain; necessary: an inevitable conclusion.
canvas: a closely woven, heavy cloth of cotton, hemp, or linen, used for tents, sails, etc.
rigging: the ropes, chains, etc., employed to support and work the masts, yards, sails, etc., on a ship.
hull: the husk, shell, or outer covering of a seed or fruit.
raft: a more or less rigid floating platform made of buoyant material or materials: an inflatable rubber raft.
iceboat: a vehicle for rapid movement on ice, usually consisting of a T -shaped frame on three runners driven by a fore-and-aft sailing rig or, sometimes, by an engine operating a propeller.
tactics: (usually used with a singular verb) the art or science of disposing military or naval forces for battle and maneuvering them in battle.
discoloration: the act or fact of discoloring or the state of being discolored.
protective: having the quality or function of protecting: a protective covering.
counterfeit: made in imitation so as to be passed off fraudulently or deceptively as genuine; not genuine; forged: counterfeit dollar bills.
authentic: not false or copied; genuine; real: an authentic antique.
antique: of or belonging to the past; not modern.
strife: vigorous or bitter conflict, discord, or antagonism: to be at strife.
aver: to assert or affirm with confidence; declare in a positive or peremptory manner.
innocence: the quality or state of being innocent; freedom from sin or moral wrong.
tubular: having the form or shape of a tube; tubiform.
tent: a portable shelter of skins, canvas, plastic, or the like, supported by one or more poles or a frame and often secured by ropes fastened to pegs in the ground.
camp: a place where an army or other group of persons or an individual is lodged in a tent or tents or other temporary means of shelter.
guise: general external appearance; aspect; semblance: an old principle in a new guise.
mislead: to lead or guide wrongly; lead astray.
deceptive: apt or tending to deceive: The enemy's peaceful overtures may be deceptive.
garb: a fashion or mode of dress, especially of a distinctive, uniform kind: in the garb of a monk.
defraud: to deprive of a right, money, or property by fraud: Dishonest employees defrauded the firm of millions of dollars.
inclusive: including or encompassing the stated limit or extremes in consideration or account (usually used postpositively): from 6 to 37 inclusive.
adopt: to choose or take as one's own; make one's own by selection or assent: to adopt a nickname.
napkin: a small piece of cloth or paper, usually square, for use in wiping the lips and fingers and to protect the clothes while eating.
acceptable: capable or worthy of being accepted.
reformer: a person devoted to bringing about reform, as in politics or society.
archbishop: a bishop of the highest rank who presides over an archbishopric or archdiocese.
foretell: to tell of beforehand; predict; prophesy.
civilization: an advanced state of human society, in which a high level of culture, science, industry, and government has been reached.
bertram: a male given name: from Germanic words meaning “bright” and “raven.”.
hubert: a male given name: from Germanic words meaning “mind” and “bright.”.
mirage: an optical phenomenon, especially in the desert or at sea, by which the image of some object appears displaced above, below, or to one side of its true position as a result of spatial variations of the index of refraction of air.
seem: to appear to be, feel, do, etc.: She seems better this morning.
withstand: to stand or hold out against; resist or oppose, especially successfully: to withstand rust; to withstand the invaders; to withstand temptation.
restrict: to confine or keep within limits, as of space, action, choice, intensity, or quantity.
resale: the act of selling a second time.
quotation: something that is quoted; a passage quoted from a book, speech, etc.: a speech full of quotations from Lincoln's letters.
heel: the back part of the human foot, below and behind the ankle.
boot: a covering of leather, rubber, or the like, for the foot and all or part of the leg.
rider: a person who rides a horse or other animal, a bicycle, etc.
urge: to push or force along; impel with force or vigor: to urge the cause along.
insane: not sane; not of sound mind; mentally deranged.
dementia: severe impairment or loss of intellectual capacity and personality integration, due to the loss of or damage to neurons in the brain.
mania: excessive excitement or enthusiasm; craze: The country has a mania for soccer.
aberration: the act of departing from the right, normal, or usual course.
saint: any of certain persons of exceptional holiness of life, formally recognized as such by the Christian Church, especially by canonization.
pope: (often initial capital letter) the bishop of Rome as head of the Roman Catholic Church.
coiffure: a style of arranging or combing the hair.
stipulation: a condition, demand, or promise in an agreement or contract.
proviso: a clause in a statute, contract, or the like, by which a condition is introduced.
vestige: a mark, trace, or visible evidence of something that is no longer present or in existence: A few columns were the last vestiges of a Greek temple.
dedicate: to set apart and consecrate to a deity or to a sacred purpose: The ancient Greeks dedicated many shrines to Aphrodite.
charm: a power of pleasing or attracting, as through personality or beauty: charm of manner; the charm of a mountain lake.
drumbeat: the rhythmic sound of a drum.
eucharist: the sacrament of Holy Communion; the sacrifice of the Mass; the Lord's Supper.
propitiation: the act of propitiating; conciliation: the propitiation of the wrathful gods.
george: a figure of St. George killing the dragon, especially one forming part of the insignia of the Order of the Garter.
gordon: Charles George ("Chinese Gordon"; "Gordon Pasha") 1833–85, British general: administrator in China and Egypt.
lord: a person who has authority, control, or power over others; a master, chief, or ruler.
baron: a member of the lowest grade of nobility.
speculation: the contemplation or consideration of some subject: to engage in speculation on humanity's ultimate destiny.
contemplation: the act of contemplating; thoughtful observation.
romans: an Epistle of the New Testament, written by Paul to the Christian community in Rome. Abbreviation:  Rom.
modular: of or relating to a module or a modulus.
conversational: of, relating to, or characteristic of conversation: a conversational tone of voice.
traverse: to pass or move over, along, or through.
discovery: the act or an instance of discovering.
senate: an assembly or council of citizens having the highest deliberative functions in a government, especially a legislative assembly of a state or nation.
engrave: to chase (letters, designs, etc.) on a hard surface, as of metal, stone, or the end grain of wood: She had the jeweler engrave her name on the back of the watch.
skilled: having skill; trained or experienced in work that requires skill.
broadcasting: the act of transmitting speech, music, visual images, etc., as by radio or television.
billboard: a flat surface or board, usually outdoors, on which large advertisements or notices are posted.
pursue: to follow in order to overtake, capture, kill, etc.; chase.
specialty: a special or distinctive quality, mark, state, or condition.
gastroenterology: the study of the structure, functions, and diseases of digestive organs.
relaxation: abatement or relief from bodily or mental work, effort, application, etc.
woodcarving: the art or technique of carving objects by hand from wood or of carving decorations into wood.
prowess: exceptional valor, bravery, or ability, especially in combat or battle.
competitive: of, pertaining to, involving, or decided by competition: competitive sports; a competitive examination.
baseball: a game of ball between two nine-player teams played usually for nine innings on a field that has as a focal point a diamond-shaped infield with a home plate and three other bases, 90 feet (27 meters) apart, forming a circuit that must be completed by a base runner in order to score, the central offensive action entailing hitting of a pitched ball with a wooden or metal bat and running of the bases, the winner being the team scoring the most runs.
tennis: a game played on a rectangular court by two players or two pairs of players equipped with rackets, in which a ball is driven back and forth over a low net that divides the court in half.
bowling: Compare boccie, candlepins (def 2), duckpins (def 2), lawn bowling, ninepins (def 1), tenpins (def 1).
athletics: (usually used with a plural verb) athletic sports, as running, rowing, or boxing.
apply: to make use of as relevant, suitable, or pertinent: to apply a theory to a problem.
offset: something that counterbalances, counteracts, or compensates for something else; compensating equivalent.
bedclothes: coverings for a bed, as sheets and blankets; bedding.
complimentary: of the nature of, conveying, or expressing a compliment, often one that is politely flattering: a complimentary remark.
liquor: a distilled or spirituous beverage, as brandy or whiskey, as distinguished from a fermented beverage, as wine or beer.
mash: to crush: He mashed his thumb with a hammer.
juniper: any evergreen, coniferous shrub or tree of the genus Juniperus, especially J. communis, having cones that resemble dark-blue or blackish berries used in flavoring gin and in medicine as a diuretic.
molasses: a thick syrup produced during the refining of sugar or from sorghum, varying from light to dark brown in color.
bitters: a liquid, often an alcoholic liquor, in which bitter herbs or roots have steeped, used as a flavoring, especially in mixed drinks, or as a tonic.
chill: coldness, especially a moderate but uncomfortably penetrating coldness: the chill of evening.
greedy: excessively or inordinately desirous of wealth, profit, etc.; avaricious: the greedy owners of the company.
sly: cunning or wily: sly as a fox.
elbow: the bend or joint of the human arm between upper arm and forearm.
forelimb: a front limb of an animal.
nitroglycerin: a colorless, thick, oily, flammable, highly explosive, slightly water-soluble liquid, C 3 H 5 N 3 O 9 , prepared from glycerol with nitric and sulfuric acids: used chiefly as a constituent of dynamite and other explosives, in rocket propellants, and in medicine as a vasodilator in the treatment of angina pectoris.
mucous: pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling mucus.
curative: serving to cure or heal; pertaining to curing or remedial treatment; remedial.
heal: to make healthy, whole, or sound; restore to health; free from ailment.
habitation: a place of residence; dwelling; abode.
tupper: Sir Charles, 1821–1915, Canadian statesman: prime minister 1896.
threaten: to utter a threat against; menace: He threatened the boy with a beating.
viewpoint: a place affording a view of something; position of observation: to sketch a river from the viewpoint of a bluff.
notion: a general understanding; vague or imperfect conception or idea of something: a notion of how something should be done.
twelfth: next after the eleventh; being the ordinal number for 12.
parade: a large public procession, usually including a marching band and often of a festive nature, held in honor of an anniversary, person, event, etc.
practical: of or relating to practice or action: practical mathematics.
stir: to move one's hand or an implement continuously or repeatedly through (a liquid or other substance) in order to cool, mix, agitate, dissolve, etc., any or all of the component parts: to stir one's coffee with a spoon.
liberality: the quality or condition of being liberal in giving; generosity; bounty.
discern: to perceive by the sight or some other sense or by the intellect; see, recognize, or apprehend: They discerned a sail on the horizon.
plentiful: existing in great plenty: Coal was plentiful, and therefore cheap, in that region.
accommodating: easy to deal with; eager to help or please; obliging.
reave: to take away by or as by force; plunder; rob.
buffalo: Compare bison, Cape buffalo, water buffalo.
domesticate: to convert (animals, plants, etc.) to domestic uses; tame.
gamble: to play at any game of chance for money or other stakes.
ivory: the hard white substance, a variety of dentin, composing the main part of the tusks of the elephant, walrus, etc.
gambling: the activity or practice of playing at a game of chance for money or other stakes.
mercury: Chemistry. a heavy, silver-white, highly toxic metallic element, the only one that is liquid at room temperature; quicksilver: used in barometers, thermometers, pesticides, pharmaceutical preparations, reflecting surfaces of mirrors, and dental fillings, in certain switches, lamps, and other electric apparatus, and as a laboratory catalyst. Symbol:  Hg; atomic weight:  200.59; atomic number:  80; specific gravity:  13.546 at 20°C; freezing point: −38.9°C; boiling point: 357°C.
hydrochloric: of or derived from hydrochloric acid.
chlorine: a halogen element, a heavy, greenish-yellow, incombustible, water-soluble, poisonous gas that is highly irritating to the respiratory organs, obtained chiefly by electrolysis of sodium chloride brine: used for water purification, in the making of bleaching powder, and in the manufacture both of chemicals that do not contain chlorine, as ethylene glycol, and of those that do. Symbol:  Cl; atomic weight:  35.453; atomic number:  17.
herb: a flowering plant whose stem above ground does not become woody.
spice: any of a class of pungent or aromatic substances of vegetable origin, as pepper, cinnamon, or cloves, used as seasoning, preservatives, etc.
diplomatic: of, relating to, or engaged in diplomacy: diplomatic officials.
onslaught: an onset, assault, or attack, especially a vigorous one.
pink: a color varying from light crimson to pale reddish purple.
pinkish: somewhat pink: The sky at sunset has a pinkish glow.
roseate: tinged with rose; rosy: a roseate dawn.
glow: a light emitted by or as if by a substance heated to luminosity; incandescence.
shed: a slight or rude structure built for shelter, storage, etc.
dim: not bright; obscure from lack of light or emitted light: a dim room; a dim flashlight.
adulterate: to debase or make impure by adding inferior materials or elements; use cheaper, inferior, or less desirable goods in the production of (any professedly genuine article): to adulterate food.
dollar: a paper money, silver or cupronickel coin, and monetary unit of the United States, equal to 100 cents. Symbol:  $.
sewage: the waste matter that passes through sewers.
foul: grossly offensive to the senses; disgustingly loathsome; noisome: a foul smell.
dirty: soiled with dirt; foul; unclean: dirty laundry.
restriction: something that restricts; a restrictive condition or regulation; limitation.
contingent: dependent for existence, occurrence, character, etc., on something not yet certain; conditional (often followed by on or upon): Our plans are contingent on the weather.
despot: a king or other ruler with absolute, unlimited power; autocrat.
despotism: the rule of a despot; the exercise of absolute authority.
autocratic: pertaining to or of the nature of autocracy or of an autocrat; absolute: autocratic government.
tyrannical: of or characteristic of a tyrant.
engrossing: fully occupying the mind or attention; absorbing: I'm reading the most engrossing book.
pi: the 16th letter of the Greek alphabet (II, π).
card: a usually rectangular piece of stiff paper, thin pasteboard, or plastic for various uses, as to write information on or printed as a means of identifying the holder: a 3″ × 5″ file card; a membership card.
denomination: a religious group, usually including many local churches, often larger than a sect: the Lutheran denomination.
expand: to increase in extent, size, volume, scope, etc.: Heat expands most metals. He hopes to expand his company.
squander: to spend or use (money, time, etc.) extravagantly or wastefully (often followed by away).
dependable: capable of being depended on; worthy of trust; reliable: a dependable employee.
helper: a person or thing that helps or gives assistance, support, etc.
sidepiece: a piece forming a side or a part of a side, or fixed by the side, of something.
byzantium: an ancient Greek city on the Bosporus and the Sea of Marmara: Constantine I rebuilt it and renamed it Constantinople a.d.
dinosaur: any chiefly terrestrial, herbivorous or carnivorous reptile of the extinct orders Saurischia and Ornithischia, from the Mesozoic Era, certain species of which are the largest known land animals.
beast: any nonhuman animal, especially a large, four-footed mammal.
conceive: to form (a notion, opinion, purpose, etc.): He conceived the project while he was on vacation.
elevate: to move or raise to a higher place or position; lift up.
aids: a disease of the immune system characterized by increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as pneumocystis carinii pneumonia and candidiasis, to certain cancers, as Kaposi's sarcoma, and to neurological disorders: caused by a retrovirus and transmitted chiefly through blood or blood products that enter the body's bloodstream, especially by sexual contact or contaminated hypodermic needles.
virus: an ultramicroscopic (20 to 300 nm in diameter), metabolically inert, infectious agent that replicates only within the cells of living hosts, mainly bacteria, plants, and animals: composed of an RNA or DNA core, a protein coat, and, in more complex types, a surrounding envelope.
discontinuance: the act or state of discontinuing or the state of being discontinued; cessation: the discontinuance of a business.
cough: to expel air from the lungs suddenly with a harsh noise, often involuntarily.
fortuitous: happening or produced by chance; accidental: a fortuitous encounter.
immersion: an act or instance of immersing.
delude: to mislead the mind or judgment of; deceive: His conceit deluded him into believing he was important.
destroyer: a person or thing that destroys.
freighter: a vessel used mainly for carrying cargo.
sham: something that is not what it purports to be; a spurious imitation; fraud or hoax.
modest: having or showing a moderate or humble estimate of one's merits, importance, etc.; free from vanity, egotism, boastfulness, or great pretensions.
thoughtless: lacking in consideration for others; inconsiderate; tactless: a thoughtless remark.
mindful: attentive, aware, or careful (usually followed by of): mindful of one's responsibilities.
unaware: not aware or conscious; unconscious: to be unaware of any change.
forgetful: apt to forget; that forgets: a forgetful person.
neglectful: characterized by neglect; disregardful; careless; negligent (often followed by of): neglectful of one's health.
provisional: providing or serving for the time being only; existing only until permanently or properly replaced; temporary: a provisional government.
socialize: to make social; make fit for life in companionship with others.
delegate: a person designated to act for or represent another or others; deputy; representative, as in a political convention.
tumultuous: full of tumult or riotousness; marked by disturbance and uproar: a tumultuous celebration.
mob: a disorderly or riotous crowd of people.
uproar: a state of violent and noisy disturbance, as of a multitude; turmoil.
premier: the head of the cabinet in France or Italy or certain other countries; first minister; prime minister.
reign: the period during which a sovereign occupies the throne.
upset: to overturn: to upset a pitcher of milk.
scenery: the general appearance of a place; the aggregate of features that give character to a landscape.
temperamental: having or exhibiting a strongly marked, individual temperament.
unnatural: contrary to the laws or course of nature.
uncomfortable: causing discomfort or distress; painful; irritating.
navigation: the act or process of navigating.
irrigation: the artificial application of water to land to assist in the production of crops.
converted: noting a specified type of person who has been converted from the religion, beliefs, or attitudes characteristic of that type: a converted Christian; a converted thief.
chlorophyll: the green coloring matter of leaves and plants, essential to the production of carbohydrates by photosynthesis, and occurring in a bluish-black form, C 55 H 72 MgN 4 O 5 (chlorophyll a) and a dark-green form, C 55 H 70 MgN 4 O 6 (chlorophyll b)
moss: any tiny, leafy-stemmed, flowerless plant of the class Musci, reproducing by spores and growing in tufts, sods, or mats on moist ground, tree trunks, rocks, etc.
liverwort: any mosslike plant of the class Hepaticae, growing chiefly on damp ground, rocks, or on tree trunks and helping the decay of logs and the disintegration of rocks.
hornwort: any aquatic plant of the genus Ceratophyllum, found in ponds and slow streams.
fungus: any of a diverse group of eukaryotic single-celled or multinucleate organisms that live by decomposing and absorbing the organic material in which they grow, comprising the mushrooms, molds, mildews, smuts, rusts, and yeasts, and classified in the kingdom Fungi or, in some classification systems, in the division Fungi (Thallophyta) of the kingdom Plantae.
classified: arranged or distributed in classes or according to class: We plan to review all the classified specimens in the laboratory.
pyrrophyta: a phylum in the kingdom Protista comprising the dinoflagellates and cryptomonads.
ubiquitous: existing or being everywhere, especially at the same time; omnipresent: ubiquitous fog; ubiquitous little ants.
spiral: Geometry. a plane curve generated by a point moving around a fixed point while constantly receding from or approaching it.
phylum: Biology. the primary subdivision of a taxonomic kingdom, grouping together all classes of organisms that have the same body plan.
monera: a taxonomic kingdom of prokaryotic organisms that typically reproduce by asexual budding or fission and have a nutritional mode of absorption, photosynthesis, or chemosynthesis, comprising the bacteria, blue-green algae, and various primitive pathogens.
putrefaction: the act or process of putrefying; the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter by bacteria and fungi that results in obnoxiously odorous products; rotting.
fixation: the act of fixing or the state of being fixed.
abound: to occur or exist in great quantities or numbers: a stream in which trout abound.
jerky: characterized by jerks or sudden starts; spasmodic.
diminish: to make or cause to seem smaller, less, less important, etc.; lessen; reduce.
barring: excepting; except for: Barring accidents, I'll be there.
saving: tending or serving to save; rescuing; preserving.
chapter: a main division of a book, treatise, or the like, usually bearing a number or title.
dessert: cake, pie, fruit, pudding, ice cream, etc., served as the final course of a meal.
sweetener: something that sweetens, as sugar or a low-calorie synthetic product used instead of sugar.
tapioca: a food substance prepared from cassava in granular, flake, pellet (pearl tapioca) or flour form, used in puddings, as a thickener, etc.
expectant: having expectations; expecting: an excited, expectant audience.
malus: there is a malus clause in his contract.
vehicular: of, relating to, or for vehicles: a vehicular tunnel.
diesel: noting a machine or vehicle powered by a diesel engine: diesel locomotive.
ecstatic: of, relating to, or characterized by ecstasy or a state of sudden, intense, overpowering emotion: an ecstatic frenzy; ecstatic cheering for the winning team.
foramen: an opening, orifice, or short passage, as in a bone or in the integument of the ovule of a plant.
thorn: a sharp excrescence on a plant, especially a sharp-pointed aborted branch; spine; prickle.
await: to wait for; expect; look for: He is still awaiting an answer.
prong: one of the pointed tines of a fork.
harpoon: a barbed, spearlike missile attached to a rope, and thrown by hand or shot from a gun, used for killing and capturing whales and large fish.
sofa: a long, upholstered couch with a back and two arms or raised ends.
violate: to break, infringe, or transgress (a law, rule, agreement, promise, instructions, etc.).
sinful: characterized by, guilty of, or full of sin; wicked: a sinful life.
iniquitous: characterized by injustice or wickedness; wicked; sinful.
servitude: slavery or bondage of any kind: political or intellectual servitude.
incompetent: not competent; lacking qualification or ability; incapable: an incompetent candidate.
entitle: to give (a person or thing) a title, right, or claim to something; furnish with grounds for laying claim: His executive position entitled him to certain courtesies rarely accorded others.
majesty: regal, lofty, or stately dignity; imposing character; grandeur: majesty of bearing; the majesty of Chartres.
nostril: either of the two external openings of the nose.
hall: a corridor or passageway in a building.
alley: a passage, as through a continuous row of houses, permitting access from the street to backyards, garages, etc.
catwalk: a narrow walkway, especially one high above the surrounding area, used to provide access or allow workers to stand or move, as over the stage in a theater, outside the roadway of a bridge, along the top of a railroad car, etc.
inhalation: an act or instance of inhaling.
breathing: the act of a person or other animal that breathes; respiration.
connective: serving or tending to connect: connective remarks between chapters.
loading: the act of a person or thing that loads.
convincing: persuading or assuring by argument or evidence: They gave a convincing demonstration of the car's safety features.
presidential: of or relating to a president or presidency.
treasurer: a person in charge of treasure or a treasury.
negligent: guilty of or characterized by neglect, as of duty: negligent officials.
neglect: to pay no attention or too little attention to; disregard or slight: The public neglected his genius for many years.
deem: to form or have an opinion; judge; think: He did not deem lightly of the issue.
obedience: the state or quality of being obedient.
pistol: a short firearm intended to be held and fired with one hand.
nock: a metal or plastic piece at the end of an arrow, having a notch for the bowstring.
liberate: to set free, as from imprisonment or bondage.
lifeline: a line, fired across a ship or boat, by means of which a hawser for a breeches buoy may be hauled aboard.
hurling: the act of throwing or casting, especially with great force or strength.
frown: to contract the brow, as in displeasure or deep thought; scowl.
trail: to drag or let drag along the ground or other surface; draw or drag along behind.
duplicate: a copy exactly like an original.
snob: a person who imitates, cultivates, or slavishly admires social superiors and is condescending or overbearing to others.
turpentine: any of various oleoresins derived from coniferous trees, especially the longleaf pine, Pinus palustris, and yielding a volatile oil and a resin when distilled.
rotatory: pertaining to or of the nature of rotation: rotatory motion.
thus: in the way just indicated; in this way: Stated thus, the problem seems trivial.
trajectory: the curve described by a projectile, rocket, or the like in its flight.
howitzer: a cannon having a comparatively short barrel, used especially for firing shells at a high angle of elevation, as for reaching a target behind cover or in a trench.
cookie: a small cake made from stiff, sweet dough rolled and sliced or dropped by spoonfuls on a large, flat pan (cookie sheet) and baked.
ensign: a flag or banner, as a military or naval standard used to indicate nationality.
banner: the flag of a country, army, troop, etc.
pennant: a long, tapering flag or burgee of distinctive form and special significance, borne on naval or other vessels and used in signaling or for identification.
communicable: capable of being easily communicated or transmitted: communicable information; a communicable disease.
haul: to pull or draw with force; move by drawing; drag: They hauled the boat up onto the beach.
sled: a small vehicle consisting of a platform mounted on runners for use in traveling over snow or ice.
tear: a drop of the saline, watery fluid continually secreted by the lacrimal glands between the surface of the eye and the eyelid, serving to moisten and lubricate these parts and keep them clear of foreign particles. Synonyms: teardrop.
hindrance: an impeding, stopping, preventing, or the like.
comfortable: (of clothing, furniture, etc.) producing or affording physical comfort, support, or ease: a comfortable chair; comfortable shoes.
pot: a container of earthenware, metal, etc., usually round and deep and having a handle or handles and often a lid, used for cooking, serving, and other purposes.
notch: an angular or V -shaped cut, indentation, or slit in an object, surface, or edge.
plow: an agricultural implement used for cutting, lifting, turning over, and partly pulverizing soil.
slat: a long thin, narrow strip of wood, metal, etc., used as a support for a bed, as one of the horizontal laths of a Venetian blind, etc.
protuberant: bulging out beyond the surrounding surface; protruding; projecting: protuberant eyes.
curvature: the act of curving or the state of being curved.
bison: Also called American bison, American buffalo. a North American, oxlike ruminant, Bison bison, having a large head and high, humped shoulders: formerly common in North America, its small remaining population in isolated western areas of the U.S. and Canada is now protected.
pressing: urgent; demanding immediate attention: a pressing need.
belligerence: a warlike or aggressively hostile nature, condition, or attitude.
wrath: strong, stern, or fierce anger; deeply resentful indignation; ire.
indignation: strong displeasure at something considered unjust, offensive, insulting, or base; righteous anger.
symptom: any phenomenon or circumstance accompanying something and serving as evidence of it.
soul: the principle of life, feeling, thought, and action in humans, regarded as a distinct entity separate from the body, and commonly held to be separable in existence from the body; the spiritual part of humans as distinct from the physical part.
patriot: a person who loves, supports, and defends his or her country and its interests with devotion.
taxonomy: the science or technique of classification.
faithful: strict or thorough in the performance of duty: a faithful worker.
genitalia: the organs of reproduction, especially the external organs.
gonad: a sex gland in which gametes are produced; an ovary or testis.
secondary: next after the first in order, place, time, etc.
presume: to take for granted, assume, or suppose: I presume you're tired after your drive.
mustache: the hair growing on the upper lip.
shave: to remove a growth of beard with a razor.
depressing: serving to depress; inducing a state of depression: depressing news.
miami: a member of a North American Indian tribe of the Algonquian family, formerly located in northern Indiana, southern Michigan, and possibly Illinois, now extinct as a tribe.
fox: any of several carnivores of the dog family, especially those of the genus Vulpes, smaller than wolves, having a pointed, slightly upturned muzzle, erect ears, and a long, bushy tail.
pitchblende: a massive variety of uraninite, occurring in black pitchlike masses: a major ore of uranium and radium.
isotope: any of two or more forms of a chemical element, having the same number of protons in the nucleus, or the same atomic number, but having different numbers of neutrons in the nucleus, or different atomic weights. There are 275 isotopes of the 81 stable elements, in addition to over 800 radioactive isotopes, and every element has known isotopic forms. Isotopes of a single element possess almost identical properties.
mine: a form of the possessive case of I used as a predicate adjective: The yellow sweater is mine.
distressed: affected with or suffering from distress.
encircle: to form a circle around; surround; encompass: to encircle an enemy.
pod: a somewhat elongated, two-valved seed vessel, as that of the pea or bean.
bee: any hymenopterous insect of the superfamily Apoidea, including social and solitary species of several families, as the bumblebees, honeybees, etc.
saccharine: of the nature of or resembling that of sugar: a powdery substance with a saccharine taste.
pollinate: to convey pollen to the stigma of (a flower).
eruptive: bursting forth, or tending to burst forth.
urticaria: a transient condition of the skin, usually caused by an allergic reaction, characterized by pale or reddened irregular, elevated patches and severe itching; hives.
chamber: a room, usually private, in a house or apartment, especially a bedroom: She retired to her chamber.
hotter: to vibrate up and down; shake, totter, or rattle, as a plate on a shelf.
prince: a nonreigning male member of a royal family.
philip: one of the 12 apostles. Mark 3:18; John 1:43–48; 6:5–7.
clinic: a place, as in connection with a medical school or a hospital, for the treatment of nonresident patients, sometimes at low cost or without charge.
hanging: the act, an instance, or the form of capital punishment carried out by suspending one by the neck from a gallows, gibbet, or the like, until dead.
flaccid: soft and limp; not firm; flabby: flaccid biceps.
portly: rather heavy or fat; stout; corpulent.
overweight: weighing too much or more than is considered normal, proper, etc.: overweight luggage; an overweight patient; two letters that may be overweight.
fission: the act of cleaving or splitting into parts.
leaven: a substance, as yeast or baking powder, that causes fermentation and expansion of dough or batter.
elegant: tastefully fine or luxurious in dress, style, design, etc.: elegant furnishings.
subtle: thin, tenuous, or rarefied, as a fluid or an odor.
maize: (chiefly in British and technical usage) corn1 (def 1).
starchy: of, relating to, or of the nature of starch.
setaria: any grass of the genus Setaria, having a dense panicle, grown for forage.
fodder: coarse food for livestock, composed of entire plants, including leaves, stalks, and grain, of such forages as corn and sorghum.
socket: a hollow part or piece for receiving and holding some part or thing.
reptile: any cold-blooded vertebrate of the class Reptilia, comprising the turtles, snakes, lizards, crocodilians, amphisbaenians, tuatara, and various extinct members including the dinosaurs.
pectin: a white, amorphous, colloidal carbohydrate of high molecular weight occurring in ripe fruits, especially in apples, currants, etc., and used in fruit jellies, pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics for its thickening and emulsifying properties and its ability to solidify to a gel.
toast: sliced bread that has been browned by dry heat.
ridicule: speech or action intended to cause contemptuous laughter at a person or thing; derision.
inept: without skill or aptitude for a particular task or assignment; maladroit: He is inept at mechanical tasks. She is inept at dealing with people.
unqualified: not qualified; not fit; lacking requisite qualifications: unqualified for the job.
upturn: to turn up or over: The farmer upturned clumps of sod with his spade.
ascendant: a position of dominance or controlling influence: possession of power, superiority, or preeminence: With his rivals in the ascendant, he soon lost his position.
domination: an act or instance of dominating.
surpassing: of a large amount or high degree; exceeding, excelling, or extraordinary: structures of surpassing magnificence.
steak: a slice of meat or fish, especially beef, cooked by broiling, frying, etc.
bosom: the breast of a human being.
hug: to clasp tightly in the arms, especially with affection; embrace.
heredity: the transmission of genetic characters from parents to offspring: it is dependent upon the segregation and recombination of genes during meiosis and fertilization and results in the genesis of a new individual similar to others of its kind but exhibiting certain variations resulting from the particular mix of genes and their interactions with the environment.
dna: Compare base pair, gene, genetic code, RNA.
rna: ribonucleic acid: any of a class of single-stranded molecules transcribed from DNA in the cell nucleus or in the mitochondrion or chloroplast, containing along the strand a linear sequence of nucleotide bases that is complementary to the DNA strand from which it is transcribed: the composition of the RNA molecule is identical with that of DNA except for the substitution of the sugar ribose for deoxyribose and the substitution of the nucleotide base uracil for thymine.
dial: a plate, disk, face, or other surface containing markings or figures upon which the time of day is indicated by hands, pointers, or shadows, as of a clock or sundial.
cash: money in the form of coins or banknotes, especially that issued by a government.
ski: one of a pair of long, slender runners made of wood, plastic, or metal used in gliding over snow.
inquisitive: given to inquiry, research, or asking questions; eager for knowledge; intellectually curious: an inquisitive mind.
clergy: the group or body of ordained persons in a religion, as distinguished from the laity.
classify: to arrange or organize by classes; order according to class.
athlete: a person trained or gifted in exercises or contests involving physical agility, stamina, or strength; a participant in a sport, exercise, or game requiring physical skill.
rudiment: the elements or first principles of a subject: the rudiments of grammar.
wonder: to think or speculate curiously: to wonder about the origin of the solar system.
deceit: the act or practice of deceiving; concealment or distortion of the truth for the purpose of misleading; duplicity; fraud; cheating: Once she exposed their deceit, no one ever trusted them again.
hypocrisy: a pretense of having a virtuous character, moral or religious beliefs or principles, etc., that one does not really possess.
apology: a written or spoken expression of one's regret, remorse, or sorrow for having insulted, failed, injured, or wronged another: He demanded an apology from me for calling him a crook.
boost: to lift or raise by pushing from behind or below.
medal: a flat piece of metal, often a disk but sometimes a cross, star, or other form, usually bearing an inscription or design, issued to commemorate a person, action, or event, or given as a reward for bravery, merit, or the like: a gold medal for the best swimmer.
reverse: opposite or contrary in position, direction, order, or character: an impression reverse to what was intended; in reverse sequence.
lightly: with little weight, force, intensity, etc.; gently: to press lightly on a door bell.
wastebasket: a standing basket for wastepaper, small items of trash, etc.
breach: the act or a result of breaking; break or rupture.
stocking: a close-fitting covering for the foot and part of the leg, usually knitted, of wool, cotton, nylon, silk, or similar material.
calf: the young of the domestic cow or other bovine animal.
luxurious: characterized by luxury; ministering or conducive to luxury: a luxurious hotel.
simmer: to cook or cook in a liquid at or just below the boiling point.
fare: the price of conveyance or passage in a bus, train, airplane, or other vehicle.
symmetry: the correspondence in size, form, and arrangement of parts on opposite sides of a plane, line, or point; regularity of form or arrangement in terms of like, reciprocal, or corresponding parts.
shower: a brief fall of rain or, sometimes, of hail or snow.
vitreous: of the nature of or resembling glass, as in transparency, brittleness, hardness, glossiness, etc.: vitreous china.
antechamber: a chamber or room that serves as a waiting room and entrance to a larger room or an apartment; anteroom.
peptide: a compound containing two or more amino acids in which the carboxyl group of one acid is linked to the amino group of the other.
tendon: Anatomy. a cord or band of dense, tough, inelastic, white, fibrous tissue, serving to connect a muscle with a bone or part; sinew.
insoluble: incapable of being dissolved: insoluble salts.
pigment: a dry insoluble substance, usually pulverized, which when suspended in a liquid vehicle becomes a paint, ink, etc.
venous: of, relating to, or of the nature of a vein.
arterial: Physiology. pertaining to the blood in the pulmonary vein, in the left side of the heart, and in most arteries, having been oxygenated during its passage through the lungs and being normally bright red.
antibody: any of numerous Y -shaped protein molecules produced by B cells as a primary immune defense, each molecule and its clones having a unique binding site that can combine with the complementary site of a foreign antigen, as on a virus or bacterium, thereby disabling the antigen and signaling other immune defenses. Abbreviation:  Ab.
inoculation: the act or process of inoculating.
enzyme: any of various proteins, as pepsin, originating from living cells and capable of producing certain chemical changes in organic substances by catalytic action, as in digestion.
faint: lacking brightness, vividness, clearness, loudness, strength, etc.: a faint light; a faint color; a faint sound.
ligament: Anatomy, Zoology. a band of tissue, usually white and fibrous, serving to connect bones, hold organs in place, etc.
horny: consisting of a horn or a hornlike substance; corneous.
ox: the adult castrated male of the genus Bos, used chiefly as a draft animal.
cashew: a tree, Anacardium occidentale, native to tropical America, having milky juice, simple, leathery leaves, and yellowish-pink flowers in open clusters.
bandage: a strip of cloth or other material used to bind up a wound, sore, sprain, etc.
mandible: the bone of the lower jaw.
maxilla: a jaw or jawbone, especially the upper.
calcareous: of, containing, or like calcium carbonate; chalky: calcareous earth.
cementum: the bonelike tissue that forms the outer surface of the root of the tooth.
headgear: any covering for the head, especially a hat, cap, bonnet, etc.
sovereignty: the quality or state of being sovereign, or of having supreme power or authority.
glassy: resembling glass, as in transparency or smoothness.
defendant: Law. a person, company, etc., against whom a claim or charge is brought in a court (opposed to plaintiff).
prism: Optics. a transparent solid body, often having triangular bases, used for dispersing light into a spectrum or for reflecting rays of light.
membranous: consisting of, of the nature of, or resembling membrane.
sincerity: freedom from deceit, hypocrisy, or duplicity; probity in intention or in communicating; earnestness.
tile: a thin slab or bent piece of baked clay, sometimes painted or glazed, used for various purposes, as to form one of the units of a roof covering, floor, or revetment.
serenity: the state or quality of being serene, calm, or tranquil; sereneness.
federal: pertaining to or of the nature of a union of states under a central government distinct from the individual governments of the separate states, as in federal government; federal system.
subsidy: a direct pecuniary aid furnished by a government to a private industrial undertaking, a charity organization, or the like.
kings: either of two books of the Bible, I Kings or II Kings, which contain the history of the kings of Israel and Judah. Abbreviation:  Ki.
interlace: to cross one another, typically passing alternately over and under, as if woven together; intertwine: Their hands interlaced.
twine: a strong thread or string composed of two or more strands twisted together.
schooner: See also ketch, topsail schooner, yawl1 (def 2).
recede: to go or move away; retreat; go to or toward a more distant point; withdraw.
cetacea: order of marine mammals containing whales, 1830, Modern Latin, from Latin cetus "any large sea creature" (whales, seals, dolphins), from Greek ketos "a whale, a sea monster," of unknown origin, + -acea. Hence cetology "the study of whales," first attested 1851 in "Moby Dick."
timber: the wood of growing trees suitable for structural uses.
thanksgiving: the act of giving thanks; grateful acknowledgment of benefits or favors, especially to God.
derivation: the act or fact of deriving or of being derived.
suspect: to believe to be guilty, false, counterfeit, undesirable, defective, bad, etc., with little or no proof: to suspect a person of murder.
innocent: free from moral wrong; without sin; pure: innocent children.
appliance: an instrument, apparatus, or device for a particular purpose or use.
mainsail: the lowermost sail on a mainmast.
earn: to gain or get in return for one's labor or service: to earn one's living.
comprehensible: capable of being comprehended or understood; intelligible.
soothe: to tranquilize or calm, as a person or the feelings; relieve, comfort, or refresh: soothing someone's anger; to soothe someone with a hot drink.
console: to alleviate or lessen the grief, sorrow, or disappointment of; give solace or comfort: Only his children could console him when his wife died.
chinese: the standard language of China, based on the speech of Beijing; Mandarin.
statistic: a numerical fact or datum, especially one computed from a sample.
barely: only just; scarcely; no more than; almost not: He had barely enough money to pay for the car.
hardly: only just; almost not; barely: We had hardly reached the lake when it started raining. hardly any; hardly ever.
calculate: to determine or ascertain by mathematical methods; compute: to calculate the velocity of light.
jacquard: a fabric with an elaborately woven pattern produced on a Jacquard loom.
dobby: British Dialect. a fatuous person; fool.
bedford: John of Lancaster, Duke of, 1389–1435, English regent of France.
ascribe: to credit or assign, as to a cause or source; attribute; impute: The alphabet is usually ascribed to the Phoenicians.
drilling: the act of a person or thing that drills.
distillation: the volatilization or evaporation and subsequent condensation of a liquid, as when water is boiled in a retort and the steam is condensed in a cool receiver.
kerosene: a mixture of liquid hydrocarbons obtained by distilling petroleum, bituminous shale, or the like, and widely used as a fuel, cleaning solvent, etc.
paraffin: a white or colorless, tasteless, odorless, water-insoluble, solid substance not easily acted upon by reagents, consisting of a mixture of hydrocarbons chiefly of the alkane series, obtained from crude petroleum: used in candles, for forming preservative coatings and seals, for waterproofing paper, etc.
piano: a musical instrument in which felt-covered hammers, operated from a keyboard, strike the metal strings.
sheath: a case or covering for the blade of a sword, dagger, or the like.
stead: the place of a person or thing as occupied by a successor or substitute: The nephew of the queen came in her stead.
ordered: neatly or conveniently arranged; well-organized: an ordered office.
possibly: perhaps; maybe: It may possibly rain today.
catastrophe: a sudden and widespread disaster: the catastrophe of war.
disastrous: causing great distress or injury; ruinous; very unfortunate; calamitous: The rain and cold proved disastrous to his health.
calamitous: causing or involving calamity; disastrous: a calamitous defeat.
dam: a barrier to obstruct the flow of water, especially one of earth, masonry, etc., built across a stream or river.
patience: the quality of being patient, as the bearing of provocation, annoyance, misfortune, or pain, without complaint, loss of temper, irritation, or the like.
periphery: the external boundary of any surface or area.
conic: Also, conical. having the form of, resembling, or pertaining to a cone.
militant: vigorously active and aggressive, especially in support of a cause: militant reformers.
dan: a degree of expertise in karate, judo, tae kwon do, etc., usually signified by the wearing of a cloth belt of a particular color; level: a sixth-degree dan.
blessed: consecrated; sacred; holy; sanctified: the Blessed Sacrament.
mortal: subject to death; having a transitory life: all mortal creatures.

nightshade: any of various plants of the genus Solanum, especially the black nightshade or the bittersweet.

glandular: consisting of, containing, or bearing glands.
abdominal: of, in, on, or for the abdomen: abdominal wall; abdominal pains.
bile: Physiology. a bitter, alkaline, yellow or greenish liquid, secreted by the liver, that aids in absorption and digestion, especially of fats.
metabolic: of, relating to, or affected by metabolism.
circulation: an act or instance of circulating, moving in a circle or circuit, or flowing.
atrium: He had reassembled the weapon in a bathroom and stepped out onto a fourth-floor walkway overlooking an atrium.
ventricle: Zoology. any of various hollow organs or parts in an animal body.
pulmonary: of or relating to the lungs.

elihu: a young man who entered into discourse with Job. Job. 32–37.

collegiate: of or relating to a college: collegiate life.
hamper: to hold back; hinder; impede: A steady rain hampered the progress of the work.

optics: (used with a singular verb) the branch of physical science that deals with the properties and phenomena of both visible and invisible light and with vision.
wand: a slender stick or rod, especially one used by a magician, conjurer, or diviner.
jean: Sometimes, jeans. a sturdy twilled fabric, usually of cotton.
lindsay: Howard, 1889–1968, U.S. playwright, producer, and actor.
renaissance: the activity, spirit, or time of the great revival of art, literature, and learning in Europe beginning in the 14th century and extending to the 17th century, marking the transition from the medieval to the modern world.
semiprecious: (of a stone) having commercial value as a gem but not classified as precious, as the amethyst or garnet.
taxing: wearingly burdensome: the day-to-day, taxing duties of a supervisor.
accommodate: to do a kindness or a favor to; oblige: to accommodate a friend by helping him move to a new apartment.
reciprocal: given or felt by each toward the other; mutual: reciprocal respect.
recommend: to present as worthy of confidence, acceptance, use, etc.; commend; mention favorably: to recommend an applicant for a job; to recommend a book.

speeder: a person or thing that speeds.
victorious: having achieved a victory; conquering; triumphant: our victorious army.

clap: to strike the palms of (one's hands) against one another resoundingly, and usually repeatedly, especially to express approval: She clapped her hands in appreciation.
gratitude: the quality or feeling of being grateful or thankful: He expressed his gratitude to everyone on the staff.
recognition: an act of recognizing or the state of being recognized.
sublime: elevated or lofty in thought, language, etc.: Paradise Lost is sublime poetry.
comic: of, relating to, or characterized by comedy: comic opera.
validity: the state or quality of being valid: to question the validity of the argument.
balkan: pertaining to the Balkan States or their inhabitants.
athens: Greek Athenai. a city in and the capital of Greece, in the SE part.
neat: in a pleasingly orderly and clean condition: a neat room.
tidy: neat, orderly, or trim, as in appearance or dress: a tidy room; a tidy person.
affable: pleasantly easy to approach and to talk to; friendly; cordial; warmly polite: an affable and courteous gentleman.
unload: to take the load from; remove the cargo or freight from: to unload a truck; to unload a cart.
lantern: a transparent or translucent, usually portable, case for enclosing a light and protecting it from the wind, rain, etc.
traveler: a person or thing that travels.
restaurant: an establishment where meals are served to customers.
survive: to remain alive after the death of someone, the cessation of something, or the occurrence of some event; continue to live: Few survived after the holocaust.
privation: lack of the usual comforts or necessaries of life: His life of privation began to affect his health.
neediness: a condition of want or need; poverty; indigence.
destitution: lack of the means of subsistence; utter poverty.
pauperism: the state or condition of utter poverty.
severity: harshness, sternness, or rigor: Their lives were marked by severity.
curl: to form into coils or ringlets, as the hair.
overlap: to lap over (something else or each other); extend over and cover a part of; imbricate.
keratin: a scleroprotein or albuminoid substance, found in the dead outer skin layer, and in horn, hair, feathers, hoofs, nails, claws, bills, etc.
silky: of or like silk; smooth, lustrous, soft, or delicate: silky skin.

moth: any of numerous insects of the order Lepidoptera, generally distinguished from the butterflies by having feathery antennae and by having crepuscular or nocturnal habits.
mori: dulce et decorum est pro patria mori
fluffy: of, resembling, or covered with fluff.
garden: a plot of ground, usually near a house, where flowers, shrubs, vegetables, fruits, or herbs are cultivated.
musk: a substance secreted in a glandular sac under the skin of the abdomen of the male musk deer, having a strong odor, and used in perfumery.
stuffing: the act of a person or thing that stuffs.
padding: material, as cotton or straw, used to pad something.
alfred: a male given name: from the Old English words meaning “elf” and “counsel.”.
anecdote: a short account of a particular incident or event, especially of an interesting or amusing nature.
laughter: the action or sound of laughing.
funny: providing fun; causing amusement or laughter; amusing; comical: a funny remark; a funny person.
winning: the act of a person or thing that wins.
ranch: an establishment maintained for raising livestock under range conditions.
tenant: a person or group that rents and occupies land, a house, an office, or the like, from another for a period of time; lessee.
capture: to take by force or stratagem; take prisoner; seize: The police captured the burglar.
runaway: a person who runs away; fugitive; deserter.

accompaniment: something incidental or added for ornament, symmetry, etc.
thud: a dull sound, as of a heavy blow or fall.

vibrate: to move rhythmically and steadily to and fro, as a pendulum; oscillate.
cheat: to defraud; swindle: He cheated her out of her inheritance.
preconceive: to form a conception or opinion of beforehand, as before seeing evidence or as a result of previously held prejudice.
unreason: inability or unwillingness to think or act rationally, reasonably, or sensibly; irrationality.
applicant: a person who applies for or requests something; a candidate: an applicant for a position.
equity: the quality of being fair or impartial; fairness; impartiality: the equity of Solomon.

etymology: the derivation of a word. Synonyms: word origin, word source, derivation, origin.
wordbook: a book of words, usually with definitions, explanations, etc.; a dictionary.
encyclopedia: a book, set of books, optical disc, mobile device, or online informational resource containing articles on various topics, usually in alphabetical arrangement, covering all branches of knowledge or, less commonly, all aspects of one subject.

electronics: (used with a singular verb) the science dealing with the development and application of devices and systems involving the flow of electrons in a vacuum, in gaseous media, and in semiconductors.
admittance: permission or right to enter: admittance into the exhibit room.
subsidiary: serving to assist or supplement; auxiliary; supplementary.
duke: (in Continental Europe) the male ruler of a duchy; the sovereign of a small state.

affirmation: the act or an instance of affirming; state of being affirmed.

windy: accompanied or characterized by wind: a windy day.

tom: the male of various animals, as the turkey.
iowa: a state in the central United States: a part of the Midwest. 56,290 sq. mi. (145,790 sq. km). Capital:  Des Moines.

breath: the air inhaled and exhaled in respiration.

arrogant: making claims or pretensions to superior importance or rights; overbearingly assuming; insolently proud: an arrogant public official.

theoretical: of, relating to, or consisting in theory; not practical (distinguished from applied).

flexed: (of a human leg) depicted as bent at the knee.
akkadian: the eastern Semitic language, now extinct, of Assyria and Babylonia, written with a cuneiform script.
wisdom: the quality or state of being wise; knowledge of what is true or right coupled with just judgment as to action; sagacity, discernment, or insight.
apsu: an Akkadian god: the consort of Tiamat and the father of the gods.
marduk: the chief of the Babylonian deities.

damaging: causing or capable of causing damages; harmful; injurious.
introductory: serving or used to introduce; preliminary; beginning: an introductory course; an introductory paragraph.

privileged: belonging to a class that enjoys special privileges; favored: the privileged few.
preacher: a person whose occupation or function it is to preach the gospel.

shaving: Often, shavings. a very thin piece or slice, especially of wood.

obsolete: no longer in general use; fallen into disuse: an obsolete expression.
momentum: force or speed of movement; impetus, as of a physical object or course of events: The car gained momentum going downhill. Her career lost momentum after two unsuccessful films.

sullen: showing irritation or ill humor by a gloomy silence or reserve.
unhappy: sad; miserable; wretched: Why is she so unhappy?
perhaps: maybe; possibly: Perhaps the package will arrive today.
ahasuerus: a king of ancient Persia, known to the Greeks as Xerxes: husband of the Biblical Esther.
garret: an attic, usually a small, wretched one.
augustus: Also called Octavian (before 27 b.c.)(Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus; Augustus Caesar) 63 b.c.–a.d. 14, first Roman emperor 27 b.c.–a.d. 14: reformer, patron of arts and literature; heir and successor to Julius Caesar.

suffrage: the right to vote, especially in a political election.

epistemology: a branch of philosophy that investigates the origin, nature, methods, and limits of human knowledge.
virginia: a state in the E United States, on the Atlantic coast: part of the historical South. 40,815 sq. mi. (105,710 sq. km). Capital:  Richmond.

translate: to turn from one language into another or from a foreign language into one's own: to translate Spanish.

pathetic: causing or evoking pity, sympathetic sadness, sorrow, etc.; pitiful; pitiable: a pathetic letter; a pathetic sight.
farewell: goodby; may you fare well: Farewell, and may we meet again in happier times.

buttock: The buttock, however, in man is different from that of all animals whatsoever.
salishan: a family of American Indian languages including Coeur d'Alêne, Kalispel, and other languages of British Columbia and the northwestern U.S.

prevention: the act of preventing; effectual hindrance.

co: Colorado (approved especially for use with zip code).
vicinity: the area or region near or about a place; surrounding district; neighborhood: There are no stores in the vicinity of our house.
sieve: an instrument with a meshed or perforated bottom, used for separating coarse from fine parts of loose matter, for straining liquids, etc., especially one with a circular frame and fine meshes or perforations.
dehydration: the act or process of dehydrating.
colorado: (of cigars) of medium color and strength.
excrement: waste matter discharged from the body, especially feces.
needles: a town in SE California: on Colorado River at Arizona line.
sprout: to begin to grow; shoot forth, as a plant from a seed.
interlock: to fit into each other, as parts of machinery, so that all action is synchronized.
poison: a substance with an inherent property that tends to destroy life or impair health.
additive: something that is added, as one substance to another, to alter or improve the general quality or to counteract undesirable properties: an additive that thins paint.
eliminate: to remove or get rid of, especially as being in some way undesirable: to eliminate risks; to eliminate hunger.
minimize: to reduce to the smallest possible amount or degree.
garrison: a body of troops stationed in a fortified place.
bivalent: Monoxide, mo-nok′sīd, n. an oxide containing a single oxygen atom in combination with two univalent atoms or one bivalent atom.
cation: a positively charged ion that is attracted to the cathode in electrolysis.
cathode: the electrode or terminal by which current leaves an electrolytic cell, voltaic cell, battery, etc.
anion: a negatively charged ion, as one attracted to the anode in electrolysis.
anode: the electrode or terminal by which current enters an electrolytic cell, voltaic cell, battery, etc.
minus: less by the subtraction of; decreased by: Ten minus six is four.
microorganism: any organism too small to be viewed by the unaided eye, as bacteria, protozoa, and some fungi and algae.
geologic: of, relating to, or based on geology.
foraminifer: any chiefly marine protozoan of the sarcodinian order Foraminifera, typically having a linear, spiral, or concentric shell perforated by small holes or pores through which pseudopodia extend.
scratch: to break, mar, or mark the surface of by rubbing, scraping, or tearing with something sharp or rough: to scratch one's hand on a nail.
pasty: of or like paste in consistency, texture, color, etc.
harden: to make hard or harder: to harden steel.
count: to check over (the separate units or groups of a collection) one by one to determine the total number; add up; enumerate: He counted his tickets and found he had ten.
rigorous: characterized by rigor; rigidly severe or harsh, as people, rules, or discipline: rigorous laws.
stringent: rigorously binding or exacting; strict; severe: stringent laws.
fuse: a tube, cord, or the like, filled or saturated with combustible matter, for igniting an explosive.
ashy: ash-colored; pale; wan: an ashy complexion.
gravy: the fat and juices that drip from cooking meat, often thickened, seasoned, flavored, etc., and used as a sauce for meat, potatoes, rice, etc.
slake: to allay (thirst, desire, wrath, etc.) by satisfying.
bleach: to make whiter or lighter in color, as by exposure to sunlight or a chemical agent; remove the color from.
