breeches: Also called knee breeches. knee-length trousers, often having ornamental buckles or elaborate decoration at or near the bottoms, commonly worn by men and boys in the 17th, 18th, and early 19th centuries.
buoy: Nautical. a distinctively shaped and marked float, sometimes carrying a signal or signals, anchored to mark a channel, anchorage, navigational hazard, etc., or to provide a mooring place away from the shore.
scowl: to draw down or contract the brows in a sullen, displeased, or angry manner.
exactly: in an exact manner; precisely; accurately.
condescending: showing or implying a usually patronizing descent from dignity or superiority: They resented the older neighbors' condescending cordiality.
overbearing: domineering; dictatorial; haughtily or rudely arrogant.
trivial: of very little importance or value; insignificant: Don't bother me with trivial matters.
nationality: the status of belonging to a particular nation, whether by birth or naturalization: the nationality of an immigrant.
burgee: a triangular flag or one having a shallow, angular indentation in the fly, forming two tails, used as an identification flag, especially by yachts.
saline: of, containing, or resembling common table salt; salty or saltlike: a saline solution.
watery: pertaining to or connected with water: watery Neptune.
eyelid: the movable lid of skin that serves to cover and uncover the eyeball.
teardrop: a tear or something suggesting a tear: A single teardrop rolled down her face.
baluster: Architecture. any of a number of closely spaced supports for a railing.
louver: any of a series of narrow openings framed at their longer edges with slanting, overlapping fins or slats, adjustable for admitting light and air while shutting out rain.
venetian: of or relating to Venice or its inhabitants.
shop: a retail store, especially a small one.
crock: an earthenware pot, jar, or other container.
dromedary: the single-humped camel, Camelus dromedarius, of Arabia and northern Africa.
imitate: to follow or endeavor to follow as a model or example: to imitate an author's style; to imitate an older brother.
typewrite: to write by means of a typewriter; type.
urgent: compelling or requiring immediate action or attention; imperative; pressing: an urgent matter.
pinch: to squeeze or compress between the finger and thumb, the teeth, the jaws of an instrument, or the like.
warlike: fit, qualified, or ready for war; martial: a warlike fleet; warlike tribes.
fierce: menacingly wild, savage, or hostile: fierce animals; a fierce look.
insulting: giving or causing insult; characterized by affronting rudeness, insolence, etc.
separable: capable of being separated, parted, or dissociated.
apprise: to give notice to; inform; advise (often followed by of): to be apprised of the death of an old friend.
instructive: serving to instruct or inform; conveying instruction, knowledge, or information; enlightening.
hormone: Biochemistry. any of various internally secreted compounds, as insulin or thyroxine, formed in endocrine glands, that affect the functions of specifically receptive organs or tissues when transported to them by the body fluids.
suppose: to assume (something), as for the sake of argument or as part of a proposition or theory: Suppose the distance to be one mile.
tribe: any aggregate of people united by ties of descent from a common ancestor, community of customs and traditions, adherence to the same leaders, etc.
indiana: Robert (Robert Clarke) born 1928, U.S. painter of pop art.
michigan: a state in the N central United States. 58,216 sq. mi. (150,780 sq. km). Capital:  Lansing.
illinois: a state in the central United States: a part of the Midwest. 56,400 sq. mi. (146,075 sq. km). Capital:  Springfield.
elector: a person who elects or may elect, especially a qualified voter.
upturned: turned or directed upward: upturned eyes.
muzzle: the mouth, or end for discharge, of the barrel of a gun, pistol, etc.
bushy: resembling a bush; thick and shaggy: bushy whiskers.
massive: consisting of or forming a large mass; bulky and heavy: massive columns.
uraninite: a mineral, probably originally uranium dioxide, UO 2 , but altered by radioactive decay, and usually containing uranium trioxide, lead, radium, and helium, occurring in several varieties, including pitchblende: the most important ore of uranium.
reactor: a person or thing that reacts or undergoes reaction.
sweater: a knitted jacket or jersey, in pullover or cardigan style, with or without sleeves.
pea: the round, edible seed of a widely cultivated plant, Pisum sativum, of the legume family.
hymenopterous: belonging or pertaining to the Hymenoptera, an order of insects having, when winged, four membranous wings, and comprising the wasps, bees, ants, ichneumon flies, and sawflies.
superfamily: a category of related families within an order or suborder.
stigma: a mark of disgrace or infamy; a stain or reproach, as on one's reputation.
wheal: a small, burning or itching swelling on the skin, as from a mosquito bite or from hives.
transient: not lasting, enduring, or permanent; transitory.
allergic: of or relating to allergy: an allergic reaction to wool.
itching: of, relating to, or characterized by an irritating sensation of the skin.
bedroom: a room furnished and used for sleeping.
shake: to move or sway with short, quick, irregular vibratory movements.
totter: to walk or go with faltering steps, as if from extreme weakness.
rattle: to give out or cause a rapid succession of short, sharp sounds, as in consequence of agitation and repeated concussions: The windows rattled in their frames.
nonresident: not resident in a particular place.
gallows: a wooden frame, consisting of a crossbeam on two uprights, on which condemned persons are executed by hanging.
gibbet: a gallows with a projecting arm at the top, from which the bodies of criminals were formerly hung in chains and left suspended after execution.
limp: to walk with a labored, jerky movement, as when lame.
biceps: either of two flexor muscles, one (biceps brachii) located in the front of the upper arm and assisting in bending the arm, and the other (biceps femoris) located on the back of the thigh and assisting in bending the leg.
bud: “bud tender” Allie Greenstone (her real name) answers the door.
tenuous: thin or slender in form, as a thread.
rarefied: extremely high or elevated; lofty; exalted: the rarefied atmosphere of a scholarly symposium.
keos: a Greek island in the Aegean, off the SE coast of the Greek mainland. 56 sq. mi. (145 sq. km).
willie: a male given name, form of William.
howard: Catherine, c1520–42, fifth wife of Henry VIII.
kernel: the softer, usually edible part contained in the shell of a nut or the stone of a fruit.
invariable: not variable; not changing or capable of being changed; static or constant.
transformation: the act or process of transforming.
tuatara: a large, primarily nocturnal, lizardlike reptile, Sphenodon punctatum, of islands near the coast of New Zealand: the only surviving rhynchocephalian.
colloidal: pertaining to or of the nature of a colloid: colloidal gold and silver.
solidify: to make solid; make into a hard or compact mass; change from a liquid or gaseous to a solid form.
gel: Physical Chemistry. a semirigid colloidal dispersion of a solid with a liquid or gas, as jelly, glue, etc.
doughnut: a small cake of sweetened or, sometimes, unsweetened dough fried in deep fat, typically shaped like a ring or, when prepared with a filling, a ball.
assignment: something assigned, as a particular task or duty: She completed the assignment and went on to other jobs.
maladroit: lacking in adroitness; unskillful; awkward; bungling; tactless: to handle a diplomatic crisis in a very maladroit way.
elicit: to draw or bring out or forth; educe; evoke: to elicit the truth; to elicit a response with a question.
sod: a section cut or torn from the surface of grassland, containing the matted roots of grass.
spade: a tool for digging, having an iron blade adapted for pressing into the ground with the foot and a long handle commonly with a grip or crosspiece at the top, and with the blade usually narrower and flatter than that of a shovel.
preeminence: the state or character of being preeminent.
overgrow: to grow over; cover with a growth of something.
segregation: the act or practice of segregating; a setting apart or separation of people or things from others or from the main body or group: gender segregation in some fundamentalist religions.
recombination: the formation of new combinations of genes, either naturally, by crossing over or independent assortment, or in the laboratory by direct manipulation of genetic material.
fertilization: an act, process, or instance of fertilizing.
nucleotide: any of a group of molecules that, when linked together, form the building blocks of DNA or RNA: composed of a phosphate group, the bases adenine, cytosine, guanine, and thymine, and a pentose sugar, in RNA the thymine base being replaced by uracil.
ribonucleic: 1931, from ribo-, comb. form of ribose, the sugar component, + nucleic acid.
mitochondrion: an organelle in the cytoplasm of cells that functions in energy production.
ribose: a white, crystalline, water-soluble, slightly sweet solid, C 5 H 1 0 O 5 , a pentose sugar obtained by the hydrolysis of RNA.
deoxyribose: any of certain carbohydrates derived from ribose by the replacement of a hydroxyl group with a hydrogen atom.
uracil: Biochemistry. a pyrimidine base, C 4 H 4 N 2 O 2 , that is one of the fundamental components of RNA, in which it forms base pairs with adenine. Symbol:  U.
thymine: a pyrimidine base, C 5 H 6 N 2 O 2 , that is one of the principal components of DNA, in which it is paired with adenine. Symbol:  T.
clock: an instrument for measuring and recording time, especially by mechanical means, usually with hands or changing numbers to indicate the hour and minute: not designed to be worn or carried about.
sundial: an instrument that indicates the time of day by means of the position, on a graduated plate or surface, of the shadow of the gnomon as it is cast by the sun.
laity: the body of religious worshipers, as distinguished from the clergy.
gifted: having great special talent or ability: the debut of a gifted artist.
agility: the power of moving quickly and easily; nimbleness: exercises demanding agility.
stamina: strength of physical constitution; power to endure disease, fatigue, privation, etc.
participant: a person or group that participates; partaker.
commend: to present, mention, or praise as worthy of confidence, notice, kindness, etc.; recommend: to commend a friend to another; to commend an applicant for employment.
speculate: to engage in thought or reflection; meditate (often followed by on, upon, or a clause).
distortion: an act or instance of distorting.
duplicity: deceitfulness in speech or conduct, as by speaking or acting in two different ways to different people concerning the same matter; double-dealing. Synonyms: deceit, deception, dissimulation, fraud, guile, hypocrisy, trickery.
pretense: pretending or feigning; make-believe: My sleepiness was all pretense.
wronged: treated unfairly or unjustly: the wronged party in the dispute.
crook: a bent or curved implement, piece, appendage, etc.; hook.
basket: a container made of twigs, rushes, thin strips of wood, or other flexible material woven together.
knitted: made by knitting, as a cloth article: a knitted bedspread.
cow: the mature female of a bovine animal, especially of the genus Bos.
luxury: a material object, service, etc., conducive to sumptuous living, usually a delicacy, elegance, or refinement of living rather than a necessity: Gold cufflinks were a luxury not allowed for in his budget.
transparency: Also, transparence. the quality or state of being transparent.
waiting: a period of waiting; pause, interval, or delay.
anteroom: a room that admits to a larger room.
inelastic: not elastic; lacking flexibility or resilience; unyielding.
site: the position or location of a town, building, etc., especially as to its environment: the site of our summer cabin.
antigen: Immunology. any substance that can stimulate the production of antibodies and combine specifically with them.
pepsin: an enzyme, produced in the stomach, that in the presence of hydrochloric acid splits proteins into proteoses and peptones.
digestion: the process in the alimentary canal by which food is broken up physically, as by the action of the teeth, and chemically, as by the action of enzymes, and converted into a substance suitable for absorption and assimilation into the body.
corneous: consisting of a horny substance; horny.
encase: to enclose in or as in a case: We encased the ancient vase in glass to preserve it.
leathery: like leather in appearance or texture; tough and flexible.
sore: physically painful or sensitive, as a wound, hurt, or diseased part: a sore arm.
sprain: to overstrain or wrench (the ligaments of an ankle, wrist, or other joint) so as to injure without fracture or dislocation.
jawbone: a bone of either jaw; a maxilla or mandible.
bonnet: a hat, usually tying under the chin and often framing the face, formerly much worn by women but now worn mostly by children.
glazed: having a surface covered with a glaze; lustrous; smooth; glassy.
revetment: a facing of masonry or the like, especially for protecting an embankment.
judah: the fourth son of Jacob and Leah. Gen. 29:35.
ki: the Sumerian goddess personifying earth: the counterpart of the Akkadian Aruru.
ketch: a sailing vessel rigged fore and aft on two masts, the larger, forward one being the mainmast and the after one, stepped forward of the rudderpost, being the mizzen or jigger.
topsail: a sail, or either of a pair of sails, set immediately above the lowermost sail of a mast and supported by a topmast.
yawl: a ship's small boat, rowed by a crew of four or six.
inlet: an indentation of a shoreline, usually long and narrow; small bay or arm.
cetus: the Whale, a constellation lying above the equator, containing the variable star Mira.
monster: a legendary animal combining features of animal and human form or having the forms of various animals in combination, as a centaur, griffin, or sphinx.
hence: as an inference from this fact; for this reason; therefore: The eggs were very fresh and hence satisfactory.
cetology: the branch of zoology dealing with whales and dolphins.
dolphin: any of several chiefly marine, cetacean mammals of the family Delphinidae, having a fishlike body, numerous teeth, and the front of the head elongated into a beaklike projection.
porpoise: any of several small, gregarious cetaceans of the genus Phocoena, usually blackish above and paler beneath, and having a blunt, rounded snout, especially the common porpoise, P. phocoena, of both the North Atlantic and Pacific.
flipper: a broad, flat limb, as of a seal or whale, especially adapted for swimming.
halberd: a shafted weapon with an axlike cutting blade, beak, and apical spike, used especially in the 15th and 16th centuries.
grateful: warmly or deeply appreciative of kindness or benefits received; thankful: I am grateful to you for your help.
defective: having a defect or flaw; faulty; imperfect: a defective machine.
mainmast: the second mast from forward in any ship having two or more masts, except for a yawl, ketch, or dandy.
scaffold: a temporary structure for holding workers and materials during the erection, repair, or decoration of a building.
visitor: a person who visits, as for reasons of friendship, business, duty, travel, or the like.
solace: comfort in sorrow, misfortune, or trouble; alleviation of distress or discomfort.
beijing: a city in and the capital of the People's Republic of China, in the NE part, in central Hebei province: traditional capital of China.
mandarin: (in the Chinese Empire) a member of any of the nine ranks of public officials, each distinguished by a particular kind of button worn on the cap.
sample: a small part of anything or one of a number, intended to show the quality, style, or nature of the whole; specimen.
compute: to determine by calculation; reckon; calculate: to compute the period of Jupiter's revolution.
loom: a hand-operated or power-driven apparatus for weaving fabrics, containing harnesses, lay, reed, shuttles, treadles, etc.
dialect: Linguistics. a variety of a language that is distinguished from other varieties of the same language by features of phonology, grammar, and vocabulary, and by its use by a group of speakers who are set off from others geographically or socially.
fatuous: foolish or inane, especially in an unconscious, complacent manner; silly.
regent: a person who exercises the ruling power in a kingdom during the minority, absence, or disability of the sovereign.
impute: to attribute or ascribe: The children imputed magical powers to the old woman.
evaporation: the act or process of evaporating.
retort: to reply to, usually in a sharp or retaliatory way; reply in kind to.
cleaning: an act or instance of making clean: Give the house a good cleaning.
nephew: a son of one's brother or sister.
maybe: perhaps; possibly: Maybe I'll go too.
disaster: a calamitous event, especially one occurring suddenly and causing great loss of life, damage, or hardship, as a flood, airplane crash, or business failure.
ruinous: bringing or tending to bring ruin; destructive; disastrous: a ruinous war.
unnecessary: not necessary or essential; needless; unessential.
angel: one of a class of spiritual beings; a celestial attendant of God. In medieval angelology, angels constituted the lowest of the nine celestial orders (seraphim, cherubim, thrones, dominations or dominions, virtues, powers, principalities or princedoms, archangels, and angels).
expertise: expert skill or knowledge; expertness; know-how: business expertise.
judo: a method of defending oneself or fighting without the use of weapons, based on jujitsu but differing from it in banning dangerous throws and blows and stressing the athletic or sport element.
signified: the thing or concept denoted by a sign.
donate: to present as a gift, grant, or contribution; make a donation of, as to a fund or cause: to donate used clothes to the Salvation Army.
transitory: not lasting, enduring, permanent, or eternal.
flue: a passage or duct for smoke in a chimney.
outgrowth: a natural development, product, or result: to consider truancy an outgrowth of parental neglect.
subterranean: existing, situated, or operating below the surface of the earth; underground.
bittersweet: both bitter and sweet to the taste: bittersweet chocolate.
mild: amiably gentle or temperate in feeling or behavior toward others.
herbaceous: of, relating to, or characteristic of an herb; herblike.
solanaceous: belonging to the Solanaceae, the nightshade family of plants.
leek: a plant, Allium ampeloprasum, of the amaryllis family, allied to the onion, having a cylindrical bulb and leaves used in cookery.
shallot: a plant, Allium cepa aggregatum (or A. ascalonicum), related to the onion, having a divided bulb used for flavoring in cookery.
garlic: a hardy plant, Allium sativum, of the amaryllis family whose strongly, pungent bulb is used in cookery and medicine.
chive: a small bulbous plant, Allium schoenoprasum, related to the leek and onion, having long, slender leaves that are used as a seasoning.
brassica: any plant belonging to the genus Brassica, of the mustard family, including many economically important vegetables, as cabbage, kale, broccoli, cauliflower, turnip, and mustard.
botrytis: any imperfect fungus of the genus Botrytis, having the conidia in grapelike bunches: a major cause of plant disease.
oxygenate: to treat, combine, or enrich with oxygen: to oxygenate the blood.
miter: the official headdress of a bishop in the Western Church, in its modern form a tall cap with a top deeply cleft crosswise, the outline of the front and back resembling that of a pointed arch.
halting: faltering or hesitating, especially in speech.
centimeter: one 100th of a meter, equivalent to 0.3937 inch. Abbreviation:  cm, cm.
deduct: to take away, as from a sum or amount: Once you deduct your expenses, there is nothing left.
enroll: to write the name of (a person) in a roll or register; place upon a list; register: It took two days to enroll the new students.
plaid: any fabric woven of differently colored yarns in a crossbarred pattern.
retard: to make slow; delay the development or progress of (an action, process, etc.); hinder or impede.
magnify: to increase the apparent size of, as a lens does.
magician: an entertainer who is skilled in producing illusion by sleight of hand, deceptive devices, etc.; conjurer.
conjurer: a person who conjures spirits or practices magic; magician.
diviner: a person who divines; soothsayer; prophet.
marten: any of several slender, chiefly arboreal carnivores of the genus Martes, of northern forests, having a long, glossy coat and bushy tail.
filth: offensive or disgusting dirt or refuse; foul matter: the filth dumped into our rivers.
correspond: to be in agreement or conformity (often followed by with or to): His actions do not correspond with his words.
abuse: to use wrongly or improperly; misuse: to abuse one's authority.
altruistic: unselfishly concerned for or devoted to the welfare of others (opposed to egoistic).
meditate: to engage in thought or contemplation; reflect.
appreciative: feeling or showing appreciation: an appreciative audience at the concert.
paradise: heaven, as the final abode of the righteous.
comedy: a play, movie, etc., of light and humorous character with a happy or cheerful ending; a dramatic work in which the central motif is the triumph over adverse circumstance, resulting in a successful or happy conclusion.
valid: sound; just; well-founded: a valid reason.
trim: to put into a neat or orderly condition by clipping, paring, pruning, etc.: to trim a hedge.
cart: a heavy two-wheeled vehicle, commonly without springs, drawn by mules, oxen, or the like, used for the conveyance of heavy goods.
holocaust: a great or complete devastation or destruction, especially by fire.
subsistence: the state or fact of subsisting.
seriously: in a serious manner: He shook his head seriously.
rigor: strictness, severity, or harshness, as in dealing with people.
lap: the front part of the human body from the waist to the knees when in a sitting position.
imbricate: overlapping in sequence, as tiles or shingles on a roof.
scleroprotein: protein that is fibrous and insoluble in water, serving a protective or supportive function in the body.
albuminoid: any of a class of simple proteins, as keratin, gelatin, or collagen, that are insoluble in all neutral solvents; scleroprotein.
pupa: an insect in the nonfeeding, usually immobile, transformation stage between the larva and the imago.
entomology: the branch of zoology dealing with insects.
immature: not mature, ripe, developed, perfected, etc.
lepidoptera: the order comprising the lepidopterous insects.
crepuscular: of, relating to, or resembling twilight; dim; indistinct.
nocturnal: of or relating to the night (opposed to diurnal).
dulce: a female given name: from the Latin word meaning “sweet.”.
et: a simple past tense of eat.
decorum: dignified propriety of behavior, speech, dress, etc.
patria: dulce et decorum est pro patria mori
fluff: light, downy particles, as of cotton.
sac: a baglike structure in an animal, plant, or fungus, as one containing fluid.
pad: a cushionlike mass of soft material used for comfort, protection, or stuffing.
elf: (in folklore) one of a class of preternatural beings, especially from mountainous regions, with magical powers, given to capricious and often mischievous interference in human affairs, and usually imagined to be a diminutive being in human form; sprite; fairy.
counsel: advice; opinion or instruction given in directing the judgment or conduct of another.
laughing: that laughs or is given to laughter: a laughing child.
fun: something that provides mirth or amusement: A picnic would be fun.
vocational: of, relating to, or connected with a vocation or occupation: a vocational aptitude.
lessee: a person, group, etc., to whom a lease is granted.
stratagem: a plan, scheme, or trick for surprising or deceiving an enemy.
fugitive: a person who is fleeing, from prosecution, intolerable circumstances, etc.; a runaway: a fugitive from justice; a fugitive from a dictatorial regime.
incidental: happening or likely to happen in an unplanned or subordinate conjunction with something else.
ecclesiastic: a member of the clergy or other person in religious orders.
dignitary: a person who holds a high rank or office, as in the government or church.
churchly: of or appropriate for the church or a church; ecclesiastical: churchly vestments.
clerical: of, pertaining to, appropriate for, or assigned to an office clerk or clerks: a clerical job.
secular: of or relating to worldly things or to things that are not regarded as religious, spiritual, or sacred; temporal: secular interests.
dictatorship: a country, government, or the form of government in which absolute power is exercised by a dictator.
quicken: to make more rapid; accelerate; hasten: She quickened her pace.
mighty: having, characterized by, or showing superior power or strength: mighty rulers.
swindle: to cheat (a person, business, etc.) out of money or other assets.
irrationality: the quality or condition of being irrational.
solomon: fl. 10th century b.c., king of Israel (son of David).
partiality: the state or character of being partial.
bite: to cut, wound, or tear with the teeth: She bit the apple greedily. The lion bit his trainer.
install: to place in position or connect for service or use: to install a heating system; to install software on a computer.
abridge: to shorten by omissions while retaining the basic contents: to abridge a reference book.
duchy: the territory ruled by a duke or duchess.
advertisement: a paid announcement, as of goods for sale, in newspapers or magazines, on radio or television, etc.
thorny: abounding in or characterized by thorns; spiny; prickly.
repent: to feel sorry, self-reproachful, or contrite for past conduct; regret or be conscience-stricken about a past action, attitude, etc. (often followed by of): He repented after his thoughtless act.
pomelo: the very large, yellow or orange citrus fruit of a tree, Citrus maxima, of southeastern Asia.
funeral: the ceremonies for a dead person prior to burial or cremation; obsequies.
kilogauss: a unit of magnetic induction, equal to 1000 gauss. Abbreviation:  kG.
castrate: to remove the testes of; emasculate; geld.
mar: to damage or spoil to a certain extent; render less perfect, attractive, useful, etc.; impair or spoil: That billboard mars the view. The holiday was marred by bad weather.
disfigure: to mar the appearance or beauty of; deform; deface: Our old towns are increasingly disfigured by tasteless new buildings.
pregnancy: the state, condition, or quality of being pregnant.
sailor: a person whose occupation is sailing or navigation; mariner.
emerge: to come forth into view or notice, as from concealment or obscurity: a ghost emerging from the grave; a ship emerging from the fog.
insist: to be emphatic, firm, or resolute on some matter of desire, demand, intention, etc.: He insists on checking every shipment.
des: used in French names as a contraction of de and the article les: François des Adrets.
knuckle: a joint of a finger, especially one of the articulations of a metacarpal with a phalanx.
amicable: characterized by or showing goodwill; friendly; peaceable: an amicable settlement.
aloof: at a distance, especially in feeling or interest; apart: They always stood aloof from their classmates.
longitude: Geography. angular distance east or west on the earth's surface, measured by the angle contained between the meridian of a particular place and some prime meridian, as that of Greenwich, England, and expressed either in degrees or by some corresponding difference in time.
bore: to weary by dullness, tedious repetition, unwelcome attentions, etc.: The long speech bored me.
spirited: having or showing mettle, courage, vigor, liveliness, etc.: a spirited defense of poetry.
armament: the arms and equipment with which a military unit or military apparatus is supplied.
isolate: to set or place apart; detach or separate so as to be alone.
inveterate: settled or confirmed in a habit, practice, feeling, or the like: an inveterate gambler.
stratum: a layer of material, naturally or artificially formed, often one of a number of parallel layers one upon another: a stratum of ancient foundations.
unwholesome: not wholesome; unhealthful; deleterious to health or physical or moral well-being: unwholesome food; unwholesome activities.
shaded: noting or pertaining to an ornamented type in which a thin white line appears along one edge of each of the main strokes of a character.
apposition: the act of placing together or bringing into proximity; juxtaposition.
gear: one of several possible arrangements of such parts in a mechanism, as an automobile transmission, for affording different relations of torque and speed between the driving and the driven machinery, or for permitting the driven machinery to run in either direction: first gear; reverse gear.
presumptuous: full of, characterized by, or showing presumption or readiness to presume in conduct or thought, as by saying or doing something without right or permission.
inflammation: Pathology. redness, swelling, pain, tenderness, heat, and disturbed function of an area of the body, especially as a reaction of tissues to injurious agents.
mow: to cut down (grass, grain, etc.) with a scythe or a machine.
martini: a cocktail made with gin or vodka and dry vermouth, usually served with a green olive or a twist of lemon peel.
dig: to break up, turn over, or remove earth, sand, etc., as with a shovel, spade, bulldozer, or claw; make an excavation.
irrigate: to supply (land) with water by artificial means, as by diverting streams, flooding, or spraying.
asian: of, belonging to, or characteristic of Asia or its inhabitants.
panther: the cougar or puma, Felis concolor.
mane: the long hair growing on the back of or around the neck and neighboring parts of some animals, as the horse or lion.
howl: to utter a loud, prolonged, mournful cry, as that of a dog or wolf.
gallinaceous: pertaining to or resembling the domestic fowls.
saudi: a native or inhabitant of Saudi Arabia.
mesopotamia: an ancient region in W Asia between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers: now part of Iraq.
baghdad: a city in and the capital of Iraq, in the central part, on the Tigris.
syria: Official name Syrian Arab Republic. a republic in SW Asia at the E end of the Mediterranean. 71,227 sq. mi. (184,478 sq. km). Capital:  Damascus.
persian: of or relating to ancient and recent Persia (now Iran), its people, or their language.
ecology: the branch of biology dealing with the relations and interactions between organisms and their environment, including other organisms.
racial: of or relating to the social construct of race: racial diversity; racial stereotypes.
ruling: an authoritative decision, as one by a judge on a debated point of law.
publish: to issue (printed or otherwise reproduced textual or graphic material, computer software, etc.) for sale or distribution to the public.
overflow: to flow or run over, as rivers or water: After the thaw, the river overflows and causes great damage.
arbitrator: a person chosen to decide a dispute or settle differences, especially one formally empowered to examine the facts and decide the issue.
judicious: using or showing judgment as to action or practical expediency; discreet, prudent, or politic: judicious use of one's money.
sagacious: having or showing acute mental discernment and keen practical sense; shrewd: a sagacious lawyer.
discreet: judicious in one's conduct or speech, especially with regard to respecting privacy or maintaining silence about something of a delicate nature; prudent; circumspect.
circumspect: watchful and discreet; cautious; prudent: circumspect behavior.
detritus: rock in small particles or other material worn or broken away from a mass, as by the action of water or glacial ice.
changeable: liable to change or to be changed; variable.
orthography: the art of writing words with the proper letters, according to accepted usage; correct spelling.
creditable: bringing or deserving credit, honor, reputation, or esteem.
rampart: In rampart, Woody Harrelson plays a corrupt, violent LAPD officer.
walled: having walls (sometimes used in combination): a high-walled prison.
repudiate: to reject as having no authority or binding force: to repudiate a claim.
perch: a pole or rod, usually horizontal, serving as a roost for birds.
chiton: Also called sea cradle. a mollusk of the class Amphineura, having a mantle covered with calcareous plates, found adhering to rocks.
snail: any mollusk of the class Gastropoda, having a spirally coiled shell and a ventral muscular foot on which it slowly glides about.
squid: any of several ten-armed cephalopods, as of the genera Loligo and Ommastrephes, having a slender body and a pair of rounded or triangular caudal fins and varying in length from 4–6 inches (10–15 cm) to 60–80 feet (18–24 meters).
octopus: any octopod of the genus Octopus, having a soft, oval body and eight sucker-bearing arms, living mostly at the bottom of the sea.
quahog: an edible clam, Venus (Mercenaria) mercenaria, inhabiting waters along the Atlantic coast, having a relatively thick shell.
pecten: Lima, a near ally of pecten, swims with the edges of the valves perpendicular.
fluted: fine, clear, and mellow; flutelike: fluted notes.
freshwater: of or living in water that is fresh or not salt: freshwater fish.
creeps: Veterinary Pathology. a disease of the bones in sheep and cattle that causes pain in walking, resulting from a deficiency of phosphorus in the diet.
griddle: a frying pan with a handle and a slightly raised edge, for cooking pancakes, bacon, etc., over direct heat.
metamorphose: to change the form or nature of; transform.
suck: to draw into the mouth by producing a partial vacuum by action of the lips and tongue: to suck lemonade through a straw.
assimilate: to take in and incorporate as one's own; absorb: He assimilated many new experiences on his European trip.
protist: any of various one-celled organisms, classified in the kingdom Protista, that are either free-living or aggregated into simple colonies and that have diverse reproductive and nutritional modes, including the protozoans, eukaryotic algae, and slime molds: some classification schemes also include the fungi and the more primitive bacteria and blue-green algae or may distribute the organisms between the kingdoms Plantae and Animalia according to dominant characteristics.
unicellular: having or consisting of a single cell.
cilia: Biology. minute hairlike organelles, identical in structure to flagella, that line the surfaces of certain cells and beat in rhythmic waves, providing locomotion to ciliate protozoans and moving liquids along internal epithelial tissue in animals.
organelle: Cell Biology. a specialized part of a cell having some specific function; a cell organ.
cytosol: the water-soluble components of cell cytoplasm, constituting the fluid portion that remains after removal of the organelles and other intracellular structures.
cytoskeleton: a shifting lattice arrangement of structural and contractile components distributed throughout the cell cytoplasm, composed of microtubules, microfilaments, and larger filaments, functioning as a structural support and transport mechanism.
spore: Biology. a walled, single- to many-celled, reproductive body of an organism, capable of giving rise to a new individual either directly or indirectly.
assyria: an ancient empire in SW Asia: greatest extent from about 750 to 612 b.c. Capital:  Nineveh.
babylonia: an ancient empire in SW Asia, in the lower Euphrates valley: its greatest period was 2800–1750 b.c. Capital:  Babylon.
cuneiform: having the form of a wedge; wedge-shaped.
sagacity: acuteness of mental discernment and soundness of judgment.
tiamat: an Akkadian goddess, the consort of Apsu and mother of the gods.
babylonian: of or relating to Babylon or Babylonia.
sumerian: of or relating to Sumer, its people, or their language.
credulous: willing to believe or trust too readily, especially without proper or adequate evidence; gullible.
differentiate: to form or mark differently from other such things; distinguish.
excrete: to separate and eliminate from an organic body; separate and expel from the blood or tissues, as waste or harmful matter.
oval: having the general form, shape, or outline of an egg; egg-shaped.
antiquated: continued from, resembling, or adhering to the past; old-fashioned: antiquated attitudes.
puff: a short, quick blast, as of wind or breath.
custard: a dessert made of eggs, sugar, and milk, either baked, boiled, or frozen.
null: without value, effect, consequence, or significance.
abolish: to do away with; put an end to; annul; make void: to abolish slavery.
abhorrence: a feeling of extreme repugnance or aversion; utter loathing; abomination.
stubborn: unreasonably obstinate; obstinately unmoving: a stubborn child.
intolerance: lack of tolerance; unwillingness or refusal to tolerate or respect opinions or beliefs contrary to one's own.
creed: any system, doctrine, or formula of religious belief, as of a denomination.
distasteful: unpleasant, offensive, or causing dislike: a distasteful chore.
temperate: moderate or self-restrained; not extreme in opinion, statement, etc.: a temperate response to an insulting challenge.
prey: an animal hunted or seized for food, especially by a carnivorous animal.
germanium: a scarce, metallic, grayish-white element, normally tetravalent, used chiefly in transistors. Symbol:  Ge; atomic weight:  72.59; atomic number:  32; specific gravity:  5.36 at 20°C.
knotty: having knots; full of knots: a knotty piece of wood.
tinfoil: tin, or an alloy of tin and lead, in the form of a thin sheet, much used as a wrapping for drugs, foods, tobacco, etc.
recruit: a newly enlisted or drafted member of the armed forces.
favored: regarded or treated with preference or partiality: Her beauty made her the favored child.
preach: to proclaim or make known by sermon (the gospel, good tidings, etc.).
gospel: the teachings of Jesus and the apostles; the Christian revelation.
vested: held completely, permanently, and inalienably: vested rights.
enlist: to enroll, usually voluntarily, for military service: He decided to enlist in the Marines.
cadet: a student in a national service academy or private military school or on a training ship.
unerring: not erring; not going astray or missing the mark: The captain set an unerring course for home.
clatter: to make a loud, rattling sound, as that produced by hard objects striking rapidly one against the other: The shutters clattered in the wind.
disuse: discontinuance of use or practice: Traditional customs are falling into disuse.
downhill: down the slope of a hill; downward.
career: an occupation or profession, especially one requiring special training, followed as one's lifework: He sought a career as a lawyer.
miserable: wretchedly unhappy, uneasy, or uncomfortable: miserable victims of war.
wretched: very unfortunate in condition or circumstances; miserable; pitiable.
why: for what? for what reason, cause, or purpose?: Why did you behave so badly?
sulk: to remain silent or hold oneself aloof in a sullen, ill-humored, or offended mood: Promise me that you won't sulk if I want to leave the party early.
persia: Also called Persian Empire. an ancient empire located in W and SW Asia: at its height it extended from Egypt and the Aegean to India; conquered by Alexander the Great 334–331 b.c.
biblical: of or in the Bible: a Biblical name.
attic: the part of a building, especially of a house, directly under a roof; garret.
julius: a male given name: a Roman family name.
malt: germinated grain, usually barley, used in brewing and distilling.
causality: the relation of cause and effect: The result is the same, however differently the causality is interpreted.
evaluate: to determine or set the value or amount of; appraise: to evaluate property.
expedient: tending to promote some proposed or desired object; fit or suitable for the purpose; proper under the circumstances: It is expedient that you go.
revise: to amend or alter: to revise one's opinion.
ideology: the body of doctrine, myth, belief, etc., that guides an individual, social movement, institution, class, or large group.
imbue: to impregnate or inspire, as with feelings, opinions, etc.: The new political leader was imbued with the teachings of Mahatma Gandhi.
partisan: an adherent or supporter of a person, group, party, or cause, especially a person who shows a biased, emotional allegiance.
pitiful: evoking or deserving pity: a pitiful fate.
pitiable: evoking or deserving pity; lamentable: pitiable, homeless children.
celebrate: to observe (a day) or commemorate (an event) with ceremonies or festivities: to celebrate Christmas; to celebrate the success of a new play.
gape: to stare with open mouth, as in wonder.
muslim: of or relating to the religion, law, or civilization of Islam.
shrine: a building or other shelter, often of a stately or sumptuous character, enclosing the remains or relics of a saint or other holy person and forming an object of religious veneration and pilgrimage.
diurnal: of or relating to a day or each day; daily.
however: nevertheless; yet; on the other hand; in spite of that: We have not yet won; however, we shall keep trying.
whatsoever: (an intensive form of whatever): whatsoever it be; in any place whatsoever.
coeur: Jacques. ?1395–1456, French merchant; councillor and court banker to Charles VII of France
kalispel: a Salishan language used by the Flathead Indians of Montana and by some neighboring tribes in Idaho and the western part of Washington.
columbia: a river in SW Canada and the NW United States, flowing S and W from SE British Columbia through Washington along the boundary between Washington and Oregon and into the Pacific. 1214 miles (1955 km) long.
pierre: a city in and the capital of South Dakota, in the central part, on the Missouri River.
milo: a grain sorghum having white, yellow, or pinkish seeds, grown chiefly in Africa, Asia, and the U.S.
effectual: producing or capable of producing an intended effect; adequate.
malformation: faulty or anomalous formation or structure, especially in a living body: malformation of the teeth.
emendation: a correction or change, as of a text.
denture: an artificial replacement of one or several of the teeth (partial denture) or all of the teeth (full denture) of either or both jaws; dental prosthesis.
web: something formed by or as if by weaving or interweaving.
gabonese: of or relating to Gabon or its inhabitants.
libreville: a port in and the capital of Gabon, in the W part, on the Gulf of Guinea.
insolent: boldly rude or disrespectful; contemptuously impertinent; insulting: an insolent reply.
scornful: full of scorn; derisive; contemptuous: He smiled in a scornful way.
disrespectful: characterized by, having, or showing disrespect; lacking courtesy or esteem: a disrespectful remark about teachers.
distended: increased, as in size, volume, etc.; expanded; dilated: the distended nostrils of the terrified horse.
disobedient: neglecting or refusing to obey; not submitting; refractory.
notation: a system of graphic symbols for a specialized use, other than ordinary writing: musical notation.
evangelist: a Protestant minister or layperson who serves as an itinerant or special preacher, especially a revivalist.
galilee: a porch or vestibule, often on the ground floor of a tower, at the entrance of some English churches.
summon: to call upon to do something specified.
apostle: any of the early followers of Jesus who carried the Christian message into the world.
leah: the first wife of Jacob. Gen. 29:23–26.
matte: having a dull or lusterless surface: matte paint; a matte complexion; a photograph with a matte finish.
prone: having a natural inclination or tendency to something; disposed; liable: to be prone to anger.
slander: defamation; calumny: rumors full of slander.
ghost: the soul of a dead person, a disembodied spirit imagined, usually as a vague, shadowy or evanescent form, as wandering among or haunting living persons.
specter: a visible incorporeal spirit, especially one of a terrifying nature; ghost; phantom; apparition.
wraith: an apparition of a living person supposed to portend his or her death.
ghostly: of, characteristic of, or resembling a ghost; phantasmal; spectral.
inseparable: incapable of being separated, parted, or disjoined: inseparable companions.
tungstate: a salt of any tungstic acid.
tabular: of, relating to, or arranged in a table or systematic arrangement by columns, rows, etc., as statistics.
bladed: having a blade or blades (often used in combination): a single-bladed leaf.
trioxide: an oxide containing three oxygen atoms, as As 2 O 3 .
pulverulent: consisting of dust or fine powder.
handled: fitted with or having a handle or handles, especially of a specified kind (often used in combination): a handled pot; a long-handled knife.
considerate: showing kindly awareness or regard for another's feelings, circumstances, etc.: a very considerate critic.
reputed: reported or supposed to be such: the reputed author of a book.
reject: to refuse to have, take, recognize, etc.: to reject the offer of a better job.
premeditated: done deliberately; planned in advance: a premeditated murder.
halfway: to half the distance; to midpoint: The rope reaches only halfway.
exceed: to go beyond in quantity, degree, rate, etc.: to exceed the speed limit.
practiced: skilled or expert; proficient through practice or experience: a practiced hand at politics.
annotation: a critical or explanatory note or body of notes added to a text.
intuition: direct perception of truth, fact, etc., independent of any reasoning process; immediate apprehension.
weed: a valueless plant growing wild, especially one that grows on cultivated ground to the exclusion or injury of the desired crop.
vendor: a person or agency that sells.
valise: a small piece of luggage that can be carried by hand, used to hold clothing, toilet articles, etc.; suitcase; traveling bag.
foreknowledge: knowledge of something before it exists or happens; prescience: Did you have any foreknowledge of the scheme?
foresight: care or provision for the future; provident care; prudence.
throb: to beat with increased force or rapidity, as the heart under the influence of emotion or excitement; palpitate.
convict: to prove or declare guilty of an offense, especially after a legal trial: to convict a prisoner of a felony.
cambridgeshire: a county in E England. 1316 sq. mi. (3410 sq. km).
anthropology: the science that deals with the origins, physical and cultural development, biological characteristics, and social customs and beliefs of humankind.
parliament: (usually initial capital letter) the legislature of Great Britain, historically the assembly of the three estates, now composed of Lords Spiritual and Lords Temporal, forming together the House of Lords, and representatives of the counties, cities, boroughs, and universities, forming the House of Commons.
stupefy: to put into a state of little or no sensibility; benumb the faculties of; put into a stupor.
exalt: to raise in rank, honor, power, character, quality, etc.; elevate: He was exalted to the position of president.
lucky: having or marked by good luck; fortunate: That was my lucky day.
sawatch: a mountain range in central Colorado: part of the Rocky Mountains. Highest peak, Mount Elbert, 14,431 feet (4400 meters).
neural: of or relating to a nerve or the nervous system.
persistence: the act or fact of persisting.
bronchus: either of the two main branches of the trachea.
untidy: not tidy or neat; slovenly; disordered: an untidy room; an untidy person.
slovenly: untidy or unclean in appearance or habits.
waxy: resembling wax in appearance or characteristics: His face had a waxy shine.
misdirect: to direct or address wrongly or incorrectly: to misdirect a person; to misdirect a letter.
debatable: open to question; in dispute; doubtful: Whether or not he is qualified for the job is debatable.
arthritis: acute or chronic inflammation of a joint, often accompanied by pain and structural changes and having diverse causes, as infection, crystal deposition, or injury.
mystic: involving or characterized by esoteric, otherworldly, or symbolic practices or content, as certain religious ceremonies and art; spiritually significant; ethereal.
portuguese: of, relating to, or characteristic of Portugal, its inhabitants, or their language.
monazite: a reddish- or yellowish-brown mineral, a phosphate of cerium and lanthanum, (Ce,La)PO 4 : the principal ore of thorium.
banal: devoid of freshness or originality; hackneyed; trite: a banal and sophomoric treatment of courage on the frontier.
formulate: to express in precise form; state definitely or systematically: He finds it extremely difficult to formulate his new theory.
effortless: requiring or involving no effort; displaying no signs of effort; easy: an effortless writing style.
ax: an instrument with a bladed head on a handle or helve, used for hewing, cleaving, chopping, etc.
chisel: a wedgelike tool with a cutting edge at the end of the blade, often made of steel, used for cutting or shaping wood, stone, etc.
carolus: any of various coins issued under monarchs named Charles, especially the broad of Charles I of England.
birdlike: having the appearance or characteristics of a bird, as quickness, lightness, fragility, etc.: birdlike gestures.
reptilian: belonging or pertaining to the Reptilia.
genital: of, relating to, or noting reproduction.
sarah: the wife of Abraham and mother of Isaac. Gen. 17:15–22.
birthright: any right or privilege to which a person is entitled by birth: Democracy maintains that freedom is a birthright.
patriarch: the male head of a family or tribal line.
lyric: (of poetry) having the form and musical quality of a song, and especially the character of a songlike outpouring of the poet's own thoughts and feelings, as distinguished from epic and dramatic poetry.
song: a short metrical composition intended or adapted for singing, especially one in rhymed stanzas; a lyric; a ballad.
array: to place in proper or desired order; marshal: Napoleon arrayed his troops for battle.
gaiety: the state of being gay or cheerful; gay spirits.
jollity: jolly or merry mood, condition, or activity; gaiety.
improper: not proper; not strictly belonging, applicable, correct, etc.; erroneous: He drew improper conclusions from the scant evidence.
assignable: capable of being specified: The word has no assignable meaning in our language.
allowable: that may be allowed; legitimate; permissible: an allowable tax deduction.
consign: to hand over or deliver formally or officially; commit (often followed by to).
venerate: to regard or treat with reverence; revere.
libel: Mayer also advises Gore to file a libel suit against the National Enquirer, which broke the story, and his accusers.
calumniate: to make false and malicious statements about; slander.
editorial: an article in a newspaper or other periodical or on a website presenting the opinion of the publisher, writer, or editor.
nautical: of or relating to sailors, ships, or navigation: nautical terms.
anchor: any of various devices dropped by a chain, cable, or rope to the bottom of a body of water for preventing or restricting the motion of a vessel or other floating object, typically having broad, hooklike arms that bury themselves in the bottom to provide a firm hold.
twisting: the practice of an insurance agent of tricking the holder of a life insurance policy into letting it lapse so that the insured will replace it with one of a company represented by the agent.
pioneer: a person who is among those who first enter or settle a region, thus opening it for occupation and development by others.
spinning: For the same reason a Hummer had cost a fortune: It comes with spinning hubcaps and stainless-steel grill guards.
portend: to indicate in advance; to foreshadow or presage, as an omen does: The street incident may portend a general uprising.
deject: to depress the spirits of; dispirit; dishearten: Such news dejects me.
dispirit: to deprive of spirit, hope, enthusiasm, etc.; depress; discourage; dishearten.
mastery: command or grasp, as of a subject: a mastery of Italian.
overpower: to overcome, master, or subdue by superior force: to overpower a maniac.
overwhelm: to overcome completely in mind or feeling: overwhelmed by remorse.
uncontrollable: incapable of being controlled or restrained: uncontrollable anger.
weeping: expressing grief, sorrow, or any overwhelming emotion by shedding tears: weeping multitudes.
dreadful: causing great dread, fear, or terror; terrible: a dreadful storm.
woke: a simple past tense of wake1 .
loathing: strong dislike or disgust; intense aversion.
nausea: sickness at the stomach, especially when accompanied by a loathing for food and an involuntary impulse to vomit.
mask: a covering for all or part of the face, worn to conceal one's identity.
tremble: to shake involuntarily with quick, short movements, as from fear, excitement, weakness, or cold; quake; quiver.
quiver: to shake with a slight but rapid motion; vibrate tremulously; tremble.
collide: to strike one another or one against the other with a forceful impact; come into violent contact; crash: The two cars collided with an ear-splitting crash.
contradict: to assert the contrary or opposite of; deny directly and categorically.
vexatious: causing vexation; troublesome; annoying: a vexatious situation.
coroner: an officer, as of a county or municipality, whose chief function is to investigate by inquest, as before a jury, any death not clearly resulting from natural causes.
calcine: to convert into calx by heating or burning.
dextrorotatory: turning to the right, as the rotation to the right of the plane of polarization of light in certain crystals and the like. Symbol: d-.
levorotatory: turning to the left, as the rotation to the left of the plane of polarization of light in certain crystals and compounds. Symbol: l-.
bold: not hesitating or fearful in the face of actual or possible danger or rebuff; courageous and daring: a bold hero.
mucilage: any of various, usually liquid, preparations of gum, glue, or the like, used as an adhesive.
cancer: Castro did not have cancer, he said, but his condition was nonetheless “terminal.”
regulus: (initial capital letter) Astronomy. a first magnitude star in the constellation Leo.
cauterize: to burn with a hot iron, electric current, fire, or a caustic, especially for curative purposes; treat with a cautery.
pulled: of or denoting meat that is cooked until the meat can easily be pulled off the bone, as in pulled pork.
hedgerow: a row of bushes or trees forming a hedge.
chitin: a nitrogen-containing polysaccharide, related chemically to cellulose, that forms a semitransparent horny substance and is a principal constituent of the exoskeleton, or outer covering, of insects, crustaceans, and arachnids.
crustacean: any chiefly aquatic arthropod of the class Crustacea, typically having the body covered with a hard shell or crust, including the lobsters, shrimps, crabs, barnacles, and wood lice.
myriapod: any arthropod of the group Myriapoda, having an elongated segmented body with numerous paired, jointed legs, formerly classified as a class comprising the centipedes and millipedes.
subdued: quiet; inhibited; repressed; controlled: After the argument he was much more subdued.
gaul: an ancient region in W Europe, including the modern areas of N Italy, France, Belgium, and the S Netherlands: consisted of two main divisions, one part S of the Alps (Cisalpine Gaul) and another part N of the Alps (Transalpine Gaul)
analogy: a similarity between like features of two things, on which a comparison may be based: the analogy between the heart and a pump.
printout: output produced by a printer, generally on continuous sheets of paper.
swerve: to turn aside abruptly in movement or direction; deviate suddenly from the straight or direct course.
province: an administrative division or unit of a country.
everest: Mount, a mountain in S Asia, on the boundary between Nepal and Tibet, in the Himalayas: the highest mountain in the world. 29,028 feet (8848 meters).
lamaism: the Buddhism of Tibet and Mongolia, a Mahayana form including non-Buddhist Indian elements as well as elements of the preexisting Bön shamanism.
pebble: a small, rounded stone, especially one worn smooth by the action of water.
immoderate: not moderate; exceeding just or reasonable limits; excessive; extreme.
drank: a simple past tense and past participle of drink.
cherish: to hold or treat as dear; feel love for: to cherish one's native land.
abominable: repugnantly hateful; detestable; loathsome: an abominable crime.
orthodox: of, relating to, or conforming to the approved form of any doctrine, philosophy, ideology, etc.
miniature: a representation or image of something on a small or reduced scale.
baseless: having no base; without foundation; groundless: a baseless claim.
derogatory: tending to lessen the merit or reputation of a person or thing; disparaging; depreciatory: a derogatory remark.
prevaricate: to speak falsely or misleadingly; deliberately misstate or create an incorrect impression; lie.
david: died c970 b.c., the second king of Israel, reigned c1010–c970, successor to Saul: slayer of the Philistine giant Goliath.
arabian: of or relating to Arabia or its inhabitants.
caliph: a spiritual leader of Islam, claiming succession from Muhammad.
ali: (ʿAlī ibn-abu-Talib"the Lion of God") a.d. c600–661, Arab caliph (cousin and son-in-law of Muhammad).
fatima: a.d. 606?–632, daughter of Muhammad and wife of Ali.
hasan: (al-Hasan) a.d. 624?–669? Arabian caliph: son of Ali and Fatima (brother of Hussein).
lancashire: a county in NW England. 1174 sq. mi. (3040 sq. km).
hungary: a republic in central Europe. 35,926 sq. mi. (93,050 sq. km). Capital:  Budapest.
mediator: a person who mediates, especially between parties at variance.
straightforward: going or directed straight ahead: a straightforward gaze.
wellborn: born of a good, noble, or highly esteemed family.
nun: a woman member of a religious order, especially one bound by vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
islam: the religious faith of Muslims, based on the words and religious system founded by the prophet Muhammad and taught by the Koran, the basic principle of which is absolute submission to a unique and personal god, Allah.
kabul: a city in and the capital of Afghanistan, in the NE part.
dhaka: a city in and the capital of Bangladesh, in the central part.
rawalpindi: a city in N Pakistan: former provisional capital.
constitutional: of or relating to the constitution of a state, organization, etc.
katmandu: a city in and the capital of Nepal, in the central part.
paisa: Also, pice. an aluminum coin and monetary unit, the 100th part of the rupee of India, Nepal, and Pakistan.
arminius: (Hermann) 17? b.c.–a.d. 21, Germanic hero who defeated Roman army a.d. 9.
foolish: resulting from or showing a lack of sense; ill-considered; unwise: a foolish action, a foolish speech.
creativity: the state or quality of being creative.
bail: property or money given as surety that a person released from custody will return at an appointed time.
tonality: For by this principle of tonality, melody and harmony as we know them became possible.
veer: to change direction or turn about or aside; shift, turn, or change from one course, position, inclination, etc., to another: The speaker kept veering from his main topic. The car veered off the road.
session: the sitting together of a court, council, legislature, or the like, for conference or the transaction of business: Congress is now in session.
vault: an arched structure, usually made of stones, concrete, or bricks, forming a ceiling or roof over a hall, room, sewer, or other wholly or partially enclosed construction.
woodwork: objects or parts made of wood.
stonework: any construction, as walls or the like, of stone; stone masonry.
progressive: favoring or advocating progress, change, improvement, or reform, as opposed to wishing to maintain things as they are, especially in political matters: a progressive mayor.
lightening: the descent of the uterus into the pelvic cavity, occurring toward the end of pregnancy, changing the contour of the abdomen and facilitating breathing by lessening pressure under the diaphragm.
memorial: something designed to preserve the memory of a person, event, etc., as a monument or a holiday.
testudo: (among the ancient Romans) a movable shelter with a strong and usually fireproof arched roof, used for protection of soldiers in siege operations.
dorsum: the back, as of the body.
venter: Cryptogastra: with the venter or belly covered or concealed.
belly: the front or under part of a vertebrate body from the breastbone to the pelvis, containing the abdominal viscera; the abdomen.
businessman: a man regularly employed in business, especially a white-collar worker, executive, or owner.
mississippi: a state in the S United States. 47,716 sq. mi. (123,585 sq. km). Capital:  Jackson.
parch: to make extremely, excessively, or completely dry, as heat, sun, and wind do.
headwaters: Sometimes, headwater. the upper tributaries of a river.
kagera: a river in equatorial Africa flowing into Lake Victoria from the west: the most remote headstream of the Nile. 430 miles (690 km) long.
scheming: given to making plans, especially sly and underhand ones; crafty.
artful: slyly crafty or cunning; deceitful; tricky: artful schemes.
crafty: skillful in underhand or evil schemes; cunning; deceitful; sly.
switzerland: a republic in central Europe. 15,944 sq. mi. (41,294 sq. km). Capital:  Bern.
austria: a republic in central Europe. 32,381 sq. mi. (83,865 sq. km). Capital:  Vienna.
slovenia: a republic in SE Europe: formerly part of Yugoslavia. 7819 sq. mi. (20,250 sq. km). Capital:  Ljubljana.
croatia: a republic in SE Europe: includes the historical regions of Dalmatia, Istria, and Slavonia; formerly a part of Yugoslavia. 21,835 sq. mi. (56,555 sq. km) Capital:  Zagreb.
blanc: a silver coin of France of the 14th–18th centuries, debased in later years.
strait: Often, straits. (used with a singular verb) a narrow passage of water connecting two large bodies of water.
palermo: a seaport in and the capital of Sicily, in the NW part.
nearby: close at hand; not far off; adjacent; neighboring: a nearby village.
corsica: an island in the Mediterranean, SE of and forming a department of France. 3367 sq. mi. (8720 sq. km). Capital:  Ajaccio.
exile: expulsion from one's native land by authoritative decree.
literal: in accordance with, involving, or being the primary or strict meaning of the word or words; not figurative or metaphorical: the literal meaning of a word.
modification: an act or instance of modifying.
concession: the act of conceding or yielding, as a right, a privilege, or a point or fact in an argument: He made no concession to caution.
unapproachable: not capable of being approached; remote; unreachable: an unapproachable spot; an unapproachable person.
bargain: an advantageous purchase, especially one acquired at less than the usual cost: The sale offered bargains galore.
ominous: portending evil or harm; foreboding; threatening; inauspicious: an ominous bank of dark clouds.
carping: characterized by fussy or petulant faultfinding; querulous: carping criticism.
uncivil: without good manners; unmannerly; rude; impolite; discourteous.
salesman: a man who sells goods, services, etc.
detach: to unfasten and separate; disengage; disunite.
dutch: of, relating to, or characteristic of the natives or inhabitants of the Netherlands or their country or language.
walcheren: an island in SW Netherlands: part of Zeeland province. 82 sq. mi. (212 sq. km).
netherlands: the, (used with a singular or plural verb) a kingdom in W Europe, bordering on the North Sea, Germany, and Belgium. 13,433 sq. mi. (34,790 sq. km). Capitals: Amsterdam and The Hague.
defecate: to void excrement from the bowels through the anus; have a bowel movement.
savage: fierce, ferocious, or cruel; untamed: savage beasts.
inhuman: lacking qualities of sympathy, pity, warmth, compassion, or the like; cruel; brutal: an inhuman master.
frankly: in a frank manner; freely; candidly; openly; plainly: He presented his arguments frankly and objectively.
disclosing: indicating or involving a substance used to reveal the presence of plaque on the teeth by staining the plaque.
disclosure: the act or an instance of disclosing; exposure; revelation.
adam: the name of the first man: husband of Eve and progenitor of the human race. Gen. 2:7; 5:1–5.
rightly: in accordance with truth or fact; correctly: to see rightly; to understand rightly.
plano: pertaining to eyeglasses that do not contain a curvature for correcting vision defects: plano sunglasses.
fastener: any of various devices for fastening.
martyr: a person who willingly suffers death rather than renounce his or her religion.
sri: a Hindu title of address prefixed to the name of a deity, holy person, etc.
erosion: the act or state of eroding; state of being eroded.
solicitous: anxious or concerned (usually followed by about, for, etc., or a clause): solicitous about a person's health.
mormon: the popular name given to a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
eponymous: giving one's name to a tribe, place, etc.: Romulus, the eponymous founder of Rome.
regenerate: to effect a complete moral reform in.
linter: linters, short cotton fibers that stick to seeds after a first ginning.
chip: a small, slender piece, as of wood, separated by chopping, cutting, or breaking.
sulfide: a compound of sulfur with a more electropositive element or, less often, a group.
cellophane: a transparent, paperlike product of viscose, impervious to moisture, germs, etc., used to wrap and package food, tobacco, etc.
spinneret: an organ or part by means of which a spider, insect larva, or the like spins a silky thread for its web or cocoon.
polyamide: a polymer in which the monomer units are linked together by the amide group –CONH–.
synthesize: to form (a material or abstract entity) by combining parts or elements (opposed to analyze): to synthesize a statement.
bristle: one of the short, stiff, coarse hairs of certain animals, especially hogs, used extensively in making brushes.
brush: an implement consisting of bristles, hair, or the like, set in or attached to a handle, used for painting, cleaning, polishing, grooming, etc.
mural: a large picture painted or affixed directly on a wall or ceiling.
lee: protective shelter: The lee of the rock gave us some protection against the storm.
dreg: dregs, the sediment of liquids; lees; grounds.
kid: Informal. a child or young person.
landfill: a low area of land that is built up from deposits of solid refuse in layers covered by soil.
feces: waste matter discharged from the intestines through the anus; excrement.
arizona: a state in SW United States. 113,909 sq. mi. (295,025 sq. km). Capital:  Phoenix.
metallocene: an organometallic coordination compound consisting of a metal bonded to one or two rings of cyclopentadiene.
counteract: to act in opposition to; frustrate by contrary action.
rid: to clear, disencumber, or free of something objectionable (usually followed by of): I want to rid the house of mice. In my opinion, you'd be wise to rid yourself of the smoking habit.
hunger: a compelling need or desire for food.
polyp: Qatar is just a little spit of land that looks like a polyp on edge of Saudi Arabia.
sarcodinian: belonging or pertaining to the protist phylum Sarcodina, comprising protozoa that move and capture food by forming pseudopodia.
scraping: the act of a person or thing that scrapes.
enumerate: to mention separately as if in counting; name one by one; specify, as in a list: Let me enumerate the many flaws in your hypothesis.
pulsate: to expand and contract rhythmically, as the heart; beat; throb.
exacting: rigid or severe in demands or requirements: an exacting teacher.
wan: of an unnatural or sickly pallor; pallid; lacking color: His wan face suddenly flushed.
drip: to let drops fall; shed drops: This faucet drips.
allay: to put (fear, doubt, suspicion, anger, etc.) to rest; calm; quiet.
thirst: a sensation of dryness in the mouth and throat caused by need of liquid.
lengthy: having or being of great length; very long: a lengthy journey.
afternoon: the time from noon until evening.
serf: a person in a condition of servitude, required to render services to a lord, commonly attached to the lord's land and transferred with it from one owner to another.
inundate: to flood; cover or overspread with water; deluge.
cattail: any tall, reedlike marsh plant of the genus Typha, especially T. latifolia, having long, sword-shaped leaves and dense, cylindrical clusters of minute brown flowers.
rush: to move, act, or progress with speed, impetuosity, or violence.
causative: acting as a cause; producing (often followed by of): a causative agency; an event causative of war.
diphtheria: a febrile, infectious disease caused by the bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and characterized by the formation of a false membrane in the air passages, especially the throat.
ricin: a white, poisonous, protein powder from the bean of the castor-oil plant.
venom: the poisonous fluid that some animals, as certain snakes and spiders, secrete and introduce into the bodies of their victims by biting, stinging, etc.
vaporize: to cause to change into vapor.
terrain: a tract of land, especially as considered with reference to its natural features, military advantages, etc.
discard: to cast aside or dispose of; get rid of: to discard an old hat.
litter: objects strewn or scattered about; scattered rubbish.
decapod: any crustacean of the order Decapoda, having five pairs of walking legs, including the crabs, lobsters, crayfish, prawns, and shrimps.
luke: an early Christian disciple and companion of Paul, a physician and probably a gentile: traditionally believed to be the author of the third Gospel and the Acts.
seclude: to place in or withdraw into solitude; remove from social contact and activity, etc.
ungovernable: impossible to govern, rule, or restrain; uncontrollable.
turbulent: being in a state of agitation or tumult; disturbed: turbulent feelings or emotions.
intractable: not easily controlled or directed; not docile or manageable; stubborn; obstinate: an intractable disposition.
lawless: contrary to or without regard for the law: lawless violence.
galvanize: to stimulate by or as if by a galvanic current.
galvanic: pertaining to or produced by galvanism; producing or caused by an electric current.
exit: a way or passage out: Please leave the theater by the nearest exit.
outflow: the act of flowing out: We need flood control to stem the river's outflow.
effusion: the act of effusing or pouring forth.
savannah: a seaport in E Georgia, near the mouth of the Savannah River.
daub: to cover or coat with soft, adhesive matter, as plaster or mud: to daub a canvas with paint; to daub stone walls with mud.
polymeric: of or relating to a polymer.
packaging: an act or instance of packing or forming packages: At the end of the production line is a machine for packaging.
aldehyde: any of a class of organic compounds containing the group −CHO, which yields acids when oxidized and alcohols when reduced.
ketone: any of a class of organic compounds containing a carbonyl group, CO, attached to two alkyl groups, as CH 3 COCH 3 or CH 3 COC 2 H 5 .
serum: the clear, pale-yellow liquid that separates from the clot in the coagulation of blood; blood serum.
placard: a paperboard sign or notice, as one posted in a public place or carried by a demonstrator or picketer.
posting: assignment to a post, command, or particular location, especially in a military or governmental capacity.
inhibit: to restrain, hinder, arrest, or check (an action, impulse, etc.).
antisepsis: destruction of the microorganisms that produce sepsis or septic disease.
carcinogen: any substance or agent that tends to produce a cancer.
matrix: something that constitutes the place or point from which something else originates, takes form, or develops: The Greco-Roman world was the matrix for Western civilization.
permeate: to pass into or through every part of: Bright sunshine permeated the room.
li: the solmization syllable used for the semitone between the sixth and seventh degrees of a scale.
sturgeon: any of various large fishes of the family Acipenseridae, inhabiting fresh and salt North Temperate waters, valued for their flesh and as a source of caviar and isinglass: A. brevirostrum, of the Atlantic coast, is endangered.
fruitful: producing good results; beneficial; profitable: fruitful investigations.
rotary: turning or capable of turning around on an axis, as a wheel.
wrecking: the act, work, or business of a wrecker.
massacre: the unnecessary, indiscriminate killing of a large number of human beings or animals, as in barbarous warfare or persecution or for revenge or plunder.
butcher: a retail or wholesale dealer in meat.
behead: to cut off the head of; kill or execute by decapitation.
guillotine: a device for beheading a person by means of a heavy blade that is dropped between two posts serving as guides: widely used during the French Revolution.
strangle: to kill by squeezing the throat in order to compress the windpipe and prevent the intake of air, as with the hands or a tightly drawn cord.
garrote: a method of capital punishment of Spanish origin in which an iron collar is tightened around a condemned person's neck until death occurs by strangulation or by injury to the spinal column at the base of the brain.
assassinate: to kill suddenly or secretively, especially a politically prominent person; murder premeditatedly and treacherously.
granulate: to form into granules or grains.
dashboard: (in an automobile or similar vehicle) a panel beneath the front window having various gauges and accessories for the use of the driver; instrument panel.
rhombus: an oblique-angled equilateral parallelogram; any equilateral parallelogram except a square.
arthur: Chester Alan, 1830–86, 21st president of the U.S. 1881–85.
vulcanize: to treat (rubber) with sulfur and heat, thereby imparting strength, greater elasticity, durability, etc.
magnificent: making a splendid appearance or show; of exceptional beauty, size, etc.: a magnificent cathedral; magnificent scenery.
splendor: brilliant or gorgeous appearance, coloring, etc.; magnificence: the splendor of the palace.
sublimity: the state or quality of being sublime.
harrisburg: a city in and the capital of Pennsylvania, in the S part, on the Susquehanna River.
maryland: a state in the E United States, on the Atlantic coast. 10,577 sq. mi. (27,395 sq. km). Capital:  Annapolis.
chesapeake: (italics) a U.S. frigate boarded in 1807 by the British, who removed part of its crew and impressed some members into British service: captured by the British in naval battle near Boston in 1813.
purify: to make pure; free from anything that debases, pollutes, adulterates, or contaminates: to purify metals.
cider: the juice pressed from apples (or formerly from some other fruit) used for drinking, either before fermentation (sweet cider) or after fermentation (hard cider) or for making applejack, vinegar, etc.
condiment: something used to give a special flavor to food, as mustard, ketchup, salt, or spices.
neutralization: the act, process, or an instance of neutralizing.
lichen: any complex organism of the group Lichenes, composed of a fungus in symbiotic union with an alga and having a greenish, gray, yellow, brown, or blackish thallus that grows in leaflike, crustlike, or branching forms on rocks, trees, etc.
kilogram: a unit of mass equal to 1000 grams: the basic unit of mass in the International System of Units (SI), equal to the mass of the international prototype of the kilogram, a platinum-iridium cylinder kept in Sèvres, France. Abbreviation:  kg.
accepter: a person or thing that accepts.
disarrange: to disturb the arrangement of; disorder; unsettle.
jewel: a cut and polished precious stone; gem.
velvet: a fabric of silk, nylon, acetate, rayon, etc., sometimes having a cotton backing, with a thick, soft pile formed of loops of the warp thread either cut at the outer end or left uncut.
forefoot: Zoology. one of the front feet of a quadruped, an insect, etc.
deck: the space between such a surface and the next such surface above: Our stateroom was on B deck.
dynamo: an electric generator, especially for direct current.
laban: the father of Leah and Rachel and the father-in-law of Jacob. Gen. 24:29; 29:16–30.
gwendolyn: a female given name: from a Welsh word meaning “white.”.
drachma: a cupronickel coin and monetary unit of modern Greece until the euro was adopted, equal to 100 lepta. Abbreviation:  dr., drch.
unsteady: not steady or firm; unstable; shaky: an unsteady hand.
positron: an elementary particle having the same mass and spin as an electron but having a positive charge equal in magnitude to that of the electron's negative charge; the antiparticle of the electron.
hadron: any elementary particle that is subject to the strong interaction. Hadrons are subdivided into baryons and mesons.
conservation: the act of conserving; prevention of injury, decay, waste, or loss; preservation: conservation of wildlife; conservation of human rights.
jutland: a peninsula comprising the continental portion of Denmark: naval battle between the British and German fleets was fought west of this peninsula 1916. 11,441 sq. mi. (29,630 sq. km).
copenhagen: a seaport in and the capital of Denmark, on the E coast of Zealand.
eulogy: a speech or writing in praise of a person or thing, especially a set oration in honor of a deceased person.
testimonial: a written declaration certifying to a person's character, conduct, or qualifications, or to the value, excellence, etc., of a thing; a letter or written statement of recommendation.
resume: to take up or go on with again after interruption; continue: to resume a journey.
feud: Also called blood feud. a bitter, continuous hostility, especially between two families, clans, etc., often lasting for many years or generations.
vitamin: any of a group of organic substances essential in small quantities to normal metabolism, found in minute amounts in natural foodstuffs or sometimes produced synthetically: deficiencies of vitamins produce specific disorders.
criticize: to censure or find fault with.
entice: to lead on by exciting hope or desire; allure; inveigle: They were enticed westward by dreams of gold.
seduce: to lead astray, as from duty, rectitude, or the like; corrupt.
margaret: a female given name: from a Greek word meaning “pearl.”.
widow: a woman who has lost her spouse by death and has not remarried.
earl: a British nobleman of a rank below that of marquis and above that of viscount: called count for a time after the Norman conquest. The wife of an earl is a countess.
peerage: the body of peers of a country or state.
ernest: a male given name: from an Old English word meaning “vigor, intent.”.
antarctic: of, at, or near the South Pole.
harry: to harass, annoy, or prove a nuisance to by or as if by repeated attacks; worry: He was harried by constant doubts.
barbara: a female given name: from a Greek word meaning “foreign, exotic.”.
