unconditional: not limited by conditions; absolute: an unconditional promise.
anatol: a male given name: from a Greek word meaning “sunrise.”.
emigrate: to leave one country or region to settle in another; migrate: to emigrate from Ireland to Australia.
afroasiatic: of, belonging to, or pertaining to Afroasiatic; Hamito-Semitic.
aramaic: Also, Aramean, Aramaean. a northwest Semitic language that from c300 b.c.–a.d. 650 was a lingua franca for nearly all of SW Asia and was the everyday speech of Syria, Mesopotamia, and Palestine. Abbreviation:  Aram.
phoenician: a native or inhabitant of Phoenicia.
yemen: Republic of, a country in S Arabia, formed in 1990 by the merger of the Yemen Arab Republic and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. 207,000 sq. mi. (536,130 sq. km). Capital:  Aden.
democratic: pertaining to or of the nature of democracy or a democracy.
oman: Sultanate of. Formerly Muscat and Oman. an independent sultanate in SE Arabia. About 82,800 sq. mi. (212,380 sq. km). Capital:  Muscat.
qatar: an independent emirate on the Persian Gulf; under British protection until 1971. 8500 sq. mi. (22,000 sq. km). Capital:  Doha.
kuwait: a sovereign monarchy in NE Arabia, on the NW coast of the Persian Gulf: formerly a British protectorate. About 8000 sq. mi. (20,720 sq. km).
felix: a male given name: from a Latin word meaning “happy, lucky.”.
oatmeal: meal made from ground or rolled oats.
composure: serene, self-controlled state of mind; calmness; tranquillity: Despite the hysteria and panic around him, he retained his composure.
desist: to cease, as from some action or proceeding; stop.
clue: anything that serves to guide or direct in the solution of a problem, mystery, etc.
gyroscope: an apparatus consisting of a rotating wheel so mounted that its axis can turn freely in certain or all directions, and capable of maintaining the same absolute direction in space in spite of movements of the mountings and surrounding parts: used to maintain equilibrium, determine direction, etc.
rejoicing: the act of a person who rejoices.
climax: the highest or most intense point in the development or resolution of something; culmination: His career reached its climax when he was elected president.
credential: Usually, credentials. evidence of authority, status, rights, entitlement to privileges, or the like, usually in written form: Only those with the proper credentials are admitted.
sorrowful: full of or feeling sorrow; grieved; sad.
mournful: feeling or expressing sorrow or grief; sorrowful; sad.
incentive: something that incites or tends to incite to action or greater effort, as a reward offered for increased productivity.
aloud: with the normal tone and volume of the speaking voice, as distinguished from whisperingly: They could not speak aloud in the library.
secretary: a person, usually an official, who is in charge of the records, correspondence, minutes of meetings, and related affairs of an organization, company, association, etc.: the secretary of the Linguistic Society of America.
atonement: satisfaction or reparation for a wrong or injury; amends.
contrite: caused by or showing sincere remorse.
overall: from one extreme limit of a thing to the other: the overall length of the bridge.
sameness: the state or quality of being the same; identity; uniformity.
homogeneity: composition from like parts, elements, or characteristics; state or quality of being homogeneous.
disorganized: functioning without adequate order, systemization, or planning; uncoordinated: a woefully disorganized enterprise.
sufficiency: the state or fact of being sufficient; adequacy.
eldest: oldest; first-born; of greatest age: eldest brother; eldest sister; eldest born.
priam: a king of Troy, the son of Laomedon, husband of Hecuba, and father of Paris, Cassandra, Hector, Polyxena, and many others. He was killed during the capture of Troy.
andromache: Classical Mythology. the wife of Hector and mother of Astyanax.
achilles: the greatest Greek warrior in the Trojan War and hero of Homer's Iliad. He killed Hector and was killed when Paris wounded him in the heel, his one vulnerable spot, with an arrow.
empower: to give power or authority to; authorize, especially by legal or official means: I empowered my agent to make the deal for me. The local ordinance empowers the board of health to close unsanitary restaurants.
molest: to bother, interfere with, or annoy.
induction: the act of inducing, bringing about, or causing: induction of the hypnotic state.
intemperate: given to or characterized by excessive or immoderate indulgence in alcoholic beverages.
joule: the standard unit of work or energy in the International System of Units (SI), equal to the work done by a force of one newton when its point of application moves through a distance of one meter in the direction of the force: equivalent to 10 7 ergs and one watt-second. Abbreviation:  J, j.
trifling: of very little importance; trivial; insignificant: a trifling matter.
extra: beyond or more than what is usual, expected, or necessary; additional: an extra copy of a newspaper; an extra charge.
acceleration: the act of accelerating; increase of speed or velocity.
abstraction: an abstract or general idea or term.
blush: to redden, as from embarrassment or shame: He blushed when they called him a conquering hero.
embarrassment: the state of being embarrassed; disconcertment; abashment.
loathe: to feel disgust or intense aversion for; abhor: I loathe people who spread malicious gossip.
chevrotain: any very small, deerlike ruminant of the family Tragulidae, of Africa, tropical Asia, the Malay Peninsula, etc.
placate: to appease or pacify, especially by concessions or conciliatory gestures: to placate an outraged citizenry.
covenant: an agreement, usually formal, between two or more persons to do or not do something specified.
fed: simple past tense and past participle of feed.
armenia: an ancient country in W Asia: now divided between Armenia, Turkey, and Iran.
teheran: a city in and the capital of Iran, in the N part: wartime conference of Roosevelt, Churchill, and Stalin 1943.
scrape: to deprive of or free from an outer layer, adhering matter, etc., or to smooth by drawing or rubbing something, especially a sharp or rough instrument, over the surface: to scrape a table to remove paint and varnish.
abrade: to wear off or down by scraping or rubbing.
transact: to carry on or conduct (business, negotiations, activities, etc.) to a conclusion or settlement. Synonyms: enact, conclude, settle, manage, negotiate.
admiral: the commander in chief of a fleet.
synchronize: to cause to indicate the same time, as one timepiece with another: Synchronize your watches.
bermuda: a group of islands in the Atlantic, 580 miles (935 km) E of North Carolina: a British colony; resort. 19 sq. mi. (49 sq. km). Capital:  Hamilton.
corduroy: a cotton-filling pile fabric with lengthwise cords or ridges.
antler: one of the solid deciduous horns, usually branched, of an animal of the deer family.
rodent: belonging or pertaining to the gnawing or nibbling mammals of the order Rodentia, including the mice, squirrels, beavers, etc.
burrow: a hole or tunnel in the ground made by a rabbit, fox, or similar animal for habitation and refuge.
leporid: an animal of the family Leporidae, comprising the rabbits and hares.
hare: any rodentlike mammal of the genus Lepus, of the family Leporidae, having long ears, a divided upper lip, and long hind limbs adapted for leaping.
pika: any of several small, brown to gray tailless mammals of the genus Ochotona, resembling rabbits with short ears and legs and inhabiting western mountains of North America and parts of eastern Europe and Asia.
loin: Usually, loins. the part or parts of the human body or of a quadruped animal on either side of the spinal column, between the false ribs and hipbone.
kidney: Anatomy. either of a pair of bean-shaped organs in the back part of the abdominal cavity that form and excrete urine, regulate fluid and electrolyte balance, and act as endocrine glands.
bull: the male of a bovine animal, especially of the genus Bos, with sexual organs intact and capable of reproduction.
unguent: an ointment or salve, usually liquid or semiliquid, for application to wounds, sores, etc.
hexagon: a polygon having six angles and six sides.
beehive: a habitation or dwelling-place constructed for bees, usually either dome-shaped or box-shaped.
fireplace: the part of a chimney that opens into a room and in which fuel is burned; hearth.
discouragement: an act or instance of discouraging.
persevering: displaying perseverance; resolutely persistent; steadfast: a persevering student.
impatient: not patient; not accepting delay, opposition, pain, etc., with calm or patience.
underwear: clothing worn next to the skin under outer clothes.
laborer: a person engaged in work that requires bodily strength rather than skill or training: a laborer in the field.
vestment: a garment, especially an outer garment.
docile: easily managed or handled; tractable: a docile horse.
emulsion: Physical Chemistry. any colloidal suspension of a liquid in another liquid.
allergy: an abnormal reaction of the body to a previously encountered allergen introduced by inhalation, ingestion, injection, or skin contact, often manifested by itchy eyes, runny nose, wheezing, skin rash, or diarrhea.
fringe: a decorative border of thread, cord, or the like, usually hanging loosely from a raveled edge or separate strip.
burglary: the felony of breaking into and entering the house of another at night with intent to steal, extended by statute to cover the breaking into and entering of any of various buildings, by night or day.
beget: (especially of a male parent) to procreate or generate (offspring).
merciful: full of mercy; characterized by, expressing, or showing mercy; compassionate: a merciful God.
lenient: agreeably tolerant; permissive; indulgent: He tended to be lenient toward the children. More lenient laws encouraged greater freedom of expression.
forgiving: disposed to forgive; indicating forgiveness: a forgiving soul; a forgiving smile.
prearrange: to arrange in advance or beforehand.
fatal: causing or capable of causing death; mortal; deadly: a fatal accident; a fatal dose of poison.
lethal: of, relating to, or causing death; deadly; fatal: a lethal weapon; a lethal dose.
lucid: easily understood; completely intelligible or comprehensible: a lucid explanation.
recipe: a set of instructions for making or preparing something, especially a food dish: a recipe for a cake.
cruelty: the state or quality of being cruel.
jumble: to mix in a confused mass; put or throw together without order: You've jumbled up all the cards.
theorize: to form a theory or theories.
classroom: a room, as in a school or college, in which classes are held.
raffle: a form of lottery in which a number of persons buy one or more chances to win a prize.
mackenzie: Sir Alexander, 1764–1820, Scottish explorer in Canada.
simplify: to make less complex or complicated; make plainer or easier: to simplify a problem.
shellac: lac that has been purified and formed into thin sheets, used for making varnish.
extravagance: excessive or unnecessary expenditure or outlay of money.
sparing: economical (often followed by in or of).
tempt: to entice or allure to do something often regarded as unwise, wrong, or immoral.
shipment: an act or instance of shipping freight or cargo.
passerine: of, belonging, or pertaining to the order Passeriformes, comprising more than half of all birds and typically having the feet adapted for perching.
handed: having or involving a hand or hands (usually used in combination): two-handed backhand; a four-handed piano work.
popularly: by the people as a whole; generally; widely: a fictitious story popularly accepted as true.
canaan: the ancient region lying between the Jordan, the Dead Sea, and the Mediterranean: the land promised by God to Abraham. Gen. 12:5–10.
founder: a person who founds or establishes.
ishmael: the son of Abraham and Hagar: both he and Hagar were cast out of Abraham's family by Sarah. Gen. 16:11, 12.
ukraine: a republic in SE Europe: rich agricultural and industrial region. 223,090 sq. mi. (603,700 sq. km). Capital:  Kiev.
byelorussia: Official name Belarus. Formerly White Russian Soviet Socialist Republic, Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic. a republic in E Europe, N of Ukraine: formerly a part of the Soviet Union. 80,154 sq. mi. (207,600 sq. km). Capital:  Minsk.
westerly: moving, directed, or situated toward the west: the westerly end of the field.
slovakia: a republic in central Europe: formerly a part of Czechoslovakia; under German protection 1939–45; independent since 1993. 18,931 sq. mi. (49,035 sq. km). Capital:  Bratislava.
slavonian: of or relating to Slavonia or its inhabitants.
bulgaria: a republic in SE Europe. 42,800 sq. mi. (110,850 sq. km). Capital:  Sofia.
hebrews: a book of the New Testament. Abbreviation:  Heb.
postexilic: being or occurring subsequent to the exile of the Jews in Babylonia 597–538 b.c.
pecan: a tall hickory tree, Carya illinoinensis, of the southern U.S. and Mexico, cultivated for its oval, smooth-shelled, edible nuts: the state tree of Texas.
shagbark: a hickory, Carya ovata, having rough, shaggy, bark and yielding a valuable wood.
tangled: snarled, interlaced, or mixed up: tangled thread.
ensnarl: to entangle in or as in a snarl.
bohrium: a superheavy, synthetic, radioactive element with a very short half-life. Symbol:  Bh; atomic number:  107.
pithy: brief, forceful, and meaningful in expression; full of vigor, substance, or meaning; terse; forcible: a pithy observation.
terse: neatly or effectively concise; brief and pithy, as language.
aphorism: a terse saying embodying a general truth, or astute observation, as “Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely” (Lord Acton).
astute: of keen penetration or discernment; sagacious: an astute analysis.
nasty: physically filthy; disgustingly unclean: a nasty pigsty of a room.
insinuating: tending to instill doubts, distrust, etc.; suggestive: an insinuating letter.
myth: a traditional or legendary story, usually concerning some being or hero or event, with or without a determinable basis of fact or a natural explanation, especially one that is concerned with deities or demigods and explains some practice, rite, or phenomenon of nature.
titan: The Orrin Hatch of the 1980s and 1990s was a Titan compared with the Orrin Hatch of today.
uranus: Astronomy. the planet seventh in order from the sun, having an equatorial diameter of 32,600 miles (56,460 km), a mean distance from the sun of 1,784 million miles (2,871 million km), a period of revolution of 84.07 years, and 15 moons.
gaea: the ancient Greek goddess of the earth, mother of the Titans.
ramie: an Asian shrub, Boehmeria nivea, of the nettle family, yielding a fiber used especially in making textiles.
chthonian: of or relating to the deities, spirits, and other beings dwelling under the earth.
protector: a person or thing that protects; defender; guardian.
ceres: a pre-Roman goddess of agriculture under whose name the Romans adopted the worship of the Greek goddess Demeter.
eleusinian: of or relating to Eleusis or to the Eleusinian mysteries.
persephone: Also, Proserpina, Proserpine. Classical Mythology. a daughter of Zeus and Demeter, abducted by Pluto to be queen of Hades, but allowed to return to the surface of the earth for part of the year.
pomegranate: a chambered, many-seeded, globose fruit, having a tough, usually red rind and surmounted by a crown of calyx lobes, the edible portion consisting of pleasantly acid flesh developed from the outer seed coat.
neptune: any whelk of the genus Neptunea, especially N. decemcostata, common along the eastern coast of North America and having a shell with seven to ten raised reddish-brown spiral ridges on a pale beige or yellow background.
demigod: a mythological being who is partly divine and partly human; an inferior deity.
groin: Anatomy. the fold or hollow on either side of the front of the body where the thigh joins the abdomen.
beaver: a large, amphibious rodent of the genus Castor, having sharp incisors, webbed hind feet, and a flattened tail, noted for its ability to dam streams with trees, branches, etc.
orestes: Classical Mythology. the son of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra, and the brother of Electra and Iphigenia: he avenged the murder of Agamemnon by killing Clytemenestra and her lover, Aegisthus, then was pursued by the Furies until saved by Athena.
electra: Also, Elektra. Classical Mythology. the daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra who incited her brother Orestes to kill Clytemnestra and her lover Aegisthus.
iphigenia: Classical Mythology. the daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra and sister of Orestes and Electra: when she was about to be sacrificed to ensure a wind to take the Greek ships to Troy, she was saved by Artemis, whose priestess she became.
lover: a person who is in love with another.
aegisthus: a cousin of Agamemnon who seduced Clytemnestra, Agamemnon's wife, and was later killed by Orestes.
mute: silent; refraining from speech or utterance.
trumpeter: a person who plays a trumpet; trumpet player.
whistling: the act of a person or thing that whistles.
whooper: a person or thing that whoops.
laconia: an ancient country in the S part of Greece. Capital:  Sparta.
peloponnesus: a peninsula forming the S part of Greece: seat of the early Mycenaean civilization and the powerful city-states of Argos, Sparta, etc. 8356 sq. mi. (21,640 sq. km).
mycenae: an ancient city in S Greece, in Argolis: important ruins.
atreus: the father of Plisthenes, Agamemnon, Menelaus, and Anaxibia upon whose house Thyestes pronounced a curse.
abduct: to carry off or lead away (a person) illegally and in secret or by force, especially to kidnap.
lourdes: a city in SW France: Roman Catholic shrine famed for miraculous cures.
annex: to attach, append, or add, especially to something larger or more important.
inspiration: an inspiring or animating action or influence: I cannot write poetry without inspiration.
thoracic: of or relating to the thorax.
chairperson: a person who presides over a meeting, committee, board, etc.
incur: to come into or acquire (some consequence, usually undesirable or injurious): to incur a huge number of debts.
allegorical: consisting of or pertaining to allegory; of the nature of or containing allegory; figurative: an allegorical poem; an allegorical meaning.
illustrate: to furnish (a book, magazine, etc.) with drawings, pictures, or other artwork intended for explanation, elucidation, or adornment.
vernacular: (of language) native or indigenous (opposed to literary or learned).
dependency: the state of being dependent; dependence.
thicken: to make or become thick or thicker.
southwest: the point or direction midway between south and west. Abbreviation:  SW.
scroll: a roll of parchment, paper, copper, or other material, especially one with writing on it: a scroll containing the entire Old Testament.
integral: of, relating to, or belonging as a part of the whole; constituent or component: integral parts.
extrinsic: not essential or inherent; not a basic part or quality; extraneous: facts that are extrinsic to the matter under discussion.
crankshaft: a shaft having one or more cranks, usually formed as integral parts.
summons: an authoritative command, message, or signal by which one is summoned.
dwindle: to become smaller and smaller; shrink; waste away: His vast fortune has dwindled away.
articulated: made clear or distinct: articulated sounds.
pleasurable: such as to give pleasure; enjoyable; agreeable; pleasant: a pleasurable experience.
extravagant: spending much more than is necessary or wise; wasteful: an extravagant shopper.
unrestrained: not restrained or controlled; uncontrolled or uncontrollable: the unrestrained birthrate in some countries.
unpredictable: not predictable; not to be foreseen or foretold: an unpredictable occurrence.
erratic: deviating from the usual or proper course in conduct or opinion; eccentric; queer: erratic behavior.
wolf: any of several large carnivorous mammals of the genus Canis, of the dog family Canidae, especially C. lupus, usually hunting in packs, formerly common throughout the Northern Hemisphere but now chiefly restricted to the more unpopulated parts of its range.
jackal: any of several nocturnal wild dogs of the genus Canis, especially C. aureus, of Asia and Africa, that scavenge or hunt in packs.
hyena: a doglike carnivore of the family Hyaenidae, of Africa, southwestern Asia, and south central Asia, having a coarse coat, a sloping back, and large teeth and feeding chiefly on carrion, often in packs.
coyote: Also called prairie wolf. a buffy-gray, wolflike canid, Canis latrans, of North America, distinguished from the wolf by its relatively small size and its slender build, large ears, and narrow muzzle.
fir: any coniferous tree belonging to the genus Abies, of the pine family, characterized by its pyramidal style of growth, flat needles, and erect cones.
ovoid: egg-shaped; having the solid form of an egg.
nut: a dry fruit consisting of an edible kernel or meat enclosed in a woody or leathery shell.
cupule: Here the involucre, in the form of a cup at the base, is called the cupule.
moralist: a person who teaches or inculcates morality.
urbane: having the polish and suavity regarded as characteristic of sophisticated social life in major cities: an urbane manner.
complacent: pleased, especially with oneself or one's merits, advantages, situation, etc., often without awareness of some potential danger or defect; self-satisfied: The voters are too complacent to change the government.
allergen: any substance, often a protein, that induces an allergy: common allergens include pollen, grasses, dust, and some medications.
anesthesia: Medicine/Medical. general or local insensibility, as to pain and other sensation, induced by certain interventions or drugs to permit the performance of surgery or other painful procedures.
halothane: a colorless liquid, C 2 HBrClF 3 , used as an inhalant for general anesthesia.
procaine: a compound, C 1 3 H 2 0 N 2 O 2 , used chiefly as a local and spinal anesthetic.
bouncing: stout, strong, or vigorous: a bouncing baby boy.
insinuate: to suggest or hint slyly: He insinuated that they were lying.
inject: to force (a fluid) into a passage, cavity, or tissue: to inject a medicine into the veins.
viviparous: Zoology. bringing forth living young rather than eggs, as most mammals and some reptiles and fishes.
gestation: the process, state, or period of gestating.
assess: to estimate officially the value of (property, income, etc.) as a basis for taxation.
diagnosis: the decision reached from such an examination. Abbreviation:  Dx.
enhance: to raise to a higher degree; intensify; magnify: The candelight enhanced her beauty.
barren: not producing or incapable of producing offspring; sterile: a barren woman.
indehiscent: not dehiscent; not opening at maturity.
drupe: any fruit, as a peach, cherry, plum, etc., consisting of an outer skin, a usually pulpy and succulent middle layer, and a hard and woody inner shell usually enclosing a single seed.
analogous: having analogy; corresponding in some particular: A brain and a computer are analogous.
refrigerate: to make or keep cold or cool, as for preservation.
premature: occurring, coming, or done too soon: a premature announcement.
displace: to compel (a person or persons) to leave home, country, etc.
battleship: any of a class of warships that are the most heavily armored and are equipped with the most powerful armament.
sank: a simple past tense of sink.
margay: a small tiger cat, Felis tigrina, of tropical America: now rare.
ocelot: a spotted leopardlike cat, Felis pardalis, ranging from Texas through South America: now greatly reduced in number and endangered in the U.S.
ossification: the act or process of ossifying.
hyoid: Also, hyoidal, hyoidean. noting or pertaining to a U -shaped bone at the root of the tongue in humans, or a corresponding bone or collection of bones in animals.
rapturous: full of, feeling, or manifesting ecstatic joy or delight.
germ: a microorganism, especially when disease-producing; microbe.
ineffectual: not effectual; without satisfactory or decisive effect: an ineffectual remedy.
ineffective: not effective; not producing results; ineffectual: ineffective efforts; ineffective remedies.
statistical: of, pertaining to, consisting of, or based on statistics.
addendum: a thing to be added; an addition.
appurtenance: something subordinate to another, more important thing; adjunct; accessory.
launch: to set (a boat or ship) in the water.
gemini: Astronomy. the Twins, a zodiacal constellation between Taurus and Cancer containing the bright stars Castor and Pollux.
aldebaran: a first-magnitude star, orange in color, in the constellation Taurus.
precarious: dependent on circumstances beyond one's control; uncertain; unstable; insecure: a precarious livelihood.
ragged: clothed in tattered garments: a ragged old man.
zigzag: a line, course, or progression characterized by sharp turns first to one side and then to the other.
crowbar: Also called crow. a steel bar, usually flattened and slightly bent at one or both ends, used as a lever.
oscar: one of a group of statuettes awarded annually by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for achievements in motion-picture production and performance.
diffident: lacking confidence in one's own ability, worth, or fitness; timid; shy.
calvin: John (Jean Chauvin or Caulvin) 1509–64, French theologian and reformer in Switzerland: leader in the Protestant Reformation.
checker: a small, usually red or black disk of plastic or wood, used in playing checkers.
redeem: to buy or pay off; clear by payment: to redeem a mortgage.
pastor: a minister or priest in charge of a church.
transvaal: a province in the NE Republic of South Africa. 110,450 sq. mi. (286,066 sq. km). Capital:  Pretoria.
johannesburg: a city in S Transvaal, in the NE Republic of South Africa.
sarcastic: of, relating to, or characterized by sarcasm: a sarcastic reply.
receptor: Physiology. an end organ or a group of end organs of sensory or afferent neurons, specialized to be sensitive to stimulating agents, as touch or heat.
effector: Also, effecter. a person or thing that effects.
invest: to put (money) to use, by purchase or expenditure, in something offering potential profitable returns, as interest, income, or appreciation in value.
ordain: to invest with ministerial or sacerdotal functions; confer holy orders upon.
enjoin: to prescribe (a course of action) with authority or emphasis: The doctor enjoined a strict diet.
protestant: any Western Christian who is not an adherent of a Catholic, Anglican, or Eastern Church.
penance: a punishment undergone in token of penitence for sin.
unction: an act of anointing, especially as a medical treatment or religious rite.
dana: Charles Anderson, 1819–97, U.S. journalist, editor, and publisher.
gorgon: Classical Mythology. any of three sister monsters commonly represented as having snakes for hair, wings, brazen claws, and eyes that turned anyone looking into them to stone. Medusa, the only mortal Gorgon, was beheaded by Perseus.
medusa: a saucer-shaped or dome-shaped, free-swimming jellyfish or hydra.
afterward: at a later or subsequent time; subsequently.
senseless: destitute or deprived of sensation; unconscious.
illogical: not logical; contrary to or disregardful of the rules of logic; unreasoning: an illogical reply.
marvelous: superb; excellent; great: a marvelous show.
weekend: the end of a week, especially the period of time between Friday evening and Monday morning: We spent the weekend at Virginia Beach.
somewhere: in or at some place not specified, determined, or known: They live somewhere in Michigan.
alumnus: a graduate or former student of a specific school, college, or university.
pablo: a male given name, Spanish form of Paul.
basque: one of a people of unknown origin inhabiting the western Pyrenees regions in France and Spain.
sickle: an implement for cutting grain, grass, etc., consisting of a curved, hooklike blade mounted in a short handle.
harvest: Also, harvesting. the gathering of crops.
workshop: a room, group of rooms, or building in which work, especially mechanical work, is carried on.
artisan: a person skilled in an applied art; a craftsperson.
incapacity: lack of ability, qualification, or strength; incapability.
alexander: a cocktail made with crème de cacao with gin or brandy (brandy alexander) and sweet cream.
dishonor: lack or loss of honor; disgraceful or dishonest character or conduct.
ridiculous: causing or worthy of ridicule or derision; absurd; preposterous; laughable: a ridiculous plan.
metalware: work of metal, especially utensils, flatware, etc.
cutlery: cutting instruments collectively, especially knives for cutting food.
fan: any device for producing a current of air by the movement of a broad surface or a number of such surfaces.
arena: the oval space in the center of a Roman amphitheater for gladiatorial combats or other performances.
horseshoe: a U -shaped metal plate, plain or with calks, nailed to a horse's hoof to protect it from being injured by hard or rough surfaces.
dip: to plunge (something, as a cloth or sponge) temporarily into a liquid, so as to moisten it, dye it, or cause it to take up some of the liquid: He dipped the brush into the paint bucket.
thunderstorm: a transient storm of lightning and thunder, usually with rain and gusty winds, sometimes with hail or snow, produced by cumulonimbus clouds.
cumuliform: having the appearance or character of cumulus clouds.
tops: ranked among the highest, as in ability, performance, comprehensiveness, or quality: His work is tops. That car is tops.
fascinating: of great interest or attraction; enchanting; charming; captivating: a fascinating story; fascinating jewelry.
supplication: an act or instance of supplicating; humble prayer, entreaty, or petition.
enrage: to make extremely angry; put into a rage; infuriate: His supercilious attitude enraged me.
exasperate: to irritate or provoke to a high degree; annoy extremely: He was exasperated by the senseless delays.
vex: to irritate; annoy; provoke: His noisy neighbors often vexed him.
retire: to withdraw, or go away or apart, to a place of privacy, shelter, or seclusion: He retired to his study.
heckle: to harass (a public speaker, performer, etc.) with impertinent questions, gibes, or the like; badger.
poland: a republic in E central Europe, on the Baltic Sea. About 121,000 sq. mi. (313,400 sq. km). Capital:  Warsaw.
handicap: a race or other contest in which certain disadvantages or advantages of weight, distance, time, etc., are placed upon competitors to equalize their chances of winning.
coerce: to compel by force, intimidation, or authority, especially without regard for individual desire or volition: They coerced him into signing the document.
hopeless: providing no hope; beyond optimism or hope; desperate: a hopeless case of cancer.
insistence: the act or fact of insisting.
reprehensible: deserving of reproof, rebuke, or censure; blameworthy.
leguminous: pertaining to, of the nature of, or bearing legumes.
guarantee: a promise or assurance, especially one in writing, that something is of specified quality, content, benefit, etc., or that it will perform satisfactorily for a given length of time: a money-back guarantee.
unfit: not fit; not adapted or suited; unsuitable: He was unfit for his office.
incapacitate: to deprive of ability, qualification, or strength; make incapable or unfit; disable.
detective: a member of the police force or a private investigator whose function is to obtain information and evidence, as of offenses against the law.
disabled: physically or mentally impaired, injured, or incapacitated.
adjusted: arranged or fitted properly: Properly adjusted shelving will accommodate books of various heights.
sacrum: a bone resulting from the fusion of two or more vertebrae between the lumbar and the coccygeal regions, in humans being composed usually of five fused vertebrae and forming the posterior wall of the pelvis.
tarsus: Anatomy, Zoology. the bones of the proximal segment of the foot; the bones between the tibia and the metatarsus, contributing to the construction of the ankle joint.
banking: the business carried on by a bank or a banker.
vying: competing; contending: All vying swimmers come to the judge's desk.
recurrent: that recurs; occurring or appearing again, especially repeatedly or periodically.
uric: of, pertaining to, contained in, or derived from urine.
nicotine: a colorless, oily, water-soluble, highly toxic, liquid alkaloid, C 1 0 H 1 4 N 2 , found in tobacco and valued as an insecticide.
morphine: a white, bitter, crystalline alkaloid, C 1 7 H 1 9 NO 3 ⋅H 2 O, the most important narcotic and addictive principle of opium, obtained by extraction and crystallization and used chiefly in medicine as a pain reliever and sedative.
calisaya: the medicinal bark of the tree Cinchona calisaya.
andes: a mountain range in W South America, extending about 4500 miles (7250 km) from N Colombia and Venezuela S to Cape Horn. Highest peak, Aconcagua, 22,834 feet (6960 meters).
java: the main island of Indonesia. 51,032 sq. mi. (132,173 sq. km).
remittent: abating for a time or at intervals: remittent symptoms.
fever: an abnormal condition of the body, characterized by undue rise in temperature, quickening of the pulse, and disturbance of various body functions.
swamp: a tract of wet, spongy land, often having a growth of certain types of trees and other vegetation, but unfit for cultivation.
parasitic: of, relating to, or characteristic of parasites.
mosquito: any of numerous dipterous insects of the family Culicidae, the females of which suck the blood of animals and humans, some species transmitting certain diseases, as malaria and yellow fever.
anopheles: any mosquito of the genus Anopheles, certain species of which are vectors of the parasite causing malaria in humans, distinguished from other mosquitoes by the absence of breathing tubes in the larvae and by the head-downward stance of the adult while resting or feeding.
sagebrush: any of several sagelike, bushy composite plants of the genus Artemisia, especially A. tridentata, having silvery, wedge-shaped leaves, with three teeth at the tip, common on the dry plains of the western U.S.
mugwort: any of certain weedy composite plants of the genus Artemisia, especially A. vulgaris, having aromatic leaves and small, greenish flower heads.
baste: to sew with long, loose stitches, as in temporarily tacking together pieces of a garment while it is being made.
relish: liking or enjoyment of the taste of something.
bribery: the act or practice of giving or accepting a bribe: Bribery of a public official is a felony.
shameless: lacking any sense of shame: immodest; audacious.
indifferent: without interest or concern; not caring; apathetic: his indifferent attitude toward the suffering of others.
insusceptible: not susceptible; incapable of being influenced or affected (usually followed by of or to): insusceptible of flattery; insusceptible to infection.
sting: to prick or wound with a sharp-pointed, often venom-bearing organ.
unemployed: not employed; without a job; out of work: an unemployed secretary.
seeming: apparent; appearing, whether truly or falsely, to be as specified: a seeming advantage.
boundless: having no bounds; infinite or vast; unlimited: His boundless energy amazed his friends.
interminable: incapable of being terminated; unending: an interminable job.
incessant: continuing without interruption; ceaseless; unending: an incessant noise.
inequitable: not equitable; unjust or unfair: an inequitable decision.
suitor: a man who courts or woos a woman.
verdict: Law. the finding or answer of a jury given to the court concerning a matter submitted to their judgment.
nevertheless: nonetheless; notwithstanding; however; in spite of that: a small but nevertheless important change.
edit: to supervise or direct the preparation of (a newspaper, magazine, book, etc.); serve as editor of; direct the editorial policies of.
imperial: of, like, or pertaining to an empire.
gal: a term used to refer to a girl or woman.
decimeter: a unit of length equal to 1/10 (0.1) meter. Abbreviation:  dm.
evade: to escape from by trickery or cleverness: to evade one's pursuers.
mast: Both French commanders died: Quiéret was killed as his ship was boarded, and Béhuchet was hanged from the mast of his ship.
boom: to make a deep, prolonged, resonant sound.
gaff: an iron hook with a handle for landing large fish.
fraudulent: characterized by, involving, or proceeding from fraud, as actions, enterprise, methods, or gains: a fraudulent scheme to evade taxes.
concord: agreement between persons, groups, nations, etc.; concurrence in attitudes, feelings, etc.; unanimity; accord: There was complete concord among the delegates.
marital: of or relating to marriage; conjugal; matrimonial: marital vows; marital discord.
peg: a pin of wood or other material driven or fitted into something, as to fasten parts together, to hang things on, to make fast a rope or string on, to stop a hole, or to mark some point.
christianity: the Christian religion, including the Catholic, Protestant, and Eastern Orthodox churches.
chastity: the state or quality of being chaste.
trickery: the use or practice of tricks or stratagems to deceive; artifice; deception.
postpositive: (of a word, particle, or affix) placed after a word to modify it or to show its relation to other elements of a sentence.
familiarity: thorough knowledge or mastery of a thing, subject, etc.
corvine: pertaining to or resembling a crow.
headquarters: a center of operations, as of the police or a business, from which orders are issued; the chief administrative office of an organization: The operatives were always in touch with headquarters.
obliquely: in an oblique manner or direction.
ferric: of or containing iron, especially in the trivalent state.
neuron: Cell Biology. a specialized, impulse-conducting cell that is the functional unit of the nervous system, consisting of the cell body and its processes, the axon and dendrites.
jealousy: jealous resentment against a rival, a person enjoying success or advantage, etc., or against another's success or advantage itself.
canonize: Ecclesiastical. to place in the canon of saints.
comb: a toothed strip of plastic, hard rubber, bone, wood, or metal, used for arranging the hair, untangling it, or holding it in place.
edifice: a building, especially one of large size or imposing appearance.
cadenced: having or marked by a rhythmical cadence: the cadenced steps of marching troops.
percussion: the striking of one body against another with some sharpness; impact; blow.
struck: simple past tense and a past participle of strike.
tapping: the act of a person or thing that taps or strikes lightly.
propitiate: to make favorably inclined; appease; conciliate.
mythical: pertaining to, of the nature of, or involving a myth.
suspender: Usually, suspenders. Also called, especially British, braces. adjustable straps or bands worn over the shoulders with the ends buttoned or clipped to the waistband of a pair of trousers or a skirt to support it.
turkish: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or derived from Turkey or the Turks.
didactic: intended for instruction; instructive: didactic poetry.
gypsy: a member of a nomadic, Caucasoid people of generally swarthy complexion, who migrated originally from India, settling in various parts of Asia, Europe, and, most recently, North America.
interchangeable: (of two things) capable of being put or used in the place of each other: interchangeable symbols.
coefficient: Mathematics. a number or quantity placed (generally) before and multiplying another quantity, as 3 in the expression 3x.
decrease: to diminish or lessen in extent, quantity, strength, power, etc.: During the ten-day march across the desert their supply of water decreased rapidly.
mitigation: the act of mitigating, or lessening the force or intensity of something unpleasant, as wrath, pain, grief, or extreme circumstances: Social support is the most important factor in the mitigation of stress among adolescents.
inning: Baseball. a division of a game during which each team has an opportunity to score until three outs have been made against it.
racket: a loud noise or clamor, especially of a disturbing or confusing kind; din; uproar: The traffic made a terrible racket in the street below.
rink: a smooth expanse of ice for ice-skating, often artificially prepared and inside a building or arena.
candlepin: a bowling pin that is almost cylindrical and can be set up on either end, used in a game resembling tenpins.
duckpin: Bowling. a short pin of relatively large diameter, used in a game resembling tenpins, and bowled at with small balls.
pins: a person of less than 16 years of age placed under the jurisdiction of a juvenile court because of habitual disobedience, intractability, or antisocial but noncriminal behavior.
haw: to utter a sound representing a hesitation or pause in speech.
ho: (used as a call to attract attention, sometimes specially used after a word denoting a destination): Westward ho! Land ho!
choreographer: a person who creates dance compositions and plans and arranges dance movements and patterns for dances and especially for ballets.
counterbalance: a weight balancing another weight; an equal weight, power, or influence acting in opposition; counterpoise.
flatter: to try to please by complimentary remarks or attention.
pork: the flesh of hogs used as food.
chop: to cut or sever with a quick, heavy blow or a series of blows, using an ax, hatchet, etc. (often followed by down, off, etc.): to chop down a tree.
conifer: any of numerous, chiefly evergreen trees or shrubs of the class Coniferinae (or group Coniferales), including the pine, fir, spruce, and other cone-bearing trees and shrubs, and also the yews and their allies that bear drupelike seeds.
refine: to bring to a fine or a pure state; free from impurities: to refine metal, sugar, or petroleum.
bicolor: Also, bicolored; especially British, bicoloured. having two colors: a bicolor flower.
subacid: slightly or moderately acid or sour: a subacid fruit.
drupaceous: resembling or relating to a drupe; consisting of drupes.
insatiable: not satiable; incapable of being satisfied or appeased: insatiable hunger for knowledge.
greed: excessive or rapacious desire, especially for wealth or possessions.
miserly: of, like, or befitting a miser; penurious; stingy; niggardly.
hoard: a supply or accumulation that is hidden or carefully guarded for preservation, future use, etc.: a vast hoard of silver.
guile: insidious cunning in attaining a goal; crafty or artful deception; duplicity.
infantry: soldiers or military units that fight on foot, in modern times typically with rifles, machine guns, grenades, mortars, etc., as weapons.
syrupy: having the appearance or quality of syrup; thick or sweet: syrupy coffee.
sweetening: something that sweetens food, beverages, etc., as sugar, saccharine, etc.
antifreeze: a liquid used in the radiator of an internal-combustion engine to lower the freezing point of the cooling medium.
ammonium: the univalent ion, NH 4 + , or group, NH 4 , which plays the part of a metal in the salt formed when ammonia reacts with an acid.
vasodilatation: dilatation of the blood vessels, as by the action of a nerve.
choking: (of the voice) husky and strained, especially because of emotion.
styrax: any tropical or subtropical tree of the genus Styrax, which includes the storaxes
sumatra: a large island in the W part of Indonesia. 164,147 sq. mi. (425,141 sq. km).
expectorant: promoting the discharge of phlegm or other fluid from the respiratory tract.
heartily: in a hearty manner; cordially: He was greeted heartily.
outspoken: uttered or expressed with frankness or without reserve: outspoken criticism.
ceremonious: carefully observant of ceremony; formally or elaborately polite: He greeted his rival with a ceremonious display of friendship.
hundredth: next after the ninety-ninth; being the ordinal number for 100.
premium: a prize, bonus, or award given as an inducement, as to purchase products, enter competitions initiated by business interests, etc.
consequently: as a result, effect, or outcome; therefore: There has been a great deal of rain and consequently the reservoirs are full.
stake: a stick or post pointed at one end for driving into the ground as a boundary mark, part of a fence, support for a plant, etc.
tusk: (in certain animals) a tooth developed to great length, usually one of a pair, as in the elephant, walrus, and wild boar, but singly in the narwhal.
africana: artifacts or artistic or literary works of any of the nations of Africa reflecting geographical, historical, or cultural development.
maximus: (bell-ringing) a method rung on twelve bells
thermometer: an instrument for measuring temperature, often a sealed glass tube that contains a column of liquid, as mercury, that expands and contracts, or rises and falls, with temperature changes, the temperature being read where the top of the column coincides with a calibrated scale marked on the tube or its frame.
pesticide: a chemical preparation for destroying plant, fungal, or animal pests.
pharmacy: Also called pharmaceutics. the art and science of preparing and dispensing drugs and medicines.
switch: a slender, flexible shoot, rod, etc., used especially in whipping or disciplining.
electronegative: containing negative electricity; tending to migrate to the positive pole in electrolysis.
fluorine: the most reactive nonmetallic element, a pale-yellow, corrosive, toxic gas that occurs combined, especially in fluorite, cryolite, phosphate rock, and other minerals. Symbol:  F; atomic weight:  18.9984; atomic number:  9.
iodine: a nonmetallic halogen element occurring at ordinary temperatures as a grayish-black crystalline solid that sublimes to a dense violet vapor when heated: used in medicine as an antiseptic. Symbol:  I; atomic weight:  126.904; atomic number:  53; specific gravity:  (solid) 4.93 at 20°C.
bromine: an element that is a dark-reddish, fuming, toxic liquid and a member of the halogen family: obtained from natural brines and ocean water, and used chiefly in the manufacture of gasoline antiknock compounds, pharmaceuticals, and dyes. Symbol:  Br; atomic weight:  79.909; atomic number:  35; specific gravity:  3.119 at 20°C.
astatine: a rare element of the halogen family. Symbol:  At; atomic number:  85.
binary: consisting of, indicating, or involving two.
piper: a person who plays on a pipe.
saigon: former name of Ho Chi Minh City: capital of former South Vietnam 1954–76.
carminative: a drug causing expulsion of gas from the stomach or bowel.
clove: the dried flower bud of a tropical tree, Syzygium aromaticum, of the myrtle family, used whole or ground as a spice.
certify: to attest as certain; give reliable information of; confirm: He certified the truth of his claim.
purplish: of or having a somewhat purple hue.
luminance: the state or quality of being luminous.
luminescence: the emission of light not caused by incandescence and occurring at a temperature below that of incandescent bodies.
torch: a light to be carried in the hand, consisting of some combustible substance, as resinous wood, or of twisted flax or the like soaked with tallow or other flammable substance, ignited at the upper end.
allegedly: according to what is or has been alleged.
cent: a bronze coin of the U.S., the 100th part of a U.S. dollar: made of steel during part of 1943. Symbol:  ¢.
unseemly: not seemly; not in keeping with established standards of taste or proper form; unbecoming or indecorous in appearance, speech, conduct, etc.: an unseemly act; unseemly behavior.
filthy: foul with, characterized by, or having the nature of filth; disgustingly or completely dirty.
grime: dirt, soot, or other filthy matter, especially adhering to or embedded in a surface.
artifice: a clever trick or stratagem; a cunning, crafty device or expedient; wile.
wile: a trick, artifice, or stratagem meant to fool, trap, or entice; device.
aegean: pertaining to the Aegean Sea or Islands.
dardanelles: the strait between European and Asian Turkey, connecting the Aegean Sea with the Sea of Marmara. 40 miles (64 km) long; 1–5 miles (1.6–8 km) wide.
istanbul: a port in NW Turkey, on both sides of the Bosporus: built by Constantine I on the site of ancient Byzantium; capital of the Eastern Roman Empire and of the Ottoman Empire; capital removed to Ankara 1923.
opportunism: the policy or practice, as in politics, business, or one's personal affairs, of adapting actions, decisions, etc., to expediency or effectiveness regardless of the sacrifice of ethical principles.
esp: extrasensory perception: perception or communication outside of normal sensory capability, as in telepathy and clairvoyance.
candida: any of the yeastlike fungi constituting the genus Candida, members of which may cause athlete's foot, vaginitis, thrush, or other infections.
malignant: disposed to cause harm, suffering, or distress deliberately; feeling or showing ill will or hatred.
embryonic: pertaining to or in the state of an embryo.
neurology: the science of the nerves and the nervous system, especially of the diseases affecting them.
helical: pertaining to or having the form of a helix; spiral.
reversal: an act or instance of reversing.
viral: of, relating to, or caused by a virus.
oncogene: any gene that is a causative factor in the initiation of cancerous growth.
introduction: the act of introducing or the state of being introduced.
ultramicroscope: an instrument that uses scattering phenomena to detect the position of objects too small to be seen by an ordinary microscope.
replicate: Also, replicated. folded; bent back on itself.
immerse: to plunge into or place under a liquid; dip; sink.
hypocritical: of the nature of hypocrisy, or pretense of having virtues, beliefs, principles, etc., that one does not actually possess: The parent who has a “do what I say and not what I do” attitude can appear hypocritical to a child.
purport: to present, especially deliberately, the appearance of being; profess or claim, often falsely: a document purporting to be official.
piltdown: village in Sussex, England, site where a fossil humanoid skull was said to have been found (1912), proved a fraud in 1953.
vain: excessively proud of or concerned about one's own appearance, qualities, achievements, etc.; conceited: a vain dandy.
boastful: given to or characterized by boasting.
pretension: the laying of a claim to something.
tact: a keen sense of what to say or do to avoid giving offense; skill in dealing with difficult or delicate situations.
tomb: an excavation in earth or rock for the burial of a corpse; grave.
pare: to cut off the outer coating, layer, or part of.
madam: (often initial capital letter) a polite term of address to a woman, originally used only to a woman of rank or authority: Madam President; May I help you, madam?
navigate: to move on, over, or through (water, air, or land) in a ship or aircraft: to navigate a river.
tuft: a bunch or cluster of small, usually soft and flexible parts, as feathers or hairs, attached or fixed closely together at the base and loose at the upper ends.
mushroom: any of various fleshy fungi including the toadstools, puffballs, coral fungi, morels, etc.
mildew: Plant Pathology. a disease of plants, characterized by a cottony, usually whitish coating on the surface of affected parts, caused by any of various fungi.
recital: a musical entertainment given usually by a single performer or by a performer and one or more accompanists.
critique: an article or essay criticizing a literary or other work; detailed evaluation; review.
evaluation: an act or instance of evaluating or appraising.
dinoflagellate: any of numerous chiefly marine plankton of the phylum Pyrrophyta (or, in some classification schemes, the order Dinoflagellata), usually having two flagella, one in a groove around the body and the other extending from its center.
cryptomonad: any of various protozoalike algae of the phylum Cryptophyta usually having two flagella, common in both marine and freshwater environments where they appear along the shore as algal blooms, some also occurring as intestinal parasites.
ant: any of numerous black, red, brown, or yellow social insects of the family Formicidae, of worldwide distribution especially in warm climates, having a large head with inner jaws for chewing and outer jaws for carrying and digging, and living in highly organized colonies containing wingless female workers, a winged queen, and, during breeding seasons, winged males, some species being noted for engaging in warfare, slavemaking, or the cultivation of food sources.
prokaryote: any cellular organism that has no nuclear membrane, no organelles in the cytoplasm except ribosomes, and has its genetic material in the form of single continuous strands forming coils or loops, characteristic of all organisms in the kingdom Monera, as the bacteria and blue-green algae.
mysterious: full of, characterized by, or involving mystery: a mysterious occurrence.
pathogen: any disease-producing agent, especially a virus, bacterium, or other microorganism.
subkingdom: a category of related phyla within a kingdom.
putrefy: to render putrid; cause to rot or decay with an offensive odor.
cutthroat: a person who cuts the throat of another; a murderer.
jerk: a quick, sharp pull, thrust, twist, throw, or the like; a sudden movement: The train started with a jerk.
spasm: Pathology. a sudden, abnormal, involuntary muscular contraction, consisting of a continued muscular contraction (tonic spasm) or of a series of alternating muscular contractions and relaxations (clonic spasm)
spurge: any of numerous plants of the genus Euphorbia, having a milky juice and flowers with no petals or sepals.
tuberous: characterized by the presence of rounded or wartlike prominences or tubers.
harmless: without the power or desire to do harm; innocuous: He looks mean but he's harmless; a harmless Halloween prank.
abort: to bring forth a fetus from the uterus before the fetus is viable; miscarry.
arrowhead: the head or tip of an arrow, usually separable from the shaft and conventionally wedge-shaped.
tine: a sharp, projecting point or prong, as of a fork.
poke: to prod or push, especially with something narrow or pointed, as a finger, elbow, stick, etc.: to poke someone in the ribs.
upholster: to provide (chairs, sofas, etc.) with coverings, cushions, stuffing, springs, etc.
seating: an act or instance of furnishing with, assigning, or escorting to a seat.
armrest: a projecting, often padded support for the forearm, as at the side of a chair or sofa or between seats in a theater, car, or airplane.
subjoin: to add at the end, as of something said or written; append.
infraction: breach; violation; infringement: an infraction of the rules.
copyright: the exclusive right to make copies, license, and otherwise exploit a literary, musical, or artistic work, whether printed, audio, video, etc.: works granted such right by law on or after January 1, 1978, are protected for the lifetime of the author or creator and for a period of 50 years after his or her death.
seldom: on only a few occasions; rarely; infrequently; not often: We seldom see our old neighbors anymore.
awesome: causing or inducing awe; inspiring an overwhelming feeling of reverence, admiration, or fear: an awesome sight.
eure: a department in NW France. 2331 sq. mi. (6035 sq. km). Capital:  Evreux.
backyard: the portion of a lot or building site behind a house, structure, or the like, sometimes fenced, walled, etc.
landing: the act of a person or thing that lands: The pilot brought his plane in for a landing.
pier: a structure built on posts extending from land out over water, used as a landing place for ships, an entertainment area, a strolling place, etc.; jetty.
archer: a person who shoots with a bow and arrow; bowman.
mooring: the act of a person or thing that moors.
anchorage: that portion of a harbor or area outside a harbor suitable for anchoring or in which ships are permitted to anchor.
slavish: of or befitting a slave: slavish subjection.
patronizing: displaying or indicative of an offensively condescending manner: a patronizing greeting, accompanied by a gentle pat on the pack.
domineering: inclined to rule arbitrarily or despotically; overbearing; tyrannical: domineering parents.
oleoresin: a mixture of an essential oil and a resin, found in nature.
insignificant: unimportant, trifling, or petty: Omit the insignificant details.
spoonful: as much as a spoon can hold.
immigrant: a person who migrates to another country, usually for permanent residence.
tails: (of a coin) with the reverse facing up: On the next toss, the coin came up tails.
salty: tasting of or containing salt; saline.
adjustable: capable of being adjusted: adjustable seat belts.
pulverize: to reduce to dust or powder, as by pounding or grinding.
lath: a thin, narrow strip of wood, used with other strips to form latticework, a backing for plaster or stucco, a support for slates and other roofing materials, etc.
venice: Italian Venezia. a seaport in NE Italy, built on numerous small islands in the Lagoon of Venice.
bactria: an ancient country in W Asia, between the Oxus River and the Hindu Kush Mountains. Capital:  Bactra.
martial: inclined or disposed to war; warlike: The ancient Romans were a martial people.
insolence: contemptuously rude or impertinent behavior or speech.
gamete: a mature sexual reproductive cell, as a sperm or egg, that unites with another cell to form a new organism.
insulin: Biochemistry. a polypeptide hormone, produced by the beta cells of the islets of Langerhans of the pancreas, that regulates the metabolism of glucose and other nutrients.
thyroxine: Biochemistry. the thyroid gland hormone that regulates the metabolic rate of the body.
endocrine: secreting internally into the blood or lymph.
receptive: having the quality of receiving, taking in, or admitting.
pop: to make a short, quick, explosive sound: The cork popped.
lansing: Robert, 1864–1928, U.S. lawyer and statesman: secretary of state 1915–20.
springfield: a city in S Massachusetts, on the Connecticut River.
elect: to choose or select by vote, as for an office: to elect a mayor.
shaggy: covered with or having long, rough hair.
uo: Urban Operations: refers to combat, warfare, and military operations in urban areas.

aft: at, close to, or toward the stern or tail: Stow the luggage aft.

The element is used in forming smoke screens, its compounds are used in matches and phosphate fertilizers, and it is a necessary constituent of plant and animal life in bones, nerves, and embryos. Symbol:  P; atomic weight:  30.974; atomic number:  15; specific gravity:  (yellow) 1.82 at 20°C, (red) 2.20 at 20°C, (black) 2.25–2.69 at 20°C.

gore: blood that is shed, especially when clotted.
website: a connected group of pages on the World Wide Web regarded as a single entity, usually maintained by one person or organization and devoted to a single topic or several closely related topics.
insured: the person, group, or organization whose life or property is covered by an insurance policy.
hummer: a person or thing that hums.
foreshadow: to show or indicate beforehand; prefigure: Political upheavals foreshadowed war.
maniac: a raving or violently insane person; lunatic.
restrained: characterized by restraint: The actor gave a restrained performance.
vomit: to eject the contents of the stomach through the mouth; regurgitate; throw up.
quake: (of persons) to shake or tremble from cold, weakness, fear, anger, or the like: He spoke boldly even though his legs were quaking.
irreparable: not reparable; incapable of being rectified, remedied, or made good: an irreparable mistake.
vandal: (initial capital letter) a member of a Germanic people who in the 5th century a.d. ravaged Gaul and Spain, settled in Africa, and in a.d. 455 sacked Rome.
yearning: deep longing, especially when accompanied by tenderness or sadness: a widower's yearning for his wife.
inquest: a legal or judicial inquiry, usually before a jury, especially an investigation made by a coroner into the cause of a death.
smelt: to fuse or melt (ore) in order to separate the metal contained.
polarization: a sharp division, as of a population or group, into opposing factions.
adventurous: inclined or willing to engage in adventures; enjoying adventures.
rebuff: a blunt or abrupt rejection, as of a person making advances.
cautery: an escharotic substance, electric current, or hot iron used to destroy tissue.
topography: the detailed mapping or charting of the features of a relatively small area, district, or locality.
polysaccharide: a carbohydrate, as starch, inulin, or cellulose, containing more than three monosaccharide units per molecule, the units being attached to each other in the manner of acetals, and therefore capable of hydrolysis by acids or enzymes to monosaccharides.
exoskeleton: an external covering or integument, especially when hard, as the shells of crustaceans (opposed to endoskeleton).
crustacea: 1814, Modern Latin neuter plural of crustaceus (animalia), literally "having a crust or shell," from Latin crusta "crust, rind, bark, hard shell" (see crust (n.)). Taken as a zoological classification by Lamarck, 1801; Cuvier (1798) had les insectes crustacées.
repressed: subjected to, affected by, or characteristic of psychological repression: repressed emotional conflicts.
cisalpine: on this (the Roman or south) side of the Alps.
transalpine: situated beyond the Alps, especially toward the north as viewed from Italy.
output: the act of turning out; production: the factory's output of cars; artistic output.
buddhism: a religion, originated in India by Buddha (Gautama) and later spreading to China, Burma, Japan, Tibet, and parts of southeast Asia, holding that life is full of suffering caused by desire and that the way to end this suffering is through enlightenment that enables one to halt the endless sequence of births and deaths to which one is otherwise subject.
mongolia: a region in Asia including Inner Mongolia of China and the Mongolian People's Republic.
mahayana: the later of the two great schools of Buddhism, chiefly in China, Tibet, and Japan, characterized by eclecticism and a general belief in a common search for salvation, sometimes thought to be attainable through faith alone.
shamanism: the animistic religion of northern Asia, embracing a belief in powerful spirits that can be influenced only by shamans.
dear: beloved or loved: a dear friend.
bald: having little or no hair on the scalp: a bald head; a bald person.
interweave: to weave together, as threads, strands, branches, or roots.
fabricate: to make by art or skill and labor; construct: The finest craftspeople fabricated this clock.
disparaging: that disparages; tending to belittle or bring reproach upon: a disparaging remark.
misstate: to state wrongly or misleadingly; make a wrong statement about.
philistine: (sometimes initial capital letter) a person who is lacking in or hostile or smugly indifferent to cultural values, intellectual pursuits, aesthetic refinement, etc., or is contentedly commonplace in ideas and tastes.
goliath: the giant warrior of the Philistines whom David killed with a stone from a sling. I Sam. 17:48–51.
muhammad: Also, Mohammed, Mahomet. a.d. 570–632, Arab prophet: founder of Islam.
ibn: son of (used in Arabic personal names): ibn Saud.
budapest: a city in and the capital of Hungary, in the central part, on the Danube River: formed 1873 from two cities on the W bank of the Danube (Buda and Obuda) and one on the E bank (Pest)
plead: to appeal or entreat earnestly: to plead for time.
acquiescent: disposed to acquiesce or consent tacitly.
gaze: to look steadily and intently, as with great curiosity, interest, pleasure, or wonder.
koran: the sacred text of Islam, divided into 114 chapters, or suras: revered as the word of God, dictated to Muhammad by the archangel Gabriel, and accepted as the foundation of Islamic law, religion, culture, and politics.
unwise: not wise; foolish; imprudent; lacking in good sense or judgment: an unwise choice; an unwise man.
improvise: to compose and perform or deliver without previous preparation; extemporize: to improvise an acceptance speech.
arched: made, covered, or spanned with an arch or arches.
pelvic: of or relating to the pelvis.
buttress: any external prop or support built to steady a structure by opposing its outward thrusts, especially a projecting support built into or against the outside of a masonry wall.
gable: the portion of the front or side of a building enclosed by or masking the end of a pitched roof.
crocket: a medieval ornament, usually in the form of a leaf that curves up and away from the supporting surface and returns partially upon itself.
foil: to prevent the success of; frustrate; balk: Loyal troops foiled his attempt to overthrow the government.
viscera: Anatomy, Zoology. the organs in the cavities of the body, especially those in the abdominal cavity.
developer: a person or thing that develops or innovates: a software developer.
headstream: a stream that is the source, or one of the sources, of a river.
underhand: not open and aboveboard; secret and crafty or dishonorable: an underhand deal with the chief of police.
intrigue: to arouse the curiosity or interest of by unusual, new, or otherwise fascinating or compelling qualities; appeal strongly to; captivate: The plan intrigues me, but I wonder if it will work.
deceitful: given to deceiving: A deceitful person cannot keep friends for long.
tricky: given to or characterized by deceitful tricks; crafty; wily.
bern: a city in and the capital of Switzerland, in the W part: capital of Bern canton.
vienna: German Wien. a port in and the capital of Austria, in the NE part, on the Danube.
yugoslavia: formerly, a federal republic in S Europe: since 1992 comprised of Serbia and Montenegro; disbanded into independent countries in 2006. 39,449 sq. mi. (102,173 sq. km). Capital:  Belgrade.
ljubljana: a city in and the capital of Slovenia, in the central part.
dalmatia: a historic region along the Adriatic coast of Croatia: a former Austrian crownland.
istria: a peninsula at the N end of the Adriatic, in SW Slovenia and W Croatia.
slavonia: a historic region in N Croatia.
zagreb: a city in and the capital of Croatia, in the NW part.
ajaccio: a seaport in and the capital of Corsica: the birthplace of Napoleon I.
expulsion: the act of driving out or expelling: expulsion of air.
galore: in abundance; in plentiful amounts: food and drink galore.
appease: to bring to a state of peace, quiet, ease, calm, or contentment; pacify; soothe: to appease an angry king.
inauspicious: not auspicious; boding ill; ill-omened; unfavorable.
fussy: excessively busy with trifles; anxious or particular about petty details.
petulant: moved to or showing sudden, impatient irritation, especially over some trifling annoyance: a petulant toss of the head.
unfasten: to release from or as from fastenings; detach.
disengage: to release from attachment or connection; loosen; unfasten: to disengage a clutch.
disunite: to sever the union of; separate; disjoin.
zeeland: a province in the SW Netherlands, consisting largely of islands. 1041 sq. mi. (2695 sq. km). Capital:  Middelburg.
hague: The, a city in the W Netherlands, near the North Sea: site of the government, royal residence, and of the International Court of Justice.
anus: the opening at the lower end of the alimentary canal, through which the solid refuse of digestion is excreted.
bowel: “My dog has just had to learn good bladder and bowel control,” he jokes.
ferocious: savagely fierce, as a wild beast, person, action, or aspect; violently cruel: a ferocious beating.
plaque: a thin, flat plate or tablet of metal, porcelain, etc., intended for ornament, as on a wall, or set in a piece of furniture.
eve: (sometimes initial capital letter) the evening or the day before a holiday, church festival, or any date or event: Christmas Eve; the eve of an execution.
cotyledon: the primary or rudimentary leaf of the embryo of seed plants.
sunglasses: eyeglasses with colored or tinted lenses that protect the eyes from the glare of sunlight.
chaff: the husks of grains and grasses that are separated during threshing.
bract: a specialized leaf or leaflike part, usually situated at the base of a flower or inflorescence.
subtend: Geometry. to extend under or be opposite to: a chord subtending an arc.
renounce: to give up or put aside voluntarily: to renounce worldly pleasures.
hindu: a person, especially of northern India, who adheres to Hinduism.
romulus: the founder of Rome, in 753 b.c., and its first king: a son of Mars and Rhea Silvia, he and his twin brother (Remus) were abandoned as babies, suckled by a she-wolf, and brought up by a shepherd; Remus was finally killed for mocking the fortifications of Rome, which Romulus had just founded.
jaredite: (in Mormon belief) a member of a tribe of people who settled America after the dispersal at Babel.
cesium: a rare, highly reactive, soft, metallic element of the alkali metal group, used chiefly in photoelectric cells. Symbol:  Cs; atomic weight:  132.905; atomic number:  55; specific gravity:  1.9 at 20°C; melts at 28.5°C.
impervious: not permitting penetration or passage; impenetrable: The coat is impervious to rain.
monomer: a molecule of low molecular weight capable of reacting with identical or different molecules of low molecular weight to form a polymer.
amide: a metallic derivative of ammonia in which the −NH 2 group is retained, as potassium amide, KNH 2 .
extrude: to thrust out; force or press out; expel: to extrude molten rock.
garland: a wreath or festoon of flowers, leaves, or other material, worn for ornament or as an honor or hung on something as a decoration: A garland of laurel was placed on the winner's head.
mesh: any knit, woven, or knotted fabric of open texture.
perforation: a hole, or one of a series of holes, bored or punched through something, as those between individual postage stamps of a sheet to facilitate separation.
dehydrate: to deprive (a chemical compound) of water or the elements of water.
phoenix: (sometimes initial capital letter) a mythical bird of great beauty fabled to live 500 or 600 years in the Arabian wilderness, to burn itself on a funeral pyre, and to rise from its ashes in the freshness of youth and live through another cycle of years: often an emblem of immortality or of reborn idealism or hope.
organometallic: pertaining to or noting an organic compound containing a metal or a metalloid linked to carbon.
coordination: the act or state of coordinating or of being coordinated.
cyclopentadiene: a colorless liquid, C 5 H 6 , derived by the distillation of coal tar: used chiefly in the manufacture of insecticides and resins.
disencumber: to free from a burden or other encumbrance; disburden.
yourself: (an emphatic appositive of you or ye1. ): a letter you yourself wrote.
spit: to eject saliva from the mouth; expectorate.
triturate: to reduce to fine particles or powder by rubbing, grinding, bruising, or the like; pulverize.
pallor: unusual or extreme paleness, as from fear, ill health, or death; wanness.
pallid: pale; faint or deficient in color; wan: a pallid countenance.
faucet: any device for controlling the flow of liquid from a pipe or the like by opening or closing an orifice; tap; cock.
deluge: a great flood of water; inundation; flood.
impetuosity: the quality or condition of being impetuous.
lockjaw: tetanus in which the jaws become firmly locked together; trismus.
febrile: pertaining to or marked by fever; feverish.
bacillus: any rod-shaped or cylindrical bacterium of the genus Bacillus, comprising spore-producing bacteria.
crayfish: Also called crawdad, crawdaddy. any freshwater decapod crustacean of the genera Astacus and Cambarus, closely related to but smaller than the lobsters.
disciple: The 40-year-old Voit studied at the Dusseldorf Academy in Germany with Thomas Ruff, a disciple of Bernd and Hilla Becher.
gentile: of or relating to any people not Jewish.
perforate: to make a hole or holes through by boring, punching, piercing, or the like.
bead: a small, usually round object of glass, wood, stone, or the like with a hole through it, often strung with others of its kind in necklaces, rosaries, etc.
manageable: that can be managed; governable; tractable; contrivable.
galvanism: Electricity. electricity, especially as produced by chemical action.
paperboard: a thick, stiff cardboard composed of layers of paper or paper pulp compressed together.
demonstrator: a person or thing that demonstrates.
wrinkle: a small furrow or crease in the skin, especially of the face, as from aging or frowning.
ripple: (of a liquid surface) to form small waves or undulations, as water agitated by a breeze.
stereoisomerism: the isomerism ascribed to different relative positions of the atoms or groups of atoms in the molecules of organic compounds.
dazzle: to overpower or dim the vision of by intense light: He was dazzled by the sudden sunlight.
flare: to burn with an unsteady, swaying flame, as a torch or candle in the wind.
flashbulb: a glass bulb, filled with oxygen and aluminum or zirconium wire or foil, which, when ignited electrically, burns with a brilliant flash to provide momentary illumination of a subject.
batterie: a beating together of the calves or feet during a leap.
solmization: the act, process, or system of using certain syllables, especially the sol-fa syllables, to represent the tones of the scale.
bladder: The girl, Mariam, was born with her bladder outside her body.
caviar: the roe of sturgeon, especially the beluga, or other fish, usually served as an hors d'oeuvre or appetizer.
clarify: to make (an idea, statement, etc.) clear or intelligible; to free from ambiguity.
blemish: to destroy or diminish the perfection of: The book is blemished by those long, ineffective descriptions.
reciprocate: to give, feel, etc., in return.
wrecker: a person or thing that wrecks.
indiscriminate: not discriminating; lacking in care, judgment, selectivity, etc.: indiscriminate in one's friendships.
revenge: to exact punishment or expiation for a wrong on behalf of, especially in a resentful or vindictive spirit: He revenged his murdered brother.
intake: the place or opening at which a fluid is taken into a channel, pipe, etc.
launcher: a person or thing that launches.
panel: a distinct portion, section, or division of a wall, wainscot, ceiling, door, shutter, fence, etc., especially of any surface sunk below or raised above the general level or enclosed by a frame or border.
equilateral: having all the sides equal: an equilateral triangle.
chester: a city in Cheshire, in NW England: only English city with the Roman walls still intact.
alan: a male given name: from a Celtic word meaning “harmony.”.
economics: (used with a singular verb) the science that deals with the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services, or the material welfare of humankind.
splendid: gorgeous; magnificent; sumptuous. Synonyms: luxurious, dazzling, imposing.
gorgeous: splendid or sumptuous in appearance, coloring, etc.; magnificent: a gorgeous gown; a gorgeous sunset.
annapolis: a seaport in and the capital of Maryland, in the central part, on Chesapeake Bay: U.S. Naval Academy.
frigate: a fast naval vessel of the late 18th and early 19th centuries, generally having a lofty ship rig and heavily armed on one or two decks.
applejack: a brandy distilled from fermented cider; apple brandy.
ketchup: a condiment consisting of puréed tomatoes, onions, vinegar, sugar, spices, etc.
symbiotic: living in symbiosis, or having an interdependent relationship: Many people feel the relationship between humans and dogs is symbiotic.
thallus: a simple vegetative body undifferentiated into true leaves, stem, and root, ranging from an aggregation of filaments to a complex plantlike form.
scrub: to rub hard with a brush, cloth, etc., or against a rough surface in washing.
petal: one of the often colored segments of the corolla of a flower.
superstructure: the part of a building or construction entirely above its foundation or basement.
stateroom: a private room or compartment on a ship, train, etc.
welsh: to cheat by failing to pay a gambling debt: You aren't going to welsh on me, are you?
wallaroo: any of several large kangaroos of the genus Macropus (Osphranter), of the grassy plains of Australia, especially M. robustus, having a reddish-gray coat and inhabiting rocky hills.
pion: the first meson to be discovered: it has spin 0 and may be positively or negatively charged or neutral; charged pions decay into a muon and a neutrino or antineutrino. Symbol:  π.
photon: a quantum of electromagnetic radiation, usually considered as an elementary particle that is its own antiparticle and that has zero rest mass and charge and a spin of one. Symbol:  γ.
graviton: the theoretical quantum of gravitation, usually assumed to be an elementary particle that is its own antiparticle and that has zero rest mass and charge and a spin of two.
boson: any particle that obeys Bose-Einstein statistics: bosons have integral spins: 0, 1, 2, ….
wildlife: undomesticated animals living in the wild, including those hunted for food, sport, or profit.
extol: to praise highly; laud; eulogize: to extol the beauty of Naples.
pictorial: pertaining to, expressed in, or of the nature of a picture.
massage: the act or art of treating the body by rubbing, kneading, patting, or the like, to stimulate circulation, increase suppleness, relieve tension, etc.
allure: to attract or tempt by something flattering or desirable.
inveigle: to entice, lure, or ensnare by flattery or artful talk or inducements (usually followed by into): to inveigle a person into playing bridge.
westward: moving, bearing, facing, or situated toward the west: a westward migration of farm workers.
rectitude: rightness of principle or conduct; moral virtue: the rectitude of her motives.
beguile: to influence by trickery, flattery, etc.; mislead; delude.
captivate: to attract and hold the attention or interest of, as by beauty or excellence; enchant: Her blue eyes and red hair captivated him.
nobleman: a man of noble birth or rank; noble; peer.
marquis: a nobleman ranking next below a duke and above an earl or count.
viscount: a nobleman next below an earl or count and next above a baron.
norman: a member of that branch of the Northmen or Scandinavians who in the 10th century conquered Normandy.
confide: to impart secrets trustfully; discuss private matters or problems (usually followed by in): She confides in no one but her husband.
harass: to disturb persistently; torment, as with troubles or cares; bother continually; pester; persecute.
exotic: of foreign origin or character; not native; introduced from abroad, but not fully naturalized or acclimatized: exotic foods; exotic plants.
aramean: a Semite of the division associated with Aram.
lingua: the tongue or a part like a tongue.
franca: a city in Sao Paulo state, SE Brazil.
everyday: of or relating to every day; daily: an everyday occurrence.
ethiopian: of or relating to Ethiopia or to its inhabitants.
phoenicia: an ancient kingdom on the Mediterranean, in the region of modern Syria, Lebanon, and Israel.
merger: a statutory combination of two or more corporations by the transfer of the properties to one surviving corporation.
