aden: a seaport in and the economic capital of the Republic of Yemen, in the S part: formerly the center of a British colony.
sultanate: the office or rule of a sultan.
muscat: a variety of grape having a pronounced sweet aroma and flavor, used for making wine and raisins.
emirate: the office or rank of an emir.
doha: a city in and the capital of the state of Qatar, on the Persian Gulf.
protectorate: the relation of a strong state toward a weaker state or territory that it protects and partly controls.
culmination: the act or fact of culminating.
productivity: the quality, state, or fact of being able to generate, create, enhance, or bring forth goods and services: The productivity of the group's effort surprised everyone.
library: a place set apart to contain books, periodicals, and other material for reading, viewing, listening, study, or reference, as a room, set of rooms, or building where books may be read or borrowed.
reparation: the making of amends for wrong or injury done: reparation for an injustice.
amends: reparation or compensation for a loss, damage, or injury of any kind; recompense.
laomedon: a king of Troy and the father of Priam, for whom the walls of Troy were built by Apollo and Poseidon.
hecuba: Classical Mythology. the wife of Priam.
cassandra: Also called Alexandra. Classical Mythology. a daughter of Priam and Hecuba, a prophet cursed by Apollo so that her prophecies, though true, were fated never to be believed.
polyxena: (Greek myth) a daughter of King Priam of Troy, who was sacrificed on the command of Achilles' ghost
astyanax: (Greek myth) the young son of Hector and Andromache, who was hurled from the walls of Troy by the Greeks
warrior: a person engaged or experienced in warfare; soldier.
wounded: suffering injury or bodily harm, as a laceration or bullet wound: to bandage a wounded hand.
vulnerable: capable of or susceptible to being wounded or hurt, as by a weapon: a vulnerable part of the body.
ordinance: an authoritative rule or law; a decree or command.
unsanitary: not sanitary; unhealthy or unhealthful; tending to harbor or spread disease: unsanitary living conditions.
interfere: to come into opposition, as one thing with another, especially with the effect of hampering action or procedure (often followed by with): Constant distractions interfere with work.
hypnotic: of or relating to hypnosis or hypnotism.
indulge: to yield to an inclination or desire; allow oneself to follow one's will (often followed by in): Dessert came, but I didn't indulge. They indulged in unbelievable shopping sprees.
indulgence: the act or practice of indulging; gratification of desire.
immeasurable: incapable of being measured; limitless: the immeasurable vastness of the universe.
abhor: to regard with extreme repugnance or aversion; detest utterly; loathe; abominate.
pacify: to bring or restore to a state of peace or tranquillity; quiet; calm: to pacify an angry man.
initiate: to begin, set going, or originate: to initiate major social reforms.
wartime: a time or period of war: Strict travel regulations apply only in wartime.
roosevelt: (Anna) Eleanor, 1884–1962, U.S. diplomat, author, and lecturer (wife of Franklin Delano Roosevelt).
stalin: Joseph V (Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili or Dzugashvili) 1879–1953, Soviet political leader: secretary general of the Communist Party 1922–53; premier of the U.S.S.R. 1941–53.
steeplechase: a horse race over a turf course furnished with artificial ditches, hedges, and other obstacles over which the horses must jump.
cruise: to sail about on a pleasure trip.
negotiate: to deal or bargain with another or others, as in the preparation of a treaty or contract or in preliminaries to a business deal.
ellen: Mount, a mountain in S Utah. 11,522 feet (3514 meters).
anderson: Carl David, 1905–91, U.S. physicist: discoverer of the positron; Nobel Prize 1936.
timepiece: an apparatus for measuring and recording the progress of time; chronometer.
carolina: a former English colony on the Atlantic coast of North America: officially divided into North Carolina and South Carolina in 1729.
hamilton: Alexander, 1757–1804, American statesman and writer on government: the first Secretary of the Treasury 1789–97; mortally wounded by Aaron Burr in a duel.
lepus: the Hare, a small southern constellation south of Orion.
medicate: to treat with medicine or medicaments.
salve: a medicinal ointment for healing or relieving wounds and sores.
dome: From deep within, looking up at the tropical sky is like staring through the dome of some kind of earthen cathedral.
phosphorescence: the property of being luminous at temperatures below incandescence, as from slow oxidation in the case of phosphorus or after exposure to light or other radiation.
persist: to continue steadfastly or firmly in some state, purpose, course of action, or the like, especially in spite of opposition, remonstrance, etc.: to persist in working for world peace; to persist in unpopular political activities.
perseverance: steady persistence in a course of action, a purpose, a state, etc., especially in spite of difficulties, obstacles, or discouragement.
steadfast: fixed in direction; steadily directed: a steadfast gaze.
bellhop: a person who is employed, especially by a hotel, to carry guests' luggage, run errands, etc.
itchy: having or causing an itching sensation.
runny: tending to run or drip: a runny paste.
rash: acting or tending to act too hastily or without due consideration.
diarrhea: an intestinal disorder characterized by abnormal frequency and fluidity of fecal evacuations.
simultaneous: existing, occurring, or operating at the same time; concurrent: simultaneous movements; simultaneous translation.
tolerant: inclined or disposed to tolerate; showing tolerance; forbearing: tolerant of errors.
permissive: habitually or characteristically accepting or tolerant of something, as social behavior or linguistic usage, that others might disapprove or forbid.
indulgent: characterized by or showing indulgence; benignly lenient or permissive: an indulgent parent.
forgive: to grant pardon for or remission of (an offense, debt, etc.); absolve.
dose: a quantity of medicine prescribed to be taken at one time.
justifiable: capable of being justified; that can be shown to be or can be defended as being just, right, or warranted; defensible: justifiable homicide.
bungle: to do clumsily and awkwardly; botch: He bungled the job.
lottery: a gambling game or method of raising money, as for some public charitable purpose, in which a large number of tickets are sold and a drawing is held for certain prizes.
highlander: a Gael inhabiting the Highlands of Scotland.
complicated: composed of elaborately interconnected parts; complex: complicated apparatus for measuring brain functions.
outlay: an expending or spending, as of money.
cutback: a reduction in rate, quantity, etc.: a cutback in production.
bunting: a coarse, open fabric of worsted or cotton for flags, signals, etc.
crossbill: any bird belonging to the genus Loxia, of the finch family, characterized by mandibles curved so that the tips cross each other when the bill is closed.
grosbeak: any of various finches having a thick, conical bill.
backhand: a stroke, slap, etc., made with the palm of the hand turned toward the body and the back of the hand turned in the direction of the stroke, slap, etc.
ration: a fixed allowance of provisions or food, especially for soldiers or sailors or for civilians during a shortage: a daily ration of meat and bread.
kiev: a city in and the capital of Ukraine, on the Dnieper River.
minsk: a city in and the capital of Byelorussia (Belarus), in the central part, on a tributary of the Berezina.
bohemian: a native or inhabitant of Bohemia.
moravian: pertaining to Moravia or its inhabitants.
czechoslovakia: a former republic in central Europe: formed after World War I; comprised Bohemia, Moravia, Slovakia, and part of Silesia: a federal republic 1968–92. 49,383 sq. mi. (127,903 sq. km). Capital:  Prague.
bratislava: the capital of Slovakia, in the SW part, on the Danube River: a former capital of Hungary.
ruthenian: Also, Ruthene  [roo-theen]  /ruˈθin/  (Show IPA). of or relating to the inhabitants of Ruthenia, Galicia, and neighboring regions.
croat: a native or inhabitant of Croatia; Croatian.
snarl: to growl threateningly or viciously, especially with a raised upper lip to bare the teeth, as a dog.
superheavy: Chemistry, Physics. pertaining to any of a series of elements having an atomic number greater than 103.
concise: expressing or covering much in few words; brief in form but comprehensive in scope; succinct; terse: a concise explanation of the company's retirement plan.
acton: a quilted garment worn under mail in the 13th and 14th centuries; gambeson.
penetration: the act or power of penetrating.
hatch: to bring forth (young) from the egg.
dethrone: to remove from a throne; depose.
eleusis: a city in ancient Greece, in Attica.
pluto: Classical Mythology. a name given to Hades, under which he is identified by the Romans with Orcus.
snack: a small portion of food or drink or a light meal, especially one eaten between regular meals.
chambered: having compartmental chambers: a spiral chambered seashell.
calyx: Botany. the outermost group of floral parts; the sepals.
whelk: any of several large, spiral-shelled, marine gastropods of the family Buccinidae, especially Buccinum undatum, that is used for food in Europe.
beige: very light brown, as of undyed wool; light gray with a brownish tinge.
amphibious: living or able to live both on land and in water; belonging to both land and water.
webbed: having the fingers or toes connected by a web or membrane: the webbed foot of a duck or beaver.
elektra: an electronic navigational system establishing approximate position through coincidence in amplitude of two radio signals.
ensure: to secure or guarantee: This letter will ensure you a hearing.
priestess: a woman who officiates in sacred rites.
trumpet: Next we'll learn that Armstrong never walked on the moon and couldn't play the trumpet.
whoops: (used to express surprise, mild embarrassment, etc., or as a casual apology.)
mycenaean: of or relating to the ancient city of Mycenae.
argos: an ancient city in SE Greece, on the Gulf of Argolis: a powerful rival of Sparta, Athens, and Corinth.
argolis: an ancient district in SE Greece.
anaxibia: a daughter of Atreus and Aërope, and the sister of Agamemnon and Menelaus.
thyestes: the brother of Atreus who unknowingly ate the flesh of his own sons when served to him by Atreus.
curse: the expression of a wish that misfortune, evil, doom, etc., befall a person, group, etc.
kidnap: to steal, carry off, or abduct by force or fraud, especially for use as a hostage or to extract ransom.
miraculous: performed by or involving a supernatural power or agency: a miraculous cure.
roam: to walk, go, or travel without a fixed purpose or direction; ramble; wander; rove: to roam about the world.
tourist: a person who is traveling, especially for pleasure.
allegory: a representation of an abstract or spiritual meaning through concrete or material forms; figurative treatment of one subject under the guise of another.
artwork: The artwork itself is gorgeous, but the fact that the exhibit exists in the first place is a bit of an anomaly––at least on paper.
exude: to come out gradually in drops, as sweat, through pores or small openings; ooze out.
parchment: the skin of sheep, goats, etc., prepared for use as a material on which to write.
whorl: a circular arrangement of like parts, as leaves or flowers, around a point on an axis; verticil.
filter: any substance, as cloth, paper, porous porcelain, or a layer of charcoal or sand, through which liquid or gas is passed to remove suspended impurities or to recover solids.
purposeless: having no purpose or apparent meaning.
facetious: not meant to be taken seriously or literally: a facetious remark.
waggish: like a wag; roguish in merriment and good humor; jocular: Fielding and Sterne are waggish writers.
birthrate: the proportion of births to the total population in a place in a given time, usually expressed as a quantity per 1000 of population.
eccentric: deviating from the recognized or customary character, practice, etc.; irregular; erratic; peculiar; odd: eccentric conduct; an eccentric person.
aureus: a gold coin and monetary unit of ancient Rome, from Caesar to Constantine I.
scavenge: to take or gather (something usable) from discarded material.
hunt: to chase or search for (game or other wild animals) for the purpose of catching or killing.
doglike: similar to a dog; having the appearance, traits, etc., of a dog.
effusive: unduly demonstrative; lacking reserve: effusive greetings; an effusive person.
uninhibited: not inhibited or restricted: uninhibited freedom to act.
lavish: expended, bestowed, or occurring in profusion: lavish spending.
fitful: coming, appearing, acting, etc., in fits or by spells; recurring irregularly.
raincoat: a waterproof or water-repellent coat worn as protection against rain.
overcoat: a coat worn over the ordinary indoor clothing, as in cold weather.
involucre: Botany. a collection or rosette of bracts subtending a flower cluster, umbel, or the like.
bland: pleasantly gentle or agreeable: a bland, affable manner.
suavity: a suave or smoothly agreeable quality.
sophisticated: (of a person, ideas, tastes, manners, etc.) altered by education, experience, etc., so as to be worldly-wise; not naive: a sophisticated young socialite; the sophisticated eye of an experienced journalist.
dx: distance (used especially to designate difficult shortwave reception).
intensify: to make intense or more intense.
sterile: free from living germs or microorganisms; aseptic: sterile surgical instruments.
maturity: the state of being mature; ripeness: The fruit will reach maturity in a few days.
armored: protected by armor or armor plate.
microbe: a microorganism, especially a pathogenic bacterium.
adsorb: to gather (a gas, liquid, or dissolved substance) on a surface in a condensed layer: Charcoal will adsorb gases.
occlude: to close, shut, or stop up (a passage, opening, etc.).
bibliography: a complete or selective list of works compiled upon some common principle, as authorship, subject, place of publication, or printer.
genitive: (in certain inflected languages) noting a case of nouns, pronouns, or adjectives, used primarily to express possession, measure, or origin: as John's hat, week's vacation, duty's call.
immaculate: free from spot or stain; spotlessly clean: immaculate linen.
insecure: subject to fears, doubts, etc.; not self-confident or assured: an insecure person.
tattered: torn to tatters; ragged: a tattered flag.
progression: the act of progressing; forward or onward movement.
quirk: a peculiarity of action, behavior, or personality; mannerism: He is full of strange quirks.
embarrass: to cause confusion and shame to; make uncomfortably self-conscious; disconcert; abash: His bad table manners embarrassed her.
theologian: a person versed in theology, especially Christian theology; divine.
reformation: the act of reforming; state of being reformed.
pretoria: a city in and the administrative capital of the Republic of South Africa, in the NE part: also the capital of Transvaal.
sarcasm: harsh or bitter derision or irony.
afferent: bringing to or leading toward an organ or part, as a nerve or arteriole (opposed to efferent).
ministerial: pertaining to the ministry of religion, or to a minister or other member of the clergy.
saucer: a small, round, shallow dish to hold a cup.
jellyfish: any of various marine coelenterates of a soft, gelatinous structure, especially one with an umbrellalike body and long, trailing tentacles; medusa.
unreasoning: not reasoning or exercising reason; reasonless; thoughtless; irrational: an unreasoning fanatic.
laughable: such as to cause laughter; funny; amusing; ludicrous.
superb: admirably fine or excellent; extremely good: a superb performance.
pyrenees: a mountain range between Spain and France. Highest peak, Pic de Néthou, 11,165 feet (3400 meters).
insurgent: a person who rises in forcible opposition to lawful authority, especially a person who engages in armed resistance to a government or to the execution of its laws; rebel.
craftsperson: a person who practices or is highly skilled in a craft; artisan.
photojournalism: journalism in which photography dominates written copy, as in certain magazines.
preposterous: completely contrary to nature, reason, or common sense; absurd; senseless; utterly foolish: a preposterous tale.
flatware: utensils, as knives, forks, and spoons, used at the table for serving and eating food.
congratulate: to express pleasure to (a person), as on a happy occasion: They congratulated him on his marriage.
amphitheater: an oval or round building with tiers of seats around a central open area, as those used in ancient Rome for gladiatorial contests.
gladiatorial: of or relating to gladiators or to their combats.
tier: one of a series of rows or ranks rising one behind or above another, as of seats in an amphitheater, boxes in a theater, guns in a man-of-war, or oars in an ancient galley.
plunge: to cast or thrust forcibly or suddenly into something, as a liquid, a penetrable substance, a place, etc.; immerse; submerge: to plunge a dagger into one's heart.
gusty: blowing or coming in gusts, as wind, rain, or storms.
merge: to cause to combine or coalesce; unite.
predispose: to give an inclination or tendency to beforehand; make susceptible: Genetic factors may predispose human beings to certain metabolic diseases.
optimistic: disposed to take a favorable view of events or conditions and to expect the most favorable outcome.
prayer: a devout petition to God or an object of worship.
rage: angry fury; violent anger (sometimes used in combination): a speech full of rage; incidents of road rage.
supercilious: haughtily disdainful or contemptuous, as a person or a facial expression.
vexed: irritated; annoyed: vexed at the slow salesclerks.
badger: any of various burrowing, carnivorous mammals of the family Mustelidae, as Taxidea taxus, of North America, and Meles meles, of Europe and Asia.
baltic: of, near, or on the Baltic Sea.
warsaw: Also called warsaw grouper. a large grouper, Epinephelus nigritus, found in the warmer waters of the Atlantic Ocean.
acquiesce: to assent tacitly; submit or comply silently or without protest; agree; consent: to acquiesce halfheartedly in a business plan.
optimism: a disposition or tendency to look on the more favorable side of events or conditions and to expect the most favorable outcome.
importunate: urgent or persistent in solicitation, sometimes annoyingly so.
trefoil: any of numerous plants belonging to the genus Trifolium, of the legume family, having usually digitate leaves of three leaflets and reddish, purple, yellow, or white flower heads, comprising the common clovers.
incapacitated: unable to act, respond, or the like (often used euphemistically when one is busy or otherwise occupied): He can't come to the phone now—he's incapacitated.
anonymous: without any name acknowledged, as that of author, contributor, or the like: an anonymous letter to the editor; an anonymous donation.
lumbar: of or relating to the loin or loins.
metatarsus: the part of a foot or hind limb, especially its bony structure, included between the tarsus and the toes or phalanges.
revenue: the income of a government from taxation, excise duties, customs, or other sources, appropriated to the payment of the public expenses.
paroxysm: any sudden, violent outburst; a fit of violent action or emotion: paroxysms of rage.
hydrochloride: a salt, especially of an alkaloid, formed by the direct union of hydrochloric acid with an organic base that makes the organic constituent more soluble.
hydrobromide: a salt formed by the direct union of hydrobromic acid and an organic base, especially an alkaloid, usually more soluble than the base.
insecticide: a substance or preparation used for killing insects.
narcotic: any of a class of substances that blunt the senses, as opium, morphine, belladonna, and alcohol, that in large quantities produce euphoria, stupor, or coma, that when used constantly can cause habituation or addiction, and that are used in medicine to relieve pain, cause sedation, and induce sleep.
addictive: producing or tending to cause addiction: an addictive drug.
opium: the dried, condensed juice of a poppy, Papaver somniferum, that has a narcotic, soporific, analgesic, and astringent effect and contains morphine, codeine, papaverine, and other alkaloids used in medicine in their isolated or derived forms: a narcotic substance, poisonous in large doses.
extraction: an act or instance of extracting: the extraction of a molar.
crystallization: the act or process of crystallizing.
colombia: a republic in NW South America. 439,828 sq. mi. (1,139,155 sq. km). Capital:  Bogotá.
venezuela: a republic in N South America. 352,143 sq. mi. (912,050 sq. km). Capital:  Caracas.
aconcagua: a mountain in W Argentina, in the Andes: the highest peak in the Western Hemisphere. 22,834 feet (6960 meters).
sweat: to perspire, especially freely or profusely.
dipterous: Entomology. belonging or pertaining to the order Diptera, comprising the houseflies, mosquitoes, and gnats, characterized by a single, anterior pair of membranous wings with the posterior pair reduced to small, knobbed structures.
parasite: an organism that lives on or in an organism of another species, known as the host, from the body of which it obtains nutriment.
stance: the position or bearing of the body while standing: legs spread in a wide stance; the threatening stance of the bull.
weedy: full of or abounding in weeds.
semifluid: imperfectly fluid; having both fluid and solid characteristics; semiliquid.
psychology: the science of the mind or of mental states and processes.
bribe: money or any other valuable consideration given or promised with a view to corrupting the behavior of a person, especially in that person's performance as an athlete, public official, etc.: The motorist offered the arresting officer a bribe to let him go.
immodest: not modest in conduct, utterance, etc.; indecent; shameless.
audacious: extremely bold or daring; recklessly brave; fearless: an audacious explorer.
apathetic: having or showing little or no emotion: apathetic behavior.
lascivious: inclined to lustfulness; wanton; lewd: a lascivious, girl-chasing old man.
libertine: a person who is morally or sexually unrestrained, especially a dissolute man; a profligate; rake.
lewd: inclined to, characterized by, or inciting to lust or lechery; lascivious.
prick: a puncture made by a needle, thorn, or the like.
truly: in accordance with fact or truth; truthfully.
amazed: greatly surprised; astounded; suddenly filled with wonder: The magician made the dove disappear before our amazed eyes.
ceaseless: without stop or pause; unending; incessant.
swear: to make a solemn declaration or affirmation by some sacred being or object, as a deity or the Bible.
quart: a unit of liquid measure of capacity, equal to one fourth of a gallon, or 57.749 cubic inches (0.946 liter) in the U.S. and 69.355 cubic inches (1.136 liters) in Great Britain.
unanimity: the state or quality of being unanimous; a consensus or undivided opinion: The unanimity of the delegates was obvious on the first ballot.
matrimonial: of or relating to matrimony; marital; nuptial; connubial; conjugal.
cenobite: a member of a religious order living in a convent or community.
chaste: refraining from sexual intercourse that is regarded as contrary to morality or religion; virtuous.
perpetrate: to commit: to perpetrate a crime.
laborious: requiring much work, exertion, or perseverance: a laborious undertaking.
battalion: Military. a ground force unit composed of a headquarters and two or more companies or similar units.
trivalent: Chemistry. having a valence of three.
axon: Cell Biology. the appendage of the neuron that transmits impulses away from the cell body.
goalkeeper: (in ice hockey, field hockey, lacrosse, soccer, etc.) a player whose chief duty is to prevent the ball or puck from crossing or entering the goal.
canon: an ecclesiastical rule or law enacted by a council or other competent authority and, in the Roman Catholic Church, approved by the pope.
cadence: rhythmic flow of a sequence of sounds or words: the cadence of language.
taps: a signal by bugle or drum, sounded at night as an order to extinguish all lights, and sometimes performed as a postlude to a military funeral.
parish: an ecclesiastical district having its own church and member of the clergy.
crest: the highest part of a hill or mountain range; summit.
clipped: characterized by quick, terse, and clear enunciation.
elisabeth: the mother of John the Baptist. Luke 1:5–25.
nomadic: of, relating to, or characteristic of nomads.
taxicab: a public passenger vehicle, especially an automobile, usually fitted with a taximeter.
abate: to reduce in amount, degree, intensity, etc.; lessen; diminish: to abate a tax; to abate one's enthusiasm.
clamor: a loud uproar, as from a crowd of people: the clamor of the crowd at the gates.
din: a loud, confused noise; a continued loud or tumultuous sound; noisy clamor.
juvenile: of, pertaining to, characteristic of, or suitable or intended for young persons: juvenile books.
disobedience: lack of obedience or refusal to comply; disregard or transgression.
antisocial: unwilling or unable to associate in a normal or friendly way with other people: He's not antisocial, just shy.
nigeria: a republic in W Africa: member of the Commonwealth of Nations; formerly a British colony and protectorate. 356,669 sq. mi. (923,773 sq. km). Capital:  Abuja.
sever: to separate (a part) from the whole, as by cutting or the like.
hatchet: a small, short-handled ax having the end of the head opposite the blade in the form of a hammer, made to be used with one hand.
spruce: any evergreen, coniferous tree of the genus Picea, of the pine family, having short, angular, needle-shaped leaves attached singly around twigs and bearing hanging cones with persistent scales.
invigorate: to give vigor to; fill with life and energy; energize.
rapacious: given to seizing for plunder or the satisfaction of greed.
miser: a person who lives in wretched circumstances in order to save and hoard money.
stingy: reluctant to give or spend; not generous; niggardly; penurious: He's a stingy old miser.
niggardly: reluctant to give or spend; stingy; miserly.
accumulation: act or state of accumulating; state of being accumulated.
guarded: cautious; careful; prudent: to be guarded in one's speech.
insidious: intended to entrap or beguile: an insidious plan.
spear: a long, stabbing weapon for thrusting or throwing, consisting of a wooden shaft to which a sharp-pointed head, as of iron or steel, is attached.
saponify: to convert (a fat) into soap by treating with an alkali.
radiator: a person or thing that radiates.
suppository: a solid, conical mass of medicinal substance that melts upon insertion into the rectum or vagina.
emollient: having the power of softening or relaxing, as a medicinal substance; soothing, especially to the skin: emollient lotions for the face.
mucin: any of a class of glycoproteins found in saliva, gastric juice, etc., that form viscous solutions and act as lubricants or protectants on external and internal surfaces of the body.
epithelium: any animal tissue that covers a surface, or lines a cavity or the like, and that, in addition, performs any of various secretory, transporting, or regulatory functions.
almond: the nutlike kernel of the fruit of either of two trees, Prunus dulcis (sweet almond) or P. dulcis amara (bitter almond) which grow in warm temperate regions.
phlegm: the thick mucus secreted in the respiratory passages and discharged through the mouth, especially that occurring in the lungs and throat passages, as during a cold.
actuate: to incite or move to action; impel; motivate: actuated by selfish motives.
korean: of or relating to Korea, its inhabitants, or their language.
ladle: a long-handled utensil with a cup-shaped bowl for dipping or conveying liquids.
bonus: something given or paid over and above what is due.
brigand: a bandit, especially one of a band of robbers in mountain or forest regions.
narwhal: a small arctic whale, Monodon monoceros, the male of which has a long, spirally twisted tusk extending forward from the upper jaw.
pachyderm: any of the thick-skinned, nonruminant ungulates, as the elephant, hippopotamus, and rhinoceros.
pharmacist: a person licensed to prepare and dispense drugs and medicines; druggist; apothecary; pharmaceutical chemist.
whipping: a beating or flogging, especially one administered with a whip or the like in punishment.
corrosive: having the quality of corroding or eating away; erosive.
fluorite: a common mineral, calcium fluoride, CaF 2 , occurring in green, blue, purple, yellow, or colorless crystals, usually in cubes: the principal source of fluorine, used also as a flux in metallurgy and for ornament.
cryolite: a mineral, sodium aluminum fluoride, Na 3 AlF 6 , occurring in white masses, used as a flux in the electrolytic production of aluminum.
chi: the twenty-second letter of the Greek alphabet (X, χ).
vietnam: Official name Socialist Republic of Vietnam. a country in SE Asia, comprising the former states of Annam, Tonkin, and Cochin-China: formerly part of French Indochina; divided into North Vietnam and South Vietnam during the Vietnam War but now reunified. 126,104 sq. mi. (326,609 sq. km). Capital:  Hanoi.
certified: having or proved by a certificate: a certified representative.
detract: to take away a part, as from quality, value, or reputation (usually followed by from).
seemly: fitting or becoming with respect to propriety or good taste; decent; decorous: Your outburst of rage was hardly seemly.
indecorous: not decorous; violating generally accepted standards of good taste or propriety; unseemly.
martin: any of several swallows having a deeply forked tail and long, pointed wings.
ottoman: of or relating to the Ottoman Empire.
ankara: a city in and the capital of Turkey, in the central part.
telepathy: communication between minds by some means other than sensory perception.
clairvoyance: the supernatural power of seeing objects or actions removed in space or time from natural viewing.
thrush: any of numerous, medium-sized songbirds of the family Turdinae, usually dull brown and often speckled below, and including many outstanding singers.
neoplasm: a new, often uncontrolled growth of abnormal tissue; tumor.
initiation: formal admission or acceptance into an organization or club, adult status in one's community or society, etc.
implicate: to show to be also involved, usually in an incriminating manner: to be implicated in a crime.
scattering: distributed or occurring here and there at irregular intervals; scattered.
profess: to lay claim to, often insincerely; pretend to: He professed extreme regret.
sussex: a former county in SE England: divided into East Sussex and West Sussex.
humanoid: having human characteristics or form; resembling human beings.
conceited: having an excessively favorable opinion of one's abilities, appearance, etc.
plankton: the aggregate of passively floating, drifting, or somewhat motile organisms occurring in a body of water, primarily comprising microscopic algae and protozoa.
intestinal: occurring in or affecting the intestines.
worldwide: extending or spread throughout the world.
cellular: pertaining to or characterized by cellules or cells, especially minute compartments or cavities.
workmanship: the art or skill of a workman or workwoman.
putrid: in a state of foul decay or decomposition, as animal or vegetable matter; rotten.
innocuous: not harmful or injurious; harmless: an innocuous home remedy.
halloween: the evening of October 31; the eve of All Saints' Day; Allhallows Eve: observed especially by children in costumes who solicit treats, often by threatening minor pranks.
prank: a trick of an amusing, playful, or sometimes malicious nature.
miscarry: to have a miscarriage of a fetus.
prod: to poke or jab with or as if with something pointed: I prodded him with my elbow.
dressmaker: a person whose occupation is the making or alteration of women's dresses, coats, etc.
infringement: a breach or infraction, as of a law, right, or obligation; violation; transgression.
exploit: a striking or notable deed; feat; spirited or heroic act: the exploits of Alexander the Great.
audio: Electronics. designating an electronic apparatus using audio frequencies: audio amplifier.
video: Capital Cities, "Kangaroo Court" This song has been around for a few weeks, but this video takes it to a whole new level.
lifetime: the time that the life of someone or something continues; the term of a life: peace within our lifetime.
infrequent: happening or occurring at long intervals or rarely: infrequent visits.
jetty: a pier or structure of stones, piles, or the like, projecting into the sea or other body of water to protect a harbor, deflect the current, etc.
tow: to pull or haul (a car, barge, trailer, etc.) by a rope, chain, or other device: The car was towed to the service station.
buckle: a clasp consisting of a rectangular or curved rim with one or more movable tongues, fixed to one end of a belt or strap, used for fastening to the other end of the same strap or to another strap.
pat: to strike lightly or gently with something flat, as with a paddle or the palm of the hand, usually in order to flatten, smooth, or shape: to pat dough into flat pastry forms.
resent: to feel or show displeasure or indignation at (a person, act, remark, etc.) from a sense of injury or insult.
haughty: disdainfully proud; snobbish; scornfully arrogant; supercilious: haughty aristocrats; a haughty salesclerk.
latticework: work consisting of crossed strips usually arranged in a diagonal pattern of open spaces.
stucco: an exterior finish for masonry or frame walls, usually composed of cement, sand, and hydrated lime mixed with water and laid on wet.
roofing: the act of covering with a roof.
dissociate: to sever the association of (oneself); separate: He tried to dissociate himself from the bigotry in his past.
beta: the second letter of the Greek alphabet (β, B).
pancreas: a gland, situated near the stomach, that secretes a digestive fluid into the intestine through one or more ducts and also secretes the hormone insulin.
thyroid: of or relating to the thyroid gland.
cork: the outer bark of an oak, Quercus suber, of Mediterranean countries, used for making stoppers for bottles, floats, etc.
wasp: any of numerous social or solitary hymenopterous insects of the Vespidae, Sphecidae, and allied families, generally having a long, slender body and narrow waist and, in the female, a stinger.
mongoose: a slender, ferretlike carnivore, Herpestes edwardsi, of India, that feeds on rodents, birds, and eggs, noted especially for its ability to kill cobras and other venomous snakes.
egyptian: of or relating to Egypt or its people: Egyptian architecture.
devour: to swallow or eat up hungrily, voraciously, or ravenously.
crocodile: any of several crocodilians of the genus Crocodylus, found in sluggish waters and swamps of the tropics.
sawfly: any of numerous hymenopterous insects of the family Tenthredinidae, the female of which has a sawlike ovipositor for inserting the eggs in the tissues of a host plant.
apis: a sacred bull worshiped at Memphis: identified originally with Ptah and later assimilated with Osiris to form the Ptolemaic Serapis.
outrageous: of the nature of or involving gross injury or wrong: an outrageous slander.
asleep: in or into a state of sleep: He fell asleep quickly.
falter: to hesitate or waver in action, purpose, intent, etc.; give way: Her courage did not falter at the prospect of hardship.
concussion: Pathology. injury to the brain or spinal cord due to jarring from a blow, fall, or the like.
joist: any of a number of small, parallel beams of timber, steel, reinforced concrete, etc., for supporting floors, ceilings, or the like.
chlorite: a group of minerals, hydrous silicates of aluminum, ferrous iron, and magnesium, occurring in green platelike crystals or scales.
epidote: a mineral, calcium aluminum iron silicate, Ca 2 (Al, Fe) 3 Si 3 O 12 (OH), occurring in green prismatic crystals.
indeterminate: not determinate; not precisely fixed in extent; indefinite; uncertain.
aerosol: Physical Chemistry. a system of colloidal particles dispersed in a gas; smoke or fog.
sol: the syllable used for the fifth tone of a diatonic scale.
raisin: a grape of any of various sweet varieties dried in the sun or by artificial means, often used in cookery.
levant: to leave secretly or hurriedly to avoid paying debts.
adroit: expert or nimble in the use of the hands or body.
clumsy: awkward in movement or action; without skill or grace: He is very clumsy and is always breaking things.
dexterity: skill or adroitness in using the hands or body; agility.
unhandy: not skillful in manual work: He's unhandy when it comes to fixing things around the house.
latent: present but not visible, apparent, or actualized; existing as potential: latent ability.
perennial: lasting for an indefinitely long time; enduring: her perennial beauty.
semiarid: characterized by very little annual rainfall, usually from 10 to 20 inches (25 to 50 cm): the struggle to raise vegetables in semiarid regions.
scoop: a ladle or ladlelike utensil, especially a small, deep-sided shovel with a short, horizontal handle, for taking up flour, sugar, etc.
segregate: to separate or set apart from others or from the main body or group; isolate: to segregate exceptional children; to segregate hardened criminals.
fundamentalism: (sometimes initial capital letter) a movement in American Protestantism that arose in the early part of the 20th century in reaction to modernism and that stresses the infallibility of the Bible not only in matters of faith and morals but also as a literal historical record, holding as essential to Christian faith belief in such doctrines as the creation of the world, the virgin birth, physical resurrection, atonement by the sacrificial death of Christ, and the Second Coming.
mining: the act, process, or industry of extracting ores, coal, etc., from mines.
purine: a white, crystalline compound, C 5 H 4 N 4 , from which is derived a group of compounds including uric acid, xanthine, and caffeine.
monosaccharide: a carbohydrate that does not hydrolyze, as glucose, fructose, or ribose, occurring naturally or obtained by the hydrolysis of glycosides or polysaccharides.
xylose: a colorless, crystalline pentose sugar, C 5 H 10 O 5 , derived from xylan, straw, corncobs, etc., by treating with heated dilute sulfuric acid, and dehydrating to furfural if stronger acid is used.
heterocyclic: of or relating to the branch of chemistry dealing with cyclic compounds in which at least one of the ring members is not a carbon atom (contrasted with homocyclic).
nimble: quick and light in movement; moving with ease; agile; active; rapid: nimble feet.
distort: to twist awry or out of shape; make crooked or deformed: Arthritis had distorted his fingers.
pretend: to cause or attempt to cause (what is not so) to seem so: to pretend illness; to pretend that nothing is wrong.
feign: to represent fictitiously; put on an appearance of: to feign sickness.
fineness: the state or quality of being fine.
cuff: a fold or band serving as a trimming or finish for the bottom of a sleeve.
cottage: a small house, usually of only one story.
proteose: any of a class of soluble compounds derived from proteins by the action of the gastric juices, pancreatic juices, etc.
peptone: any of a class of diffusible, soluble substances into which proteins are converted by partial hydrolysis.
mound: a natural elevation of earth; a hillock or knoll.
dike: an embankment for controlling or holding back the waters of the sea or a river: They built a temporary dike of sandbags to keep the river from flooding the town.
stow: Mrs. Ford would have politely told her critics to stow it, though she might have agreed with them on a thing or two.
sternpost: an upright member rising from the after end of a keel; a rudderpost or propeller post.
crossjack: the lowermost square sail set on the mizzenmast of a ship or of a bark with four or more masts; mizzen course.
spanker: spanker, in riding home full gallop the preceding day, had been thrown from her horse by an old woman.
authenticity: the quality of being authentic; genuineness.
fabled: celebrated in fables: a fabled goddess of the wood.
vengeance: infliction of injury, harm, humiliation, or the like, on a person by another who has been harmed by that person; violent revenge: But have you the right to vengeance?
argyle: (of knitted articles) having a diamond-shaped pattern in two or more colors.
fop: a man who is excessively vain and concerned about his dress, appearance, and manners.
shijiazhuang: a city in and the capital of Hebei province, in NE China, SW of Beijing.
phragmites: any of several tall grasses of the genus Phragmites, having plumed heads, growing in marshy areas, especially the common reed P. australis (or P. communis).
shuttle: a device in a loom for passing or shooting the weft thread through the shed from one side of the web to the other, usually consisting of a boat-shaped piece of wood containing a bobbin on which the weft thread is wound.
treadle: a lever or the like worked by continual action of the foot to impart motion to a machine.
semantics: How important are the semantics when it comes to talking about Hitler?
pragmatics: Logic, Philosophy. the branch of semiotics dealing with the causal and other relations between words, expressions, or symbols and their users.
seraph: one of the celestial beings hovering above God's throne in Isaiah's vision. Isa. 6.
dominion: the power or right of governing and controlling; sovereign authority.
principality: a state ruled by a prince, usually a relatively small state or a state that falls within a larger state such as an empire.
princedom: the position, rank, or dignity of a prince.
denote: to be a mark or sign of; indicate: A fever often denotes an infection.
truant: a student who stays away from school without permission.
occasionally: at times; from time to time; now and then.
rutabaga: a brassicaceous plant, Brassica napobrassica, having a yellow- or white-fleshed, edible tuber.
conidium: (in fungi) an asexual spore formed by abstriction at the top of a hyphal branch.
conjure: to affect or influence by or as if by invocation or spell.
zebedee: the father of the apostles James and John. Matt. 4:21.
nirvana: (often initial capital letter). Pali nibbana. Buddhism. freedom from the endless cycle of personal reincarnations, with their consequent suffering, as a result of the extinction of individual passion, hatred, and delusion: attained by the Arhat as his goal but postponed by the Bodhisattva.
dump: to drop or let fall in a mass; fling down or drop heavily or suddenly: Dump the topsoil here.
egoism: the habit of valuing everything only in reference to one's personal interest; selfishness (opposed to altruism).
prune: a variety of plum that dries without spoiling.
devastating: tending or threatening to devastate: a devastating fire.
aerial: of, in, or produced by the air: aerial currents.
daybreak: the first appearance of daylight in the morning; dawn.
nightfall: the coming of night; the end of daylight; dusk.
layout: an arrangement or plan: We objected to the layout of the house.
goblin: a grotesque sprite or elf that is mischievous or malicious toward people.
laugh: to express mirth, pleasure, derision, or nervousness with an audible, vocal expulsion of air from the lungs that can range from a loud burst of sound to a series of quiet chuckles and is usually accompanied by characteristic facial and bodily movements.
lessor: a person, group, etc., who grants a lease.
flee: to run away, as from danger or pursuers; take flight.
harris: Benjamin, c1660–c1720, English journalist who published the first newspaper in America 1690.
tolerable: capable of being tolerated; endurable: His arrogance is no longer tolerable.
insufferable: not to be endured; intolerable; unbearable: their insufferable insolence.
asset: a useful and desirable thing or quality: Organizational ability is an asset.
maximum: the greatest quantity or amount possible, assignable, allowable, etc.
cremate: to reduce (a dead body) to ashes by fire, especially as a funeral rite.
abcoulomb: Electricity. the centimeter-gram-second unit of quantity of electricity, equivalent to 10 coulombs.
dyne: the standard centimeter-gram-second unit of force, equal to the force that produces an acceleration of one centimeter per second per second on a mass of one gram. Abbreviation:  dyn.
maxwell: the centimeter-gram-second unit of magnetic flux, equal to the magnetic flux through one square centimeter normal to a magnetic field of one gauss. Abbreviation:  Mx.
weber: the standard unit of magnetic flux and magnetic pole strength in the International System of Units (SI), equal to a flux that produces an electromotive force of one volt in a single turn of wire when the flux is uniformly reduced to zero in a period of one second; 10 8 maxwells. Abbreviation:  Wb.
emergent: coming into view or notice; issuing.
sphincter: a circular band of voluntary or involuntary muscle that encircles an orifice of the body or one of its hollow organs.
francis: a male given name: from an Old French word meaning “Frenchman.”.
adret: a side of a mountain receiving direct sunlight.
dissension: strong disagreement; a contention or quarrel; discord.
argumentative: fond of or given to argument and dispute; disputatious; contentious: The law students were an unusually argumentative group.
classmate: a member of the same class at a school or college.
borough: (in certain states of the U.S.) an incorporated municipality smaller than a city.
observatory: a place or building equipped and used for making observations of astronomical, meteorological, or other natural phenomena, especially a place equipped with a powerful telescope for observing the planets and stars.
monotony: wearisome uniformity or lack of variety, as in occupation or scenery.
tedium: the quality or state of being wearisome; irksomeness; tediousness.
tiresome: causing or liable to cause a person to tire; wearisome: a tiresome job.
fortitude: mental and emotional strength in facing difficulty, adversity, danger, or temptation courageously: Never once did her fortitude waver during that long illness.
overcrowd: to crowd to an uncomfortable or undesirable excess.
clog: to hinder or obstruct with thick or sticky matter; choke up: to clog a drain.
celtic: a branch of the Indo-European family of languages, including especially Irish, Scots Gaelic, Welsh, and Breton, which survive now in Ireland, the Scottish Highlands, Wales, and Brittany. Abbreviation:  Celt.
manx: of or relating to the Isle of Man, its inhabitants, or their language.
goidelic: of or belonging to Goidelic; Q-Celtic.
subbranch: a subordinate branch or a branch of a branch, as of a bank, business, or the like.
psychotherapy: the treatment of psychological disorders or maladjustments by a professional technique, as psychoanalysis, group therapy, or behavioral therapy.
spray: water or other liquid broken up into minute droplets and blown, ejected into, or falling through the air.
curvilinear: consisting of or bounded by curved lines: a curvilinear figure.
tracery: ornamental work consisting of ramified ribs, bars, or the like, as in the upper part of a Gothic window, in panels, screens, etc.
vaulting: the act or process of constructing vaults.
stereotype: a process, now often replaced by more advanced methods, for making metal printing plates by taking a mold of composed type or the like in papier-mâché or other material and then taking from this mold a cast in type metal.
mingle: to become mixed, blended, or united.
cloak: a loose outer garment, as a cape or coat.
tactful: having or manifesting tact: a tactful person; a tactful reply.
cephalopod: any mollusk of the class Cephalopoda, having tentacles attached to the head, including the cuttlefish, squid, and octopus.
flute: a musical wind instrument consisting of a tube with a series of fingerholes or keys, in which the wind is directed against a sharp edge, either directly, as in the modern transverse flute, or through a flue, as in the recorder.
allotropic: pertaining to or characterized by allotropy.
pancake: a thin, flat cake of batter fried on both sides on a griddle or in a frying pan; griddlecake or flapjack.
protoplasm: Biology. (no longer in technical use) the colloidal and liquid substance of which cells are formed, excluding horny, chitinous, and other structural material; the cytoplasm and nucleus.
crossed: (of partial derivatives) mixed, especially of order two.
diagonal: The young man weaves through clusters of bamboo and cuts a diagonal slash into a tree, positioning a hollow log at the end.
microtubule: a hollow cylindrical structure in the cytoplasm of most cells, involved in intracellular shape and transport.
microfilament: a minute, narrow tubelike cell structure composed of a protein similar to actin, occurring singly and in bundles, involved in cytoplasmic movement and changes in cell shape.
mosul: a city in N Iraq, on the Tigris, opposite the ruins of Nineveh.
chaldean: one of an ancient Semitic people that formed the dominant element in Babylonia.
ur: an ancient Sumerian city on the Euphrates, in S Iraq: extensive excavations, especially of royal tombs.
uruk: an ancient Sumerian city in S Iraq, near the Euphrates, important before 2000 b.c.: exclusive archaeological excavations, notably of a ziggurat and of tablets with very early Sumerian script.
kish: a mixture of graphite and slag separated from and floating on the surface of molten pig iron or cast iron as it cools.
lagash: an ancient Sumerian city between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, at the modern village of Telloh in SE Iraq: a palace, statuary, and inscribed clay tablets unearthed here.
ethnic: pertaining to or characteristic of a people, especially a group (ethnic group) sharing a common and distinctive culture, religion, language, or the like.
predatory: Zoology. preying upon other organisms for food.
transistor: Electronics. a semiconductor device that amplifies, oscillates, or switches the flow of current between two terminals by varying the current or voltage between one of the terminals and a third: although much smaller in size than a vacuum tube, it performs similar functions without requiring current to heat a cathode.
paraguay: a republic in central South America between Bolivia, Brazil, and Argentina. 157,047 sq. mi. (406,750 sq. km). Capital:  Asunción.
exhortation: the act or process of exhorting.
inalienable: not alienable; not transferable to another or capable of being repudiated: inalienable rights.
smithereens: small pieces; bits: broken into smithereens.
jurist: a person versed in the law, as a judge, lawyer, or scholar.
germinate: to begin to grow or develop.
sage: a profoundly wise person; a person famed for wisdom.
lamented: mourned for, as a person who is dead: Our late lamented friend.
regrettable: causing or deserving regret; unfortunate; deplorable.
parting: the act of a person or thing that parts.
relic: a surviving memorial of something past.
scorpaenoid: resembling or related to the family Scorpaenidae.
boise: a city in and the capital of Idaho, in the SW part: built on the site of an army post on the Oregon Trail.
salem: a seaport in NE Massachusetts: founded 1626; execution of persons accused of being witches 1692; home of Nathaniel Hawthorne.
miscellaneous: consisting of members or elements of different kinds; of mixed character: a book of miscellaneous essays on American history.
loser: a person, team, nation, etc., that loses: The visiting team was the loser in the series.
intrusive: tending or apt to intrude; coming without invitation or welcome: intrusive memories of a lost love.
brash: impertinent; impudent; tactless: a brash young man.
incivility: the quality or condition of being uncivil; discourteous behavior or treatment.
disembody: to divest (a soul, spirit, etc.) of a body.
fleeting: passing swiftly; vanishing quickly; transient; transitory: fleeting beauty; a fleeting glance.
nightmare: a terrifying dream in which the dreamer experiences feelings of helplessness, extreme anxiety, sorrow, etc.
flutter: to wave, flap, or toss about: Banners fluttered in the breeze.
graver: any of various tools for chasing, engraving, etc., as a burin.
elective: pertaining to the principle of electing to an office, position, etc.
responsiveness: the quality or state of being responsive.
numb: deprived of physical sensation or the ability to move: fingers numb with cold.
excuse: to regard or judge with forgiveness or indulgence; pardon or forgive; overlook (a fault, error, etc.): Excuse his bad manners.
recondite: dealing with very profound, difficult, or abstruse subject matter: a recondite treatise.
airy: open to a free current of fresh air; breezy: airy rooms.
iberian: of or relating to Iberia in SW Europe, its inhabitants, or their language.
azores: a group of islands in the N Atlantic, W of Portugal: politically part of Portugal. 890 sq. mi. (2305 sq. km).
madeira: a group of eight islands off the NW coast of Africa, part of Portugal. 308 sq. mi. (798 sq. km). Capital:  Funchal.
lisbon: a seaport in and the capital of Portugal, in the SW part, on the Tagus estuary.
la: the syllable used for the sixth tone of a diatonic scale.
stale: not fresh; vapid or flat, as beverages; dry or hardened, as bread.
sophomore: a student in the second year of high school or college.
borders: a region in SE Scotland. 1804 sq. mi. (4671 sq. km).
hew: to strike forcibly with an ax, sword, or other cutting instrument; chop; hack.
tasmania: an island S of Australia: a state of the commonwealth of Australia. 26,382 sq. mi. (68,330 sq. km). Capital:  Hobart.
anteater: Compare giant anteater, silky anteater, tamandua.
sentimental: expressive of or appealing to sentiment, especially the tender emotions and feelings, as love, pity, or nostalgia: a sentimental song.
romantic: of, relating to, or of the nature of romance; characteristic or suggestive of the world of romance: a romantic adventure.
sung: a simple past tense and past participle of sing.
homosexual: Older Use: Sometimes Disparaging. sexually attracted to members of one's own sex: homosexual students.
inadequate: not adequate or sufficient; inept or unsuitable.
sentimentality: the quality or state of being sentimental or excessively sentimental.
von: from; of (used in German and Austrian personal names, originally to indicate place of origin and later to indicate nobility): Paul von Hindenburg.
accuser: a person who accuses, especially in a court of law: a trial in which the accuser and accused may freely speak.
hubcap: a removable cover for the center area of the exposed side of an automobile wheel, covering the axle.
exult: to show or feel a lively or triumphant joy; rejoice exceedingly; be highly elated or jubilant: They exulted over their victory.
prefigure: to show or represent beforehand by a figure or type; foreshadow.
presentiment: a feeling or impression that something is about to happen, especially something evil; foreboding.
insurrection: an act or instance of rising in revolt, rebellion, or resistance against civil authority or an established government.
raving: talking wildly; delirious; frenzied: a raving maniac.
lunatic: (no longer in technical use; now considered offensive) an insane person.
regurgitate: to surge or rush back, as liquids, gases, undigested food, etc.
reparable: capable of being repaired or remedied.
widower: a man who has lost his spouse by death and has not remarried.
categorical: without exceptions or conditions; absolute; unqualified and unconditional: a categorical denial.
escharotic: producing an eschar, as a medicinal substance; caustic.
mapping: the act or operation of making a map or maps.
inulin: a polysaccharide, (C 6 H 10 O 5) n , obtained from the roots of certain plants, especially elecampane, dahlia, and Jerusalem artichoke, that undergoes hydrolysis to the dextrorotatory form of fructose: used chiefly as an ingredient in diabetic bread, in processed foods to increase their fiber content, and as a reagent in diagnosing kidney function.
endoskeleton: the internal skeleton or framework of the body of an animal (opposed to exoskeleton).
literally: in the literal or strict sense: She failed to grasp the metaphor and interpreted the poem literally. What does the word mean literally?
lamarck: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet de
lobster: any of various large, edible, marine, usually dull-green, stalk-eyed decapod crustaceans of the family Homaridae, especially of the genus Homarus, having large, asymmetrical pincers on the first pair of legs, one used for crushing and the other for cutting and tearing: the shell turns bright red when cooked.
crab: any decapod crustacean of the suborder Brachyura, having the eyes on short stalks and a short, broad, more or less flattened body, the abdomen being small and folded under the thorax.
barnacle: any marine crustacean of the subclass Cirripedia, usually having a calcareous shell, being either stalked (goose barnacle) and attaching itself to ship bottoms and floating timber, or stalkless (rock barnacle or acorn barnacle) and attaching itself to rocks, especially in the intertidal zone.
louse: any small, wingless insect of the order Anoplura (sucking louse) parasitic on humans and other mammals and having mouthparts adapted for sucking, as Pediculus humanus (body louse or head louse) and Phthirius pubis (crab louse or pubic louse)
centipede: any of numerous predaceous, chiefly nocturnal arthropods constituting the class Chilopoda, having an elongated, flattened body composed of from 15 to 173 segments, each with a pair of legs, the first pair being modified into poison fangs.
millipede: any terrestrial arthropod of the class Diplopoda, having a cylindrical body composed of 20 to more than 100 segments, each with two pairs of legs.
overly: excessively; too: a voyage not overly dangerous.
repression: the act of repressing; state of being repressed.
buddha: Also called Butsu, Gautama, Gautama Buddha. (Prince Siddhāttha or Siddhartha) 566?–c480 b.c, Indian religious leader: founder of Buddhism.
burma: a republic in SE Asia, on the Bay of Bengal. 261,789 sq. mi. (678,034 sq. km). Capital:  Yangon.
halt: to stop; cease moving, operating, etc., either permanently or temporarily: They halted for lunch and strolled about.
eclecticism: the use or advocacy of an eclectic method.
beloved: greatly loved; dear to the heart.
loved: held in deep affection; cherished: loved companions; much-loved friends.
scalp: the integument of the upper part of the head, usually including the associated subcutaneous structures.
finest: the police: New York City's finest.
belittle: to regard or portray as less impressive or important than appearances indicate; depreciate; disparage.
depreciate: to reduce the purchasing value of (money).
sling: a device for hurling stones or other missiles that consists, typically, of a short strap with a long string at each end and that is operated by placing the missile in the strap, and, holding the ends of the strings in one hand, whirling the instrument around in a circle and releasing one of the strings to discharge the missile.
saud: (Saud ibn Abdul-Aziz), 1901?–69, king of Saudi Arabia 1953–64 (son of ibn-Saud and brother of Faisal).
danube: a river in central and SE Europe, flowing E from southern Germany to the Black Sea. 1725 miles (2775 km) long.
pest: an annoying or troublesome person, animal, or thing; nuisance.
entreat: to ask (a person) earnestly; beseech; implore; beg: to entreat the judge for mercy.
gabriel: one of the archangels, appearing usually as a divine messenger. Dan. 8:16, 9:21; Luke 1:19, 26.
imprudent: not prudent; lacking discretion; incautious; rash.
extemporize: to speak extemporaneously: He can extemporize on any of a number of subjects.
immigrate: to come to a country of which one is not a native, usually for permanent residence.
prop: to support, or prevent from falling, with or as if with a prop (often followed by up): to prop an old fence; to prop up an unpopular government.
balk: to stop, as at an obstacle, and refuse to proceed or to do something specified (usually followed by at): He balked at making the speech.
foiled: ornamented with foils, as a gable, spandrel, or balustrade.
tributary: a stream that flows to a larger stream or other body of water.
aboveboard: in open sight; without tricks, concealment, or disguise: Their actions are open and aboveboard.
canton: a small territorial district, especially one of the states of the Swiss confederation.
serbia: a republic in S Europe since 2006; includes the autonomous province of Vojvodina and claims sovereignty over the autonomous province of Kosovo, which has declared itself independent; formerly part of Yugoslavia, in the N part: a former kingdom in S Europe. 34,116 sq. mi. (88,360 sq. km). Capital:  Belgrade.
montenegro: a republic in S Europe since 2006: formerly a constituent republic of Yugoslavia, in the SW part (1918–2006); an independent kingdom 1878–1918. 6333 sq. mi. (13,812 sq. km). Capital:  Podgorica.
belgrade: a city in and the capital of Serbia, at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers.
historic: well-known or important in history: a historic building; historic occasions.
adriatic: of or relating to the Adriatic Sea.
concede: to acknowledge as true, just, or proper; admit: He finally conceded that she was right.
auspicious: promising success; propitious; opportune; favorable: an auspicious occasion.
mannerly: having or showing good manners; courteous; polite.
loosen: to unfasten or undo, as a bond or fetter.
clutch: to seize with or as with the hands or claws; snatch: The bird swooped down and clutched its prey with its claws.
disjoin: to undo or prevent the junction or union of; disunite; separate.
middelburg: a city in the SW Netherlands.
candid: frank; outspoken; open and sincere: a candid critic.
tablet: a number of sheets of writing paper, business forms, etc., fastened together at the edge; pad.
glare: a very harsh, bright, dazzling light: in the glare of sunlight.
chord: a feeling or emotion: His story struck a chord of pity in the listeners.
hinduism: the common religion of India, based upon the religion of the original Aryan settlers as expounded and evolved in the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Bhagavad-Gita, etc., having an extremely diversified character with many schools of philosophy and theology, many popular cults, and a large pantheon symbolizing the many attributes of a single god. Buddhism and Jainism are outside the Hindu tradition but are regarded as related religions.
erode: to eat into or away; destroy by slow consumption or disintegration: Battery acid had eroded the engine. Inflation erodes the value of our money.
silvia: a female given name: from a Latin word meaning “forest.”.
abandoned: forsaken or deserted: an abandoned building; an abandoned kitten.
shepherd: a person who herds, tends, and guards sheep.
babel: an ancient city in the land of Shinar in which the building of a tower (Tower of Babel) intended to reach heaven was begun and the confusion of the language of the people took place. Gen. 11:4–9.
photoelectric: pertaining to the electronic or other electric effects produced by light.
wreath: a circular band of flowers, foliage, or any ornamental work, for adorning the head or for any decorative purpose; a garland or chaplet.
festoon: a string or chain of flowers, foliage, ribbon, etc., suspended in a curve between two points.
postage: the charge for the conveyance of a letter or other matter sent by mail, usually prepaid by means of a stamp or stamps.
intestine: Usually, intestines. the lower part of the alimentary canal, extending from the pylorus to the anus.
pyre: a pile or heap of wood or other combustible material.
cycle: any complete round or series of occurrences that repeats or is repeated.
immortality: immortal condition or quality; unending life.
idealism: the cherishing or pursuit of high or noble principles, purposes, goals, etc.
metalloid: a nonmetal that in combination with a metal forms an alloy.
encumbrance: something that encumbers; something burdensome, useless, or superfluous; burden; hindrance: Poverty was a lifelong encumbrance.
disburden: to remove a burden from; rid of a burden.
mouse: any of numerous small Old World rodents of the family Muridae, especially of the genus Mus, introduced widely in other parts of the world.
ye: (used nominatively as the plural of thou especially in rhetorical, didactic, or poetic contexts, in addressing a group of persons or things): O ye of little faith; ye brooks and hills.
saliva: a viscid, watery fluid, secreted into the mouth by the salivary glands, that functions in the tasting, chewing, and swallowing of food, moistens the mouth, and starts the digestion of starches.
expectorate: to eject or expel matter, as phlegm, from the throat or lungs by coughing or hawking and spitting; spit.
flush: a blush; rosy glow: a flush of embarrassment on his face.
tap: to strike with a light but audible blow or blows; hit with repeated, slight blows: He tapped the door twice.
impetuous: of, relating to, or characterized by sudden or rash action, emotion, etc.; impulsive: an impetuous decision; an impetuous person.
trismus: a spasm of the jaw muscles that makes it difficult to open the mouth.
corynebacteria: rod-shaped bacteria of the genus Corynebacterium, many species of which are pathogenic.
strew: to let fall in separate pieces or particles over a surface; scatter or sprinkle: to strew seed in a garden bed.
prawn: any of various shrimplike decapod crustaceans of the genera Palaemon, Penaeus, etc., certain of which are used as food.
thomas: an apostle who demanded proof of Christ's Resurrection. John 20:24–29.
ruff: a neckpiece or collar of lace, lawn, or the like, gathered or drawn into deep, full, regular folds, worn in the 16th and 17th centuries.
hilla: a city in central Iraq, S of Baghdad.
boring: causing or marked by boredom: a boring discussion; to have a boring time.
strung: simple past tense and past participle of string.
effuse: to pour out or forth; shed; disseminate: The town effuses warmth and hospitality.
insulate: to cover, line, or separate with a material that prevents or reduces the passage, transfer, or leakage of heat, electricity, or sound: to insulate an electric wire with a rubber sheath; to insulate a coat with down.
picket: a post, stake, pale, or peg that is used in a fence or barrier, to fasten down a tent, etc.
crease: a ridge or groove produced in anything by folding, heat, pressure, etc.; fold; furrow.
zirconium: a metallic element found combined in zircon, baddeleyite, etc., resembling titanium chemically: used in steel metallurgy, as a scavenger, as a refractory, and as an opacifier in vitreous enamels. Symbol:  Zr; atomic weight:  91.22; atomic number:  40; specific gravity:  6.49 at 20°C.
momentary: lasting but a moment; very brief; fleeting: a momentary glimpse.
roe: the mass of eggs, or spawn, within the ovarian membrane of the female fish.
beluga: Also called hausen. a white sturgeon, Huso huso, of the Black and Caspian seas, valued as a source of caviar and isinglass.
appetizer: a small portion of a food or drink served before or at the beginning of a meal to stimulate the desire to eat.
ambiguity: doubtfulness or uncertainty of meaning or intention: to speak with ambiguity; an ambiguity of manner.
selectivity: the state or quality of being selective.
vindictive: disposed or inclined to revenge; vengeful: a vindictive person.
decapitate: to cut off the head of; behead: Many people were decapitated during the French Revolution.
tighten: to make or become tight or tighter.
strangulate: Pathology, Surgery. to compress or constrict (a duct, intestine, vessel, etc.) so as to prevent circulation or suppress function.
secretive: having or showing a disposition to secrecy; reticent: He seems secretive about his new job.
treacherous: characterized by faithlessness or readiness to betray trust; traitorous.
wainscot: wood, especially oak and usually in the form of paneling, for lining interior walls.
sunk: a simple past tense and past participle of sink.
gauge: to determine the exact dimensions, capacity, quantity, or force of; measure.
cheshire: Formerly Chester. a county in NW England. 899 sq. mi. (2328 sq. km).
symbiosis: A professional ballroom dancer and instructor, her name reflects a parallel that runs in both BDSM and dance: symbiosis.
vegetative: growing or developing as or like plants; vegetating.
corolla: the inner envelope of floral leaves of a flower, usually of delicate texture and of some color other than green; the petals considered collectively.
basement: a story of a building, partly or wholly underground.
neutrino: any of the massless or nearly massless electrically neutral leptons. There is a distinct kind of neutrino associated with each of the massive leptons.
antineutrino: the antiparticle of a neutrino, distinguished from the neutrino by having clockwise rather than counterclockwise spin when observing in the direction of motion.
conserve: to prevent injury, decay, waste, or loss of: Conserve your strength for the race.
naples: Italian Napoli. a seaport in SW Italy.
foodstuff: a substance used or capable of being used as nutriment.
lure: anything that attracts, entices, or allures.
ensnare: to capture in, or involve as in, a snare: to be ensnared by lies; to ensnare birds.
enchant: to subject to magical influence; bewitch: fairytales about witches who enchant handsome princes and beautiful maidens.
peer: a person of the same legal status: a jury of one's peers.
normandy: a region in N France along the English Channel: invaded and settled by Scandinavians in the 10th century, becoming a duchy in a.d. 911; later a province, the capital of which was Rouen; Allied invasion in World War II began here June 6, 1944.
persecute: to pursue with harassing or oppressive treatment, especially because of religious or political beliefs, ethnic or racial origin, gender identity, or sexual orientation.
interview: a formal meeting in which one or more persons question, consult, or evaluate another person: a job interview.
semite: a member of any of various ancient and modern peoples originating in southwestern Asia, including the Akkadians, Canaanites, Phoenicians, Hebrews, and Arabs.
ethiopia: Formerly Abyssinia. a republic in E Africa: formerly a monarchy. 409,266 sq. mi. (1,060,000 sq. km). Present boundaries include Eritrea. Capital:  Addis Ababa.
lebanon: a republic at the E end of the Mediterranean, N of Israel. 3927 sq. mi. (10,170 sq. km). Capital:  Beirut.
sultan: the sovereign of an Islamic country.
emir: a chieftain, prince, commander, or head of state in some Islamic countries.
rejoice: to be glad; take delight (often followed by in): to rejoice in another's happiness.
concurrent: occurring or existing simultaneously or side by side: concurrent attacks by land, sea, and air.
grieve: to feel grief or great sorrow: She has grieved over his death for nearly three years.
woeful: full of woe; wretched; unhappy: a woeful situation.
superlative: of the highest kind, quality, or order; surpassing all else or others; supreme; extreme: superlative wisdom.
apollo: the ancient Greek and Roman god of light, healing, music, poetry, prophecy, and manly beauty; the son of Leto and brother of Artemis.
fated: subject to, guided by, or predetermined by fate; destined.
laceration: the result of lacerating; a rough, jagged tear.
sanitary: of or relating to health or the conditions affecting health, especially with reference to cleanliness, precautions against disease, etc.
hypnosis: an artificially induced trance state resembling sleep, characterized by heightened susceptibility to suggestion.
hypnotism: the science dealing with the induction of hypnosis.
unbelievable: too dubious or improbable to be believed: an unbelievable excuse.
erg: the centimeter-gram-second unit of work or energy, equal to the work done by a force of one dyne when its point of application moves through a distance of one centimeter in the direction of the force; 10− 7 joule.
limitless: without limit; boundless: limitless ambition; limitless space.
disconcert: to disturb the self-possession of; perturb; ruffle: Her angry reply disconcerted me completely.
abash: to destroy the self-confidence, poise, or self-possession of; disconcert; make ashamed or embarrassed: to abash someone by sneering.
abominate: to regard with intense aversion or loathing; abhor.
outrage: an act of wanton cruelty or violence; any gross violation of law or decency.
eleanor: a female given name, form of Helen.
franklin: (in the 14th and 15th centuries) a freeholder who was not of noble birth.
turf: a layer of matted earth formed by grass and plant roots.
utah: a state in the W United States. 84,916 sq. mi. (219,930 sq. km). Capital:  Salt Lake City.
chronometer: a timepiece or timing device with a special mechanism for ensuring and adjusting its accuracy, for use in determining longitude at sea or for any purpose where very exact measurement of time is required.
aaron: the older brother of Moses, usually regarded as the first high priest of the Hebrews. Ex. 28; 40:13–16.
burr: Also, buhr. a protruding, ragged edge raised on the surface of metal during drilling, shearing, punching, or engraving.
knickerbocker: a descendant of the Dutch settlers of New York.
squirrel: any of numerous arboreal, bushy-tailed rodents of the genus Sciurus, of the family Sciuridae.
orion: Classical Mythology. a giant hunter who pursued the Pleiades, was eventually slain by Artemis, and was then placed in the sky as a constellation.
remonstrance: an act or instance of remonstrating.
unpopular: not popular; disliked or ignored by the public or by persons generally.
ingest: to take, as food, into the body (opposed to egest).
wheeze: to breathe with difficulty and with a whistling sound: Asthma caused him to wheeze.
fluidity: the quality or state of being fluid.
fecal: of, relating to, or being feces.
ravel: to disentangle or unravel the threads or fibers of (a woven or knitted fabric, rope, etc.).
pardon: kind indulgence, as in forgiveness of an offense or discourtesy or in tolerance of a distraction or inconvenience: I beg your pardon, but which way is Spruce Street?
absolve: to free from guilt or blame or their consequences: The court absolved her of guilt in his death.
defensible: capable of being defended against assault or injury: The troops were bivouacked in a defensible position.
homicide: the killing of one human being by another.
botch: to spoil by poor work; bungle (often followed by up): He botched up the job thoroughly.
highlands: (used with a singular verb) a mountainous region in N Scotland, N of the Grampians.
slap: a sharp blow or smack, especially with the open hand or with something flat.
dnieper: a river rising in the W Russian Federation flowing S through Byelorussia (Belarus) and Ukraine to the Black Sea. 1400 miles (2250 km) long.
berezina: a river in central Byelorussia (Belarus), flowing SE into the Dnieper River: costly crossing by Napoleon 1812. 350 miles (565 km) long.
bohemia: Czech Čechy. a region in the W Czech Republic: formerly a kingdom in central Europe; under Hapsburg rule 1526–1918. 20,101 sq. mi. (52,060 sq. km).
silesia: a lightweight, smoothly finished, twilled fabric of acetate, rayon, or cotton, for garment linings.
prague: a city in and the capital of the Czech Republic, in the W central part, on the Vltava: formerly capital of Czechoslovakia.
ruthenia: a former province in E Czechoslovakia.
galicia: a region in E central Europe: a former crown land of Austria, included in S Poland after World War I, and now partly in Ukraine. About 30,500 sq. mi. (79,000 sq. km).
serbian: of or relating to Serbia, its inhabitants, or their language.
croatian: of or relating to Croatia, its people, or their language.
growl: to utter a deep guttural sound of anger or hostility: The dog growled at the mail carrier.
succinct: expressed in few words; concise; terse.
embody: to give a concrete form to; express, personify, or exemplify in concrete form: to embody an idea in an allegorical painting.
quilted: resembling a quilt, as in texture, design, stitching, etc.
gambeson: a quilted garment worn under mail.
attica: a region in SE Greece, surrounding Athens: under Athenian rule in ancient times.
orcus: the ancient Roman god of the underworld, identified with the Greek Pluto, or Hades.
compartmental: divided into compartments: a compartmental office; a compartmental agency.
seashell: the shell of any marine mollusk.
surmount: to mount upon; get on the top of; mount upon and cross over: to surmount a hill.
floral: pertaining to or consisting of flowers: floral decoration.
incisor: any of the four anterior teeth in each jaw, used for cutting and gnawing.
avenge: to take vengeance or exact satisfaction for: to avenge a grave insult.
fury: unrestrained or violent anger, rage, passion, or the like: The gods unleashed their fury on the offending mortal.
coincidence: a striking occurrence of two or more events at one time apparently by mere chance: Our meeting in Venice was pure coincidence.
amplitude: the state or quality of being ample, especially as to breadth or width; largeness; greatness of extent.
diana: (Princess of Wales; Lady Diana Spencer) 1961–97, former wife of Charles, Prince of Wales.
armstrong: (Daniel) Louis ("Satchmo") 1900–71, U.S. jazz trumpeter and bandleader.
whistle: to make a clear musical sound, a series of such sounds, or a high-pitched, warbling sound by the forcible expulsion of the breath through a small opening formed by contracting the lips, or through the teeth, with the aid of the tongue.
corinth: an ancient city in Greece, on the Isthmus of Corinth: one of the wealthiest and most powerful of the ancient Greek cities.
doom: fate or destiny, especially adverse fate; unavoidable ill fortune: In exile and poverty, he met his doom.
hostage: a person given or held as security for the fulfillment of certain conditions or terms, promises, etc., by another.
ransom: the redemption of a prisoner, slave, or kidnapped person, of captured goods, etc., for a price.
ramble: to wander around in a leisurely, aimless manner: They rambled through the shops until closing time.
wander: to ramble without a definite purpose or objective; roam, rove, or stray: to wander over the earth.
rove: to wander about without definite destination; move hither and thither at random, especially over a wide area.
anomaly: a deviation from the common rule, type, arrangement, or form. Synonyms: abnormality, exception, peculiarity.
ooze: (of moisture, liquid, etc.) to flow, percolate, or exude slowly, as through holes or small openings.
verticil: a whorl or circle, as of leaves or hairs, arranged around a point on an axis.
crank: Machinery. any of several types of arms or levers for imparting rotary or oscillatory motion to a rotating shaft, one end of the crank being fixed to the shaft and the other end receiving reciprocating motion from a hand, connecting rod, etc.
whimsical: given to whimsy or fanciful notions; capricious: a pixyish, whimsical fellow.
