wag: to move from side to side, forward and backward, or up and down, especially rapidly and repeatedly: a dog wagging its tail.
roguish: pertaining to, characteristic of, or acting like a rogue; knavish or rascally.
merriment: cheerful or joyful gaiety; mirth; hilarity; laughter.
jocular: given to, characterized by, intended for, or suited to joking or jesting; waggish; facetious: jocular remarks about opera stars.
fielding: Henry, 1707–54, English novelist, dramatist, and essayist.
pampas: the vast grassy plains of southern South America, especially in Argentina.
savanna: a plain characterized by coarse grasses and scattered tree growth, especially on the margins of the tropics where the rainfall is seasonal, as in eastern Africa.
steppe: an extensive plain, especially one without trees.
buff: a soft, thick, light-yellow leather with a napped surface, originally made from buffalo skin but later also from other skins, used for making belts, pouches, etc.
abie: a male given name, form of Abraham.
inculcate: to implant by repeated statement or admonition; teach persistently and earnestly (usually followed by upon or in): to inculcate virtue in the young.
naive: having or showing unaffected simplicity of nature or absence of artificiality; unsophisticated; ingenuous.
medication: the use or application of medicine.
insensible: incapable of feeling or perceiving; deprived of sensation; unconscious, as a person after a violent blow.
gestate: to carry in the womb during the period from conception to delivery.
shortwave: Electricity. a radio wave, shorter than that used in AM broadcasting, corresponding to frequencies of over 1600 kilohertz: used for long-distance reception or transmission.
aseptic: free from the living germs of disease, fermentation, or putrefaction.
dehiscence: Biology. the release of materials by the splitting open of an organ or tissue.
ossify: to convert into or cause to harden like bone.
selective: having the function or power of selecting; making a selection.
authorship: origin, especially with reference to an author, creator, producer, etc., of a work: establishing the authorship of early medieval manuscripts.
peculiarity: a trait, manner, characteristic, or habit that is odd or unusual.
mannerism: a habitual or characteristic manner, mode, or way of doing something; distinctive quality or style, as in behavior or speech: He has an annoying mannerism of tapping his fingers while he talks. They copied his literary mannerisms but always lacked his ebullience.
reforming: Chemistry. the process of cracking low-octane petroleum fractions in order to increase the octane number.
reformed: amended by removal of faults, abuses, etc.
irony: the use of words to convey a meaning that is the opposite of its literal meaning: the irony of her reply, “How nice!” when I said I had to work all weekend.
arteriole: Anatomy. any of the smallest branches of an artery, terminating in capillaries.
efferent: conveying or conducting away from an organ or part (opposed to afferent).
priestly: of or relating to a priest; sacerdotal: priestly vestments.
impudent: of, relating to, or characterized by impertinence or effrontery: The student was kept late for impudent behavior.
gelatinous: having the nature of or resembling jelly, especially in consistency; jellylike.
reasonless: not having any reason or sense: an utterly reasonless display of anger.
fanatic: a person with an extreme and uncritical enthusiasm or zeal, as in religion or politics.
ludicrous: causing laughter because of absurdity; provoking or deserving derision; ridiculous; laughable: a ludicrous lack of efficiency.
oars: (used as a command to the crew of a scull or other similar boat to cease rowing and hold the oars horizontal with blades feathered.)
galley: a kitchen or an area with kitchen facilities in a ship, plane, or camper.
submerge: to put or sink below the surface of water or any other enveloping medium.
blowing: the sound of any vapor or gas issuing from a vent under pressure.
coalesce: to grow together or into one body: The two lakes coalesced into one.
supplicate: to pray humbly; make humble and earnest entreaty or petition.
devout: devoted to divine worship or service; pious; religious: a devout Catholic.
furious: full of fury, violent passion, or rage; extremely angry; enraged: He was furious about the accident.
disdainful: full of or showing disdain; scornful.
gibe: to utter mocking or scoffing words; jeer.
grouper: any of various sea basses of the family Serranidae, especially of the genera Epinephelus and Mycteroperca, of tropical and subtropical seas.
digitate: Zoology. having digits or digitlike processes.
contributor: a person who contributes money, assistance, etc.
coccyx: a small triangular bone forming the lower extremity of the spinal column in humans, consisting of four ankylosed rudimentary vertebrae.
excise: an internal tax or duty on certain commodities, as liquor or tobacco, levied on their manufacture, sale, or consumption within the country.
recur: to occur again, as an event, experience, etc.
hydrobromic: of or derived from hydrobromic acid.
belladonna: Also called deadly nightshade. a poisonous plant, Atropa belladonna, of the nightshade family, having purplish-red flowers and black berries.
euphoria: a state of intense happiness and self-confidence: She was flooded with euphoria as she went to the podium to receive her Student Research Award.
coma: a state of prolonged unconsciousness, including a lack of response to stimuli, from which it is impossible to rouse a person.
addiction: the state of being enslaved to a habit or practice or to something that is psychologically or physically habit-forming, as narcotics, to such an extent that its cessation causes severe trauma.
sedation: the calming of mental excitement or abatement of physiological function, especially by the administration of a drug.
soporific: causing or tending to cause sleep.
analgesic: a remedy that relieves or allays pain.
codeine: a white, crystalline, slightly bitter alkaloid, C 18 H 21 NO 3 , obtained from opium, used in medicine chiefly as an analgesic or sedative and to inhibit coughing.
papaverine: a white, crystalline, nonnarcotic, alkaloidal powder, C 2 0 H 2 1 NO 4 , obtained from opium, but not a morphine derivative and not habit-forming or addicting, used in the treatment of spasms of involuntary muscle, especially of the stomach, bronchi, and arteries.
molar: Also called molar tooth. a tooth having a broad biting surface adapted for grinding, being one of twelve in humans, with three on each side of the upper and lower jaws.
caracas: a city in and the capital of Venezuela, in the N part.
argentina: a republic in S South America. 1,084,120 sq. mi. (2,807,870 sq. km). Capital:  Buenos Aires.
indies: the. (used with a plural verb) West Indies (def 1).
perspire: to secrete a salty, watery fluid from the sweat glands of the skin, especially when very warm as a result of strenuous exertion; sweat.
diptera: the order comprising the dipterous insects.
vector: a quantity possessing both magnitude and direction, represented by an arrow the direction of which indicates the direction of the quantity and the length of which is proportional to the magnitude. Compare scalar (def 4).
tack: a short, sharp-pointed nail, usually with a flat, broad head.
motorist: a person who drives or travels in a privately owned automobile.
arresting: attracting or capable of attracting attention or interest; striking: an arresting smile.
indecent: offending against generally accepted standards of propriety or good taste; improper; vulgar: indecent jokes; indecent language; indecent behavior.
fearless: without fear; bold or brave; intrepid.
rake: an agricultural implement with teeth or tines for gathering cut grass, hay, or the like or for smoothing the surface of the ground.
lechery: unrestrained or excessive indulgence of sexual desire.
disappear: to cease to be seen; vanish from sight.
woo: to seek the favor, affection, or love of, especially with a view to marriage. Synonyms: court, pursue, chase.
pursuer: a person or thing that pursues.
consensus: majority of opinion: The consensus of the group was that they should meet twice a month.
ballot: a slip or sheet of paper, cardboard, or the like, on which a voter marks his or her vote.
nuptial: of or relating to marriage or the marriage ceremony: the nuptial day; nuptial vows.
connubial: of marriage or wedlock; matrimonial; conjugal: connubial love.
whiz: to make a humming, buzzing, or hissing sound, as an object passing swiftly through the air.
dendrite: These axon runners from one cell connect through synapses to dendrite runners on other cells.
lacrosse: a game, originated by Indians of North America, in which two 10-member teams attempt to send a small ball into each other's netted goal, each player being equipped with a crosse or stick at the end of which is a netted pocket for catching, carrying, or throwing the ball.
puck: Ice Hockey. a black disk of vulcanized rubber that is to be hit into the goal.
saintly: pertaining to, like, or befitting a saint: saintly lives.
godly: conforming to the laws and wishes of God; devout; pious.
untangle: to bring out of a tangled state; disentangle; unsnarl.
bugle: a brass wind instrument resembling a cornet and sometimes having keys or valves, used typically for sounding military signals.
brace: something that holds parts together or in place, as a clasp or clamp.
enunciation: an act or manner of enunciating.
douai: a city in N France, SE of Calais.
baptist: a member of a Christian denomination that baptizes believers by immersion and that is usually Calvinistic in doctrine.
turk: a native or inhabitant of Turkey.
caucasian: Anthropology. (no longer in technical use) of, relating to, or characteristic of one of the traditional racial divisions of humankind, marked by fair to dark skin, straight to tightly curled hair, and light to very dark eyes, and originally inhabiting Europe, parts of North Africa, western Asia, and India.
taximeter: a device fitted to a taxicab or other vehicle, for automatically computing and indicating the fare due.
adolescent: growing to manhood or womanhood; youthful.
gates: Horatio, 1728–1806, American Revolutionary general, born in England.
abuja: the capital of Nigeria, in the central part.
ballet: a classical dance form demanding grace and precision and employing formalized steps and gestures set in intricate, flowing patterns to create expression through movement.
yew: any of several evergreen, coniferous trees and shrubs of the genera Taxus and Torreya, constituting the family Taxaceae, of the Old World, North America, and Japan, having needlelike or scalelike foliage and seeds enclosed in a fleshy aril.
impurity: the quality or state of being impure.
energize: to give energy to; rouse into activity: to energize the spirit with brave words.
satiated: satisfied, as one's appetite or desire, to the point of boredom.
parsimonious: characterized by or showing parsimony; frugal or stingy.
entrap: to catch in or as in a trap; ensnare: The hunters used nets to entrap the lion.
insertion: the act of inserting: the insertion of a coin in a vending machine.
rectum: the comparatively straight, terminal section of the intestine, ending in the anus.
burly: large in bodily size; stout; sturdy.
balm: any of various oily, fragrant, resinous substances, often of medicinal value, exuding from certain plants, especially tropical trees of the genus Commiphora.
storax: a solid resin with a vanillalike odor, obtained from a small tree, Styrax officinalis: formerly used in medicine and perfumery.
candor: the state or quality of being frank, open, and sincere in speech or expression; candidness: The candor of the speech impressed the audience.
reservoir: a natural or artificial place where water is collected and stored for use, especially water for supplying a community, irrigating land, furnishing power, etc.
bandit: a robber, especially a member of a gang or marauding band.
monoceros: the Unicorn, a constellation south of Gemini and east of Orion.
hippopotamus: a large herbivorous mammal, Hippopotamus amphibius, having a thick hairless body, short legs, and a large head and muzzle, found in and near the rivers, lakes, etc., of Africa, and able to remain under water for a considerable time.
rhinoceros: any of several large, thick-skinned, perissodactyl mammals of the family Rhinocerotidae, of Africa and India, having one or two upright horns on the snout: all rhinoceroses are endangered.
artifact: any object made by human beings, especially with a view to subsequent use.
coincide: to occupy the same place in space, the same point or period in time, or the same relative position: The centers of concentric circles coincide. Our vacations coincided this year.
calibrate: to determine, check, or rectify the graduation of (any instrument giving quantitative measurements).
fungous: of, relating to, or caused by fungi; fungal.
dispense: to deal out; distribute: to dispense wisdom.
druggist: a person who compounds or prepares drugs according to medical prescriptions; apothecary; pharmacist; dispensing chemist.
whip: to beat with a strap, lash, rod, or the like, especially by way of punishment or chastisement; flog; thrash: Criminals used to be whipped for minor offenses.
fluoride: a salt of hydrofluoric acid consisting of two elements, one of which is fluorine, as sodium fluoride, NaF.
metallurgy: the technique or science of working or heating metals so as to give them certain desired shapes or properties.
alf: a male given name, form of Alfred.
annam: a former kingdom and French protectorate along the E coast of French Indochina: now part of Vietnam.
tonkin: a former state in N French Indochina, now part of Vietnam.
cochin: one of an Asian breed of chickens, resembling the Brahma but slightly smaller.
indochina: a peninsula in SE Asia, between the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea, comprising Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, W Malaysia, and Burma (Myanmar).
hanoi: a city in and the capital of Vietnam, in the N part, on the Songka River.
indurate: to make hard; harden, as rock, tissue, etc.: Cold indurates the soil.
decent: conforming to the recognized standard of propriety, good taste, modesty, etc., as in behavior or speech.
forked: having a fork or fork-like branches.
boast: to speak with exaggeration and excessive pride, especially about oneself.
toadstool: any of various mushrooms having a stalk with an umbrellalike cap, especially the agarics.
puffball: any of various basidiomycetous fungi, especially of the genus Lycoperdon and allied genera, characterized by a ball-like fruit body that emits a cloud of spores when broken.
morel: any edible mushroom of the genus Morchella, especially M. esculenta.
accompanist: Music. a person who plays an accompaniment.
ribosome: a tiny, somewhat mitten-shaped organelle occurring in great numbers in the cell cytoplasm either freely, in small clusters, or attached to the outer surfaces of endoplasmic reticula, and functioning as the site of protein manufacture.
workman: a man employed or skilled in some form of manual, mechanical, or industrial work.
incredible: so extraordinary as to seem impossible: incredible speed.
rotten: decomposing or decaying; putrid; tainted, foul, or bad-smelling.
clonus: a rapid succession of flexions and extensions of a group of muscles, usually signifying an affection of the brain or spinal cord.
sepal: one of the individual leaves or parts of the calyx of a flower.
october: the tenth month of the year, containing 31 days. Abbreviation:  Oct.
playful: full of play or fun; sportive; frolicsome.
amplifier: a person or thing that amplifies or enlarges.
kangaroo: any herbivorous marsupial of the family Macropodidae, of Australia and adjacent islands, having a small head, short forelimbs, powerful hind legs used for leaping, and a long, thick tail: several species are threatened or endangered.
stroll: to walk leisurely as inclination directs; ramble; saunter; take a walk: to stroll along the beach.
moor: a tract of open, peaty, wasteland, often overgrown with heath, common in high latitudes and altitudes where drainage is poor; heath.
barge: a capacious, flat-bottomed vessel, usually intended to be pushed or towed, for transporting freight or passengers; lighter.
paddle: a short, flat bladed oar for propelling and steering a canoe or small boat, usually held by both hands and moved more or less through a vertical arc.
salesclerk: a person who sells goods in a store.
slate: a fine-grained rock formed by the metamorphosis of clay, shale, etc., that tends to split along parallel cleavage planes, usually at an angle to the planes of stratification.
venetia: an ancient district in NE Italy: later a Roman province bounded by the Alps, the Po River, and the Adriatic Sea.
laguna: a bay, inlet, or other narrow or shallow body of water (often used in placenames).
cush: money, especially when reserved for some special use.
balkh: a town in N Afghanistan: capital of ancient Bactria; center of Zoroastrianism.
semen: the viscid, whitish fluid produced in the male reproductive organs, containing spermatozoa.
airship: a self-propelled, lighter-than-air aircraft with means of controlling the direction of flight; dirigible.
stinger: a person or thing that stings.
sluggish: indisposed to action or exertion; lacking in energy; lazy; indolent: a sluggish disposition.
ovipositor: (in certain female insects) an organ at the end of the abdomen, by which eggs are deposited.
memphis: a port in SW Tennessee, on the Mississippi.
ptah: an ancient Egyptian deity, believed to be a universal creator and sometimes identified with other gods: worshiped especially at Memphis when it was the royal residence.
osiris: the king and judge of the dead, the husband and brother of Isis, and father (or brother) of Horus, killed by Set but later resurrected (after Horus killed Set): usually depicted as a man, partly wrapped as a mummy, having a beard and wearing the atef-crown.
ptolemaic: of or relating to Ptolemy or his system of astronomy.
serapis: Also, Sarapis. a Greco-Egyptian deity combining the attributes of Osiris and Apis, identified in Egypt with the Ptolemies: later worshiped throughout the Greek and Roman empires.
waver: to sway to and fro; flutter: Foliage wavers in the breeze.
cripple: Offensive. a person who is disabled or impaired in any way: a mental cripple.
basalt: the dark, dense igneous rock of a lava flow or minor intrusion, composed essentially of labradorite and pyroxene and often displaying a columnar structure.
prismatic: of, relating to, or like a prism.
pedicel: The rudimentary ramus is only one seventh part longer than the pedicel which supports both it and the normal ramus.
alligator: either of two broad-snouted crocodilians of the genus Alligator, of the southeastern U.S. and eastern China.
caiman: any of several tropical American crocodilians of the genus Caiman and allied genera: some are endangered.
gavial: a large crocodilian, Gavialis gangeticus, of India and Pakistan, having elongated, garlike jaws: an endangered species.
unskilled: of or relating to workers who lack technical training or skill.
modernism: modern character, tendencies, or values; adherence to or sympathy with what is modern.
infallibility: Sometimes, infallibleness. the quality of being infallible, or of being absolutely trustworthy: He believed in the infallibility of his leadership.
resurrection: the act of rising from the dead.
assort: to distribute, place, or arrange according to kind or class; classify; sort.
gash: a long, deep wound or cut; slash.
xanthine: a crystalline, nitrogenous compound, C 5 H 4 N 4 O 2 , related to uric acid, occurring in urine, blood, and certain animal and vegetable tissues.
caffeine: a white, crystalline, bitter alkaloid, C 8 H 10 N 4 O 2 , usually derived from coffee or tea: used in medicine chiefly as a nervous system stimulant.
hydrolyze: to subject or be subjected to hydrolysis.
fructose: Chemistry, Pharmacology. a yellowish to white, crystalline, water-soluble, levorotatory ketose sugar, C 6 H 12 O 6 , sweeter than sucrose, occurring in invert sugar, honey, and a great many fruits: used in foodstuffs and in medicine chiefly in solution as an intravenous nutrient.
xylan: the pentosan occurring in woody tissue that hydrolyzes to xylose: used as a source of furfural.
furfural: a colorless, oily liquid, C 5 H 4 O 2 , having an aromatic odor, obtained from bran, sugar, wood, corncobs, or the like, by distillation: used chiefly in the manufacture of plastics and as a solvent in the refining of lubricating oils.
pentosan: any of a class of polysaccharides that occur in plants, humus, etc., and form pentoses upon hydrolysis.
cyclic: revolving or recurring in cycles; characterized by recurrence in cycles.
homocyclic: of or noting a cyclic compound having atoms of only one element, usually carbon, in the ring (contrasted with heterocyclic).
intercept: to take, seize, or halt (someone or something on the way from one place to another); cut off from an intended destination: to intercept a messenger.
awry: with a turn or twist to one side; askew: to glance or look awry.
distorted: not truly or completely representing the facts or reality; misrepresented; false: She has a distorted view of life.
dissimulate: to disguise or conceal under a false appearance; dissemble: to dissimulate one's true feelings about a rival.
dainty: of delicate beauty; exquisite: a dainty lace handkerchief.
episode: an incident in the course of a series of events, in a person's life or experience, etc.
dislocate: to put out of place; put out of proper relative position; displace: The glacier dislocated great stones. The earthquake dislocated several buildings.
knoll: a small, rounded hill or eminence; hillock.
ford: a place where a river or other body of water is shallow enough to be crossed by wading.
told: simple past tense and past participle of tell1 .
keel: Nautical. a central fore-and-aft structural member in the bottom of a hull, extending from the stem to the sternpost and having the floors or frames attached to it, usually at right angles: sometimes projecting from the bottom of the hull to provide stability.
mizzenmast: the third mast from forward in a vessel having three or more masts.
gallop: to ride a horse at a gallop; ride at full speed: They galloped off to meet their friends.
jig: Machinery. a plate, box, or open frame for holding work and for guiding a machine tool to the work, used especially for locating and spacing drilled holes; fixture.
emboss: to raise or represent (surface designs) in relief.
humiliation: an act or instance of humiliating or being humiliated.
plumed: having or appearing to have a plume or plumes.
bobbin: a reel, cylinder, or spool upon which yarn or thread is wound, as used in spinning, machine sewing, lacemaking, etc.
continual: of regular or frequent recurrence; often repeated; very frequent: continual bus departures.
semiotics: the study of signs and symbols as elements of communicative behavior; the analysis of systems of communication, as language, gestures, or clothing.
causal: of, constituting, or implying a cause.
isaiah: Also called Isaiah of Jerusalem. a Major Prophet of the 8th century b.c.
poultice: a soft, moist mass of cloth, bread, meal, herbs, etc., applied hot as a medicament to the body.
brassicaceous: belonging to the plant family Brassicaceae, an alternative name for the plant family Cruciferae.
abstriction: a method of spore formation in fungi in which successive portions of the sporophore are cut off through the growth of septa; abjunction.
invocation: the act of invoking or calling upon a deity, spirit, etc., for aid, protection, inspiration, or the like; supplication.
pali: (in Hawaii) a steep slope or cliff.
consequent: following as an effect or result; resulting (often followed by on, upon, or to): a fall in price consequent to a rise in production.
delusion: an act or instance of deluding.
topsoil: the fertile, upper part of the soil.
misapply: to make a wrong application or use of.
altruism: the principle or practice of unselfish concern for or devotion to the welfare of others (opposed to egoism).
clip: to cut, or cut off or out, as with shears: to clip a rose from a bush.
devastate: to lay waste; render desolate: The invaders devastated the city.
chickenpox: a disease, commonly of children, caused by the varicella zoster virus and characterized by mild headache and fever, malaise, and eruption of blisters on the skin and mucous membranes.
skipper: the master or captain of a vessel, especially of a small trading or fishing vessel.
dusk: the state or period of partial darkness between day and night; the dark part of twilight.
grotesque: odd or unnatural in shape, appearance, or character; fantastically ugly or absurd; bizarre.
grants: a town in W New Mexico.
endurable: capable of being endured; bearable; tolerable.
arrogance: offensive display of superiority or self-importance; overbearing pride.
mx: missile experimental: a ten-warhead U.S. intercontinental ballistic missile.
frenchman: a native or inhabitant of the French nation.
disputatious: fond of or given to disputation; argumentative; contentious: disputatious litigants.
contentious: tending to argument or strife; quarrelsome: a contentious crew.
meteorological: pertaining to meteorology or to phenomena of the atmosphere or weather.
wearisome: causing weariness; fatiguing: a difficult and wearisome march.
choke: to stop the breath of by squeezing or obstructing the windpipe; strangle; stifle.
breton: a native or inhabitant of Brittany.
brittany: a region in NW France, on a peninsula between the English Channel and the Bay of Biscay: a former duchy and province.
celt: an ax of stone or metal without perforations or grooves, for hafting.
stump: the lower end of a tree or plant left after the main part falls or is cut off; a standing tree trunk from which the upper part and branches have been removed.
psychoanalysis: a systematic structure of theories concerning the relation of conscious and unconscious psychological processes.
stonecutter: a person who cuts or carves stone.
glacier: an extended mass of ice formed from snow falling and accumulating over the years and moving very slowly, either descending from high mountains, as in valley glaciers, or moving outward from centers of accumulation, as in continental glaciers.
rocker: Also called runner. one of the curved pieces on which a cradle or a rocking chair, rocks.
cuttlefish: any of several cephalopods, especially of the genus Sepia, having eight arms with suckers and two tentacles, and ejecting a black, inklike fluid when in danger.
nautilus: Also called chambered nautilus, pearly nautilus. any cephalopod of the genus Nautilus, having a spiral, chambered shell with pearly septa.
recorder: a person who records, especially as an official duty.
allotropy: a property of certain elements, as carbon, sulfur, and phosphorus, of existing in two or more distinct forms; allomorphism.
screen: a movable or fixed device, usually consisting of a covered frame, that provides shelter, serves as a partition, etc.
griddlecake: a thin cake of batter cooked on a griddle; pancake.
bamboo: any of the woody or treelike tropical and semitropical grasses of the genera Bambusa, Phyllostachys, Dendrocalamus, and allied genera, having woody, usually hollow stems with stalked blades and flowering only after years of growth.
slash: to cut with a violent sweeping stroke or by striking violently and at random, as with a knife or sword.
actin: a globulin that is present in muscle plasma and that in connection with myosin plays an important role in muscle contraction.
elamite: a native or inhabitant of ancient Elam.
ziggurat: (among the ancient Babylonians and Assyrians) a temple of Sumerian origin in the form of a pyramidal tower, consisting of a number of stories and having about the outside a broad ascent winding round the structure, presenting the appearance of a series of terraces.
slag: Also called cinder. the more or less completely fused and vitrified matter separated during the reduction of a metal from its ore.
telloh: a village in SE Iraq, between the lower Tigris and Euphrates: site of the ancient Sumerian city of Lagash.
archaeology: the scientific study of historic or prehistoric peoples and their cultures by analysis of their artifacts, inscriptions, monuments, and other such remains, especially those that have been excavated.
voltage: electromotive force or potential difference expressed in volts.
bolivia: a republic in W South America. 404,388 sq. mi. (1,047,370 sq. km). Capitals:  La Paz and Sucre.
latinize: to cause to conform to the customs, traditions, beliefs, etc., of the Latins or the Latin Church.
alienable: capable of being sold or transferred.
kshatriya: a member of the Hindu royal and warrior class above the Vaisyas and below the Brahmans.
shudra: a Hindu of the lowest caste, that of the workers.
deplorable: causing or being a subject for grief or regret; lamentable: the deplorable death of a friend.
accused: charged with a crime, wrongdoing, fault, etc.: the accused boy.
hawthorne: Nathaniel, 1804–64, U.S. novelist and short-story writer.
intrude: to thrust or bring in without invitation, permission, or welcome.
mock: to attack or treat with ridicule, contempt, or derision.
itinerate: to go from place to place, especially in a regular circuit, as a preacher or judge.
sue: to institute a process in law against; bring a civil action against: to sue someone for damages.
divest: to strip of clothing, ornament, etc.: The wind divested the trees of their leaves.
vanish: to disappear from sight, especially quickly; become invisible: The frost vanished when the sun came out.
intrinsic: belonging to a thing by its very nature: the intrinsic value of a gold ring.
burin: a tempered steel rod, with a lozenge-shaped point and a rounded handle, used for engraving furrows in metal.
misdemeanor: Law. a criminal offense defined as less serious than a felony.
responsive: responding especially readily and sympathetically to appeals, efforts, influences, etc.: a responsive government.
intoxicant: an intoxicating agent, as alcoholic liquor or certain drugs.
accuse: to charge with the fault, offense, or crime (usually followed by of): He accused him of murder.
abstruse: hard to understand; recondite; esoteric: abstruse theories.
allusion: a passing or casual reference; an incidental mention of something, either directly or by implication: The novel's title is an allusion to Shakespeare.
iberia: Also called Iberian Peninsula. a peninsula in SW Europe, comprising Spain and Portugal.
funchal: a seaport in and the capital of the Madeira islands, on SE Madeira: winter resort.
tagus: a river in SW Europe, flowing W through central Spain and Portugal to the Atlantic at Lisbon. 566 miles (910 km) long.
hack: to cut, notch, slice, chop, or sever (something) with or as with heavy, irregular blows (often followed by up or down): to hack meat; to hack down trees.
tamandua: a tree-dwelling, tropical American anteater, Tamandua tetradactyla, having a prehensile tail, four-clawed forelimbs, and coarse, tan hair with black markings on the trunk.
nostalgia: a wistful desire to return in thought or in fact to a former time in one's life, to one's home or homeland, or to one's family and friends; a sentimental yearning for the happiness of a former place or time: a nostalgia for his college days.
romance: a novel or other prose narrative depicting heroic or marvelous deeds, pageantry, romantic exploits, etc., usually in a historical or imaginary setting.
adventure: an exciting or very unusual experience.
hum: to make a low, continuous, droning sound.
axle: Machinery. the pin, bar, shaft, or the like, on which or by means of which a wheel or pair of wheels rotates.
upheaval: strong or violent change or disturbance, as in a society: the upheaval of war.
delirious: Pathology. affected with or characteristic of delirium.
surge: a strong, wavelike, forward movement, rush, or sweep: the onward surge of an angry mob.
rectify: to make, put, or set right; remedy; correct: He sent them a check to rectify his account.
ravage: to work havoc upon; damage or mar by ravages: a face ravaged by grief.
faction: a group or clique within a larger group, party, government, organization, or the like: a faction in favor of big business.
eschar: a hard crust or scab, as from a burn.
chart: a sheet exhibiting information in tabular form.
elecampane: a composite weed, Inula helenium, naturalized in North America, having large yellow flowers and aromatic leaves and root.
dahlia: any composite plant of the genus Dahlia, native to Mexico and Central America and widely cultivated for its showy, variously colored flower heads.
artichoke: a tall, thistlelike composite plant, Cynara scolymus, native to the Mediterranean region, of which the numerous scalelike bracts and receptacle of the immature flower head are eaten as a vegetable.
diabetic: of or relating to diabetes or persons having diabetes.
acetal: Also called diethylacetal. a colorless, volatile, sparingly water-soluble liquid, C 6 H 14 O 2 , having a nutlike aftertaste, obtained from acetaldehyde and ethyl alcohol: used chiefly as a solvent and in the manufacture of perfumes.
pincers: a gripping tool consisting of two pivoted limbs forming a pair of jaws and a pair of handles (usually used with pair of).
subclass: a primary division of a class.
intertidal: of or relating to the littoral region that is above the low-water mark and below the high-water mark.
pubis: that part of either innominate bone that, with the corresponding part of the other, forms the front of the pelvis.
pubic: of, relating to, or situated near the pubes or the pubis.
siddhartha: an epithet of Buddha meaning “he who has attained his goal.”.
yangon: the capital of Burma (Myanmar), in the S part.
advocacy: the act of pleading for, supporting, or recommending; active espousal: He was known for his advocacy of states' rights.
eclectic: selecting or choosing from various sources.
animism: the belief that natural objects, natural phenomena, and the universe itself possess souls.
shaman: (especially among certain tribal peoples) a person who acts as intermediary between the natural and supernatural worlds, using magic to cure illness, foretell the future, control spiritual forces, etc.
subcutaneous: situated or lying under the skin, as tissue.
disparage: to speak of or treat slightingly; depreciate; belittle: Do not disparage good manners.
faisal: (Faisal Abdul-Aziz al Saud al Faisal) 1904–75, king of Saudi Arabia 1964–75 (son of ibn-Saud and brother of Saud).
beseech: to implore urgently: They besought him to go at once.
implore: to beg urgently or piteously, as for aid or mercy; beseech; entreat: They implored him to go.
beg: to ask for as a gift, as charity, or as a favor: to beg alms; to beg forgiveness.
sura: any of the 114 chapters of the Koran.
spandrel: Architecture. an area between the extradoses of two adjoining arches, or between the extrados of an arch and a perpendicular through the extrados at the springing line.
innovate: to introduce something new; make changes in anything established.
territorial: of or relating to territory or land.
swiss: of, pertaining to, associated with, or characteristic of Switzerland or its inhabitants.
wilhelm: a male given name, German form of William.
vojvodina: an autonomous province within Serbia. 8303 sq. mi. (21,506 sq. km). Capital:  Novi Sad.
kosovo: an autonomous province of Serbia, in the SW: chiefly Albanian in population since the 13th century; Serb suppression of separatists escalated to a policy of ethnic cleansing in 1998, provoking NATO airstrikes against Serbia in 1999 and takeover by UN administration; unilaterally declared independence in 2008. Mainly a plateau. Capital: Priština. Pop: 1 847 708 (2013 est). Area: 10 887 sq km (4203 sq miles) Full Serbian name Kosovo-Metohija (Serbian) (ˈkɔsɔvɔmɛˌtɔhija)
disband: to break up or dissolve (an organization): They disbanded the corporation.
sava: a river flowing E from W Slovenia, through Croatia to the Danube at Belgrade, Serbia. 450 miles (725 km) long.
propitious: presenting favorable conditions; favorable: propitious weather.
opportune: appropriate, favorable, or suitable: an opportune phrase for the occasion.
trifle: an article or thing of very little value.
undo: to reverse the doing of; cause to be as if never done: Murder once done can never be undone.
fetter: a chain or shackle placed on the feet.
snatch: to make a sudden effort to seize something, as with the hand; grab (usually followed by at).
joke: something said or done to provoke laughter or cause amusement, as a witticism, a short and amusing anecdote, or a prankish act: He tells very funny jokes. She played a joke on him.
thresh: to separate the grain or seeds from (a cereal plant or the like) by some mechanical means, as by beating with a flail or by the action of a threshing machine.
aryan: Ethnology. a member or descendant of the prehistoric people who spoke Indo-European.
pantheon: a domed circular temple at Rome, erected a.d. 120–124 by Hadrian, used as a church since a.d.
jainism: a dualistic religion founded in the 6th century b.c. as a revolt against current Hinduism and emphasizing the perfectibility of human nature and liberation of the soul, especially through asceticism and nonviolence toward all living creatures.
inflation: Economics. a persistent, substantial rise in the general level of prices related to an increase in the volume of money and resulting in the loss of value of currency (opposed to deflation).
deserted: abandoned; forsaken: the problems of deserted wives and children.
suckle: to nurse at the breast or udder.
shinar: a land mentioned in the Bible, often identified with Sumer.
bridegroom: a newly married man or a man about to be married.
chaplet: a wreath or garland for the head.
pylorus: the opening between the stomach and the duodenum.
immortal: not mortal; not liable or subject to death; undying: our immortal souls.
rebirth: a new or second birth: the rebirth of the soul.
superfluous: being more than is sufficient or required; excessive.
thou: Archaic (except in some elevated or ecclesiastical prose) the personal pronoun of the second person singular in the nominative case (used to denote the person or thing addressed): Thou shalt not kill.
rhetorical: used for, belonging to, or concerned with mere style or effect.
hawking: the sport of hunting with hawks or other birds of prey; falconry.
rooster: the male of domestic fowl and certain game birds; cock.
impulsive: actuated or swayed by emotional or involuntary impulses: an impulsive child.
karl: a male given name, form of Charles.
neckpiece: a scarf, especially one of fur.
boredom: the state of being bored; tedium; ennui.
rosary: On Wednesday mornings before mass, he recites the rosary in a special prayer of liberation from the chains of the devil.
disseminate: to scatter or spread widely, as though sowing seed; promulgate extensively; broadcast; disperse: to disseminate information about preventive medicine.
cathodic: pertaining to a cathode or phenomena in its vicinity.
undulation: an act of undulating; a wavelike motion.
zircon: a common mineral, zirconium silicate, ZrSiO 4 , occurring in small tetragonal crystals or grains of various colors, usually opaque: used as a refractory when opaque and as a gem when transparent.
baddeleyite: a mineral, zirconium oxide, ZrO 2 , used as a refractory.
titanium: a dark-gray or silvery, lustrous, very hard, light, corrosion-resistant, metallic element, occurring combined in various minerals: used in metallurgy to remove oxygen and nitrogen from steel and to toughen it. Symbol:  Ti; atomic weight:  47.90; atomic number:  22; specific gravity:  4.5 at 20°C.
scavenger: an animal or other organism that feeds on dead organic matter.
glimpse: a very brief, passing look, sight, or view.
spawn: Zoology. the mass of eggs deposited by fishes, amphibians, mollusks, crustaceans, etc.
ovarian: of or relating to an ovary.
wreck: any building, structure, or thing reduced to a state of ruin.
vengeful: desiring or seeking vengeance; vindictive: a vengeful attitude.
reticent: disposed to be silent or not to speak freely; reserved.
betray: to deliver or expose to an enemy by treachery or disloyalty: Benedict Arnold betrayed his country.
traitorous: having the character of a traitor; treacherous; perfidious.
paneling: wood or other material made into panels.
purr: to utter a low, continuous, murmuring sound expressive of contentment or pleasure, as a cat does.
massless: pertaining to an elementary particle having zero rest mass, as a photon.
clockwise: in the direction of the rotation of the hands of a clock as viewed from the front or above; circularly to the right from a point taken as the top.
counterclockwise: in a direction opposite to that of the normal rotation of the hands of a clock; not clockwise.
knead: to work (dough, clay, etc.) into a uniform mixture by pressing, folding, and stretching.
snare: a device, often consisting of a noose, for capturing small game.
bewitch: to affect by witchcraft or magic; cast a spell over.
northman: one of the ancient Scandinavians, especially a member of the group that from about the 8th to the 11th century made many raids and established settlements in Great Britain, Ireland, many parts of continental Europe, and probably in parts of North America.
scandinavian: of or relating to Scandinavia, its inhabitants, or their languages.
rouen: a city in and the capital of Seine-Maritime, in N France, on the Seine: famous cathedral; execution of Joan of Arc 1431.
eritrea: a republic in NE Africa, on the Red Sea: Italian colony 1890–1941; province of Ethiopia 1962–93; independent since 1993. 47,076 sq. mi. (121,927 sq. km). Capital:  Asmara.
beirut: a seaport in and the capital of Lebanon.
chieftain: the chief of a clan or a tribe.
culminate: to reach the highest point, summit, or highest development (usually followed by in).
whispered: rumored; reported: He is whispered to be planning to run for governor.
systematize: to arrange in or according to a system; reduce to a system; make systematic.
manly: having qualities traditionally ascribed to men, as strength or bravery.
leto: the mother by Zeus of Apollo and Artemis, called Latona by the Romans.
damned: condemned or doomed, especially to eternal punishment: the wailing of damned souls.
trance: a half-conscious state, seemingly between sleeping and waking, in which ability to function voluntarily may be suspended.
dubious: doubtful; marked by or occasioning doubt: a dubious reply.
ambition: an earnest desire for some type of achievement or distinction, as power, honor, fame, or wealth, and the willingness to strive for its attainment: Too much ambition caused him to be disliked by his colleagues.
ruffle: to destroy the smoothness or evenness of: The wind ruffled the sand.
disconcerted: disturbed, as in one's composure or self-possession; perturbed; ruffled: She was disconcerted by the sudden attack on her integrity.
poise: a state of balance or equilibrium, as from equality or equal distribution of weight; equipoise.
ashamed: feeling shame; distressed or embarrassed by feelings of guilt, foolishness, or disgrace: He felt ashamed for having spoken so cruelly.
decency: the state or quality of being decent.
timing: The timing that served Pastras so well that he swam in the 2004 Athens Olympics at the age of just 18 has deserted him.
shearing: (Sir) George Albert, 1919–2011, English jazz pianist and composer.
pleiades: Classical Mythology. seven daughters of Atlas and half sisters of the Hyades, placed among the stars to save them from the pursuit of Orion. One of them (the Lost Pleiad, ) hides, either from grief or shame.
eventually: finally; ultimately; at some later time: Eventually we will own the house free and clear.
egest: to discharge, as from the body; void (opposed to ingest).
asthma: Pathology. a paroxysmal, often allergic disorder of respiration, characterized by bronchospasm, wheezing, and difficulty in expiration, often accompanied by coughing and a feeling of constriction in the chest.
evacuation: the act or process of evacuating, or the condition of being evacuated; discharge or expulsion, as of contents.
disentangle: to free or become free from entanglement; untangle; extricate (often followed by from).
unravel: to separate or disentangle the threads of (a woven or knitted fabric, a rope, etc.).
benign: having a kindly disposition; gracious: a benign king.
inconvenience: the quality or state of being inconvenient.
grampians: The, (used with a plural verb) a range of low mountains in central Scotland, separating the Highlands from the Lowlands. Highest peak, Ben Nevis, 4406 feet (1343 meters).
smack: a taste or flavor, especially a slight flavor distinctive or suggestive of something: The chicken had just a smack of garlic.
hapsburg: a German princely family, prominent since the 13th century, that has furnished sovereigns to the Holy Roman Empire, Austria, Spain, etc.
vltava: a river in the W Czech Republic, flowing N to the Elbe. 270 miles (435 km) long.
ruthenium: a steel-gray, rare metallic element, belonging to the platinum group of metals. Symbol:  Ru; atomic weight:  101.07; atomic number:  44; specific gravity:  12.2 at 20°C.
guttural: of or relating to the throat.
quilt: a coverlet for a bed, made of two layers of fabric with some soft substance, as wool or down, between them and stitched in patterns or tufted through all thicknesses in order to prevent the filling from shifting.
stitching: the act of a person or thing that stitches.
underworld: the criminal element of human society.
gastropod: any mollusk of the class Gastropoda, comprising the snails, whelks, slugs, etc.
princess: a nonreigning female member of a royal family.
spencer: a short, close-fitting jacket, frequently trimmed with fur, worn in the 19th century by women and children.
officiate: to perform the office of a member of the clergy, as at a divine service.
daniel: the book of the Bible bearing his name. Abbreviation:  Dan.
bandleader: the leader of a musical band, especially a dance band.
unknowing: ignorant or unaware: unknowing aid to the enemy.
redemption: an act of redeeming or atoning for a fault or mistake, or the state of being redeemed.
kidnapped: a novel (1886) by Robert Louis Stevenson.
leisurely: acting, proceeding, or done without haste; unhurried; deliberate: a leisurely conversation.
stray: to deviate from the direct course, leave the proper place, or go beyond the proper limits, especially without a fixed course or purpose; ramble: to stray from the main road.
hither: to or toward this place: to come hither.
random: proceeding, made, or occurring without definite aim, reason, or pattern: the random selection of numbers.
abnormality: an abnormal condition, state, or quality; irregularity; deviation.
percolate: to cause (a liquid) to pass through a porous body; filter.
whimsy: capricious humor or disposition; extravagant, fanciful, or excessively playful expression: a play with lots of whimsy.
fanciful: characterized by or showing fancy; capricious or whimsical in appearance: a fanciful design of butterflies and flowers.
knavish: like or befitting a knave; untrustworthy; dishonest.
rascally: being, characteristic of, or befitting a rascal.
seasonal: pertaining to, dependent on, or accompanying the seasons of the year or some particular season; periodical: seasonal work.
unaffected: free from affectation; sincere; genuine: The man showed unaffected grief at the death of his former opponent.
ingenuous: free from reserve, restraint, or dissimulation; candid; sincere.
kilohertz: a unit of frequency, equal to 1000 cycles per second. Abbreviation:  kHz.
tatter: a torn piece hanging loose from the main part, as of a garment or flag.
octane: any of 18 isomeric saturated hydrocarbons having the formula C 8 H 1 8 , some of which are obtained in the distillation and cracking of petroleum.
effrontery: shameless or impudent boldness; barefaced audacity: She had the effrontery to ask for two free samples.
tentacle: Zoology. any of various slender, flexible processes or appendages in animals, especially invertebrates, that serve as organs of touch, prehension, etc.; feeler.
uncritical: not inclined or able to judge, especially by the application of comparative standards: an uncritical reader.
absurdity: the state or quality of being absurd.
efficiency: the state or quality of being efficient, or able to accomplish something with the least waste of time and effort; competency in performance.
gladiator: (in ancient Rome) a person, often a slave or captive, who was armed with a sword or other weapon and compelled to fight to the death in a public arena against another person or a wild animal, for the entertainment of the spectators.
caulk: to fill or close seams or crevices of (a tank, window, etc.) in order to make watertight, airtight, etc.
scull: an oar mounted on a fulcrum at the stern of a small boat and moved from side to side to propel the boat forward.
camper: a person who camps out for recreation, especially in the wilderness.
pray: to offer devout petition, praise, thanks, etc., to (God or an object of worship).
jeer: to speak or shout derisively; scoff or gibe rudely: Don't jeer unless you can do better.
halfhearted: having or showing little enthusiasm: a halfhearted attempt to work.
euphemism: the substitution of a mild, indirect, or vague expression for one thought to be offensive, harsh, or blunt.
podium: a small platform for the conductor of an orchestra, for a public speaker, etc.
trauma: It doesn't make you a better person because you endured the indignity and trauma of it.
alkaloidal: of, relating to, or derived from alkaloids.
strenuous: characterized by vigorous exertion, as action, efforts, life, etc.: a strenuous afternoon of hunting.
profuse: spending or giving freely and in large amount, often to excess; extravagant (often followed by in): profuse praise.
housefly: a medium-sized, gray-striped fly, Musca domestica, common around human habitations in nearly all parts of the world.
gnat: any of certain small flies, especially the biting gnats or punkies of the family Ceratopogonidae, the midges of the family Chironomidae, and the black flies of the family Simuliidae.
scalar: representable by position on a scale or line; having only magnitude: a scalar variable.
vulgar: characterized by ignorance of or lack of good breeding or taste: vulgar ostentation.
intrepid: resolutely fearless; dauntless: an intrepid explorer.
lustful: full of or motivated by lust, greed, or the like: He was an emperor lustful of power.
appetite: a desire for food or drink: I have no appetite for lunch today.
astound: to overwhelm with amazement; astonish greatly; shock with wonder or surprise.
crosse: a long-handled racket used in the game of lacrosse.
unsnarl: to bring out of a snarled condition; disentangle.
cornet: Music. a valved wind instrument of the trumpet family.
gutter: a channel at the side or in the middle of a road or street, for leading off surface water.
clamp: a device, usually of some rigid material, for strengthening or supporting objects or fastening them together.
calais: a seaport in N France, on the Strait of Dover: the French port nearest England.
nomad: a member of a people or tribe that has no permanent abode but moves about from place to place, usually seasonally and often following a traditional route or circuit according to the state of the pasturage or food supply.
manhood: the state or time of being a man or adult male person; male maturity.
womanhood: the state of being a woman; womanly character or qualities.
revolutionary: of, pertaining to, characterized by, or of the nature of a revolution, or a sudden, complete, or marked change: a revolutionary junta.
aril: a usually fleshy appendage or covering of certain seeds, as of the bittersweet, Celastrus scandens, or the nutmeg.
parsimony: extreme or excessive economy or frugality; stinginess; niggardliness.
relax: to make less tense, rigid, or firm; make lax: to relax the muscles.
glycoprotein: any of a group of complex proteins, as mucin, containing a carbohydrate combined with a simple protein.
protectant: a substance, as a chemical spray, that provides protection, as against insects, frost, rust, etc.; protective agent.
gang: a group or band: A gang of boys gathered around the winning pitcher.
marauding: engaged in raiding for plunder, especially roaming about and ravaging an area: marauding bands of outlaws.
unicorn: a mythical creature resembling a horse, with a single horn in the center of its forehead: often symbolic of chastity or purity.
hairless: without hair; bald: his pink hairless pate.
perissodactyl: having an uneven number of toes or digits on each foot.
graduation: an act of graduating; the state of being graduated.
quantitative: that is or may be estimated by quantity.
flog: to beat with a whip, stick, etc., especially as punishment; whip; scourge.
lash: the flexible part of a whip; the section of cord or the like forming the extremity of a whip.
chastisement: severe criticism; a rebuke or strong reprimand.
thrash: to beat soundly in punishment; flog.
hydrofluoric: of or derived from hydrofluoric acid.
cambodia: a republic in SE Asia: formerly part of French Indochina. 69,866 sq. mi. (180,953 sq. km). Capital:  Phnom Penh.
laos: a country in SE Asia: formerly part of French Indochina. 91,500 sq. mi. (236,985 sq. km). Capital:  Vientiane.
thailand: Formerly Siam. a kingdom in SE Asia: official name of Siam 1939–45 and since 1949. 198,242 sq. mi. (513,445 sq. km). Capital:  Bangkok.
malaysia: a constitutional monarchy in SE Asia: a federation, comprising the former British territories of Malaya, Sabah, and Sarawak: member of the Commonwealth of Nations. 126,310 sq. mi. (327,143 sq. km). Capital:  Kuala Lumpur.
myanmar: Union of, official name of Burma.
songka: a river in SE Asia, flowing SE from SW China through Indochina to the Gulf of Tonkin. 500 miles (800 km) long.
modesty: the quality of being modest; freedom from vanity, boastfulness, etc.
speckle: a small speck, spot, or mark, as on skin.
incriminate: to accuse of or present proof of a crime or fault: He incriminated both men to the grand jury.
exaggeration: the act of exaggerating or overstating.
basidiomycetous: belonging or pertaining to the basidiomycetes.
mitten: a hand covering enclosing the four fingers together and the thumb separately.
costume: a style of dress, including accessories and hairdos, especially that peculiar to a nation, region, group, or historical period.
sportive: playful or frolicsome; jesting, jocose, or merry: a sportive puppy.
marsupial: any viviparous, nonplacental mammal of the order Marsupialia, comprising the opossums, kangaroos, wombats, and bandicoots, the females of most species having a marsupium containing the mammary glands and serving as a receptacle for the young.
saunter: to walk with a leisurely gait; stroll: sauntering through the woods.
peaty: of, pertaining to, resembling, or containing the substance peat.
drainage: the act or process of draining.
capacious: capable of holding much; spacious or roomy: a capacious storage bin.
canoe: any of various slender, open boats, tapering to a point at both ends, propelled by paddles or sometimes sails and traditionally formed of light framework covered with bark, skins, or canvas, or formed from a dug-out or burned-out log or logs, and now usually made of aluminum, fiberglass, etc.
aristocrat: a member of an aristocracy, especially a noble.
stratification: the act or an instance of stratifying.
veneti: an ancient people of NE Italy absorbed by Rome after the Second Punic War.
reserved: kept or set apart for some particular use or purpose.
zoroastrianism: an Iranian religion, founded c600 b.c. by Zoroaster, the principal beliefs of which are in the existence of a supreme deity, Ahura Mazda, and in a cosmic struggle between a spirit of good, Spenta Mainyu, and a spirit of evil, Angra Mainyu.
stopper: a person or thing that stops.
cobra: any of several highly venomous, Old World elapid snakes of the genera Naja and Ophiophagus, characterized by the ability to flatten the neck into a hoodlike form when disturbed.
hungry: having a desire, craving, or need for food; feeling hunger.
voracious: craving or consuming large quantities of food: a voracious appetite.
ravenous: extremely hungry; famished; voracious: feeling ravenous after a hard day's work.
lazy: averse or disinclined to work, activity, or exertion; indolent.
indolent: having or showing a disposition to avoid exertion; slothful: an indolent person.
insert: to put or place in: to insert a key in a lock.
tennessee: a state in the SE United States. 42,246 sq. mi. (109,415 sq. km). Capital:  Nashville.
isis: a goddess of fertility, the sister and wife of Osiris and mother of Horus, and usually represented as a woman with a cow's horns with the solar disk between them: later worshiped in the Greek and Roman empires.
horus: a solar deity, regarded as either the son or the brother of Isis and Osiris, and usually represented as a falcon or as a man with the head of a falcon.
mummy: the dead body of a human being or animal preserved by the ancient Egyptian process or some similar method of embalming.
ptolemy: (Claudius Ptolemaeus) flourished a.d. 127–151, Hellenistic mathematician, astronomer, and geographer in Alexandria.
intrusion: an act or instance of intruding.
labradorite: a feldspar mineral of the plagioclase group, often characterized by a brilliant change of colors, with blue and green most common.
pyroxene: any of a very common group of minerals of many varieties, silicates of magnesium, iron, calcium, and other elements, occurring as important constituents of many kinds of rocks, especially basic igneous rocks.
ramus: a branch, as of a plant, vein, bone, etc.
sweetmeat: a sweet delicacy, prepared with sugar, honey, or the like, as preserves, candy, or, formerly, cakes or pastry.
actualize: to make actual or real; turn into action or fact.
infallible: absolutely trustworthy or sure: an infallible rule.
stimulant: Physiology, Medicine/Medical. something that temporarily quickens some vital process or the functional activity of some organ or part: Adrenalin is a stimulant for the heart.
ketose: a monosaccharide that contains a ketone group.
sucrose: a crystalline disaccharide, C 1 2 H 2 2 O 1 1 , the sugar obtained from the sugarcane, the sugar beet, and sorghum, and forming the greater part of maple sugar; sugar.
glycoside: any of the class of compounds that yield a sugar and an aglycon upon hydrolysis.
corncob: the elongated woody core in which the grains of an ear of corn are embedded.
bran: the partly ground husk of wheat or other grain, separated from flour meal by sifting.
askew: to one side; out of line; in a crooked position; awry: to wear one's hat askew; to hang a picture askew.
dissemble: to give a false or misleading appearance to; conceal the truth or real nature of: to dissemble one's incompetence in business.
exquisite: of special beauty or charm, or rare and appealing excellence, as a face, a flower, coloring, music, or poetry.
handkerchief: a small piece of linen, silk, or other fabric, usually square, and used especially for wiping one's nose, eyes, face, etc., or for decorative purposes.
sandbag: a bag filled with sand, used in fortification, as ballast, etc.
spacing: an act of someone or something that spaces.
fable: a short tale to teach a moral lesson, often with animals or inanimate objects as characters; apologue: the fable of the tortoise and the hare; Aesop's fables.
humiliating: lowering the pride, self-respect, or dignity of a person; mortifying: Such a humiliating defeat was good for his overblown ego.
reel: a cylinder, frame, or other device that turns on an axis and is used to wind up or pay out something.
spool: any cylindrical piece or device on which something is wound.
lacemaking: the art, act, or process of making, lace.
adolf: a male given name: from Germanic words meaning “noble” and “wolf.”.
hover: to hang fluttering or suspended in the air: The helicopter hovered over the building.
sporophore: a fungus hypha specialized to bear spores.
hypha: (in a fungus) one of the threadlike elements of the mycelium.
hawaii: a state of the United States comprising the N Pacific islands of Hawaii, Kahoolawe, Kauai, Lanai, Maui, Molokai, Niihau, and Oahu: a U.S. territory 1900–59; admitted to the Union 1959. 6424 sq. mi. (16,715 sq. km). Capital:  Honolulu.
reincarnation: the belief that the soul, upon death of the body, comes back to earth in another body or form.
desolate: barren or laid waste; devastated: a treeless, desolate landscape.
zoster: Also called herpes zoster. Pathology, shingles.
malaise: a condition of general bodily weakness or discomfort, often marking the onset of a disease.
bizarre: markedly unusual in appearance, style, or general character and often involving incongruous or unexpected elements; outrageously or whimsically strange; odd: bizarre clothing; bizarre behavior.
chuckle: to laugh softly or amusedly, usually with satisfaction: They chuckled at the child's efforts to walk.
bearable: capable of being endured or tolerated; endurable.
intercontinental: between or among continents; involving two or more continents: intercontinental trade.
meteorology: the science dealing with the atmosphere and its phenomena, including weather and climate.
irksome: annoying; irritating; exasperating; tiresome: irksome restrictions.
biscay: Bay of, a bay of the Atlantic between W France and N Spain.
ramify: to divide or spread out into branches or branchlike parts; extend into subdivisions.
sepia: a brown pigment obtained from the inklike secretion of various cuttlefish and used with brush or pen in drawing.
pearly: like a pearl, especially in being white or lustrous; nacreous: her pearly teeth.
allomorphism: variability in crystalline form without change in chemical constitution.
globulin: any of a group of proteins, as myosin, occurring in plant and animal tissue, insoluble in pure water but soluble in dilute salt solutions and coagulable by heat.
myosin: the principal contractile protein of muscle.
elam: an ancient kingdom E of Babylonia and N of the Persian Gulf. Capital:  Susa.
unearth: to dig or get out of the earth; dig up.
amplify: to make larger, greater, or stronger; enlarge; extend.
exhort: to urge, advise, or caution earnestly; admonish urgently.
caste: If races are our castes, then this makes sense, since—in a caste system—your status is mostly a function of your position.
darling: a person very dear to another; one dearly loved.
sweetheart: either of a pair of lovers in relation to the other.
bartholomew: one of the 12 apostles: sometimes called Nathanael. Mark 3:18.
tempered: having a temper or disposition of a specified character (usually used in combination): a good-tempered child.
lozenge: a small, flavored tablet made from sugar or syrup, often medicated, originally diamond-shaped.
intoxicating: causing or capable of causing intoxication: intoxicating beverages.
implication: something implied or suggested as naturally to be inferred or understood: to resent an implication of dishonesty.
tan: to convert (a hide) into leather, especially by soaking or steeping in a bath prepared from tanbark or synthetically.
pageantry: spectacular display; pomp: the pageantry of a coronation.
delirium: Pathology. a more or less temporary disorder of the mental faculties, as in fevers, disturbances of consciousness, or intoxication, characterized by restlessness, excitement, delusions, hallucinations, etc.
sweep: to move or remove (dust, dirt, etc.) with or as if with a broom, brush, or the like.
havoc: great destruction or devastation; ruinous damage.
clique: a small, exclusive group of people; coterie; set.
scab: the incrustation that forms over a sore or wound during healing.
helenium: any plant of the American genus Helenium, up to 1.6 m (5 ft) tall, some species of which are grown as border plants for their daisy-like yellow or variegated flowers: family Asteraceae
diabetes: any of several disorders characterized by increased urine production.
diagnose: to determine the identity of (a disease, illness, etc.) by a medical examination: The doctor diagnosed the illness as influenza.
aftertaste: a taste remaining after the substance causing it is no longer in the mouth.
acetaldehyde: a volatile, colorless, water-soluble liquid, C 2 H 4 O, having a pungent, fruitlike odor: used chiefly in the silvering of mirrors and in organic synthesis.
asymmetric: not identical on both sides of a central line; unsymmetrical; lacking symmetry: Most faces are asymmetric.
gripping: holding the attention or interest intensely; fascinating; enthralling: a gripping play; a gripping book.
littoral: of or relating to the shore of a lake, sea, or ocean.
mouthpart: Usually, mouthparts. the appendages surrounding or associated with the mouth of arthropods.
pubes: the lower part of the abdomen, especially the region between the right and left iliac regions.
fang: one of the long, sharp, hollow or grooved teeth of a venomous snake by which poison is injected.
epithet: any word or phrase applied to a person or thing to describe an actual or attributed quality: “Richard the Lion-Hearted” is an epithet of Richard I.
espousal: adoption or advocacy, as of a cause or principle.
craftsman: a person who practices or is highly skilled in a craft; artisan.
craftswoman: a woman who practices or is highly skilled in a craft; artisan.
whirl: to turn around, spin, or rotate rapidly: The merry-go-round whirled noisily.
besought: a simple past tense and past participle of beseech.
alms: money, food, or other donations given to the poor or needy; anything given as charity: The hands of the beggars were outstretched for alms.
extemporaneous: done, spoken, performed, etc., without special advance preparation; impromptu: an extemporaneous speech.
extrados: the exterior curve or surface of an arch or vault.
springing: the act or process of a person or thing that springs.
albanian: pertaining to Albania, its inhabitants, or their language.
nato: an organization formed in Washington, D.C. (1949), comprising the 12 nations of the Atlantic Pact together with Greece, Turkey, and the Federal Republic of Germany, for the purpose of collective defense against aggression.
takeover: the act of seizing, appropriating, or arrogating authority, control, management, etc.
plateau: a land area having a relatively level surface considerably raised above adjoining land on at least one side, and often cut by deep canyons.
undone: not done; not accomplished or completed.
shackle: a ring or other fastening, as of iron, for securing the wrist, ankle, etc.; fetter.
grab: to seize suddenly or quickly; snatch; clutch: He grabbed me by the collar.
swoop: to sweep through the air, as a bird or a bat, especially down upon prey.
prankish: of the nature of a prank: a prankish plan.
flail: an instrument for threshing grain, consisting of a staff or handle to one end of which is attached a freely swinging stick or bar.
ethnology: a branch of anthropology that analyzes cultures, especially in regard to their historical development and the similarities and dissimilarities between them.
expound: to set forth or state in detail: to expound theories.
veda: Sometimes, Vedas. the entire body of Hindu sacred writings, chief among which are four books, the Rig-Veda, the Sama-Veda, the Atharva-Veda, and the Yajur-Veda.
upanishad: any of a class of speculative prose treatises composed between the 8th and 6th centuries b.c. and first written a.d. c1300: they represent a philosophical development beyond the Vedas, having as their principal message the unity of Brahman and Atman.
cult: a particular system of religious worship, especially with reference to its rites and ceremonies.
domed: shaped like a dome: a domed forehead.
dualistic: of, relating to, or of the nature of dualism.
liberation: the act of liberating or the state of being liberated.
asceticism: the manner of life, practices, or principles of an ascetic.
nonviolence: absence or lack of violence; state or condition of avoiding violence.
deflation: the act of deflating or the state of being deflated.
forsake: to quit or leave entirely; abandon; desert: She has forsaken her country for an island in the South Pacific.
udder: a mamma or mammary gland, especially when baggy and with more than one teat, as in cows.
herd: a number of animals kept, feeding, or traveling together; drove; flock: a herd of cattle; a herd of sheep; a herd of zebras.
prepay: to pay or arrange to pay beforehand or before due: to prepay the loan.
duodenum: the first portion of the small intestine, from the stomach to the jejunum.
encumber: to impede or hinder; hamper; retard: Red tape encumbers all our attempts at action.
falconry: the sport of hunting with falcons, hawks, eagles, etc.; hawking.
ennui: a feeling of utter weariness and discontent resulting from satiety or lack of interest; boredom: The endless lecture produced an unbearable ennui.
mornings: in or during the morning regularly.
preventive: Medicine/Medical. of or noting a drug, vaccine, etc., for preventing disease; prophylactic.
tetragonal: pertaining to or having the form of a tetragon.
ti: the syllable for the seventh tone of a diatonic scale.
expiate: to atone for; make amends or reparation for: to expiate one's crimes.
treachery: violation of faith; betrayal of trust; treason.
disloyalty: the quality of being disloyal; lack of loyalty; unfaithfulness.
benedict: a newly married man, especially one who has been long a bachelor.
arnold: Benedict, 1741–1801, American general in the Revolutionary War who became a traitor.
traitor: a person who betrays another, a cause, or any trust.
perfidious: deliberately faithless; treacherous; deceitful: a perfidious lover.
vegetate: to grow in, or as in, the manner of a plant.
noose: a loop with a running knot, as in a snare, lasso, or hangman's halter, that tightens as the rope is pulled.
witchcraft: the art or practices of a witch; sorcery; magic.
maiden: a girl or young unmarried woman; maid.
scandinavia: Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and sometimes Finland, Iceland, and the Faeroe Islands.
seine: a fishing net that hangs vertically in the water, having floats at the upper edge and sinkers at the lower.
joan: ("Fair Maid of Kent") 1328–85, wife of Edward, the Black Prince, and mother of Richard II.
acclimate: to accustom or become accustomed to a new climate or environment; adapt.
canaanite: a member of a Semitic people that inhabited parts of ancient Palestine and were conquered by the Israelites and largely absorbed by them.
asmara: a city in and the capital of Eritrea, in N Ethiopia.
latona: the goddess Leto as identified in Roman mythology.
predetermine: to settle or decide in advance: He had predetermined his answer to the offer.
lacerate: to tear roughly; mangle: The barbed wire lacerated his hands.
cleanly: personally neat; careful to keep or make clean: The cat is by nature a cleanly animal.
precaution: a measure taken in advance to avert possible evil or to secure good results.
fame: widespread reputation, especially of a favorable character; renown; public eminence: to seek fame as an opera singer.
sneer: to smile, laugh, or contort the face in a manner that shows scorn or contempt: They sneered at his pretensions.
freehold: an estate in land, inherited or held for life.
pianist: a person who plays the piano, especially one who performs expertly or professionally.
hyades: Astronomy. a group of stars comprising a moving cluster in the constellation Taurus, supposed by the ancients to indicate the approach of rain when they rose with the sun.
remonstrate: to say or plead in protest, objection, or disapproval.
bronchospasm: spasmodic contraction of the muscular lining of the bronchi, as in asthma, causing difficulty in breathing.
expiration: a coming to an end; termination; close: the expiration of a contract.
extricate: to free or release from entanglement; disengage: to extricate someone from a dangerous situation.
inconvenient: not easily accessible or at hand: The phone is in an inconvenient place.
remit: to transmit or send (money, a check, etc.) to a person or place, usually in payment.
bivouac: a military encampment made with tents or improvised shelters, usually without shelter or protection from enemy fire.
ben: the inner or back room of a two-room cottage, especially when used as a combined parlor and bedroom.
princely: greatly liberal; lavish; magnificent: a princely entertainment.
elbe: a river in central Europe, flowing from the W Czech Republic NW through Germany to the North Sea. 725 miles (1165 km) long.
unleash: to release from or as if from a leash; set loose to pursue or run at will.
warble: to sing or whistle with trills, quavers, or melodic embellishments: The canary warbled most of the day.
ignorant: lacking in knowledge or training; unlearned: an ignorant man.
redeeming: offsetting or counterbalancing some fault, defect, or the like: a redeeming quality.
unhurried: not hurried; leisurely; deliberate: an unhurried day; an unhurried decision.
pixie: a fairy or sprite, especially a mischievous one.
knave: an unprincipled, untrustworthy, or dishonest person.
rascal: a base, dishonest, or unscrupulous person.
jest: a joke or witty remark; witticism.
affectation: an effort to appear to have a quality not really or fully possessed; the pretense of actual possession: an affectation of interest in art; affectation of great wealth.
artless: free from deceit, cunning, or craftiness; ingenuous: an artless child.
exuberance: Also, exuberancy. the state of being exuberant.
capillary: pertaining to or occurring in or as if in a tube of fine bore.
audacity: boldness or daring, especially with confident or arrogant disregard for personal safety, conventional thought, or other restrictions.
cnidarian: any invertebrate animal, as a hydra, jellyfish, sea anemone, or coral, considered as belonging to the phylum Cnidaria, characterized by the specialized stinging structures in the tentacles surrounding the mouth; a coelenterate.
feeler: a person or thing that feels.
watertight: constructed or fitted so tightly as to be impervious to water: The ship had six watertight compartments.
airtight: preventing the entrance or escape of air or gas.
fulcrum: the support, or point of rest, on which a lever turns in moving a body.
scoff: to speak derisively; mock; jeer (often followed by at): If you can't do any better, don't scoff. Their efforts toward a peaceful settlement are not to be scoffed at.
bass: low in pitch; of the lowest pitch or range: a bass voice; a bass instrument.
ankylose: to unite or grow together, as the bones of a joint or the root of a tooth and its surrounding bone.
orchestra: a group of performers on various musical instruments, including especially stringed instruments of the viol class, clarinets and flutes, cornets and trombones, drums, and cymbals, for playing music, as symphonies, operas, popular music, or other compositions.
habituate: to accustom (a person, the mind, etc.), as to a particular situation: Wealth habituated him to luxury.
enslave: to make a slave of; reduce to slavery: His drug addiction has completely enslaved him.
indignity: an injury to a person's dignity; slighting or contemptuous treatment; humiliating affront, insult, or injury.
addict: a person who is addicted to an activity, habit, or substance: a drug addict.
musca: the Fly, a small southern constellation between Crux and Chamaeleon.
ignorance: the state or fact of being ignorant; lack of knowledge, learning, information, etc.
ostentation: pretentious or conspicuous show, as of wealth or importance; display intended to impress others.
dauntless: not to be daunted or intimidated; fearless; intrepid; bold: a dauntless hero.
astonish: to fill with sudden and overpowering surprise or wonder; amaze: Her easy humor and keen intellect astonished me.
buzz: a low, vibrating, humming sound, as of bees, machinery, or people talking.
synapse: a region where nerve impulses are transmitted and received, encompassing the axon terminal of a neuron that releases neurotransmitters in response to an impulse, an extremely small gap across which the neurotransmitters travel, and the adjacent membrane of an axon, dendrite, or muscle or gland cell with the appropriate receptor molecules for picking up the neurotransmitters.
valved: having or furnished with valves: a valved trumpet.
dover: a seaport in E Kent, in SE England: point nearest the coast of France.
baptize: to immerse in water or sprinkle or pour water on in the Christian rite of baptism: They baptized the new baby.
automatic: having the capability of starting, operating, moving, etc., independently: an automatic sprinkler system; an automatic car wash.
womanly: like or befitting a woman; feminine; not masculine or girlish.
junta: a small group ruling a country, especially immediately after a coup d'état and before a legally constituted government has been instituted.
formalize: to make formal, especially for the sake of official or authorized acceptance: to formalize an understanding by drawing up a legal contract.
nutmeg: the hard, aromatic seed of the fruit of an East Indian tree, Myristica fragrans, used in grated form as a spice.
vend: to sell as one's business or occupation, especially by peddling: to vend flowers at a sidewalk stand.
lax: not strict or severe; careless or negligent: lax morals; a lax attitude toward discipline.
pate: the crown or top of the head.
prescription: the medicine prescribed: Take this prescription three times a day.
scourge: a whip or lash, especially for the infliction of punishment or torture.
vientiane: a city in and the capital of Laos, on the Mekong River, in the NW part.
bangkok: a seaport in and the capital of Thailand, in the S central part, on the Chao Phraya.
sabah: a state in Malaysia, on the N tip of Borneo: formerly a British crown colony. 29,347 sq. mi. (76,008 sq. km). Capital:  Kota Kinabalu.
sarawak: a state in the federation of Malaysia, on NW Borneo: formerly a British crown colony (1946–63) and British protectorate (1888–1946). About 50,000 sq. mi. (129,500 sq. km). Capital:  Kuching.
agaric: any fungus of the family Agaricaceae, including several common edible mushrooms.
reticulum: a network; any reticulated system or structure.
flexion: Fractures are most common in the lumbar region, where flexion is most restricted.
jocose: given to or characterized by joking; jesting; humorous; playful: a jocose and amusing manner.
puppy: a young dog, especially one less than a year old.
merrily: a female given name, form of Merry.
marsupium: the pouch or fold of skin on the abdomen of a female marsupial.
gait: a manner of walking, stepping, or running.
spacious: containing much space, as a house, room, or vehicle; amply large.
bin: a box or enclosed place for storing grain, coal, or the like.
dug: a simple past tense and past participle of dig1. and dig2 .
fiberglass: a material consisting of extremely fine filaments of glass that are combined in yarn and woven into fabrics, used in masses as a thermal and acoustical insulator, or embedded in various resins to make boat hulls, fishing rods, and the like.
aristocracy: a class of persons holding exceptional rank and privileges, especially the hereditary nobility.
absorbed: deeply interested or involved; preoccupied: He had an absorbed look on his face.
punic: of or relating to the ancient Carthaginians.
