placename: the name given to or held by a geographical location, as a town, city, village, etc.
iranian: of or relating to Iran, its inhabitants, or their language.
zoroaster: flourished 6th century b.c, Persian religious teacher.
ahura: generic title for benevolent deities in Zoroastrianism or evil deities in Hinduism.
spermatozoon: one of the minute, usually actively motile gametes in semen, which serve to fertilize the ovum; a mature male reproductive cell.
elapid: any of numerous cosmopolitan snakes of the family Elapidae, having permanently erect fangs in the front of the upper jaw and including the New World coral snakes, the cobras, and most Australian snakes.
famished: extremely hungry: to be famished after a hike; famished, homeless multitudes.
nashville: a city in and the capital of Tennessee, in the central part: battle 1864.
falcon: any of several birds of prey of the family Falconidae, especially of the genus Falco, usually distinguished by long, pointed wings, a hooked beak with a toothlike notch on each side of the upper bill, and swift, agile flight, typically diving to seize prey: some falcon species are close to extinction.
resurrect: to raise from the dead; bring to life again.
claudius: Appius  [ap-ee-uh s]  /ˈæp i əs/  (Show IPA), (Appius Claudius Crassus) Roman decemvir and consul, 5th cent. b.c.
ptolemaeus: a walled plain in the third quadrant of the face of the moon: about 90 miles (144 km) in diameter.
mathematician: an expert or specialist in mathematics.
astronomer: an expert in astronomy; a scientific observer of the celestial bodies.
geographer: a person who specializes in geographical research, delineation, and study.
alexandria: Arabic Al-Iskandarîyah. a seaport in N Egypt, in the Nile delta: founded in 332 b.c. by Alexander the Great; ancient center of learning.
plagioclase: any of the feldspar minerals varying in composition from acidic albite, NaAlSi 3 O 8 , to basic anorthite, CaAl 2 Si 2 O 8 , found in most igneous rocks: shows twinning striations on good cleavage surfaces.
disaccharide: any of a group of carbohydrates, as sucrose or lactose, that yield monosaccharides on hydrolysis.
sugarcane: a tall grass, Saccharum officinarum, of tropical and warm regions, having a stout, jointed stalk, and constituting the chief source of sugar.
aglycon: a noncarbohydrate group, usually an alcohol or phenol, combined with a sugar to form a glycoside.
misrepresent: to represent incorrectly, improperly, or falsely.
ballast: Nautical. any heavy material carried temporarily or permanently in a vessel to provide desired draft and stability.
wade: to walk in water, when partially immersed: He wasn't swimming, he was wading.
apologue: a didactic narrative; a moral fable.
tortoise: a turtle, especially a terrestrial turtle.
aesop: c620–c560 b.c, Greek writer of fables.
lowering: dark and threatening, as the sky, clouds, or weather; overcast; gloomy: lowering skies.
ego: the “I” or self of any person; a person as thinking, feeling, and willing, and distinguishing itself from the selves of others and from objects of its thought.
septum: a dividing wall, membrane, or the like, in a plant or animal structure; dissepiment.
mycelium: the mass of hyphae that form the vegetative part of a fungus.
invoke: to call for with earnest desire; make supplication or pray for: to invoke God's mercy.
kahoolawe: an island in central Hawaii, S of Maui: uninhabited. 45 sq. mi. (117 sq. km).
kauai: an island in NW Hawaii. 511 sq. mi. (1325 sq. km).
lanai: a veranda, especially a fully furnished one used as a living room.
maui: an island in central Hawaii. 728 sq. mi. (1886 sq. km).
molokai: an island in central Hawaii: leper colony. 259 sq. mi. (670 sq. km).
niihau: an island in NW Hawaii, W of Kauai. 72 sq. mi. (186 sq. km).
oahu: an island in central Hawaii: third largest and most important island of the state; location of Honolulu. 589 sq. mi. (1525 sq. km).
honolulu: a seaport in and the capital of Hawaii, on S Oahu.
herpes: Compare chickenpox, genital herpes, oral herpes, shingles.
blister: a thin vesicle on the skin, containing watery matter or serum, as from a burn or other injury.
fantastic: conceived or appearing as if conceived by an unrestrained imagination; odd and remarkable; bizarre; grotesque: fantastic rock formations; fantastic designs.
ballistics: the science or study of the motion of projectiles, as bullets, shells, or bombs.
litigant: a person engaged in a lawsuit.
haft: a handle, especially of a knife, sword, or dagger.
unsatisfactory: not satisfactory; not satisfying or meeting one's demands; inadequate.
susa: a ruined city in W Iran: the capital of ancient Elam; palaces of Darius and Artaxerxes I; stele containing the Code of Hammurabi discovered here.
assyrian: of or relating to Assyria, its inhabitants, or their language.
terrace: a raised level with a vertical or sloping front or sides faced with masonry, turf, or the like, especially one of a series of levels rising one above another.
admonish: to caution, advise, or counsel against something.
warlock: a man who professes or is supposed to practice magic or sorcery; a male witch; sorcerer.
nathanael: a disciple of Jesus, possibly Bartholomew. John 1:45–51.
tanbark: the bark of the oak, hemlock, etc., bruised and broken by a mill and used especially in tanning hides.
melancholy: a gloomy state of mind, especially when habitual or prolonged; depression.
spectacular: of or like a spectacle; marked by or given to an impressive, large-scale display.
pomp: stately or splendid display; splendor; magnificence.
drone: the male of the honeybee and other bees, stingless and making no honey.
broom: an implement for sweeping, consisting of a brush of straw or stiff strands of synthetic material bound tightly to the end of a long handle.
coterie: a group of people who associate closely.
daisy: any of various composite plants the flowers of which have a yellow disk and white rays, as the English daisy and the oxeye daisy.
thistle: any of various prickly, composite plants having showy, purple flower heads, especially of the genera Cirsium, Carduus, or Onopordum.
silvering: the act or process of coating with silver or a substance resembling silver.
pivot: a pin, point, or short shaft on the end of which something rests and turns, or upon and about which something rotates or oscillates.
wean: to accustom (a child or young animal) to food other than its mother's milk; cause to lose the need to suckle or turn to the mother for food.
iliac: of, relating to, or situated near the ilium.
grooved: simple past tense and past participle of groove.
richard: Maurice  [maw-rees;; French moh-rees]  /mɔˈris;; French moʊˈris/  (Show IPA), ("Rocket") 1921–2000, Canadian hockey player.
piteous: evoking or deserving pity; pathetic: piteous cries for help.
impromptu: made or done without previous preparation: an impromptu address to the unexpected crowds.
confederate: united in a league, alliance, or conspiracy.
albania: a republic in S Europe, in the Balkan Peninsula, W of Macedonia and NW of Greece. 10,632 sq. mi. (27,535 sq. km). Capital:  Tirana.
separatist: a person who separates, withdraws, or secedes, as from an established church.
escalate: to increase in intensity, magnitude, etc.: to escalate a war; a time when prices escalate.
pact: an agreement, covenant, or compact: We made a pact not to argue any more.
aggression: the action of a state in violating by force the rights of another state, particularly its territorial rights; an unprovoked offensive, attack, invasion, or the like: The army is prepared to stop any foreign aggression.
unilateral: relating to, occurring on, or involving one side only: unilateral development; a unilateral approach.
swinging: characterized by or capable of swinging, being swung, or causing to swing.
dualism: the state of being dual or consisting of two parts; division into two.
perfectible: capable of becoming or of being made perfect; improvable.
ascetic: a person who dedicates his or her life to a pursuit of contemplative ideals and practices extreme self-denial or self-mortification for religious reasons.
abandon: to leave completely and finally; forsake utterly; desert: to abandon one's farm; to abandon a child; to abandon a sinking ship.
teat: the protuberance on the breast or udder in female mammals, except the monotremes, through which the milk ducts discharge; nipple or mammilla.
flock: a number of animals of one kind, especially sheep, goats, or birds, that keep or feed together or are herded together.
jejunum: the middle portion of the small intestine, between the duodenum and the ileum.
deathless: not subject to death; immortal: the belief that the human soul is deathless.
winchester: a city in Hampshire, in S England: cathedral; capital of the early Wessex kingdom and of medieval England.
swaybacked: having the back sagged to an unusual degree; having a sway-back.
satiety: the state of being satiated; surfeit.
sow: to scatter (seed) over land, earth, etc., for growth; plant.
vaccine: any preparation used as a preventive inoculation to confer immunity against a specific disease, usually employing an innocuous form of the disease agent, as killed or weakened bacteria or viruses, to stimulate antibody production.
prophylactic: defending or protecting from disease or infection, as a drug.
undulate: to move with a sinuous or wavelike motion; display a smooth rising-and-falling or side-to-side alternation of movement: The flag undulates in the breeze.
tetragon: a polygon having four angles or sides; a quadrangle or quadrilateral.
amphibian: any cold-blooded vertebrate of the class Amphibia, comprising frogs and toads, newts and salamanders, and caecilians, the larvae being typically aquatic, breathing by gills, and the adults being typically semiterrestrial, breathing by lungs and through the moist, glandular skin.
atone: to make amends or reparation, as for an offense or a crime, or for an offender (usually followed by for): to atone for one's sins.
treason: the offense of acting to overthrow one's government or to harm or kill its sovereign.
disloyal: false to one's obligations or allegiances; not loyal; faithless; treacherous.
faithless: not adhering to allegiance, promises, vows, or duty: the faithless behavior of Benedict Arnold.
murmur: a low, continuous sound, as of a brook, the wind, or trees, or of low, indistinct voices.
lasso: a long rope or line of hide or other material with a running noose at one end, used for roping horses, cattle, etc.
hangman: a person who hangs criminals who are condemned to death; public executioner.
halter: a rope or strap with a noose or headstall for leading or restraining horses or cattle.
sorcery: the art, practices, or spells of a person who is supposed to exercise supernatural powers through the aid of evil spirits; black magic; witchery.
norway: Norwegian Norge. a kingdom in N Europe, in the W part of the Scandinavian Peninsula. 124,555 sq. mi. (322,597 sq. km). Capital:  Oslo.
sweden: a kingdom in N Europe, in the E part of the Scandinavian Peninsula. 173,732 sq. mi. (449,964 sq. km). Capital:  Stockholm.
finland: Finnish Suomi. a republic in N Europe: formerly a province of the Russian Empire. 130,119 sq. mi. (337,010 sq. km). Capital:  Helsinki.
iceland: a large island in the N Atlantic between Greenland and Scandinavia. 39,698 sq. mi. (102,820 sq. km).
accustom: to familiarize by custom or use; habituate: to accustom oneself to cold weather.
accustomed: customary; usual; habitual: in their accustomed manner.
wail: to utter a prolonged, inarticulate, mournful cry, usually high-pitched or clear-sounding, as in grief or suffering: to wail with pain.
mangle: to injure severely, disfigure, or mutilate by cutting, slashing, or crushing: The coat sleeve was mangled in the gears of the machine.
distract: to draw away or divert, as the mind or attention: The music distracted him from his work.
contort: to twist, bend, or draw out of shape; distort.
evacuate: to leave empty; vacate. Synonyms: empty, void, drain.
encampment: an act or instance of encamping; lodgment in a camp.
improvised: made or said without previous preparation: an improvised skit.
lowland: land that is low or level, in comparison with the adjacent country.
parlor: Older Use. a room for the reception and entertainment of visitors to one's home; living room.
slug: any of various snaillike terrestrial gastropods having no shell or only a rudimentary one, feeding on plants and a pest of leafy garden crops.
leash: a chain, strap, etc., for controlling or leading a dog or other animal; lead.
unlearned: not learned; not scholarly or erudite.
ewing: a township in W New Jersey.
unprincipled: lacking or not based on moral scruples or principles: an unprincipled person; unprincipled behavior.
villain: a cruelly malicious person who is involved in or devoted to wickedness or crime; scoundrel.
unscrupulous: not scrupulous; unrestrained by scruples; conscienceless; unprincipled.
mirthful: joyous; gay; jolly: a mirthful laugh.
scintillating: animated; vivacious; effervescent: a scintillating personality.
anemone: any of various plants belonging to the genus Anemone, of the buttercup family, having petallike sepals and including several wild species with white flowers as well as others cultivated for their showy flowers in a variety of colors.
cnidaria: an alternative name for the invertebrate phylum Coelenterata, giving emphasis to the stinging structures as characteristic of the phylum.
crevice: a crack forming an opening; cleft; rift; fissure.
stringed: fitted with strings (often used in combination): a five-stringed banjo.
viol: a bowed musical instrument, differing from the violin in having deeper ribs, sloping shoulders, a greater number of strings, usually six, and frets: common in the 16th and 17th centuries in various sizes from the treble viol to the bass viol.
crux: a vital, basic, decisive, or pivotal point: The crux of the trial was his whereabouts at the time of the murder.
chamaeleon: a small southern constellation between Musca and Hydrus.
punkie: any of the minute biting gnats of the family Ceratopogonidae.
pretentious: characterized by assumption of dignity or importance, especially when exaggerated or undeserved: a pretentious, self-important waiter.
amaze: to overwhelm with surprise or sudden wonder; astonish greatly.
picking: the act of a person or thing that picks.
sprinkler: any of various devices for sprinkling, as a watering pot, a container of water with a perforated top used to sprinkle clothes before ironing, or especially a perforated ring or small stand with a revolving nozzle to which a hose is attached for watering a lawn with a fine, even spray.
feminine: pertaining to a woman or girl: feminine beauty; feminine dress.
masculine: pertaining to or characteristic of a man or men: masculine attire.
girlish: of, like, or befitting a girl or girlhood: girlish laughter.
coup: a highly successful, unexpected stroke, act, or move; a clever action or accomplishment.
outlaw: a lawless person or habitual criminal, especially one who is a fugitive from the law.
torture: the act of inflicting excruciating pain, as punishment or revenge, as a means of getting a confession or information, or for sheer cruelty.
mekong: a river whose source is in SW China, flowing SE along most of the boundary between Thailand and Laos to the South China Sea. 2600 miles (4200 km) long.
borneo: an island in the Malay Archipelago, politically divided among Indonesia, Malaysia, and the British-protected sultanate of Brunei. 290,000 sq. mi. (750,000 sq. km).
kota: a city in NW India, in Rajasthan on the Chambal River: textile industry. op.: 695 899 (2001)
kinabalu: a mountain in N Sabah, in Malaysia: highest peak on the island of Borneo. 13,455 feet (4101 meters).
kuching: a seaport in and capital of Sarawak state, in E Malaysia: capital of the former colony of Sarawak.
exaggerate: to magnify beyond the limits of truth; overstate; represent disproportionately: to exaggerate the difficulties of a situation.
overstate: to state too strongly; exaggerate: to overstate one's position in a controversy.
basidiomycete: Mycology. any of a group of fungi constituting the phylum Basidiomycota of the kingdom Fungi (or, in older classification schemes, the class Basidiomycetes of the kingdom Plantae), characterized by bearing the spores on a basidium, including the smuts, rust, mushrooms, and puffballs.
placenta: Anatomy, Zoology. the organ in most mammals, formed in the lining of the uterus by the union of the uterine mucous membrane with the membranes of the fetus, that provides for the nourishment of the fetus and the elimination of its waste products.
opossum: a prehensile-tailed marsupial, Didelphis virginiana, of the eastern U.S., the female having an abdominal pouch in which its young are carried: noted for the habit of feigning death when in danger.
wombat: any of several stocky, burrowing, herbivorous marsupials of the family Vombatidae, of Australia, about the size of a badger.
bandicoot: any of several large East Indian rats of the genus Nesokia.
stratify: to form or place in strata or layers.
generic: of, applicable to, or referring to all the members of a genus, class, group, or kind; general.
cosmopolitan: free from local, provincial, or national ideas, prejudices, or attachments; at home all over the world.
australian: of or relating to Australia, its inhabitants, or their languages.
hood: a soft or flexible covering for the head and neck, either separate or attached to a cloak, coat, or the like.
sluggardly: like or befitting a sluggard; slothful; lazy.
embalm: to treat (a dead body) so as to preserve it, as with chemicals, drugs, or balsams.
decemvir: a member of a permanent board or a special commission of ten members in ancient Rome, especially the commission that drew up Rome's first code of law.
consul: an official appointed by the government of one country to look after its commercial interests and the welfare of its citizens in another country.
quadrant: a quarter of a circle; an arc of 90°.
delineation: the act or process of delineating.
delta: the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet (Δ, δ).
albite: the sodium end member of the plagioclase feldspar group, light-colored and found in alkalic igneous rocks.
anorthite: a white or gray feldspar mineral, CaAl 2 Si 2 O 8 , calcic plagioclase.
twinning: the bearing of two children at one birth.
epinephrine: Biochemistry. a hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla upon stimulation by the central nervous system in response to stress, as anger or fear, and acting to increase heart rate, blood pressure, cardiac output, and carbohydrate metabolism.
lactose: Biochemistry. a disaccharide, C 12 H 22 O 11 , present in milk, that upon hydrolysis yields glucose and galactose.
sift: to separate and retain the coarse parts of (flour, ashes, etc.) with a sieve.
immersed: plunged or sunk in or as if in a liquid.
dissepiment: Anatomy, Zoology. a partition or septum in a tissue.
veranda: Also, verandah. Chiefly South Midland and Southern U.S. a large, open porch, usually roofed and partly enclosed, as by a railing, often extending across the front and sides of a house; gallery.
stele: an upright stone slab or pillar bearing an inscription or design and serving as a monument, marker, or the like.
hammurabi: 18th century b.c. or earlier, king of Babylonia.
sorcerer: a person who practices sorcery; black magician; wizard.
hemlock: a poisonous plant, Conium maculatum, of the parsley family, having purple-spotted stems, finely divided leaves, and umbels of small white flowers, used medicinally as a powerful sedative.
mill: a factory for certain kinds of manufacture, as paper, steel, or textiles.
spectacle: anything presented to the sight or view, especially something of a striking or impressive kind: The stars make a fine spectacle tonight.
hallucination: a sensory experience of something that does not exist outside the mind, caused by various physical and mental disorders, or by reaction to certain toxic substances, and usually manifested as visual or auditory images.
oxeye: any of several composite plants, especially of the genera Heliopsis and Buphthalum, having ray flowers surrounding a conspicuous disk.
symmetrical: characterized by or exhibiting symmetry; well-proportioned, as a body or whole; regular in form or arrangement of corresponding parts.
ilium: the broad, upper portion of either hipbone.
maw: the mouth, throat, or gullet of an animal, especially a carnivorous mammal.
beggar: a person who begs alms or lives by begging.
outstretch: to stretch forth; extend: to outstretch one's hand in welcome.
arrogate: to claim unwarrantably or presumptuously; assume or appropriate to oneself without right: to arrogate the right to make decisions.
canyon: a deep valley with steep sides, often with a stream flowing through it.
swung: simple past tense and past participle of swing1 .
dual: of, relating to, or noting two.
contemplative: given to or characterized by contemplation: a contemplative mind.
deflate: to release the air or gas from (something inflated, as a balloon): They deflated the tires slightly to allow the truck to drive under the overpass.
nipple: a protuberance of the mamma or breast where, in the female, the milk ducts discharge; teat.
mammilla: Anatomy. the nipple of the mamma, or breast.
ileum: Anatomy. the third and lowest division of the small intestine, extending from the jejunum to the cecum.
wessex: (in the Middle Ages) a kingdom, later an earldom, in S England. Capital:  Winchester.
surfeit: excess; an excessive amount: a surfeit of speechmaking.
sinuous: having many curves, bends, or turns; winding: a sinuous path.
alternation: the act or process of alternating or the state of being alternated.
quadrangle: a plane figure having four angles and four sides, as a square.
semiterrestrial: living mostly on land but requiring a moist environment or nearby water, especially as a breeding site: Most amphibians are semiterrestrial.
unfaithful: not faithful; false to duty, obligation, or promises; faithless; disloyal.
executioner: an official who inflicts capital punishment in pursuance of a legal warrant.
headstall: that part of a bridle or halter that encompasses the head of an animal.
norwegian: of or relating to Norway, its inhabitants, or their language.
oslo: a seaport in and the capital of Norway, in the SE part, at the head of Oslo Fiord.
stockholm: the chief seaport in and the capital of Sweden, in the SE part.
finnish: the principal language of Finland, a Uralic language related closely to Estonian and remotely to Hungarian. Abbreviation:  Finn.
helsinki: a seaport in and the capital of Finland, on the S coast.
sinker: a person or thing that sinks.
familiarize: to make (onself or another) well-acquainted or conversant with something.
distracted: having the attention diverted: She tossed several rocks to the far left and slipped past the distracted sentry.
vacate: to give up possession or occupancy of: to vacate an apartment.
skit: a short literary piece of a humorous or satirical character.
trill: to sing or play with a vibratory or quavering effect.
quaver: to shake tremulously; quiver or tremble: He stood there quavering with fear.
township: a unit of local government, usually a subdivision of a county, found in most midwestern and northeastern states of the U.S. and in most Canadian provinces.
scrupulous: having scruples, or moral or ethical standards; having or showing a strict regard for what one considers right; principled: scrupulous about defending human rights.
vivacious: lively; animated; gay: a vivacious folk dance.
exhilarate: to enliven; invigorate; stimulate: The cold weather exhilarated the walkers.
buttercup: any of numerous plants of the genus Ranunculus, having glossy yellow flowers and deeply cut leaves.
rift: an opening made by splitting, cleaving, etc.; fissure; cleft; chink.
banjo: a musical instrument of the guitar family, having a circular body covered in front with tightly stretched parchment and played with the fingers or a plectrum.
clarinet: a woodwind instrument in the form of a cylindrical tube with a single reed attached to its mouthpiece.
trombone: a musical wind instrument consisting of a cylindrical metal tube expanding into a bell and bent twice in a U shape, usually equipped with a slide (slide trombone)
cymbal: a concave plate of brass or bronze that produces a sharp, ringing sound when struck: played either in pairs, by being struck together, or singly, by being struck with a drumstick or the like.
pivotal: of, relating to, or serving as a pivot.
hydrus: the Water Snake, a southern constellation between Eridanus and Octans.
exaggerated: unduly or unrealistically magnified: to have an exaggerated opinion of oneself.
waiter: a person, especially a man, who waits on tables, as in a restaurant.
neurotransmitter: any of several chemical substances, as epinephrine or acetylcholine, that transmit nerve impulses across a synapse to a postsynaptic element, as another nerve, muscle, or gland.
sprinkling: a small quantity or number scattered here and there.
watering: the act of a person or thing that waters.
ironing: the act or process of smoothing or pressing clothes, linens, etc., with a heated iron.
girlhood: the state or time of being a girl.
paltry: ridiculously or insultingly small: a paltry sum.
piddling: amounting to very little; trifling; negligible: a piddling sum of money.
excruciating: extremely painful; causing intense suffering; unbearably distressing; torturing: an excruciating noise; excruciating pain.
sheer: transparently thin; diaphanous, as some fabrics: sheer stockings.
brunei: a sultanate under British protection on the NW coast of Borneo: formerly a British protectorate; gained independence 1984. 2220 sq. mi. (5750 sq. km). Capital:  Bandar Seri Begawan.
rajasthan: a state in NW India; formerly Rajputana and a group of small states. 132,078 sq. mi. (342,056 sq. km). Capital:  Jaipur.
mycology: the branch of biology dealing with fungi.
basidiomycota: the basidiomycetes considered as belonging to the phylum Basidiomycota of the kingdom Fungi.
basidium: a special form of sporophore, characteristic of basidiomycetous fungi, on which the sexual spores are borne, usually at the tips of slender projections.
uterine: of or relating to the uterus or womb.
carthage: an ancient city-state in N Africa, near modern Tunis: founded by the Phoenicians in the middle of the 9th century b.c.; destroyed in 146 b.c. in the last of the Punic Wars.
provincial: belonging or peculiar to some particular province; local: the provincial newspaper.
sluggard: a person who is habitually inactive or lazy.
dive: to plunge into water, especially headfirst.
quarter: one of the four equal or equivalent parts into which anything is or may be divided: a quarter of an apple; a quarter of a book.
hellenist: a person, especially in ancient times, adopting Greek speech, ideas, or customs.
alkalic: (of igneous rock) containing a relatively high percentage of sodium and potassium alkali.
calcic: pertaining to or containing lime or calcium.
adrenal: of or produced by the adrenal glands.
medulla: I still felt like pushing the man's Adam's apple through his medulla oblongata.
cardiac: of or relating to the heart: cardiac disease.
galactose: a white, crystalline, water-soluble hexose sugar, C 6 H 12 O 6 , obtained in its dextrorotatory form from milk sugar by hydrolysis and in its levorotatory form from mucilages.
overdo: to do to excess; overindulge in: to overdo dieting.
midland: the middle or interior part of a country.
leprosy: a chronic, mildly infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, affecting the peripheral nervous system, skin, and nasal mucosa and variously characterized by ulcerations, tubercular nodules, and loss of sensation that sometimes leads to traumatic amputation of the anesthetized part.
cyst: Pathology. a closed, bladderlike sac formed in animal tissues, containing fluid or semifluid matter.
marker: a person or thing that marks.
wizard: a person who practices magic; magician or sorcerer.
incrust: to cover or line with a crust or hard coating.
enthrall: to captivate or charm: a performer whose grace, skill, and virtuosity enthrall her audiences.
secede: to withdraw formally from an alliance, federation, or association, as from a political union, a religious organization, etc.
overpass: a road, pedestrian walkway, railroad, bridge, etc., crossing over some barrier, as another road or walkway.
cecum: a cul-de-sac, especially that in which the large intestine begins.
earldom: Also called earlship. the rank or title of an earl.
sag: to sink or bend downward by weight or pressure, especially in the middle: The roof sags.
frog: any tailless, stout-bodied amphibian of the order Anura, including the smooth, moist-skinned frog species that live in a damp or semiaquatic habitat and the warty, drier-skinned toad species that are mostly terrestrial as adults.
newt: any of several brilliantly colored salamanders of the family Salamandridae, especially those of the genera Triturus and Notophthalmus, of North America, Europe, and northern Asia.
salamander: any tailed amphibian of the order Caudata, having a soft, moist, scaleless skin, typically aquatic as a larva and semiterrestrial as an adult: several species are endangered.
caecilian: Also called blindworm. a legless, wormlike tropical amphibian of the order Gymnophiona (formerly Apoda), spending most of its life underground and usually almost blind.
pursuance: the following or carrying out of some plan, course, injunction, or the like.
bridle: part of the tack or harness of a horse, consisting usually of a headstall, bit, and reins.
uralic: a family of languages that comprises Finno-Ugric and Samoyed as subfamilies. Hungarian, Finnish, and Estonian belong to Uralic.
estonian: of or relating to Estonia or its people.
hungarian: of, relating to, or characteristic of Hungary, its people, or their language.
finn: a native or inhabitant of Finland.
occupancy: the act, state, or condition of being or becoming a tenant or of living in or taking up quarters or space in or on something: Continued occupancy of the office depends on a rent reduction.
encamp: to settle or lodge in a camp.
satirical: of, pertaining to, containing, or characterized by satire: satirical novels.
scruple: a moral or ethical consideration or standard that acts as a restraining force or inhibits certain actions.
principled: imbued with or having moral principles (often used in combination): high-principled.
folk: Usually, folks. (used with a plural verb) people in general: Folks say there wasn't much rain last summer.
enliven: to make vigorous or active; invigorate: The wit of Mencken enlivened his age.
ranunculus: any ranunculaceous plant of the genus Ranunculus, having finely divided leaves and typically yellow five-petalled flowers. The genus includes buttercup, crowfoot, spearwort, and lesser celandine
chink: a crack, cleft, or fissure: a chink in a wall.
guitar: a stringed musical instrument with a long, fretted neck, a flat, somewhat violinlike body, and typically six strings, which are plucked with the fingers or with a plectrum.
plectrum: a small piece of plastic, metal, ivory, etc., for plucking the strings of a guitar, lyre, mandolin, etc.
woodwind: a musical wind instrument of the group comprising the flutes, clarinets, oboes, bassoons, and occasionally, the saxophones.
mouthpiece: a piece placed at or forming the mouth, as of a receptacle or tube.
drumstick: a stick for beating a drum.
eridanus: the River, a large southern constellation between Cetus and Orion, containing the bright star Achernar.
octans: the Octant, a southern constellation that contains the south celestial pole.
acetylcholine: Biochemistry. the acetic acid ester of choline, C 7 H 17 NO 3 , released and hydrolyzed during nerve conduction and causing muscle action by transmitting nerve impulses across synapses.
postsynaptic: being or occurring on the receiving end of a discharge across the synapse.
diaphanous: very sheer and light; almost completely transparent or translucent.
seri: a member of an American Indian people of western Sonora state, Mexico, on the Gulf of California.
rajputana: a former region in NW India, now making up the principal part of Rajasthan.
jaipur: a former state in NW India, now part of Rajasthan.
disproportionate: not proportionate; out of proportion, as in size or number.
rat: any of several long-tailed rodents of the family Muridae, of the genus Rattus and related genera, distinguished from the mouse by being larger.
engross: to occupy completely, as the mind or attention; absorb: Their discussion engrossed his attention. She is engrossed in her work.
tunis: a city in and the capital of Tunisia, in the NE part.
headfirst: with the head in front or bent forward; headforemost: He dived headfirst into the sea.
percentage: a rate or proportion per hundred.
striated: marked with striae; furrowed; striped; streaked.
hexose: any of a class of sugars containing six atoms of carbon, including glucose and fructose.
overindulge: to indulge to excess: to overindulge one's fondness for candy.
peripheral: pertaining to, situated in, or constituting the periphery: peripheral resistance on the outskirts of the battle area.
traumatic: of, relating to, or produced by a trauma or wound.
virtuosity: the character, ability, or skill of a virtuoso.
conspire: to agree together, especially secretly, to do something wrong, evil, or illegal: They conspired to kill the king.
pedestrian: a person who goes or travels on foot; walker.
semiaquatic: partly aquatic; growing or living in or close to water, or carrying out part of its life cycle in water.
habitat: the natural environment of an organism; place that is natural for the life and growth of an organism: a tropical habitat.
warty: having warts; covered with or as with warts.
drier: a person or thing that dries.
blindworm: a limbless European lizard, Anguis fragilis, related to the glass lizards.
injunction: Law. a judicial process or order requiring the person or persons to whom it is directed to do a particular act or to refrain from doing a particular act.
fjord: a long, narrow arm of the sea bordered by steep cliffs: usually formed by glacial erosion.
samoyed: a member of a Uralic people dwelling in W Siberia and the far NE parts of European Russia.
estonia: a republic in N Europe, on the Baltic, S of the Gulf of Finland: an independent republic 1918–40; annexed by the Soviet Union 1940; regained independence 1991. 17,413 sq. mi. (45,100 sq. km). Capital:  Tallinn.
lodge: a small, makeshift or crude shelter or habitation, as of boughs, poles, skins, earth, or rough boards; cabin or hut.
satire: the use of irony, sarcasm, ridicule, or the like, in exposing, denouncing, or deriding vice, folly, etc.
effervesce: to give off bubbles of gas, as fermenting liquors.
mencken: H(enry) L(ouis) 1880–1956, U.S. writer, editor, and critic.
walker: an enclosing framework on casters or wheels for supporting a baby who is learning to walk.
ranunculaceous: belonging to the Ranunculaceae, the buttercup family of plants.
crowfoot: any plant of the genus Ranunculus, especially one with divided leaves suggestive of a crow's foot; buttercup.
spearwort: any of several buttercups having lance-shaped leaves and small flowers, as Ranunculus ambigens, of the eastern U.S., growing in mud.
celandine: Also called greater celandine, swallowwort. an Old World plant, Chelidonium majus, of the poppy family, having yellow flowers.
fretted: ornamented or provided with frets: a fretted molding.
mandolin: a musical instrument with a pear-shaped wooden body and a fretted neck.
achernar: a star of the first magnitude in the constellation Eridanus.
octant: the eighth part of a circle.
realistic: interested in, concerned with, or based on what is real or practical: a realistic estimate of costs; a realistic planner.
choline: Biochemistry. a quaternary ammonium cation, C 5 H 14 N + O, one of the B-complex vitamins, found in the lecithin of many plants and animals.
monkey: Compare New World monkey, Old World monkey.
sonora: a state in NW Mexico. 70,484 sq. mi. (182,555 sq. km). Capital:  Hermosillo.
tunisia: a republic in N Africa, on the Mediterranean: a French protectorate until 1956. 48,330 sq. mi. (125,175 sq. km). Capital:  Tunis.
fondness: the state or quality of being fond.
mycobacteria: rod-shaped aerobic bacteria of the genus Mycobacterium, certain species of which, as M. tuberculosis, are pathogenic for humans and animals.
ulcerate: to form an ulcer; become ulcerous: His skin ulcerated after exposure to radioactive material.
tuberculosis: an infectious disease that may affect almost any tissue of the body, especially the lungs, caused by the organism Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and characterized by tubercles.
nodule: a small node, knot, or knob.
amputate: to cut off (all or part of a limb or digit of the body), as by surgery.
anesthetize: to render physically insensible, as by an anesthetic.
worm: Zoology. any of numerous long, slender, soft-bodied, legless, bilaterally symmetrical invertebrates, including the flatworms, roundworms, acanthocephalans, nemerteans, gordiaceans, and annelids.
tallinn: a seaport in and the capital of Estonia, on the Gulf of Finland.
makeshift: a temporary expedient or substitute: We used boxes as a makeshift while the kitchen chairs were being painted.
folly: the state or quality of being foolish; lack of understanding or sense.
molding: the act or process of molding.
oboe: a woodwind instrument having a slender conical, tubular body and a double-reed mouthpiece.
bassoon: a large woodwind instrument of low range, with a doubled tube and a curved metal crook to which a double reed is attached.
saxophone: a musical wind instrument consisting of a conical, usually brass tube with keys or valves and a mouthpiece with one reed.
lecithin: Biochemistry. any of a group of phospholipids, occurring in animal and plant tissues and egg yolk, composed of units of choline, phosphoric acid, fatty acids, and glycerol.
hermosillo: a city in and the capital of Sonora, in NW Mexico.
stria: a slight or narrow furrow, ridge, stripe, or streak, especially one of a number in parallel arrangement: striae of muscle fiber.
aerobic: (of an organism or tissue) requiring the presence of air or free oxygen for life.
outskirt: Often, outskirts. the outlying district or region, as of a city, metropolitan area, or the like: to live on the outskirts of town; a sparsely populated outskirt.
ulcer: Pathology. a sore on the skin or a mucous membrane, accompanied by the disintegration of tissue, the formation of pus, etc.
ulcerous: of the nature of an ulcer; characterized by the formation of ulcers.
wart: a small, often hard, abnormal elevation on the skin, usually caused by a papomavirus.
denounce: to condemn or censure openly or publicly: to denounce a politician as morally corrupt.
deride: to laugh at in scorn or contempt; scoff or jeer at; mock.
caster: a person or thing that casts.
phosphoric: of or containing phosphorus, especially in the pentavalent state.
outlying: lying at a distance from the center or the main body; remote; out-of-the-way: outlying military posts.
metropolitan: of, noting, or characteristic of a metropolis or its inhabitants, especially in culture, sophistication, or in accepting and combining a wide variety of people, ideas, etc.
pus: a yellow-white, more or less viscid substance produced by suppuration and found in abscesses, sores, etc., consisting of a liquid plasma in which white blood cells are suspended.
tubercle: a small rounded projection or excrescence, as on a bone or on the surface of the body.
bilateral: pertaining to, involving, or affecting two or both sides, factions, parties, or the like: a bilateral agreement; bilateral sponsorship.
flatworm: any worm of the phylum Platyhelminthes, having bilateral symmetry and a soft, solid, usually flattened body, including the planarians, tapeworms, and trematodes; platyhelminth.
roundworm: any nematode, especially Ascaris lumbricoides, that infests the intestine of humans and other mammals.
acanthocephalan: any parasitic worm of the phylum or class Acanthocephala, having a proboscis covered with recurved hooks.
nemertean: any member of the invertebrate phylum Nemertea, comprising the ribbon worms.
annelid: any segmented worm of the phylum Annelida, including the earthworms, leeches, and various marine forms.
phospholipid: any of a group of fatty compounds, as lecithin, composed of phosphoric esters, and occurring in living cells.
sophistication: sophisticated character, ideas, tastes, or ways as the result of education, worldly experience, etc.: the sophistication of the wealthy.
platyhelminthes: a phylum of worms having bilateral symmetry and a soft, usually flattened body, comprising the flatworms.
platyhelminth: any worm of the phylum Platyhelminthes; a flatworm.
nematode: any unsegmented worm of the phylum Nematoda, having an elongated, cylindrical body; a roundworm.
ascaris: any parasitic roundworm of the genus Ascaris, found in the human small intestine and causing colic and diarrhea.
recurved: curved upward, as the bill of a bird.
hooks: Benjamin Lawson, born 1925, U.S. lawyer, clergyman, and civil-rights advocate: executive director of the NAACP 1977–93.
worms: a city in E Rhineland-Palatinate, in SW Germany.
abscess: a localized collection of pus in the tissues of the body, often accompanied by swelling and inflammation and frequently caused by bacteria.
sponsor: a person who vouches or is responsible for a person or thing.
planarian: any of various free-swimming, mostly freshwater flatworms of the class Turbellaria, having an undulating or sluglike motion: popular in laboratory studies for the ability to regenerate lost parts.
tapeworm: any of various flat or tapelike worms of the class Cestoidea, lacking an alimentary canal, and parasitic when adult in the alimentary canal of humans and other vertebrates: the larval and adult stages are usually in different hosts.
trematode: any parasitic platyhelminth or flatworm of the class Trematoda, having one or more external suckers; fluke.
nematoda: a class of worms, Modern Latin compound of nemat- "thread" (from Greek nema, genitive nematos "thread," from stem of nein "to spin;" see needle (n.)) + -odes "like, of the nature of" (see -oid).
colic: paroxysmal pain in the abdomen or bowels.
infest: to live in or overrun to an unwanted degree or in a troublesome manner, especially as predatory animals or vermin do: Sharks infested the coastline.
lawson: Robert, 1892–1957, U.S. illustrator and author, especially of children's books.
naacp: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
rhineland: that part of Germany W of the Rhine.
earthworm: any one of numerous annelid worms that burrow in soil and feed on soil nutrients and decaying organic matter.
leech: any bloodsucking or carnivorous aquatic or terrestrial worm of the class Hirudinea, certain freshwater species of which were formerly much used in medicine for bloodletting.
suppurate: to produce or discharge pus, as a wound; maturate.
larval: of, relating to, or in the form of a larva.
fluke: the part of an anchor that catches in the ground, especially the flat triangular piece at the end of each arm.
overrun: to rove over (a country, region, etc.); invade; ravage: a time when looting hordes had overrun the province.
vermin: noxious, objectionable, or disgusting animals collectively, especially those of small size that appear commonly and are difficult to control, as flies, lice, bedbugs, cockroaches, mice, and rats.
coastline: the outline or contour of a coast; shoreline.
illustrator: an artist who makes illustrations: an illustrator of children's books.
rhine: Joseph Banks, 1895–1980, U.S. psychologist: pioneer in parapsychology.
bloodletting: the act or practice of letting blood by opening a vein; phlebotomy.
localize: to make local; fix in, or assign or restrict to, a particular place, locality, etc.
vouch: to support as being true, certain, reliable, etc. (usually followed by for): Her record in office vouches for her integrity.
ode: a lyric poem typically of elaborate or irregular metrical form and expressive of exalted or enthusiastic emotion.
shark: any of a group of elongate elasmobranch, mostly marine fishes, certain species of which are large, voracious, and sometimes dangerous to humans.
parapsychology: the branch of psychology that deals with the investigation of purportedly psychic phenomena, as clairvoyance, extrasensory perception, telepathy, and the like.
bloodsucker: any animal that sucks blood, especially a leech.
phlebotomy: the act or practice of opening a vein for letting or drawing blood as a therapeutic or diagnostic measure; venesection; bleeding.
loot: spoils or plunder taken by pillaging, as in war.
horde: a large group, multitude, number, etc.; a mass or crowd: a horde of tourists.
bedbug: a flat, wingless, bloodsucking hemipterous insect, Cimex lectularius, that infests houses and especially beds.
cockroach: any of numerous orthopterous insects of the family Blattidae, characterized by a flattened body, rapid movements, and nocturnal habits and including several common household pests.
elasmobranch: belonging or pertaining to the Elasmobranchii, the subclass of cartilaginous fishes comprising the sharks and rays.
psychic: of or relating to the human soul or mind; mental (opposed to physical).
therapeutic: of or relating to the treating or curing of disease; curative.
diagnostic: of, relating to, or used in diagnosis.
bleeding: the act, fact, or process of losing blood or having blood flow.
hemipterous: belonging or pertaining to the Hemiptera, an order of insects having forewings that are thickened and leathery at the base and membranous at the apex, comprising the true bugs.
cimex: a bedbug of the genus Cimex.
orthopterous: belonging or pertaining to the Orthoptera, an order of insects, including the cockroaches, mantids, walking sticks, crickets, grasshoppers, and katydids, characterized by leathery forewings, membranous hind wings, and chewing mouthparts.
purported: reputed or claimed; alleged: We saw no evidence of his purported wealth.
pillage: to strip ruthlessly of money or goods by open violence, as in war; plunder: The barbarians pillaged every conquered city.
hemiptera: the order comprising the true bugs.
bedfordshire: a county in central England. 477 sq. mi. (1235 sq. km).
forewing: either of the anterior and usually smaller pair of wings of an insect having four wings.
cricket: any of several jumping, orthopterous insects of the family Gryllidae, characterized by long antennae and stridulating organs on the forewings of the male, as one of the species commonly found in pastures and meadows (field cricket) or on trees and shrubs (tree cricket)
katydid: any of several large, usually green, American long-horned grasshoppers, the males of which produce a characteristic song.
ruthless: without pity or compassion; cruel; merciless: a ruthless tyrant.
barbarian: a person in a savage, primitive state; uncivilized person.
mantis: any of several predaceous insects of the order Mantidae, having a long prothorax and typically holding the forelegs in an upraised position as if in prayer.
locust: Also called acridid, short-horned grasshopper. any of several grasshoppers of the family Acrididae, having short antennae and commonly migrating in swarms that strip the vegetation from large areas.
merciless: without mercy; having or showing no mercy; pitiless; cruel: a merciless critic.
prothorax: the anterior division of the thorax of an insect, bearing the first pair of legs.
stridulate: to produce a shrill, grating sound, as a cricket does, by rubbing together certain parts of the body; shrill.
meadow: a tract of grassland used for pasture or serving as a hayfield.
pitiless: feeling or showing no pity; merciless: pitiless criticism of his last novel.
foreleg: one of the front legs of a quadruped, an insect, etc.
upraise: to raise up; lift or elevate.
grating: a fixed frame of bars or the like covering an opening to exclude persons, animals, coarse material, or objects while admitting light, air, or fine material.
hayfield: a field where grass, alfalfa, etc., are grown for making into hay.
swarm: a body of honeybees that emigrate from a hive and fly off together, accompanied by a queen, to start a new colony.
